Only the trains run with any respectable efficiency to reduce the trek from rental car drop-off to gate to a mere mile. Nearly 2 hours from car to gate is unacceptable for such a central airport. I will avoid flying through here at all costs in the future. Also, unable to get on the wi-fi.

2h20m from leaving aircraft to getting to next gate. Horrendous queues to get to passport check and why they bother paying staff to simply look at the queues and do nothing except "reassure" passengers the airline will have to rebook you if you miss your flight is beyond me.

I parked my car at the airport and picked it up when I flew back to Atlanta. I drove to the gate to pay for the ticket and my ticket was rejected. I went to another line and the same thing happen. There were cars everywhere backing up and switching lines. 30 minutes have passed and I’m still sitting behind 3 other cars in another line. Finally a cashier was able to manually scan my ticket. The problem was that all of these cars could not leave the airport until the problem was fix. That was not my fault that something was wrong with the machines that scanned the tickets.

Every time I fly out of Atlanta I am completely appalled by TSA. They are by far the most unpleasant and rude TSA staff of any airport I fly out of. Their bin system when you are about to send your luggage through at security is confusing and frankly stupid. The TSA employees don’t communicate professionally in any way. They don’t make eye contact and answer questions rudely like an insubordinate child would. Why are people with such poor communication skills being hired? They are also many people that simply stand around with no apparent responsibilities. I don’t see these problems with anywhere near the severity and frequency at other large airports. This is a problem with hiring, training and evaluation of TSA staff.

This was the worst, rudest, and disgusting TSA precheck experience ever and TSA needs to be held accountable. I don’t mind that the line was long but the TSA employees were unhelpful and extremely disrespectful with the bin process which caused inefficiencies which resulted in such a long wait. This happened to me and a number of travelers, who then had to wait even longer for their bags to be searched and rescanned by only one person! I lived in ATL, but I’m disgusted! They need to train their personnel to communicate this process properly with manners or hire more personnel to account for the inefficiencies that they will continue to face.

I was waiting for my bag to come through and the TSA lady was extremely rude to me for no reason. She rolled her eyes twice at me for simply answering her questions she asked me and was condescending. It was extremely unprofessional and uncalled for.

Typically I don't write reviews for poor service because I believe that most people don't write them for good service either. However, the customer service at Atlanta-Hartsfield airport has been consistently very rude and condescending. It's become so common place that I don't even want to choose Delta anymore to avoid going through Atlanta. Almost every employee has an attitude and you can tell they think it's funny to be rude. I went to the food court to get a slice of pizza and am greeted with, "what u want?". When I politely said, "I'm sorry", the employee repeated herself. I proceeded to be nice and smiled throughout my experience only to be met with mumbling, no eye contact and laughter among the employees. It's not just the food service employees. I witnessed an older gentleman who was an airport employee ask another young employee for help with an elderly passenger. The young employee responded with some verbal disgust and then she proceeded to roughly handle the elderly passenger in a wheelchair. I really think the airport should focus on customer service relations and training. Every experience I've had there has involved a minimum of one, and usually more than one rude employees. Please be advised that I'm not talking about any TSA employee. They have a tough job and aren't part of this conversation. I would have airport management take off their uniform and interact with the airport employees. It won't take them long to see what myself and many others are telling them. Quite frankly, I'm extremely embarrassed the customer service at Atlanta-Hartsfield is what many foreign travelers base their opinion of Americans and our hospitality on.

Airport Authority severely punishes ride-share (Uber/Lyft) users. This is truly my least favorite airport in the US. Part of it is the fact that as I fly out of the DFW airport most of the time, I am usually on American Airlines and their gates at the Atlanta airport are about a mile from any ground transportation area. I have suffered that indignity in silence for several years, however I finally was tipped over the edge this latest trip when I dared to use Uber/Lyft at the airport. The airport authority clearly has a strong distaste for ride share companies and is doing all they can to frustrate travelers from using them. After walking a mile from the gate to the ground transportation area, I had to ask 3 individuals how to get to the ride share area before I found the down escalator nestled among the baggage carousels that took me to the correct exit. Upon finding the exit, it was another mile walk outside in the Atlanta heat to the designated ride share pickup area. At that point, as the ride share app would not let me choose a location for pickup until I was there, I had to wait another 10 minutes for the Lyft driver to come from their designated wait area. The drivers for the ride shares are also confused about where to pull in to pick up passengers and there was often traffic bottlenecks as folks loaded up. There were also about 100 riders waiting in the pickup area and this was at 8.30pm on a Monday night. The ordeal added at least 30 minutes to my arrival time and left me hot and angry. Let me repeat, the Atlanta airport sucks.

I frequently travel out of Atlanta airport and the last time was in May 2018 and it was a disaster with TSA! They changed the locations of the TSA Pre-Check and when I asked an employee where to go, I was snapped at. I heard a TSA worker mumble something at a man that asked her a legitimate question and when he asked her "pardon?" she replied "Don't yell at me sir!". Since I had TSA pre-check I assumed that we did not need to remove shoes, laptops, etc. so I did not. The agent at the Checkpoint basically "goated" me into a response when she got nasty with me about leaving my iPad in my carry on. She removed it and just started "bouncing & slamming" it through the x-ray. They basically opened up my carry on and took items out randomly and re-ran them through x-ray. (I figured if you want to see my dirty underwear - that's your prerogative!) However, I did not say a word because I cannot afford to end up on a no-fly list. I was then herded through the scanner. I felt sorry for a poor elderly lady in front of me. She was in a wheelchair and they were trying to make her walk through the x-ray. She clearly could not walk - no mercy or kindness from the TSA agents. (Like this 80+ year old woman was a security risk!). I am very disappointed in Atlanta TSA - actually I'm still very angry at the rudeness they showed. But the thing that angers me the most is that these TSA agents can act/speak to you any way they want - but when you try to speak back to them in the same tone, you are the one that suffers. That behavior enrages me!

While I understand Hartsfield Jackson is an international airport and very busy, what I dont understand is why my family and I just waited in a line for over 2.5 hrs only to have our passport simply “reviewed” to then pass more than 12 airport employees standing around doing nothing on our way out. And more than half of them were in the passport control area. Had those 12 employees been task to assist maybe the process could have been more customer accommodating. Maybe our qualitifications for hiring should be reviewed, we traveled through seven countries and were not treated as poorly as our home airport. It is embarrassing and unnecessary. We just need more people that care about the customer.

Traveling is always a taxing experience and going through security, baggage, immigration, etc. is slow and painful. An agent in Atlanta airport made this trip the exception. He was polite, professional, and while doing his job he took the time to talk to my wife and daughter about completing their citizenship. I hope all your agents and staff take notes from him. He very much impressed me.

I travel very frequently, and have only had a problem with staff at Atlanta airport. They are exceedingly rude. A while back, a female employee proceeded to mumble instructions under her breath without making eye contact and then angrily snapped at me when I didn’t follow these indescipherable instructions right away. Today, the security checkpoint pulled numerous bags out to search in a row, including mine. When she said I couldn’t have an aerosol with me (holding a hair product that I’ve flown with several times), I calmly said “oh that isn’t a liquid or aerosol” and she responded “oh well it’s in the trash” and threw it away. The Atlanta airport would benefit greatly from overhauling their employees.

Horrendous! Spent over 2 hours getting through immigration and missed our connecting flights as did so many others. When asked for help all we got told was if you miss your flight you just have to catch the next one or be put up in a hotel until the next day. The problem is if your flight landed on time then the airline does not have to put you up in a hotel which then leaves you out of pocket because immigration can’t get their act together and are on some kind of power high. There was only one to two immigration officers and a dozen other airport employees waltzing around being very unhelpful and quite frankly rude to everyone. Worst airport I have ever been through.

We traveled to Mexico. Coming back in to Customs was a nightmare. The employees were contradicting each other. The left hand didn't know what the right hand was doing. There were signs about downloading the Global Passport APP which was supposed to help only to get to the counter and find it didn't. It's very sad when Mexico's airport has it together better than the busiest Airport in the USA. Not enough Customs Agents and the Staff had no clue or were standing around talking to each other or running around trying to figure out what to do. A complete disaster.

commentHeader: line system needs a lot of help
reviewContent: The worst customs I have ever seen in the world. It takes at least 1 hour every time. The staff and are not well informed. The line system needs a lot of help. I just can believe an airport can run this way. I have to give the airport as a whole a bad review because of customs. International arrivals needs help.

Our flight from Providenciales landed a bit earlier than scheduled in ATL, landing around 5:15. Our next flight to Indianapolis was scheduled to depart at 7:24 pm. Getting through Customs and security was an absolute nightmare. After clearing customs and security, we had to move quickly and arrived at our gate for the next flight as they were boarding Zone 2. We had nothing to declare, there weren't any issues with us, the problem is the lack of adequate working staff for the volume of people attempting to clear customs. Everyone around us was frantic about potentially missing their connections and there is no recourse because as were told by the airport employees "everyone here has a connecting flight". We have no intention of ever taking another international flight that requires us to go through customs in Atlanta. We have cleared customs in O'Hare, Dallas, Miami, and New York, and Atlanta is by far the most unorganized, poorly staffed and chaotic we have encountered and will be avoided in the future unless you have four to five hours between connections.

I am highly disappointed with the way the security line was set up this morning. It was chaos, and no one was willing to help the several people who were standing in line and missing their flights. Not to mention, every employee I interacted with at the airport was very unpleasant and rude. I had to spend over $200 to book another flight since I missed mine. I’m sure this happens often, but I’m very displeased with the treatment by the employees and the way security was run. For a busy airport, they have poor organization. Im going to make my best efforts to never fly out of this airport ever again.

I like this airport overall but passport control was over crowded and not enough agents working. The lines were excessive. Out of many other airports I have been to over the years this was one of the worst for lines and the time it took to get the customs. I will be sure to to book my next international flight thu a different airport.

The staff are always extremely rude! I fly every month, sometimes several times per month and it's just absolutely horrible, especially the check-in and security check point. There's no help or any kind of assistance, not to mention staff attitude. It's not a one time experience, I'd not even bother to write but when it's consistent, something has to be done about it. It should be all about customer service.

Leaving Atlanta was fine. The return was not fine. Customs was extremely busy. Seems like there are plenty of employees doing nothing. You have to check in at a kiosk, lucky to find a working one. Then onto a long line for an actual customs agent. My flight alone had 570 people on it with 4 customs agents. As a US Citizen, I found the agent arrogant, intimidating and you could tell he "loved" the "power". I would recommend domestic through ATL but 2nd thoughts on recommending for International.

Quite horrible experience trying to move through customs. Here there are literally more employed bystanders/onlookers than there are people actually doing something sensible. Most of those working there are unable to communicate or help people. Together with some other passengers I was approaching the end of the line (maybe 30 other passengers left in front of three counters actually operated, 15-16 counters were not), when we were told to use the self-service kiosks. When this was finished they sent us to the end of another line consisting of 4-500 people, with yet another manual check. They simply don’t have clue on how to manage these processes at Atlanta. I’ll advise them to check out maybe Schiphol to learn something. Don’t ever travel through Atlanta with kids.

After reading the reviews of this airport and being fully aware of its humongous size, one has to be apprehensive about using this airport. However, if you are traveling to places in the American South, it is difficult to avoid Atlanta especially with Delta being the predominant carrier here. But my recent trip through Hartsfield was totally stress free. I arrived in Terminal 1 and had to connect at an end gate in Terminal 3 and I had exactly 2 hours and 1 minute to accomplish this. The directional signs were prominent and plentiful and I took the shuttle train that connects the terminals - no wait for it at all. All the terminals had plenty of eateries at all price points. I found many chairs to sit. Bathrooms were located at convenient intervals in each terminals and were clean with working faucets, liquid soaps and paper towels. Announcements at the gates were frequently made. Big display boards listed all departing flights and gates. It was a very smooth connection I had without causing any anxiety or uncertainty. It is a remarkable accomplishment to process so many people all the time every day!

I wish I knew about this website before I booked my flight. 2 hours in an immigration queue. 500 people and only 4 booths open for international passengers. Twice as many for domestic. And at least 10 TSA staff standing around literally doing nothing. I had a lot of time to observe them! When I commented to the immigration official as to how shocked I was at how it was managed he laughed and I must never have been to Atlanta before. Well I never will again. Shambolic. Everyone in the queue around me knew they had missed their connecting flight.

Worst airport experience ever. Took two hours to travel from Domestic to Int'l terminals. No train, just poky little minibuses that could only take ten passengers at a time, leaving long lines, fuming. 19th century service. Will never fly through this airport again unless forced.

This has to be the worst airport I’ve had the displeasure of travelling through. There is nothing in place to separate people who are in transit to those who are actually staying in the US so it was complete mayhem as people queued for an hour at immigration watching the minutes to their next flight tick by. The staff were rude and completely unhelpful and seemed to shift lines about randomly so some people ended up through quicker despite others having earlier flights to catch. We asked several times, as did others, what to do about our connecting flight and were quite bluntly told it was basically tough luck and the only option was to see if people would let you cut in line. If that’s your only suggestion what exactly is your job role here other than to stand around and annoy people? We then had the same queue and problems at security therefore missing our flight. The staff at the Delta desk were also very rude and blamed the fact that it’s the busiest airport in the world. Clearly better systems should be in place if that’s the case. The consequence was that we had to actually pay to stay in a hotel overnight so we could fly the next morning. An absolute shambles of an airport with rude and very unhelpful staff. I’ve used many airports around the world for transit and have never had this issue before.

After flying the last flight on Southwest Airlines from Dallas to Atlanta, March 11, 2018 the trains were not running and I had to walk over 3 miles from the D gate to baggage claim. The road was blocked by construction and no one announced that we had to exit to a lower level for pickup. No communication with passengers!

Absolutely awful airport. Busy and so unorganised. You are asked to queue in various queues at customs and watch as people who come after you in the queue are moved to a new queue that is seen to be faster than you are and then as you approach the front of the queue you get moved again. So badly organised, queues should be first come first serve. Takes so long to get through customs before you can claim baggage to walk around a corner and place it to be on your next flight just because you're transit is in Altlanta. This is before you even get through security and run to your gate to catch your next plane. Staff do not care that you may have a connecting flight. Awful experience both to and from whilst using Atlanta as transit. Will certainly be avoiding in the future.

Missed Flight to Milwaukee because gate change not called out. Arrived at Hartsfield Terminal D from Columbia SC at 8:15AM Friday morning checked monitors upon exiting plane stating Milwaukee flight at Gate B29 departing at 10:26AM. Walked to tram and checked the board again for gate information. Still B29. Got off at Terminal B and walked to Gate B29. Checked the board once again. B29. Sat down at B29 for at least an hour and a half. No mention of a gate change. No announcement of a gate change. Other flights going out to Philly and Pittsburgh from B29. Fifteen minutes before departure, I see a monitor stating that gate was now B6, all the way across the terminal other end. Hustled down to B6. with two minutes to departure time. Was told the cabin door had been closed and the plane was about to pull away. They could rebook me for another flight later that day. Was smugly told I should look at the monitors to get gate information. Really disappointed in Delta especially given this was their hub operation. Not pleasant. Rethinking future plans.

In transit from Punta Cana (Dom. Rep.) to Amsterdam. The largest and busiest airport in the world, but clearly under-capacity. Bag drop and customer assistance counters had reasonably short wait times, but queues for immigration and security checks were very long, even at off-peak times. The immigration officer I had was much more polite and respectful than most of those I've experienced at US airports. TSA agents were polite and seemed professional, if a little laid-back. Some areas of the airport have better food options than others, depending on which concourse/terminal you're in. One thing that caused me some stress was the fact that I received different answers from different personnel. Every time I've passed through the US in the past, I've always had to clear immigration with my baggage (i.e. collect baggage from the carousel, clear immigration, then drop off baggage again). As my baggage wasn't on the carousel, I asked a few airport personnel, who were all polite and friendly enough, but they all told me different things. Some said always collect your baggage, some said it wasn't necessary because of my final destination, some said my luggage must have been lost, and some said to check at the gate when boarding (which would have been too late at that point). My layover was 2hrs 25mins. I only arrived at the departure gate around 20 mins before scheduled departure time, which was 40 mins after they started boarding. My advice would be to leave yourself at least 3 hours between flights but, even at that, you won't have much time to eat, shop or relax. Because of this, I will avoid this airport in future.

We (6 person group) arrived at Atlanta Airport at 7.22pm on Wednesday night 2/28 (on time from SJO Costa Rica). The planning included an almost three hour layover at ATL to pass through Customs and security. The confusion, lack of available personnel to help and administer travelers was the worst I have seen in 50 years of airline travel. It took more than two and one half hours to clear customs and security. We have TSA traveler number, but the attendant told us it was not applicable at this location. Many travelers missed their connecting flights, and pickup service. After running, we finally arrived at our gate at 9.55, only to be told our airline was on the tamac and was being held up. So after all of that delay we got on the Delta plane after it was 25 minutes late. This is all in good clear weather? Over three hours later.

Unbelievably bad airport to pass through. Even though the people were nice enough, the airport was so busy that our early arriving plane of 10 minutes had to wait 30 minutes to get to the gate. Then after going through a Global Entry, I found out they don’t have Global Entry security lanes from international to local travel. Why be a known Traveler with Global Entry when you can’t through security for another hour? From the time of landing to getting through security for our connecting flight was 2 hours! I will never buy a ticket again with ATL as a connecting airport. Backwards airport with lazy TSA.

commentHeader: continues to be one of the worst
reviewContent: ATL is the busiest airport in the United States, so you'd assume that the ground staff and TSA folks at this airport take their jobs seriously, and are efficient. Unfortunately, that's not true. As someone who's traveled extensively through the US (every week) and internationally (several times a year), I'd like to believe I've seen the gamut of airport experiences. ATL continues to be one of the worst on my list (rivaling SEA). The security screening process at ATL is an absolute nightmare. It's the slowest, most inefficient security check process I've seen. It'll take you well over 35-40 mins to get to the TSA officer who screens your boarding pass, and that's on a "good" day. The TSA staff can clearly see the huge line, but refuse to open up more checkpoints/belts. Worse, the airport monitors continue to project a delusion that the wait time at all the checkpoints is less than 15 mins. I'm baffled how they could lie outright like that. Another issue is the belts for carry on screening. They have a bin system, wherein you have to fill up several and push them on to the belt. Leads to all sorts of confusion, and I've timed it and know for a fact that it's slower than the simple "push through" at most major airports. Overall, despite being the busiest airport in the country, ATL has a huge scope for improvement in terms of the efficiency of the security screening and boarding process.

TSA are very unorganized, lazy, and couldn't care less about the travelers. Once you have waited over an hour to get through security, there was a group of about 10-15 TSA agents standing around at the security tower with their thumbs in their mouth. This is one job I’m sure everyone wouldn’t mind if they were all replaced by machines. Also not to mention the Southwest check-in/bag drop agents had the same type of I don’t care attitude. I’ve been traveling though Atlanta for many years and it keeps getting worse. Better off driving an extra hour or two to fly out of another airport if possible.

commentHeader: not many people around to help
reviewContent: The facility is nice but not many people around to help. TSA agents here are the worst. Very rude and condescending. I have to travel through here 3 or 4 times a year. By far the worst TSA I’ve ever encountered! Be prepared to be berated and talked down to.

This was the worst airport that I have ever been through, unorganized, bad customer services, bad attitudes. Just as many of the reviews stated everything is blamed on the weather. I was connecting through ATL on my way to Brazil, the concourse changed, I missed my plane. My luggage was lost twice. It gets worse, never again.

What happened? This airport has always been my favorite. I've traveled for over 30 years and have never had anything but kind, personable staff at this airport. This last trip through Atlanta was completely unrecognizable. Passport control was absolutely hateful to me and my 77 year old mother. He took our passports and hammered us with questions about our trip and when he handed us our passports back he literally said the words "get outta here". We were putting our passports away and he said "go". It's a horrible thing when I feel more kindness and freedom when I leave the United States. We then get to the security checkpoint and we have more hateful agents screaming at passengers. Their directions are so unclear and confusing that everyone was getting flustered and even seasoned travelers were now confused on what these agents were wanting. Screaming isn't a way to convey a message. Its inefficient, confusion, unnecessary and actually slows down the process. I just cannot figure out what happened to my favorite airport but it makes me sad. It was the only airport that I looked forward to visiting.

commentHeader: complaint is really about my return
reviewContent: On the way to Cancun the flight was delayed nearly an hour, causing me grief upon arrival in Mexico. But my complaint is really about my return and 2-3 hour stopover. It was cold on Concourse E, even fully dressed with shoes and jacket. Even the mens room was the same way, I figured I could get warm in there, no way.

This is hands down the least efficient aiport I have ever been to in my life. Security lines are awful, the concourses are filthy and the staff are completely incompetent. The flight was delayed due to heavy take-off traffic. Avoid this airport at all costs.

commentHeader: worst airport I have ever seen
reviewContent: The worst airport I have ever seen in my life. We were there just for a connecting flight from Costa Rica to Montreal and we had to wait in line for 2h15 to pass customs. It is unacceptable! We didn’t have any baggage claim, it was directly shipped to Montreal. In other airport there is a special line for those who have a flight to catch soon. Here nobody care if you miss it. The most part of the staff was not professional. We had to take a night at an Hotel, without any compensation from the customs. It is not finish, I bought 2 bottles of rum at the duty free in costa rica, they put it in a sealed bag written duty free, but at the custom in Atlanta they told us that we had to put it in their special red plastic bag? Remember that i was in costa rica and it was just a connecting flight to go to Montreal! there was no way I could make it.

commentHeader: TSA are short of a lesson in manners
reviewContent: We arrived into Atlanta from Paris with an hour to catch an ongoing flight to Baltimore. We got in the queue for immigration and were treated like cattle and shouted at to stay in line. I politely asked if my wife and I could jump the queue so we could be able to get our connecting flight. I was sternly told no and it would just be too bad if we missed our flight! We argued and I asked for the supervisor and was told the same so we did indeed miss the flight because of the ill mannered nature of the US border control officers. The UK is the USA's best ally yet we are treated like we owe the US a favour. TSA are short of a lesson in manners and interpersonal skills. Never again will I go through Atlanta and will avoid the place like the plague. I will say though that I found the Delta Airlines staff very helpful in finding us a flight 2 hours later and they were very sympathetic and aware that the US Immigration staff are a bunch of jobsworths at this airport.

It seems like every time I fly into Atlanta there are delays, yesterday was no exception after arriving into Atlanta I was supposed to go on to Kentucky. That didn’t happen I was booked on two different flights and both were cancelled. No reason, everything was blamed on weather. Today my flight is delayed again as we have to wait for a crew. The entire customer base gets to wait as they need to get a crew into Louisville to make up a flight there. Although you consistently advertise this as the largest you certainly don’t advertise it to have the overwhelming amount of delays. Also my luggage was already delivered to Louisville or at least some of it. I realize weather plays a part but as an airport a a major hub for Delta you do nothing to accommodate your passengers.

We flew from Cancun Mexico to Atlanta for a connecting flight to London, we passed security as expected in Mexico without any issues the process was thorough but quick, in fact the flight was able to leave a bit early which allowed us two and a half hours to catch our connecting in the same terminal. However when we arrived it was absolute chaos, we had to queue initially for an hour to go through security, we were directed to a machine which took fingerprints and a photo then queued again for forty minutes just to have our fingerprints and photo taken again by a border official, we then had to queue for nearly an hour to have our hand luggage scanned and belongings checked by which time we had missed our flight too London. Staff in Atlanta are on a different planner, their streaming process is haywire, they don't want to help and basically kettle everyone like cattle into pointless queues and then have the nerve to have a go at customers for minor misunderstandings. Yes it was quite busy but not so much so to cause this much chaos. Also going to the desk to report missing our flight Delta were not at all interested and just wanted to move the problem onto someone else or rather blame someone else. I work in this business in the UK and am aghast at how utterly useless staff are here. Taking this all into account at the end of the day this was only a connecting flight, we were not even entering the US so completely ruined what was a nice holiday.

commentHeader: no signs for rental car dropping
plain lazy and so very unorganized
reviewContent: The power went out as soon as we got off the plane. Came back on for 15 seconds, long enough for us to read what gate we needed to go to for our next flight, arrived at 1.00, was supposed to have left at 2.10pm. At 4.00pm an employee came out and told us that the entire airport was without power and they should have it fixed in 2 to 4 hours. It came back on at 11.15pm. the employees were nowhere to be found to find out what was going on. We were stuck there for 15.5 hours with an employee coming thru 5 times with hot bottles of water, small bags of peanuts and pretzels. Thank goodness for chick-fil-a for the warm chicken sandwiches! My daughter waited in line for 3 hours with only one employee working to tell us there was no flights! They canceled our flights without telling us, didn't even try to rebook us. We missed our cruise because this airport is just plain lazy and so very unorganized. I had to rent a rental car and drive 6 hours home. Finally got our luggage 3 days later! Will never ever go back to that airport and will warn others not to go as well!

This has to be the most unprepared airport in the country. Not only are the TSA rude as hell but no one knows what is going on. Out of all Delta take first place in the we don’t care about the passengers, we just want you money. ATL is the worst airport in the country.

commentHeader: has to be the most unprepared airport
reviewContent: This has to be the most unprepared airport in the country. Not only are the TSA rude as anything but no one knows what is going on. Out of all Delta take first place in we don’t care about the passengers, we just want your money. ATL is the worst airport in the country.

Worst airport design I have ever seen and I have traveled to over 30 countries and at least 20 states. The rental car agencies are about 5 miles away from the terminal, and you'll spend about half of that walking and going up and down multiple escalators, and the other half taking two separate shuttles. Complete nonsensical nightmare that I never will go out of my way to avoid. I'm even writing this review on my sixth escalator ride after just completing the two shuttle rides.

commentHeader: something that needs to be addressed
reviewContent: I'm an 18 year disabled veteran and during my recent travels through Atlanta the customs team was without a doubt the worst I've ever dealt with in my life! I use a CPAP machine due to my OSA (Obstructive Sleep Apnea) and on my return transit through Atlanta customs I was treated like a common criminal. I know the customs protocols because I'm still customs certified. Before I went through I allowed a flight crew to get in front of me to expedite their process. The TSA customs agents are very belligerent and unprofessional I can understand the type of job they do on a day to day basis. But, since they deal in a profession that requires you to have interpersonal skills it really leaves something to be desired! My machine was set aside and the agent I asked as to why. Initially she didn't give me an explanation she just said I'll get to your situation in the order in which I receive it in a gruff manner. As a disabled veteran who served his country I truly feel that this is something that needs to be addressed ASAP! We are supposed to be the greatest nation in the world we should set the gold standard!

I am a frequent business traveler, using Atlanta airport as a home base and flying around USA and occasionally outside US. I am absolutely floored by the TSA disrespect in Atlanta compared to any other airport. It's a mess! Travelers are treated like cattle in chutes with TSA shouting at us. The new bin process to wait in a queue while bins pass before us is complete chaos. My belongings get separated and I now have greater risk of items being taken because I can't get through the screen to collect items. I now have to wait for a second bin to be allowed to pass into the bin screen lane. Throughout this process TSA are very very rude! They must truly hate their jobs. In contrast at other airports TSA are remarkably professional, courteous and helpful. What's wrong with TSA in Atlanta? It all starts with upper leadership to shape the work culture and attitudes of staff. Leadership should not tolerate workers who disrespect travelers. We are their customers. Atlanta Airport TSA - get it together!! This situation is deplorable and must change! I am a leader and know how to motivate, coach and hire staff who do excellent work. Get new leadership in TSA so this culture changes for the positive!

It has been many years since we last flew into Atlanta, and it was with some trepidation that we flew into Hartsfield with Virgin Atlantic this time. The memories of endless immigration queues, officious and rude staff, missing a connection and previous reviews of this airport were still with us so it was a very pleasant surprise when we landed. Bit of a queue at immigration with, of course, the obligatory lack of officers to deal with several long haul flights landing in a short space of time. But there were plenty of the electronic entry machines so the queue moved along OK. Through in about 1/2 hour and then a long trek to the baggage reclaim where our bags were already in. We had a connection to Savannah and upon entry to the transit check-in desks were spotted and told we were already checked into the Delta Flight - so handed over the luggage and were off the the domstic terminal - all within 1 1/4 hours! Very impressive - and even more impressed with the personnel because, without fail, each person we spoke to was courteous, cheerful and helpful! Really nice to actually feel welcome at a US port of Entry. As for the airport facilities, well, it was the usual mish mash of pizza and fast food joints, sports bars and coffee bars. But on this evidence would use again.

Awful airport. Very confusing. The staff very rude and unhelpful. When travelling a long way and not used to self service check in Staff could be more helpful to visitors. Worst airport I have been through. Need to improve the customer service.

The new UBER pickup point at Atlanta Hartsfield is extremely disappointing. The walk to the designated area is extremely long and seems to be an effort to discourage UBER customers. This was definitely a hindrance to my arrival in Atlanta. Upon my departure, I used my CLEAR membership for security. I was again disappointed with Atlanta Hartsfield. I had to wait an extended amount of time as non-CLEAR members were served first. After finally getting past this point at security, the speed of the security scans and poor attitudes of the TSA working there was yet again another disappointing part of traveling through this airport.

I use ATL for connections to Europe/Turkey a few times per year. Flying domestically into ATL and leaving on International flight is usually no issue and quite convenient. Returning to the US then connecting to a domestic flight is a headache every time. Two hours and 15 minutes this past Monday was not enough time to deplane, go through customs, find my bags and recheck them, then go through security again. Something needs to change, at the least expand the security screening area for International to Domestic terminals. On a positive note, the staff at ATL are the most helpful I have encountered in airports

Security staff are intentionally aggressive, intimidating and rude. The staff shout at you for not following instructions, yet there are no instruction signs to follow. Staff need to be taught that treating all passengers like criminals is not acceptable. I for one will never fly to Atlanta again and would advise everyone else from the UK to not fly here either.

commentHeader: we'll try to avoid using Atlanta in future
reviewContent: My wife and I were flying from the UK to the US to see the Total Solar Eclipse, we officially had just over 1.5 hours to make our connection to Denver, and were told that this would be tight. We actually arrived ahead of schedule, which was great, and then we got to immigration. Used the automatic terminals, which we thought were going to be a great time saver, but then we had to queue for an immigration officer, and our line didn't move for nearly an hour - what's the point in the auto terminals when you still have to queue anyway? Managed to get to our departure gate with about 10-15 minutes to spare (the "Plane Train" shuttle breaking down 3 times didn't help). During all this time no-one told us what the delay was caused by, and the (2) officers working the immigration desks were so slow it was almost unbelievable. By the time we finally got through the line behind us was huge, and there must've been people that missed connections - we were just lucky. Wherever possible, we'll try to avoid using Atlanta in future.

commentHeader: the employees are rude and condescending
reviewContent: The customs and security process at the international terminal is a disaster. There are not enough employees to handle large flights full of people, especially since the majority have connecting flights to catch. The worst part is that the employees are rude and condescending. They seem to have no idea that on international flights most likely some people don't speak English and yelling instructions in a louder voice isn't going to help. Nor are inappropriate comments by an old man about frisking women in the past helpful. I lived in Atlanta for many years and unfortunately it seems like nothing has changed to improve this process. I was embarrassed to be an American in that line Thursday, August 31.

I fly through this airport at least two times per week. I love many aspects but lately the golf cart drivers are honking their horn to get people to move out of their way. I find this horn honking to be rude and obnoxious. Please develop a better procedure and maintain a more peaceful environment.

Arrived to Atlanta Airport with 1.5hrs to spare between connectig international flights. Queues at immigration were ok but the service officers were super slow. Tried to speak to one of them to explain we had less than an hour, they couldn't care less. They then split us and half of the queue went through the side US citizens go. Used the machines but then they made us queue again to see an officer. What was the point? Awful treatment, dismissive, rude.

Unacceptable passport control waiting times. While I totally appreciate extra security protocols across the US airports, the level of inefficiency and lack of customer service is what I find totally unacceptable. This is for an airport that is the number 1 for passenger volume. I just came back from an international flight, and waited for 2 hours in line to go thru passport control. There were 4 officers reviewing passports for thousands of passengers, and more arriving as I stood in line.

Atlanta airport is a chaotic mess. Security lines are long and between TSA precheck, clear and general you will have a hard time finding where you need to go through. The scanning area is a joke. Food overpriced with long lines. Trains packed to overflowing. Biggest mess. Staff has no clue when you ask for help.

commentHeader: The officers were nothing but rude
reviewContent: Awful experience at CBP. After my husband was randomly selected for further screening, we where sent into a line for non US citizens that went on for as far as you could see. The booth for this line had one beyond slow attendant. He spent an average of five minutes plus for one person. The line for US citizens had 4 officers that simply glanced at the passport and literally moved hundreds of people through as our line got longer and longer. We along with a few other US citizens got moved up in line by an employee. When he told us to go to the officer, we along with the employee where yelled at by an another CBP officer to never come up to the booth until called by the officer in the most rude manner, embarrassing the employee and us. The officers were nothing but rude and could not have cared less about the massive amount of people in line, most of which where missing their flights because of a multiple hour process. I do not understand why there was only one officer for what had to be hundreds of people and why they had to be so rude and nasty to everyone. I am all for security, but this was the most inept and rude process I have ever encountered. Atlanta CBP needs much better staffing and officers who are not so rude, angry, and slow.

commentHeader: This was such a colossal mess
will avoid Atlanta Airport at all costs
reviewContent: From security to TSA to a "customer service rep" at the gates, every single encounter was rude. No one was willing to help. I arrived at my gate early. I saw a long line of people trying to board a flight that was leaving only thirty minutes before mine was to board. I couldn't get anyone to tell me if my gate had changed. No one would help because I wasn't on the flight they were handling. No one at another gate, no one at the gate I was at. They ended up changing the gates like I suspected. Security had attitude, TSA had attitude and the lady at American Airlines gate was the worst! I will avoid Atlanta Airport at all costs from this day forward.

commentHeader: never seen such a chaotic airport

reviewContent: Never have I seen such a shambolic process and never anywhere in the world have I met such surly and rude officials. Hundreds and hundreds of passengers crammed into endless lines moving at a snails pace. Most of these people had connections and from the fuming and disgruntled comments from just about everyone, it was clear virtually all missed their connections. With hundreds of tired passengers queueing patiently and growing increasingly anxious as it dawned on them that despite having stopover times of over 3 hours they were not going to make their connections. Just imagine that. In that short time period one Sunday afternoon literally hundreds and hundreds of passengers had their travel plans ruined. What was truly astonishing was the fact that the truly miserable and obnoxious officials seemed to somehow relish the chaos they were causing. Throughout most of this time only about 4 booths were operational with most standing unoccupied. In our case, my family had 3 and a half hours between flights but we still missed our onward connection. I personally was led like a criminal to a locked room with several others in order to answer questions regarding something which "showed up" on their computer system. The Officer who spoke at me (at not to) clearly had problems understanding the system and eventually I was told that there was a glitch in the system and was free to go. Needless to say no hint of an apology. Having just retired after 30 years in the Police Force I am a staunch supporter of offialdom and of Police and Customs everywhere but I have to say I was astonished at the attitude of the Officers I met and the general shambolic system at Atlanta. One place in the world I will never ever return to.

Worst airport for customs and border. Interminable lines - took more than 2 hours to get through and then had no idea where to go for connecting flights. All airport staff had no idea either. Signage was awful and mostly non-existent. I could not count how many people were complaining of missed connections - never again!

Probably the worst airport experience I have had and I have been to a few dozen airports in my life across Asia, Europe and even Africa. The queue at the border is mind boggling, it appears they want passengers to miss connections. Some serious work is needed, I'll do everything to avoid the spot in the future.

Terrible long and slow lines operated by TSA people. We are USA citizens and were not able to make it from flight Bonair to Atlanta to Omaha for 2 hours. Missed our flight as many other transit passengers, had to pay for night in hotel. TSA people worked extremely slow and seemed to enjoy holding hundreds of people without moving while letting others who arrived later to go ahead. They would call "Older than 70 yrs" to go forward but ot was big group of men in their 40s. TSA people just liked to be bosses. I asked to move us ahead when we had 15 min till next flight and long walk, all I heard was "everybody has flight in 5 minutes". The terminal had no air conditioning, people are sweaty, TSA knew about delays and didnt care to call gates about that.  I missed my Sunday job in Omaha and lost $150. Hotel was $99. I am rating this service 1 because of a  Delta lady who was nice to rebook our tickets for next day. Otherwise I would rate it 0. We had no chance to try food or anything. It took 1 hour to find hotel. All those promising ads on terminal wall were joke.

commentHeader: well over an hour in the passport line
reviewContent: After a long day of travel my husband and I were looking forward to arriving at our final destination at 830pm this evening. Instead we spent well over an hour in the passport check line in Atlanta airport and even after proceeding through the self check machines which were entirely a waste. The poor quality and lack of efficiency with the passport check process resulted in us missing our flight. We had to take the latest flight of the day after traveling since before 9am Zurich time. Avoid going to the Atlanta airport if you can.

We've just had our first transit experience at Atlanta and it will assuredly be our last - and that goes for the US as a whole, if Atlanta's inefficient, officious and frequently offensive staff are representative of national practice. Like many other correspondents, we nearly missed our connection, having only allowed 3 whole hours to get through this mess of a 'homeland security system'. Two desultory officials on the 10+ Esta / visa checking desks. Nobody in a hurry, nobody bothered as hoardes of clearly stressed and distressed passengers who'd waited for hours pleaded for help because they were risking missing their flights (many we saw today did). Representative comment from man vaguely minding the queue: 'ain't my problem'. Then downstairs to join another massive queue to go through security screening again (we'd earlier spent 4 hours checking in and being screened in Guatemala). And all the while being barked at by staff standing around chatting (plenty of those available, apparently, after the Esta staff shortage upstairs). Example of one crass command screamed at me (I had the temerity to be pulling my carry-on bag behind me in the queue): 'Bag in front of you - now!' Great welcome to 'the Land of the Free' to be treated like a criminal when you're just trying to change planes - having already submitted to - and paid for - the intrusive Esta check online. It's a shameful, stress-inducing shambles - to be avoided at all costs.

Very easy to navigate within the airport, very good food options. Going through customs was very easy and I mean super quick. I took me all but 5 mins to go through the kiosk and hand them my form. I have TSA precheck and that was not an option to use as of yet. The line was long but they kept us moving and talking with us.

commentHeader: leave a good 4 hours in transit
no sense of efficiency or speed
so easy to pass through the airport
experience is subpar to say the least

reviewContent: Arrived with Delta Air Lines on April 23 at around 1pm, in transit to Fort Lauderdale, departure at 3pm. We had two bags checked in at Panama City, tagged for the final destination. We are non-US citizens, we do have a valid ESTA since a previous visit. On arrival we were directed to a "first-time-ESTA" queue because of overload of the correct queue. We were over 100 persons in queue - only one (1) employee serving at the roundabout 20 parallel control points. The queue hardly advanced, frustrated people everywhere. After 1.5 hrs it was our turn. We hurried on, but were told to pick up our checked-in baggage and drop it at another location. We then entered another endless queue for security check. By the time we were thru, it was 3.30, our plane was gone. A nightmare. We do not mind the security rules, but we hate being disrespectfully treated.

commentHeader: it took ages to be processed
surprised by how friendly and helpful the staff were
good airport, customs officer was very friendly

reviewContent: At the Austin airport, it was presumed by the CLEAR agent that I was not a CLEAR member so when I entered the line, they tried to re-direct me. I stated I had clear, they again re-directed my “all the way down” to a different clear line, maybe? I instead opted for the TSA line which was adjacent to the CLEAR station I was at, however when I entered the TSA line… same clear agent screams “all the way around the corner, that’s not the line, it’s not the line” to which I responded I’m doing TSA pre-check instead so she again ye;;sacross asking “but is that on your boarding pass?”  oblivious that I have TSA pre-check and CLEAR. Furthermore, CLEAR always makes me show my ID despite it advertising as ID-less. All in all, TSA precheck is a more efficient, respectful, organized process. CLEAR is lacking manners.

I have a been a frequent traveler of Austin-Bergstrom Airport (AUS/KAUS) since the airport opened back in 1999. I have seen the airport grow and change over the years. The changes over the years have been for the better! Notable things about Austin-Bergstrom International (AUS): - there are two terminals the (main) Barbara Jordan terminal where all the restaurants, lounges and stores are, and the South Terminal currently Allegiant and Frontier Airlines. - there is a family viewing area outside the airport for watching planes and having a picnic. There are currently 4 lounges (AA, UA, DL and a Chase Sapphire Terrace) - there are many good places to eat including many local restaurants (my favorite are Taco Deli, Salt Lick BBQ, Second Bar + Kitchen, Annie's, and Juiceland. - it takes about 20 minutes to walk from one end of the terminal to the other, along the way you will see lots of places to eat, drink and shop. Pros: clean, great dining, bars, and rest areas. The Delta lounge is the nicest lounge in the airport. Cons: restaurants close early, so if you arrive on a late(ish) flight you will not have food options.

Making your customers walk in the searing heat halfway across the airport to find taxis and rides is pathetic. Any chance I get I will tell people what a lousy setup it is. Also there are too few elevators to deal with the people.
Getting through security early in the mornings is a nightmare. Very poorly managed. Almost missed my flight. It is necessary to have at least 2 of the 3 checkpoints open any time of the day.

commentHeader: the bathrooms didn’t used to be this dirty
reviewContent: I’m from Austin, and the bathrooms didn’t used to be this dirty. Since Covid I’ve traveled 10-15 per year, and the bathrooms have consistently been getting dirtier. Even just now, there’s water all over the floor, multiple stalls have no toilet paper, there’s one stall that was too gross to mention, soap and water all over the sinks and mirrors. Please fix this so Austinites can go back to being proud of our airport.

Been traveling for a week only have my petty cash left. Get to the airport in Austin Texas expecting to get something to eat and drink for my six year old. Nowhere accepts cash in this  airport except conveniently enough all the bars serving liquor do! Tell me why the staff here find it laughable that I can get a cocktail and pay in cash, but getting a juice is not happening.

I had ae three hour lay-over and my first time in Austin's airport. From the time I walked into the bathroom, the stench was overwhelming, I actually had to vomit. There was toilet paper all over the floor and body fluids from people utilizing the bathroom on the toilets, floor and especially the most disgusting part tissue holder. I went to find a sandwich to take on my flight and decided to sit at the countertop. The tables were filthy, the trash cans were overflowing. There was no one to ask to assist or call to have someone clean the area. I will avoid at all cost never to go through this airport again. This was and is disgusting.

Never been so disgusted at customer service before, I am usually not the type to ever write a bad review but everyone I spoke with was rolling eyes and talking with attitude, not to mention there’s no one to help get around considering not everyone knows what exactly to do. dirty bathrooms, extremely crowded and it made me super uncomfortable. I just got off a 4 hour flight, super tired just want to go home, my flight got delayed which isn’t their fault because of the weather but overall so disappointed. This is the first time I have ever been so disappointed in an airport and I have flied many times to many different countries. And we should have higher standards for American airports. How does that happen seriously so disgusting. I have lived here 18 years and have never been more disappointed!

As a nursing mother the lactation pod as the only option for privacy was absolutely disgusting. Filthy, dirty, dusty, sticky. Wrappers everywhere. Unacceptable to say the least. I used my wipes to try and clean it. And they were almost black. Do better Austin Airport.

This airport is absolutely disgusting. Trash and food everywhere, packed full of people, rude staff, and limited food options. Not to mention that every time I fly out of here, my flight is delayed. There’s gang stickers all over the place. Just sit down and look around. (If you can even find a seat) The only positive thing I can say is that they offer Disabled Veterans free parking.

AUS has limited food options, specifically at breakfast. Those with a 0500 flight time have no real breakfast options. Additionally, I was disappointed the airport didn’t prepare better for holiday travel. Austin has had an influx in its population and the airport already struggles. The holiday travel rush was not well prepared for and the patrons struggled. Open airline check in earlier and security to better serve their customer.

Austin-Bergstrom International Airport was chaos this morning.  We've already eaten the cost of Delta Airlines tickets, and we're scrambling to get on another airline. There were hundreds of people Outside the doors of the airport at Each security line! It took 2 hours to get through Security this morning. We went to American Airlines where the folks in front of us had missed their flight and they were trying to rebook, and the family behind us had missed their flight and they were trying to rebook. It's 5:45 AM, clear skies, no weather problems. I hope I Never have to use this airport again.

commentHeader: The south terminal was a nightmare getting to/from
reviewContent: The south terminal was a nightmare getting to/from. They must have been short handed because the shuttles were about 30 minutes apart and could only hold around 10-15 people at a time. Definitely needs better logistics getting from main terminal to the south terminal.

commentHeader: no place to sit down or eat
reviewContent: Terrible experience at this airport! Spent too long waiting for transport to South terminal. Once there no place to sit down or eat! Felt punished for choosing to fly Allegiant!!

commentHeader: escalators and elevators were turned off
reviewContent: Upon returning my car rental on the 3rd floor of the rental garage, all escalators and elevators were turned off. Since the car was returned there was no way to go down without walking the entire length of the escalator with luggage. Other passengers that were in wheel chairs had children and the elderly could not get down. There were no attendants to assist anyone. This was at 5:30am on a Monday. These should be on 24 hours a day since you can return your car anytime.

commentHeader: no social distancing or hand sanitizers around
reviewContent: There was no social distancing or hand sanitizers around, people were just crammed in lines, no one was even worried about it. Every other airport took it seriously and had hand sanitizers everywhere. Austin didn’t seem to take it seriously at all.

commentHeader: seems to continue its decline year after year
reviewContent: Austin airport seems to continue its decline year after year. Moving taxis and rideshares to an inconvenient spot that is poorly marked (albeit improved from a few months ago) is compounded by poor shuttle service for those traveling with luggage. The interior is beautiful and I love that they’re bringing in more local businesses, however this could never mask the abysmal experience in trying to leave the airport. The “shuttles” to the taxi stand don’t even assist with luggage anymore. It is such a hassle getting out of this airport I would avoid it at all costs if I didn’t have to go for work.

Simply put, Austin Bergstrom is a surprisingly disappointing airport. Before I venture into the negatives, I do want to highlight the positives of the airport: The terminal opened in 1999, and has largely, recently been renovated. The dining options in the terminal are largely from very local, and locally-themed, restaurants, something unique to airport terminals around the world (as opposed to a local restaurant being located amongst a terminal full of chains). The airport's clean, modern and fairly spacious even given its small size. The seating areas feel more like very nice doctor's offices than the traditional airport seating arrangements. Parking is close to the terminal, even economy parking, and it's reasonably priced. Access off Highway 71 is easy, whether coming from Austin and I-35 to the west or Bastrop and Houston to the southeast. The airport doesn't feel particularly crowded, even during peak passenger traffic hours. And yet, I can't bring myself to give this airport any more than a 4/10 overall rating. I don't particularly enjoy flying out of here. For one, the signs directing drivers to parking areas, arrivals, departures, and the correct lanes for regular vehicles and buses/livery are poorly marked, in my opinion. Even chaotic airports like LAX and O'Hare have better signage for such, strangely. Secondly, once you're within the airport, signage to direct people to check-in areas, rideshare and taxi pickup areas, and security isn't exactly the clearest, not the worst I've seen, but enough to make a small airport relatively confusing. Thirdly, once you're past security, it's surprising to find that the restaurants that serve tacos, meals, margaritas, beers - the things you'd expect to find in an airport in Austin and Texas are slowing down or even closed after 8.00pm. Fourthly, the personnel that work here are very hit and miss, but generally unfriendly. For example, the ticketing agent for Spirit Airlines (not exactly the budget airline with the best reputation) was very pleasant and courteous. The TSA agent who checked my driver's license, a super friendly and chatty guy. But, the shuttle bus drivers between economy parking and the terminal were little more than manner-devoid rubes. The actual x-ray screening agents for TSA were some of the biggest smart-asses (and not the fun kind, but the unpleasant kind) that I've ever met in my life, period. The restaurant servers and bartenders don't give customers eye contact while providing service, and can often be found tapping their feet while interacting with customers and not interacting with one another at all while working. That's the part that leaves me cold; for all the talk of Texas hospitality, it is sparse in this airport. In summary, there are much worse airports in the USA, but there are also much better airports in the USA and abroad. Only fly into Austin if you must!

commentHeader: the best experience we’ve ever had entering the USA
reviewContent: This was the best experience we’ve ever had entering the USA. We were literally the first off our plane through an extremely quiet immigration area and greeted by the most pleasant Customs Officer ever. He was so charming and full of local advice and obviously very proud of his city. He even searched for events for us to go to and could not have been more helpful. It is a quieter airport compared to somewhere like Miami so maybe they are more laid back but the difference it made to the start of our holiday was amazing. Well done Austin.

None of the vendors take cash. None of the food service people understand that folks have flights to catch. Slow as molasses like they could not care less with 5 others in the back. Very unprofessional. Where is the Starbucks? I’ve tried all the coffee places with the many trips I have taken and none come close. I just want a large, (big) iced coffee when I get off the plane like any other airport. Of the many airports I travel through, Austin gets the worst rating.

Austin International Airport fail. Waited 30 minutes to open the airplane doors. 10 electronic passport control machines for nearly 500 passengers. 8 work. Had to stand in line to recheck our bags to our final destination behind all the people that were originating in Austin (we had just flown 11 hrs in from Lisbon.) Other airports do a simple recheck right after customs. TSA very rude and inefficient. I’ve never had to separate carryon snacks for the X-ray at any other airport. Of course our bags didn’t make it and the airline won’t deliver them since the recheck made them categorized as late. Alaska personnel were fantastic but I will avoid Austin at all costs from now on.

commentHeader: very hard to see in the dark
reviewContent: The parking garage also houses the rental car companies. The garage is under construction and the signage for Rental Car Return is so dusty it is very hard to see in the dark (5.45 am on May 19, 2018). I missed it twice and had to ask airport security where it was. It took 30 minutes to find it, causing me to miss my flight. (Also, on entering the terminal there is no signage showing which airlines are to the left and to the right.) Fortunately my airline re-booked me on the afternoon flight at no extra charge. The chances are very low that I will never use this airport again.

commentHeader: Hard to find where you need to go"
reviewContent: Shuttles to and from parking areas and south terminal involve a long wait in the heat and a rather long ride. Shuttle drivers are courteous. Hard to find where you need to go because directions are not clearly posted. All in all rather inconvenient. Maybe it will be better when construction is complete.

I have traveled all over the world and have used some digusting mens rooms. Today, I felt like I entered a 3rd world men's room this morning. Had to clean my own toilet seat. My wife used the ladies room the same time. She was surprised how filthy it was. Someone should lose their job.

Austin-Bergstrom is a pleasant airport. The lines at TSA were very mild while we were at this airport, and the design of the airport is open and clean. Check-in with Southwest was as easy as usual, staff were friendly. The seating at the gates was plentiful, something which is surprisingly uncommon across the US. However, food and shopping options seemed severely limited and the airport was undergoing construction.

commentHeader: Long delays due to technical difficulties
reviewContent: Long delays due to technical difficulties at the airport. On my original day of departure, the Austin computers were down and the flight was expected to be delayed by 45 mins due to manual checking process. Since I was going to miss my Atlanta connection, I rebooked my flight for the next morning and stayed an extra night in Austin. The next morning the jetway was broken at my gate and the flight was delayed yet again for more than 45 mins. Both times, it seemed to take much longer than necessary to adjust to or fix these problems which is just unaccectable. Austin airport is currently not able to adapt to the increased traffic of this city.

commentHeader: This is the worst airport ever"
reviewContent: This is the worst airport ever. As a business traveler and having just moved to Austin this year from Dallas, TX I never realized how spoiled I was living in Dallas and traveling from DFW. The city of Austin is in denial. This airport is so busy and doesn’t even have enough gates, not many direct flights, no services. Security lines horrible, traffic at drop off and pick up is a nightmare. With all the people moving in to Austin you would think that the city would expand the airport, expand highways and improve infrastructure. Unfortunately this city lacks major infrastructure. If you are thinking about moving to Austin think again. I am moving back due to this airport. This year has been nothing but living hell traveling weekly through this airport.

commentHeader: badly in need of expansion and modernization
found the airport clean and fresh
everything at this airport is very close
reviewContent: Hartford airport is very small - I arrived 2 hours before my flight because I was coming from Vermont and wanted to allow for traffic, but that was way too early for what was available at the airport. The hall immediately past security has plenty of restaurants to choose from, along with a number of rocking chairs that have a nice view of the apron. The Gates 1-12 concourse also looked like it had been recently renovated and also had a nice selection of restaurants and shops. However, the pre-security areas and the Gates 20-30 concourse were dark and dim, and were unpleasant places to wait. Fortunately, everything at this airport is very close, so if your flight leaves from Gates 20-30 you can wait in the post-security hall and go to your gate at the last moment. Still, it'd be nice if the airport would renovate the Gates 20-30 concourse and the pre-security areas so that it looks as nice as the Gates 1-12 concourse.

Easy to park, easy to whiz through security, super friendly, clean, good services. I got there a bit late for check in and people let me skip the line! So nice. Security was extra careful to check bins so I did not leave anything behind in my rush. My airline pages me to board!

Small airport, very friendly staff, not too many food choices but the best for long layovers if you need a place for sleep, plenty of big chairs/couches, comfortable and with outlets for charging electronics.

The TSA pre check line is not adequately highlighted when coming in to depart. As a result we ended up in the annoying line where you have to remove coats, belts, shoes, laptops everything but tooth fillings. Plus a full body screen, breast area pat down, leg pat down. Really? I have no artificial limbs, no metal knees. Tampa isn’t nearly as annoying. TSA pre check lines are clearly identified from the moment you enter the airport. Cmon CT, shape up.

Staff should be retrained on customer service! Especially American. They are very rude and disrespectful. Flight crew got off the plane and went to another gate 20 min after we were “suppose” to board. When we asked what’s going on we received nothing but attitude from the gate agent. Another gate agent walked up and totally ignored our concerns. We’re at B1 for flight 5253 to CLT. Shortly after the gate agent says there is a maintenance issue and they won’t be in for another 2 hours. We all had the same question: Why wasn’t the plane inspected the night before, being it’s an early morning flight. Secondly, why isn’t maintenance on-site during hours of operation? This is very unprofessional! If there were other options outside of this place that were closer I’d explore it because no one deserves to be treated this way especially early in the morning. I’d rather drive 3 hours to Atlanta than to deal with these Attitudes after we pay our money for a service! My recommendation Don’t fly out of BHM especially with American !

Spent the last two days and one night inside the airport. My husband went to several different bathrooms and he said they all smell like urine. Terrible like the guy mopping is just smearing all around. The women’s bathroom had dirty floors and pieces of trash lying around. Several of the toilets weren’t flushed. Food options are very limited. Bham is a foodie city and we should show that off to the world. Maybe allow local favorites to set up pop ups during the tourist seasons!! I could give you tons of recommendations as to who to invite and share their menus with travelers. Give them a true taste of Birmingham.

Security lines are insane. This is my 3rd experience with it, and I’m starting to piece together the scam. Don’t we pay a surcharge on every ticket purchased for the delightful experience of trusting TSA to keep us safe by making us remove our shoes and other useless acts. They keep the security lines long creating stress and panic so you consider signing up for Clear ($179/year and more privacy invasion with a retina scan and fingerprint capture). So the elite (those willing to fork over the dollars on top of their federal and any other taxes that fund airports and plane ticket fees) cruise on through security while the other ~97% of passengers languish in line and miss their flights. How on earth the warlord of the Birmingham airport allows 70% of TSA staff to service the elites on the TSA Precheck/Clear side vs the 30% (~4 TSA employees) on the side of the regular people, only makes sense in a corrupt government deal. I thought that this would be aggravating for the airlines on the other side of the curtain wondering where the passengers were who paid a pretty penny to fly like cattle while being prodded to pull their masks over their nose the whole time. But a little research revealed that the airlines invest in companies like Clear. Silly me. It’s a circular racquet probably formulated along the lines of the Chicago red light camera and parking meter debacle. Bottom line: pay your toll at the troll bridge or suffer along with the peasants.

Bismarck Airport does not have a 24-hour Terminal. The Terminal closes 1/2 an hour after last flight for the day. The terminal will not re-open until 3am. Everyone in the Terminal will be required to leave from 1/2 an hour after last flight until 3am so that required security checks can be completed. It is not allowed to spend the night in the Bismarck Airport Terminal. Please plan appropriately.

I'm not sure what ultimate plan is for gates C4- C11 is, but in its current state, its awful. I have never walked as much as I have in an airport as I have here. The shuttle bus process is really bad. Driving in a fully loaded bus with NO air is un excusable. The two tiny windows that were letting a tiny bit of air were not enough. We ended up sitting on the bus for a good 4 or 5 minutes while we waited for 3 Southwest planes to pass. When the last jet went by and started throttling up we got a nice HOT blast of the smell of jet fuel.  I can't say that I won't be back, but we may change airlines so we don't need to endure the poorly planned annex wing.

Shuttle between terminals to get to bag claim takes forever. Very poor design has shuttle bus.  Absolutely no controls at ride share pickup. Ubers double parried everywhere created 15 minute traffic jam delay. If you come to Nashville airport plan to wait. Everything takes three times longer than required. Poor design and poor governance.

Worst experience arriving to an airport. Have to stand in extremely long line waiting for shuttle to take you to main terminal to then get your bags and rental car. Took over 15 minutes standing in line with no official information from the airport staff. All information came from locals who were also in the line. Worst experience, arriving in a city. No soap on the ladies bathroom. Finally get on the shuttle to stand on the runway waiting for planes to taxi in and out. So now on a crowded shuttle watching planes move all around and still not to the terminal. Absolutely ridiculous and a miserable introduction to a city.

After having stood in line with my family for an hour and finally reaching the check-in counters for our airline, we were told to wait while while another 20+ people checked in before us, causing us to wait another 30 minutes. We were the only ones going to a separate state, so it would have been so easy to just check our 2 bags when we first got to check-in. So because adults couldn't plan ahead and get to the airport with plenty of time for their flight, we were the ones that had to stand there and wait for them. We finally made it to our gate with 10 minutes to spare. To say I was angry and frustrated that the employees had zero sense, is an understatement.

Had a great experience. Going through security was fast, had no wait time. They had great local beers on tap and even a smoking section. It costs 10 bucks to enter, but considering I haven't been in an airport that had one in 15 years it made the wait SO much better. 10/10 will layover in.

I am writing to complain about the cost of long-term economy parking. I have lived in large cities around the country and long-term economy parking is around 8-10$ per day. This airport has continuously raised its long-term parking fee over the last few years to a now astronomical amount of 18$ per day! That is unsatisfactory and unacceptable. There have been no improvements to the parking lot and there are not buses running more often to them. Why the unreasonable raise. The traffic at the terminals themselves is also horrible. People will be waiting for almost an hour to pick someone up around the holidays.

commentHeader: everything is worse than was before
reviewContent: Getting in and out of the airport is now a real problem. Traffic does not flow around and is backed up constantly. New design has added stop lights which just backs up traffic even more. Years ago, BNA built a parking deck, then 2 years ago tore it down to do the new terminal and parking. Now everything is worse than was before. Even the shuttles to the parking areas are affected and now take forever to go to and from the pickup/drop off areas. Parking spaces are blocked off, constant construction. Cell phone lots have moved off site causing drivers to “Park” on the road. Traffic cops at arrivals do not enforce people from parking and moving on causing traffic to back up all the way around the short term parking area.

Flight 1101. Dec 23 12:23AM: We have been sitting on the tarmac for 2 hours tonight. Yes there was some snow here. We were told there are no open gates. Get the other passengers off the planes at the gates if they aren’t going to fly out. There is no reason for planes to stay boarded sitting and blocking the gates. Ridiculous. Very very dissatisfied.
Fantastic. Ample and clean restrooms. Great restaurants. Napping rooms available to rent. Everyone was kind and assisted as needed. They asked me if I needed help. Super customer friendly service.
Extremely noisy. Loud music, requiring loud announcements. In C terminal floor constantly shakes, it seems to be an engineering flaw. Avoid if you need to layover.

This was my first visit to Nashville airport and it will be my last. We arrived to fly back home to the UK. Airport was under construction, very few seats to sit while you waited for check-in to open. No where to purchase any snacks while waiting. After we checked in we had priority security. We proceeded to use priority lane but got so far and it was closed. There was a few of us and we had to join the end of the queue. One of the gentlemen asked a TSA agent what was happening with security. She was extremely rude and dismissive of him. So much for friendly and helpful staff! After security the selection of food and shops is quite sparse. Not what I would have expected from an airport the size of Nashville. We were extremely disappointed with our experience of this airport!
