The first train took much longer and was very crowded. It was worse for the second train. We waited a good 10 minutes as the crowd grew, and very nearly did not get onto the hot crowded car. The pre-pay facility at the parking ramp was in poor repair. It took a long time to figure out where to touch the screen to get the buttons to work, (down about an inch from the buttons themselvs!). There were only two lanes open to exit the ramp, and one of them was blocked by another car who couldn't get the automatic ticket to open the gate. Overall, it took almost an hour from landing to getting out of the airport in my car. This place is a mess, is poorly run, and is unfortunately about the only option we have.

Worst airport I have used in many years. Getting there torturous, chaotic at Penn station and then big queues for airtrain. Huge queues at security, very hot, rude staff and extremely poor airside facilities. Extortionate prices for food and drinks and hardly any choice. Awful - avoid if you can.

Genuinely cannot begin to explain how awful our experience at this airport was. The staff were rude beyond belief and if it were warranted I wouldn’t bother posting a review but it absolutely was not. The girl who was checking us in at the BA desk in terminal B did not want to be there and made no effort to connect with us, grabbed my bag from me as if I were an inconvenience to her, and as a nervous traveller these kind of experiences just make it worse. She was asked by an employee if she was being nice and her response with an eye roll was ‘trying to be’. I encountered very few polite people in this establishment and genuinely do not want to fly to this airport again. Toilets were absolutely disgusting, any time you ask for assistance with anything you are treated with a sigh.

I’ve never had any problems at Newark Airport. Pretty swift, but know you’ll be waiting in some lines. I went to check a bag that came to be one pound over the limit. The kiosk told me it would be $225. We were rushing, so I paid it. In shock that I just paid that and didn’t even ask questions, we looked around where to go next. A woman working there came up to me and asked if I wanted her to put on my bag ticket. She noticed it said heavy and asked how heavy it was. The staff member immediately took me through lines to get a refund. It was so kind of her to do that for me - it absolutely made my day and started out my vacation on such a more pleasant note. I am extremely grateful for her! Thank you!

We traveled through Newark twice in Sept. 2018. Unfortunately, I have to report that this is the worst airport experience in years, and we are world travelers. The worst part of the experience was the awful, terrible, confusing and misleading signage. I would really suggest they hire a consultant to review and drastically improve the signage. There were no maps that I could find in the airport, and I had to ask multiple people, often other travelers, to try to find our way around. The worst was trying to locate the SkyTrain. The small signs appear to have an arrow at the end of them, so we followed those, and ended up nowhere. After asking, we were directed upstairs. Then, I think on the 3rd level, there are conflicting signs, one with an arrow down and another, on the 2nd level, with an arrow up! Again we had to ask where to find it. When we finally got to the station, there was a nice official man, who helped make sure we got oriented to the right train. Even on the way back, we had to ask directions again, because we again got confused by the conflicting directions. All of this could have been avoided with clear maps and well-designed signage. On our return from an international flight, we had the misfortune of having to go through customs and security there. It was ridiculously redundant, I think we had to complete 5 lines before getting out, and it was so slow we almost missed our connection. After completing immigration, we had a very slow and inefficient security clearance before getting on our next flight. It seems more personnel are needed, or else streamlining the process.

I can echo most of the previous review word for word" "Awful. Terminal C very loud and not enough seating. Have to listen to irritating music the whole wait. The music is awful. It's like sitting amongst a bunch of bars. I have found this extremely stressful. It's 7:30 am, so most people have been awake for a few hours already. Desperately looking for a quiet place to sit, but the beer garden (completely empty) that takes up a huge section of Terminal C is blasting thumping music. Go somewhere else, it's TVs. The food that is available is overpriced junk food. What an extremely unpleasant place.

Awful. Terminal C very loud and not enough seating. Have to listen to irritating music the whole wait. There was trash in the few available (non table chairs). I had to remove old food containers to find a place to sit. The music is awful. It's like sitting amongst a bunch of bars. I have found this extremely stressful.

My arrival at Newark was my first experience of the USA in the Trump era. I don't know if The Donald is to blame, but it wasn't good. 400 or so people on the plane. Probably 300 of them, including me, foreign passport holders who were directed to one open processing point, while our US friends sailed through their multiple open gates. After an hour in the queue another international plane arrived, probably from China. At this point someone decided to let the international queue go through the US processing gates. If this is what America First means it also may mean less visitors and less of our money. At least the delay meant my bag was waiting for me. Transport from the Airport was good on the train.

commentHeader: the lines are beyond a joke"
reviewContent: I am one of these people who never conplains, usually just get on and deal but this trip tipped me over the edge, cannot deal with Newark airport. It is disgusting, the bathrooms always have huge lines and are gross as is the concourse. My husband and I are TSA approved, the lines are beyond a joke. The TSA agents are rude to put it mildly. I am 51, had a hip replacement 18 months ago, not the average age for this surgery however I get spoken to and treated like I am a moron especially when I line up at the revolving body scanner. It took 20 mins to get through on Sat 8/17/18. Is this seriously the best an airport with mass footfall can do? These people are jobs worth, have no patience and are condescending. Came from Tampa this morning, the experience was so different. Airport is spotless, TSA agents are polite and for the first time ever whilst lining up to go through the body scanner I was asked in a friendly manner if I had metal in my body, it took no time at all to get through. Doubt this review will change anything as no one at Newark seems to care!

After a 4+ hour delay our flight to London was cancelled due to a ‘20 minute’ storm. However it seems that this a common occurrence in this part of the world, at this airport that they are ill prepared for. Terrible communication and service at all levels (bar one woman who helped rebook our flights) which by the way was 2 days later! Seating areas are uncomfortable and sparse. Tired, dirty concourse, hot food left out for hours in the open and very expensive with limited choices. As for baggage reclaim - a total nightmare! I would not recommend this airport to any traveler coming in or out of New York at any time of the year.

Newark airport has always been a hot mess. My specific complaint is the terminal letters and locations. My husband and I arrived to Newark on Thursday July 19, 2018 all was good. On Friday July 20th my 3 kids were coming in. They called us to let us know that they arrived and would be in baggage claim. Coming into the airport we saw terminals A, B and C. They were in C. To get to them with your upper and lower roads was the most craziest thing I have experienced. We kept missing how to get to terminal C going slow and reading the signs. Then trying to get back into the airport it put us out of the way no wehre close to where we were. After 45 minutes circling the airport and almost getting stuck in the parking garage we got to them. Coming back home we flew out of Philadelphia. A piece of cake! Tell your road people to get two civilians to get in a car, read the signs and see if they can get to their people to pick up in baggage claim.

Filthy restrooms, poor food options with quality below expectations. Messy corridors. Staircases without help for elderly people. Worst airport experience so far. Clocks out of order showing wrong time.

commentHeader: does a horrible job at hiring staff
reviewContent: This is not the first time I have had a bad experience with TSA. This is the second time in a row and it will happen again next year I just know it. I don’t know what kind of people you are hiring but Newark does a horrible job at hiring staff. The bathrooms are gross and the toilet seats always have something on them. Food is overpriced for whatever reason. Newark is just money hungry but is bad quality.

Wendy’s always closes early. There is no one to complain to because the manager says we have run out of food, but that is clearly not the case because when I asked for a drink or frosty they said machines have already been cleaned or register is already close. They just simply start closing early regardless the situation. Tonight it was 9.43 and ropes were already barricading the entrance. Terrible attitude by employees.

One of the worst airports I have transited through. In the past, travelled through here en route to Florida. It seemed ok at the time although just before I boarded my connection I realised my wallet had been stolen. The security staff I contacted, and lost and found personnel were extremely unhelpful. It left a bad impression. I was reluctant to book a flight passing through Newark again, but it has been several years so I thought it may have improved - it is worse. This time around, the customer service aspect has not improved one bit. The airport has three terminals. If you are arriving from outside the US (even if you're not staying), you'll need to clear customs and go through security etc. all again. Also be aware that because there is no "within airport" transit area, you need appropriate ESTA to clear customs. There is extremely poor signage for transit passengers. To go between terminals, you hop on the AirTrain which only takes a few minutes. I had plenty of time to kill so explored each of the terminals (pre-security). I would suggest getting your food and drink (if you have time) before checking through security. At terminal A, there is very little beyond the security check point. There are few toilets too, and the terminal is very crowded. So if you can put off checking through to this terminal till you absolutely need to, I would. Terminal C is a lot bigger, and more choices for seating, food and drink but it is also a lot more expensive, even the fast food joints. The cheapest burger place charges about $8 for a burger, another 4-5 bucks for fries, and there was one poor soul making the food for everyone so long waits. I overheard a customer saying "sorry, I know you're busy, but I've been waiting 45 minutes for a chocolate milkshake". Both Terminal A and C security check staff were rude, and would not answer people's questions. At terminal C in particular, there are confusing TSA lines ups. Nobody knows where to go, there is no signage. None of the staff will answer a question, just point you towards another area or queue. There is really nowhere to get food/drink at terminal C until you pass security other than a dunkin donuts. If you have time to spare, go along to Terminal B or A, there are a few other choices like Manchu Wok, Subway, Wendy's etc. Given the airport is so busy, there seem to be routine flight delays. Both my flights out of Newark were delayed. If you have a tight schedule, factor in a couple hours just in case. Also pay attention to your gate. The gate for my return flight changed three times within an hour and there was no announcement in the lounge. It just happened that people were looking at their airline App which updated them. If you have a choice, I would not fly through Newark if I could transit through somewhere else. It's a shame as I like flying with the main carrier using Newark (can't name in this post) but the aggro of going through this place again puts me off entirely.

commentHeader: practically flung my passport at me
reviewContent: I’ve landed and departed at Newark a few times in the past eight years and although I don’t like it, this time there was over a half hour delay to get a gate for disembarking, but then arriving at the queue at Passport Control was unbelievable. I counted over 30 desks and only SIX were manned. The wait to get checked was over an hour, and finally when I did manage to get seen, the arrogant Inspector, chewing gum and looking over my shoulder, told me he couldn’t get my fingerprints. When I asked him why, he still didn’t look my way, but told me to try again and press harder on the screen. When this appeared to also fail I asked him what I was supposed to do. He asked if I was wearing hand cream, to which I replied no. When further pressed, he suggested my hands were “too dry”. What utter nonsense. All the latest fancy technology and it required wet or sweaty hands to get fingerprints taken. I told him I had no problems before, to which he just glared at me. I asked if he had any wipes, so I could clean the screen - which seemed to irritate him more. Finally, I took out my own wipes (luckily I had some, or I would have licked each finger - most unhygienic!). I dampened each finger with the wipes, placed them on the screen and bingo! He practically flung my passport at me. I’m 79 yrs of age, travelling alone, and usually am quite tolerant, but Newark airport has the most rude, arrogant, unhelpful staff and since there was no good reason for holding me up, and worrying my waiting family, I will happily never fly into there again.

Worst airport ever! Where do I even begin, the food is extremely overpriced and gross, although the restaurants look nice they are deceiving. Every single table has an ipad attached to it and when I say every, I mean every. Everyone is on screens, but there is zero wifi which makes no sense. The staff couldn't care less about helping, is understaffed, and is rude. The customer service line was the longest I've ever seen. The staff doesn't pick up food so there is other peoples old food on the table, no thanks. I would avoid this at all cost and go through JFK.
Absolutely the worst in the country. Dirty restrooms, unfriendly TSA and airport personnel, always late due to air traffic control, always problems with airtrain system.

Needs to invest in an urban designer, outside the airport luggage lines block entire sidewalk forcing people into traffic to enter airport. Security lines are set it up so you have to prep for screening one at a time, and there are no family lines. Zero common sense. Workers are indifferent, our daughter was car sick in the line and the guard would not help us with a garbage can. There are no garbage cans in the long line.

Absolutely horrible. I travel all the time and this was worst airport I have ever seen. Rude rude TSA and others. Can't even tell where the queue was for customs - mob scene. I feel so sorry for non Americans arriving here. In the future can travel through Dublin or Shannon and go thru customs there and not have to do it in Newark.

I traveled through this airport going to Spain. I agree with most of these reviews I have read on this site. I experienced long lines because of unprepared TSA officers, not adequately staffed and listened to their bickering between themselves. The TSA officers were rude and seemed not able to exhibit even the smallest of cordial interaction. As we went through customs some of the police officers also exhibited similar behavior. I understand the need for the security checks but there needs to be some component of decency and civility in the process. I intend on never utilizing this airport again and am embarrassed for foreigners visiting the United States and thinking this is how Americans act. It is clear that the TSA and some of the police officers have no checks on their behavior. A simple lesson of manners would serve them well.

commentHeader: longest I have ever had to wait
reviewContent: On arrival, we waited in a 1.5 hour queue for passport control - the longest I have ever had to wait. The airport seems to be operating way over capacity as there were under 10 staff checking passports for hundreds if not thousands of passengers. On departure, the security screening areas also seem far too small and you are forced to stand and wait for at least half an hour. The only positive aspect I experienced was the quality of the food in the departure lounge, however it was extremely expensive.

Worst airport I have experienced. Limited seating even when arrived 2 hours early. Rude employees. Couldn't even sit at open tables around restaurant that for some reason they were roped off. Never again!

commentHeader: Worst airport I have ever been to
reviewContent: Worst airport I have ever been to in my life, staff are unbelievably rude, also lost my luggage a week ago and still have not received it. I have been constantly contacting the airport and have gotten absolutely nowhere. No one seems to want to help and now I am stuck in the UK with no luggage I will never ever go back to the airport or travel with Spirit again.

Horrible experience! Avoid at all costs! Immigration was beyond a nightmare as it was poorly staffed for the number of passengers needed to get through. Dozens of families lost their connecting flights. Have read previous reviews that also stated inadequacies yet management does nothing to improve. Why? Is upper management too lackadaisical? Send your people to Disney to learn how to move volumes of people. In retrospect I will forever avoid this poorly functioning airport. Shame on management. You all need leadership training also. It is a noted fact that all successful corporate cultures start at the top. It was disgraceful that today on June 9 2018 you had so few people on hand to work.

A living dystopia. Noisy and chaotic. Screens everywhere rather than servers, non-stop barrage of ads and news, store selling meancing Trump cutouts and ironic "Keep America Great" sweatshirts, copious alcohol flowing at every turn, presumably to stop people from killing themelves during their connecting flights. People who work in the shops seem pleasant, but general feeling of dread while walking this hellish labyrinth unavoidable except for truly soulless.

I've attached a picture which summarizes the work ethic at this airport. Its a picture of the security people in charge of checking and verifying baggage ownership, they are supposed to ask to see your claim ticket before you leave the terminal with the bag, but these security members played with their phones, oblivious to people around them, like me taking pictures of them. Its a shame, no responsibility, no supervision, no work ethic. This is why Newark Airport is such a mess.

commentHeader: the worst airport in every way
reviewContent: I have travelled through this airport many times. It is the worst airport in every way. It is always loud, overcrowded with very limited service. There is nothing pleasing about the environment. There is limited charging locations. The PA system is always hard to hear. Acoustics are terrible. The facilities are not clean. It seems that all flights are late leaving Newark.

Travelled from Glasgow to Newark with my wife on a city break to NY on arrival and reaching immigration we were faced with very lengthy queue which I can accept however the nature the passengers were processed with was quite an eye opener and disappointing that staff can speak to people with a complete lack of respect. I don't accept that the jobs these people do gives them the autonomy to sit and chew gum and roll there eyes at you is if you are thick. On arriving at Newark for departure home it was more of the same, the staff I believe were having competitions to see who could be the least helpful, I have travelled many destinations and airports but this was on another level for complete lack of customer care which had really taken me by surprise. Overall an unpleasant experience which spoilt an excellent trip to NY.

By far the worst airport I have ever experienced. My sister and I had a connecting flight to Montreal. We almost missed the flight despite arriving an hour and thirty minutes before. We did not stop for food, just five minutes each in the bathroom. We made our flight by the grace of God and the kind people ahead of us in line, allowed us to past them. The TSA agents were so rude, it was actually like a game of let’s see who can be the rudest. They were unhelpful, unorganized and extremely unpleasant. This airport is so confusing. I mean no one knows what they’re doing or how to get to their gates and that is because nobody wants to do their job. Please avoid this airport at all costs. If you have to fly in, be prepared to possibly miss your flight. The other reviews are 100% accurate.

This was the absolute worst experience I have ever had. Truly embarrassing as a major American airport. Complete mayhem, the rudest people I have ever encountered - zero care that you make the flight you have paid for and arrived on-time. Disaster.

I’ve flown at least 50 times. Hands down worst experience of my life. I renewed my drivers license before I left for Florida. Had zero issues there. Zero issues till return trip through Newark NJ. They held me up at front counter tsa for 30 min plus. Then made me do public pat down and ripped through my luggage which took another 30 min. Almost missed my flight...because I renewed my driver lic. In last 7 days! It had not expired. And I had additional documents proving who I am. Stay away at all costs!!! You’ve been warned

Me and my husband we're going on an outbound flight heading for Copenhagen, but sadly, we had to experience Newark airport first. This was by far the worst experience either one of us had of an airport. Both being in our 30s, we have travelled a fair share and seen different kind of airports in different countries, but this was shocking! Our carrier (SAS) informed us to be at Newark airport approx. 1,5-2 hours before departure. But since the weather was a bit off in N.Y.C, we decided to go out to the airport almost 3 hours before departure at 11.30 pm in the evening. As luck would have it! The airport is extremely disorganized, with few signs pointing you in the right direction and not even informative calling in the loudspeakers. Instead, airport staff were going around yelling and shouting seemingly important info, such as that some passengers had to go ahead in line or were missing. Absolutely shocking. The security process itself was also a joke, and very, very time consuming. We stood in line for our security check 1 hour and 45 minutes. The procedure was very shattered and whimsical, and the staff was borderlining on being rude, screaming in peoples faces to remove their shoes. Why not put up a bunch of signs in different languages that explains the security process instead, so people can read and understand while standing in line? That would save both time and frustration. Not all security checks are the same either. All in all, being spoiled by the efficent security and customs in Copenhagen and Amsterdam, it was a nightmare going through Newark airport. There's certainly room for some massive improvements, and hopefully, improvements and effiency are on the top of the list of what to do next at Newark airport. The best advice we can give you, is to be at the airport with very wide time margins. It takes longer than you think (almost forever) and it's not an uncomplicated system. At least for departures, in this regard.

Worst airport in the world. We have been traveling for the past 3 months have been through 10 different airports and Newark is the worst. Badly made gates and terminals. Have to go through multiple security checks because of the stupid gates. Next time I see a flight transiting in Newark I will chose another flight.

I had a connecting flight in Newark on my way to Japan, and I thought it was alright. The staff were okay and decently nice. After check-in, I was amazed at all of the shops and food options and had a great time waiting for my next flight. When I came home from Japan though, it was a completely different experience. The staff were incredibly rude and obnoxious. I was a little confused where I was going and asked an employee for help, she was annoyed that I was confused and yelled directions at me. The other employees were just as rude and the overall atmosphere was unpleasant. Employees wouldn't look people in the eyes, they were on their phones, and leaning on walls/objects lazily. The staff at TSA were horrible, screaming directions at people and were just rude in general. I never experienced such rudeness from TSA/other staff at any other airport I've been to. If you have an option to go/connect to another airport, please do! Also, the WIFI was really bad and I had a hard time connecting to it on 2 different phones.

commentHeader: they are no longer serving food
reviewContent: I am used to UK airports standard, with plenty of choices to eat, and mall-style shopping. However, when you are at a Newark Airport restaurant early evening with 2 hours to spare and told that at 8.30pm they are no longer serving food, and that the only other restaurant in the airport serves food in plastic plates (at $15 for a burger and kettle crisps), you will be let down, no matter what your standards are. I was travelling from Newark terminal B. The queue for security was also appalling, the staff came across as disorganised and did not direct passengers properly so there was a long delay. To add to the bad experience, taxis to Newark from Manhattan do not have a fixed fee so if you are stuck in traffic for 1 hour you could end up paying easily double the usual fare, I would recommend the train to and from Penn Station to Newark airport if you are travelling light, guaranteed price and more reliable than getting stuck in the Holland tunnel during rush hour in a taxi. America, you need to sort out your airports and keep your restaurants open until the last flights of the day and start adding shops, you have a captive audience there, so it's no brainer! Also start adding signs for directions, i.e. signs for departure. I will fly from JFK next time hoping it is better!

commentHeader: worst airport I have been in
reviewContent: Absolutely the worst airport I have been in! No way finding signage to identify where you need to go, incredibly rude staff, slowest screening line I’ve ever seen, filthy bathroom that had a line around the corner.  I will go out of my way to never fly in or out of this airport

The gates at this airport need to be renovated, there was trash and it was dirty. The seats at the gates were falling apart and were very old. The seats did not have chargers for your phone, if you wanted to charge your phone you would have to walk to white tables near restaurants that had chargers. So if you wanted to charge your phone you could not do it at the gate were your plane would take off. I spent a long time looking for a map/directory that displayed restaurants and shops, and I never found it. I visited places to eat and found that the prices are ridiculous for what you are getting. The Wifi Connectivity was really poor, it would suddenly cut on and off at times. The ratio of passengers to staff is awful. It took me 30 minutes to get halfway through the travel assistance line. There was only 2 airline staff for so many people that needed assistance, which made the lines so slow. They need to hire more staff.

commentHeader: one of the worst airport experiences
reviewContent: I could also copy word for word the previous review. I had a six hour layover and it was one of the worst airport experiences of my life. My first thought was the general filth of the place. Staff were rude and unhelpful. The queues were massive and poorly laid out so that they blocked other traffic. Amenities are very limited beyond security. I had a gate change that was not announced. While I was in the toilet two airport workers came in bantering with each other with 'threats' and foul language which I at first thought was intended for me. The chairs were terribly uncomfortable making any rest impossible. In the future I will pay extra for tickets to avoid Newark.

This is one of the worst airports I’ve ever used and I fly most weeks with my job. Poor layout, massive queues, rude/arrogant staff. Having flown for many hours and needing a quick turn around to next flight we found the staff to be unhelpful, uncaring, unprofessional and rude. Based on the other comments on here it seems no one cares that everyone seems extremely unhappy with their service. Terrible airport!

Horrible ground service. Luggage came out 45 minutes after we landed. Then there was only 2 officers for the customs. I missed my connecting flight because of that. Then I had to go through security again even it was just a connecting flight. The lines were crazy. I took me more than 90 minutes to pass the security. Employees are rude and not helpful at all. It was a nightmare at this airport.

The self service food market and restaurants with iPad service are just horrible. Difficult to find a coffee shop. The photos on the ipad menus are not at all like the real food served. All digital instead of people facing service. Reallly inhuman. Lots of horrible clashing music. The worst place in earth to eat or wait. Shame on you UDA.

One of the worst airports in the world. Internet access is very bad, requires stupid Boingo hot spot. It can take a good ten minutes to actually connect if you can figure it out in the first place. No departure board for all airlines you have to find the board for the airline you are using.

I am a very frequent traveler and normally a patient soul. However it continuously stikes me how bad Newark Airport is at handling security and basic customer service. The lines are up to an hour long and while some of the staff is trying to keep the mood up the term customer service is not something most staff has encountered. Traveling from Terminal A it is the same whether in priority line or not. Go on a study tour abroad and see how others handle it. Get some logistic experts to help you out. You are loosing money and customers, myself included.

commentHeader: facilities leave much to be desired
reviewContent: It is clear by the horrendous reviews that no one at EWR cares about what passengers say. No surprise. Get rid of Ruby Tuesdays, and find someone to run a restaurant with somewhast decent service and food. This is not high brow. I typically wait 25 minutes before anyone even shows up to take my order. Terminal A. "A" Third World terminal. (And, I have been to many 3rd world airports. While facilities leave much to be desired, at least service to well-paying customers makes it worth it. Not EWR.

commentHeader: no standard of professionalism or kindness"
reviewContent: Newark and the TSA agents that work there in particular are an absolute joke and a national nightmare. Do everything in your power to avoid this airport. I just stood through an hour and thirty minute wait on a security "training day" (which is somehow happening every single time that I fly through this airport, I have never gotten through security in less than 30 minutes in 3 visits). Many of the passengers on our flight had finally reached the front of the line and were now having our names called out on the intercom. Clearly frustrated by now being on track to miss our flight after arriving hours before our flight, we began pleading with TSA to please hurry up the process as we were going to miss our flights despite being at the airport hours in advance. The TSA woman who was clearly in charge got into a verbal argument with another passenger (not joking), while displaying tremendous attitude, disrespect, and a fundamental lack of empathy. She then ordered a shift change to make a point or spite us or something, further delaying us 10 minutes. There is no standard of professionalism or kindness. Avoid like the plague. Worst airport in the United States.

To be honest, this must be a national embarrassment for the US? Horrendous design, tired and outdated, with dirty restrooms and an appalling restaurant at gate B54. Disappointed not to be told that the 'best' food options were landside, and I did not know that we would not be able to visit any outlets at any other B gate areas once through security. Security queue was slow. I was told iPads did not have to come out of bags (not the same in other global airports). Then I saw a bag being pulled aside from the X-Ray because there was an iPad inside it! TSA agent shouting at a passenger whose tray was being searched, because he was trying to help organise things in the tray to make them easier to inspect. The passenger was forcibly told to get back, then the TSA agent flicked his hands at the man. There's a real problem here with people having some bizarre personal space issues, like every person is out to get them (note - we normal passengers are not out to get you). Food at gate B54 was there worst I have ever seen, anywhere, ever. $14 for 5 dried out chicken nuggets and $9.99 for a beer. The Unusual Times 'restaurant' should be ashamed to even open. Apparently I was the first person today to complain. If it is, people here are far too polite and should rebel at such awful food! Last of all, toilet floors dirty, one sink blocked off, the other one not even stuck down to the shelf, when I pushed the faucet to turn on the water, the whole sink moved. First time into EWR, hopefully my last.

Flew into terminal A from Miami. It was completely hectic. TSA agents were so rude and not helpful at all. When flying back on my return trip I was asking which baggage claim area to go to and all I was told was to go downstairs. Most TSA agents and customer service representative would not help me at all, if it wasn’t for some young man working on the escalators I would have never found my baggage. Thank goodness that young man took the time to actually walk me over to the correct carousel. There actually are some nice people left in this world.

Airline staff are great but airport workers do not care one little bit about their jobs or customers. Bathroom I visited near gate C130 was dirty and the girl working there was busy with her hair. I bought food and coffee which was good but again, poor customer service and a general lethargic attitude. They don’t even have to cash you out, customers do that at kiosks. I will avoid when I can.

I arrived at this airport for the first time from international flight originating from Bangkok to Tokyo. This is approximately 20 hours of economy class comfort and Newark was my connection to RDU (Raleigh-Durham). It was also my third security gate passage in that 20 hour span and I had been mostly without sleep for the last 24 hours upon arrival at Newark. Overall, I found the security gate staff at Newark to be among the rudest and worst-behaved non-professionals in my limited flying experience as a passenger. They bark orders like you're in boot camp, and do not allow passengers ample organization time to move through the gate. I was carrying laptop computer and other carry-on bag, and did not wish to separate too far from them while moving through the gate. I was tired, slightly confused and forgot to place my smartphone in my personal items bin. They made a big deal about my forgetting to do this, and I commented back to them about their rudeness. A supervisor was immediately called by staff to investigate me further. I was then subjected to a full body pat-down, including full touching of my midsection. While being subjected to the full pat down, two more times the supervisor was called by staff to further inspect me. Only when I offered a verbal apology to TSA staff for negative comments made about their behavior and lack of common courtesy was I allowed to proceed through the gate. With the exception of the supervisor, who clearly could find no visible violations in my passage, I found all the staff completely lacking in professionalism and common courtesy, and feel they actually went out of their way to make my passage through the gate even more difficult when I responded to their negative and aggressive behavior. On whole, this was the dirtiest, most disgusting aiport I've encountered. The floors are dirty, the restrooms not particularly clean, the staff are rude. I will do my best to avoid ever connecting here again.

commentHeader: run in the most unprofessional manner
reviewContent: Flew Icelandair into Newark Airport with connection to Florida. We arrived at Newark at 6.30pm and was down at carousel 2 to pick up bags by 6.45pm. We received our bags around 8.30pm. Many people with small kids and connecting flights with no updates from either Icelandair or Airport employees. Icelandair said it was a carousel issue but no one thought of switching us to the many carousels that were open. When I asked Airport employees for assistance and a Manager, I was shrugged off and told no manager was available. This is the worst airport I have ever used and the baggage areas are run in the most unprofessional manner I have ever experienced. Will never pass through again if I can avoid it.

Currently been standing in the queue for 1hr 40mins to check in and drop bags for a British Airways flight (even though we had already checked in online in the hope of avoiding any long queues). 250+ in the line and only one staff member checking customers in. The line was holding flyers to London and France and as the flight to France was boarding 40 mins earlier, all customers on this flight were allowed to queue jump to the front, even though many many people had prempted and planned to get to the airport early, and this was dismissed and still currently handing in the queue. Awful customer service and never queued at a stand still for so long, then disregarded to priorities customers that arrived late, with only ONE college checking people in at he counter. Ridiculous.

I tried 3 different Terminal C bathrooms and all were disgustingly dirty. Human waste all over toilets and floors. Puddles everywhere. It was absolutely horrible. Never seen anything like it in a US airport. The TSA lines were unnecessary slow. Couldn't wait to get out of there. I will never set foot in it again.

After many years, I was using Newark airport. Accessing it from New York City was smooth. I bought a through ticket from Penn Station on New Jersey Transit and made the connection at the Newark Airport Station on to the Air Train which connects the terminals. I was using Terminal C, a hub for United. Although it was crowded, the security line moved smoothly. The terminal does not have enough "lower end" food services. Seating space is also insufficient. Besides the gate was a separate enclosed section for travelers to be security checked again. This was for travelers to Israel. The checks were unobtrusive and the movement of people were well controlled. On returning back to Newark, although I used the automatic machines to get my passport read, we had to wait in line to have the passport the computer print out examined by an immigration officer. It was a 15 minute wait primarily because only four agents were on duty. The officer was pleasant and wished me in that most wonderful of ways - Welcome back! With that I was in the baggage hall and followed the Exit signs out to the Air Train. At the conclusion of the Air Train ride, you buy the ticket for New Jersey Transit to go to Penn Station. Train staff are there to help you. The C Terminal is big and one has to focus on the signs to ensure avoiding getting lost It was not a hassle to use this airport.

I have just returned to Denmark from Costa Rica via Newark International Airport. Newark really was a very sad experience with extremely long security lines and - in general - staff that did not care about the passengers.

The TSA staff here are terrible - the worst of any I have ever experienced. It's not a security line at Newark if the TSA "agents" aren't sighing, rolling their eyes, and mocking and yelling at passengers (when we are unfortunate enough to attract their attention. Otherwise they just yell at each other). Recently, they seem to be on some kind of security kick. I have been randomly selected for a security check, or my bag selected for further inspection every time. Now, actual safety and security are great, but what we're getting are pat downs and suitcase inspections where they spill your belongings all over the floor. The security lines are slow and cramped, with limited space to unpack all your liquids/electronics. Another TSA agent specialty is just as you near the front of your line, they will usher you into a different line. I know it doesn't make sense. You have to see it to believe it, but I hope you don't see it. If you fly out of Terminal A in the morning, you get a lovely view of the sunrise over Manhattan. This helps me remember that there is some beauty and joy in our world when all around is darkness. (Look, I get it's not a nice job, worse than the service jobs I've worked, but if I pulled half this behavior I'd have been fired in a minute. More importantly, it's no way to treat your fellow human beings.) The gate staff are pleasant and helpful and always had good experiences there. I'm chalking that up to my airline though, which is why I'm a loyal customer. There are very limited food options. This doesn't bother me because i'm good with a sandwich, but your options are a sandwich or Ruby Tuesday. "Shopping" is nonexistant. Lines for the bathrooms (especially the women's) are always ~20 people long.

commentHeader: the airport feels a bit rundown
reviewContent: Upon arrival the airport feels a bit rundown. The ground staff seem miserable and unfriendly and the passport control queue was massive (we arrived on a Thursday around noon). The queue was very slow moving and it took us about an hour to get through. I then expected our bags to be on the carousel, but they took another 15 mins to come through. On the plus side, when flying out everything was smooth and quick and there are plenty of shops, bars and eating places to choose from.

commentHeader: terminal A is hell on earth
reviewContent: Let me just say that terminal A is hell on earth. It is small, crowded, and smells like an overflowing bathroom. I think that this place was Dante's inspiration. If you have a layover here do yourself a favor and take the shuttle to the much nicer terminal C. Whatever you do do not take the monorail-you will have to go through security again. Hellish. Just hellish.

This is by far the worst airport I’ve ever been to. Everything from the check in lines, to security lines, food lines, etc... is the epitome of inefficient. The facility is outdated, the staff are rude and unpleasant. I fly Southwest all the time, and I’ve never had anything but positive experiences, that is, until I encountered Newark Southwest staff. Completely unacceptable experience. Do better, Newark!

From an experienced traveler: Avoid Newark Airport. TSA line management employee was rude, yelling and insulting travelers. She asked one person if they were a Trump supporter and threatened another with moving them to the back of the line. It is generally dirty, long lines for toilets, long lines for security which is extra dirty, and again, the screaming security personnel who did not inspire confidence. Just discussing with other travelers who experienced the same and worse with this security employee.

Nothing wrong with this airport. We found our way quickly, and the skytrain took us fast to the car rental office. The only problem we had was with the very unfriendly TSA officers who were shouting in a hostile way to us, while there was absolutly no reason to do so. We flew from Newark to London Heathrow, and had to pass security again, and the British showed how to approach people in a decent way.

commentHeader: it has just added another level of hassle
reviewContent: In sales for 40 years. Enjoyed relaxing with a beer and sandwich at various airport restaurants. Now, can not simply talk to a person and place your order. Can't buy a stinking bag of pretzels without using a computer. Stuck in lines behind elderly and non English speakers who get frustrated and nobody offers assistance. Fire the person who came up with this idea, it has just added another level of hassle to traveling and sapped the fun outta "having a few pops, before the flight".

commentHeader: Food crumbs and debris all around
reviewContent: In Terminal A, I am sitting next to actual trash. On the floors, in the seats. Food crumbs and debris all around. The ceilings have large stains and holes. The carpet tiles are ripped up. A young girl tripped on one. Signage to go from our international flight in Term C to here was practically non-existent. There were no staff to assist. A bag belt worker helped us located a map to the airport. There don't seem to be operational water fountains in the area. The terminal is packed with nowhere to sit due to everyone's flight delays. We've had plenty of airport experiences around the world, this is the most disgusting. And who has only 30 minutes of free wifi for an airport notorious for delays?

commentHeader: shows no interest in providing a quality experience
reviewContent: I am sitting outside gate C132 at Newark. Newark is very convenient for me but the airport itself shows no interest in providing a quality experience. They seem to have recently added food and beverage in this area and it's a total mess. Uninviting. Tons of potato chips and soda stacked high on the shelves. I bought a straight forward sandwich that was inedible. The main attraction, sitting in the middle of the concourse, is a bar with 100's of bottles of liquor. It's all in very poor taste.

The worst airport in the world in my opinion as someone who travels every week. Poor technology, hostile united and TSA staff, inept, told to use my app to figure out where and if my flight would land and depart since all terminals said on time. Hours delayed flight never shown on monitors said either on time or closed, staff told me flight had left, when it hadn't even arrived from Hartford. Once it was boarded, later flight was cancelled and then they over fueled flight, and tried to get people off, lack of information, signage, air bus than shuttle to flight, stairs to plane. Tried to leave and drive to my destination but was informed by baggage claim that to get my checked bag could take up to two hours. This airport and many others in America simply should be shut down. It's government, it's the airlines, it's what we have created. I just returned from Japan and all I can say as an American, we should all be embarrassed. It is such a joke, it seems intentional - culture, service, technology all make it the worst airport in memory and the worst airline experience

commentHeader: it was the worst airport experience
reviewContent: My family have travelled regularly for years via Newark to Ireland and have come to expect a busy and crowded security area: hence we always allow adequate time for moving through the check in and security. On our last trip we had over 3 and half hours to get though security and I have to say it was the worst airport experience any of the family have endured at any airport. The new and improved system that is now in place at Newark consists of TSA staff yelling at travelers from the moment they join the security line. We were consisting yelled at to "keep moving" and "move on" despite the line moving as fast as anyone could. It was extremely stressful and totally unnecessary as there was no where to move on to any faster than we were already moving. It was nothing short of abusive and disrespectful. Getting through security in Newark was never pleasant but now the TSA are treating passengers nothing short of cattle to be herded. After 35 minutes of being screamed at my bag was selected for a search. This was no problem except the many staff that were supervising this section of security were extremely slow and uncommunicative. I stood for 20 minutes while the staff avoided all eye contact with the passengers and spoke only to each other. A passenger beside me who was in a wheel chair was visibly upset by the loss of her documents - which the staff appeared unconcerned with. Eventually someone checked my bag, rudely and without any civil communication with me. I can only assume that TSA training is now to treat passengers with distain as that was our experience from the start to the end of getting through Newark security. Occasionally a staff member would single out a lucky passenger who would be allowed to jump ahead in the line or have his bag prioritized in the inspection area. There may have been good cause for both these things to occur but in a system which already treats the passengers with contempt it seemed a random and arbitrary abuse of power. As it stands right now it is inefficient and there is an obvious disregard for passenger experience or wellbeing. When you finally get through security you will be rewarded by extortionate pricing for food and drinks. We all know that food in airports is expensive but Newark takes it to new heights! And forget it if you have a family and try to use the bazaar - it will takes forever and you will need a minimum of 2 adults and even this is still expensive. My advise is avoid Newark if at all possible - I am going to drive an extra hour next time right past Newark - just to avoid the horror! If I could give zero stars I would!

Newark is by far the worst airport I fly into or out of and I fly every week all across the country. The TSA for gates A, American Airlines is a joke - sometimes open, sometimes closed, sometimes I wait in line with everyone without pre check - total joke. And rude? I know why everyone around the country looks at Jersey in a negative light because Newark airport and its employees are the first expierience and impression of NJ. I could go on and on! If you can avoid Newark airport do it.

commentHeader: no one wants to offer help"
reviewContent: I have been a frequent flier for the past 17 years. I am from NJ so Newark is my best bet to travel to and from. It is really hard to find something good to write about this airport. Besides the fact that delays are the norm both in and out, the people working there are so miserable its depressing. No one smiles, no one wants to offer help. The TSA there are even rude. I think it all comes down to the leadership. If you look at any organization that gets horrible reviews you must start with the head of the snake. Newark needs to fire the head of the airport (both Port Autority and the Airport). They need to start over. Newark is an embarrassment to our Tri State area. Maybe someone will read this who has the ability to make change.

Terminal A is a nightmare compared to other airports of similar size. Not enough seating, services or space - and that's when flights are on time. Delayed flights - the terminal becomes purgatory! Staff are good - very helpful. The problem is management.

Not only was security really rude, but everything is confusing and signs lead to the wrong areas. We flew in after a long 5 hour flight, and went searching for some food to eat. If you want to pay 22.00 for a burger or 12.00 for a veggie wrap, 28.00 chicken, what? Do you think everyone who travels has money to just blow on mediocre food? This is appalling! There is one fast food option, Wendys, and it's in gate B, not A, or C, and if you want to get to any other gate, you have to walk out of security, take a bus to gate B and then go back through security just to get a Wendys burger? Also where's the water fountains where you can fill up your water bottles? Such a disgrace.

commentHeader: avoid this airport at all costs
reviewContent: I had the worst experience at Newark Airport. Going through security made me feel like a prisoner not a paying passenger - people working there were yelling the rules at you while you're in line for security, one airport staff dropped my bin with my whole bag and phone in it and all of my bag's contents fell on the floor, she then picked up my stuff from the floor and threw my shoes and purse onto the conveyor belt with all my stuff emptied out on the belt. When I said "please don't throw my bag" she looked at me, rolled her eyes and then yelled at the crowd "people hurry up and move forward!" Rude, uncaring, depressing people working at a poorly maintained airport that looks like it's experienced no updates or renovations since the '90's. Anyone traveling with older passengers who need more time through security should especially avoid this airport at all costs.

commentHeader: will avoid this airport in the future
reviewContent: I was connecting through Newark airport! They made me go through the full procedure as if I were staying in the US! I had to line up to show my passport and my ESTA, I had to wait for my suitcase, stay in line again to clear custom, then give back my suitcase. I had to stay in line a 4th time to go again through security! During all this process the staff were not helpful at all! I had to run from one place to the other asking people to let me pass in front of them! Ridiculous! I will avoid this airport in the future.

Arrived for the second time at Newark and this time, if was a great experience. Particularly arrival, was smooth and with friendly but professional treatment by customs etc. Departing was also quick (very nice that SAS has self-service at the terminal) and security went quick and efficient as well. The airport was pretty calm and not chaotic at all. The only two things I would like, was quicker boarding. The staff was so slow and it seemed very unorganized. And also, why does this airport not have free unlimited wifi? It is something almost everyone uses and something I really value when traveling. I don't understand why such a huge and international hub, do not offer this as a service. Upon arrival, we used the airtrain, which worked really well. My first time at Newark was fine, but this was a pleasent experience.

commentHeader: experience in EWR is a mixed bag
reviewContent: International experience in EWR is a mixed bag. Arrived via CX late evening. Immigration and customs were surprisingly quick and even friendly but the EWR staff directing arriving passengers to the appropriate queues were rude and even bordering on offensive. Perhaps someone should remind them that the passengers they were shouting at just endured a 16 hour flight from literally halfway around the world. Nevertheless, baggage claim, even for non priority passengers went pretty quick, so this was a 5-star arrival for me. Departing was another story. I could not imagine how US airports catering to internationally departing passengers have the gall to charge $6 for a cart when Asian airports (even the "worst" ones like MNL) offer it as a free service. Check in and TSA security was quick and even courteous, but beyond security for a midnight trans-pacific flight, there were no (not even little) dining, shopping nor lounging options outside of the gate seating. The bars and restaurants were closed and even the snack shop which offered dodgy cold selections closed 2 hours before the flight boarded. No wifi available meant a lot of bored passengers.

commentHeader: old and need a major update
reviewContent: The terminal buildings are old and need a major update. I have been to many airports in Asia and Western-Europe, but Newark is definitely not on the same level with those airports. On arrival, we were confronted with a long line of queues for the paspoort check. We queued for about 1.5 hours. The TSA agents did a good job guiding the queue and kept everyone "on the leash" during queuing. But the Homeland Security agents do not have a good work ethic. One of the agents just left his station to chit chat with another agent a few feet away from his post while there was a queue for his counter and "our agent" was just casually talking about hockey with another agent while handling our documents. The bagage claim area was overloaded with luggage from different flights. One luggage carousel handled more than two flights at the same time resulting in the luggage from the earlier fights being unloaded and put on the floor, all mixed up. On departure day, I found out that I had to pay $6 to use the luggage trolley! Never ever occurred to me that I had to pay for an airport trolley everywhere in the world. So I decided not to use them. Ground crew was not friendly at all, no smile and didn't even look me in the eye during check in. Beverages and foods were overpriced. A total of $13 for a glass of beer! No wifi available and very limited choice of restaurants. To sum it all up, Newark Liberty airport is just a horrible place to be. Bad service, overpriced foods and beverages (even for American standards), old buildings and probably way beyond its capacity.

We used Terminal C flying with United Airlines. I could not believe that I couldn't buy an alcoholic drink at any of the bar/food outlets with cash. You are required to use credit cards which I won't do when abroad. The staff were totally unhelpful. Our flight was announced as delayed from 7.35pm you 8.00 pm but we didn't start boarding until 8.40pm. No explanation whatsoever, the toilets were also a disgrace. I have always been under the impression that American service and hospitality is second to none. Don't believe a word of it. Do not use UA or Newark airport.

commentHeader: no dialogue between customer and staff
reviewContent: Terminal C, Self check-in was easy, there was the usual queue for passport control, but nothing too bad. My gate was C80, so I made my way down to the gate, and feeling hungry and I fancied a beer, so called in at one 'eatery' where I was welcomed and sat at a table with an iPad in front of me. A quick glance around told me that every table had a tablet - so I listened while I was told to scan my boarding card barcode and shown how my my name instantly popped up with flight details for all to see - especially as the waiter read my name out quite loudly (which I wasn't terrifically thrilled about in these days of identity theft). I quickly scanned through the menu, the food was astronomically highly priced for even the simplest dish, and beers likewise for ales I'd never heard of. So I fled the place, thinking I'd find a cheaper bar where I could pay by dollar notes, and discuss a choice of food and beers with a friendly barman. But alas, no. Some mastermind of planning had persuaded the airport chiefs of Newark to adopt a full tablet ordering system for every eat and drink outlet. Thirsty, I decided to call in at the Vesper Tavern. At least I recognised the beers on tap, and after my stomach had flipped a somersault at the prices, I decided that I needed a drink, fast. I scanned my barcode again, selected my beer from the menu (note, that the picture of each draft beer shows a full pint - or at least large looking glass of frothing beer), pressed the pay button, and as already mentioned by someone else, spotted the service charge was set at 18%. For what? I'd had no service so far! So I wound it down to 0%, and begrudgingly, I swiped my card (although I'd preferred to have paid in dollars), and waited for my beer to come. Along strolled the waiter with a wimpy looking glass of beer. It certainly wasnt the pint I'd seen pictured on the menu! I sat and observed others coming, and of their dismay at ordering expensive food and drink by tablet. My issue with this is that there's no dialogue between the customer and the staff. Little chance to discuss the food, how you would like the food cooked? Which option would they recommend from experience? Could I sample a beer that I'd never heard of? And if the service was good, then at the end, I'll leave a tip to reflect it - not to have an 18% surcharge lumped onto my bill for something that could have been delivered by a little train on a track, sushi style. I'd love to think that in a year or two I'll re-visit terminal C and all the tablets will have been strpped out and replaced once again by the happy chatter of conversion between customer and bar staff. But somehow, the investment made in this new technology will be made to work. Somehow.

Waiting for TSA is a joke. Unless you give yourself 2 hours you will miss your flight, nothing is organized and nobody understands customer service. I have missed my flight and everyone around me is antsy and nervous. Some others have missed theirs as well. I fly extremely often and I have never experienced a TSA as bad as this one.

A friend told me not to arrive too early at this airport and I wish I'd heeded his advice. I had no check-in luggage and whilst there was a single line queue for security which stretched someway down a narrow passageway, I still had plenty of time to kill. The terminal for American is like a step back in time to the 1970's. Old and worn. Food options are depressing and I had the most inedible breakfast I can ever remember. Depressing in the extreme.

A really unpleasant airport for a longer transit. Uncomfortable seating, no quiet areas to relax a little and a lot of construction work going on. But the most unpleasant thing was the restriction to only 30 minutes of free WiFi. That's almost like stone age and kind of frustrating.

Arrived last evening on United Airlines flight 1051 from Cancun, Mexico. Arrived at 7.35 pm. The information on monitors had incorrect information about what carousel your flight's luggage would be on. In fact all the flights coming in were put on one carousel (# 11) and the other carousels were empty. Even the announcement overhead was giving out incorrect information. There were virtually no personnel around to direct people coming in from all over the world and the signage was very poor. After passport check the chaos really began. The line for customs stretched around the entire baggage area with more and more people arriving it was impossible to know where to go. Again, there was no one supervising or directing people. There was no visible sign for global entry. People started to get desperate and cutting into lines, people were threatening each other and fistfights were imminent. There was no one to even ask what lines to get on. I had to use my cell phone to call Homeland Security to alert them to the increasingly dangerous situation. I will avoid this airport at all costs in the future. Worst airport experience I have ever had.

Arriving in Newark airport after a 6 hour flight on November 3rd, 2016 was the most humiliating experience of my life. I arrived on Icelandair flight FI623 at around 7:30. Hundreds of people lined up in long queues for passport check. Only One agent was available for the hordes of passengers. The wait was excruciating. Another agent showed up in his booth, 2nd to last from the right, but took about 30 minutes to get settled in, arranging his fan, walking around, looking up at us and smirking without any sense of urgency. It is obvious the people hired to do this job do not have great work ethics. Another agent came into his booth and left promptly to talk on his phone. By the way, many of the employees were sitting around texting on their phones so maybe you ought to make it a rule that texting or talking on the phone is not permitted during work hours. When departing from Iceland, we encountered a long line upon arrival to airport but we were processed so quickly and efficiently in under 10 minutes.  I will discourage people from using Newark airport from now on. It's an embarrassment the way they treat customers. This airport gives our country a very bad first impression to our first time visitors.

We landed just before 8 pm. There was very long queue in immigration but the staff were trying their best to ease out things. Unfortunately at such a busy time there were only two counters open for the non USA passport passengers. Overall it took around 45 minutes to clear immigration. Staff were polite and not overly friendly. Luggage came out by the time I reached the carousel. However its really unfair for passengers arriving from international flights to pay 6$ for a luggage trolley which should actually be free. We exited without any issues and took a yellow cab for the trek into busy Manhattan. Overall much better than JFK.

commentHeader: best avoided if at all possible
reviewContent: Newark Airport is best avoided if at all possible. The only reason I use it is that United Airlines flies to the destinations that I need. Security lines are long and the security people can get stressed and be can be abrupt. Recently all of the restaurants appear to have transitioned to a system where you order your food through an iPad situated on your table. Throughout your meal you are bombarded with screens trying to entice you to buy something or other. Service and food quality is mediocre and food prices are extremely high. The best advice I could give to travellers would be:- 1) For international travellers arriving at Newark allow plenty of time if you have a connecting flight as you have to reclaim and recheck your baggage and the time it takes to get through immigration, customs and security can be very long. I usually allow three hours. Try to fly direct and avoid connection at Newark if possible. 2) Join the United Airlines club so you will have somewhere to get out of the noisy and busy terminal and you can get a snack so you can avoid using the expensive restaurants.

My wife and I flew out of Newark Terminal C Friday and back Sunday. We had no problems. Plenty of seats at the gate with lots of places to plug your phone or laptop in to charge. One thing I noticed, the cheap eat options at EWR are gone and replaced with expensive options. So if your trying to be savvy about spending eat before you go into security. Security was pleasant too and the staff were friendly. One thing terminal C is in bad need of is moving walkways. As when we landed back we arrived at gate C98 which a very long walk with no moving walkways. EWR is still the best airport in the NYC/NJ area.

Newark Terminal C is mass chaos, complete breakdown of any sort of organization, absolute pandemonium. This morning, the line for the security stretched from one end of the terminal to the other. There were numerous kiosks to check in but the lines were not organized and completely jumbled. And now they have you putting your own bag tag onto your bag - like that is going to save any time whatsoever. If they say be here 3 hours ahead, even for a quick flight to say, Atlanta, be here 3 hours ahead or else you will miss your flight. Guaranteed. Terminal C is absolutely the worst terminal I have ever been in. And I won't even begin to tell you about trying to drive up to the terminal just to be dropped off. I'm sure you can imagine the nightmare. Atlanta may be the busiest in the US but Newark terminal C needs a complete overhaul.

I arrived at Newark Airport for transit to a domestic flight to Memphis. General view of this airport is that it is old, worn and cramped. Also it was not as clean, as I am used to. It was also poor air conditioning and it was warm. It took quite a lot of time to get from the international terminal via the immigration control and get to the United Airlines domestic terminal. The immigration control was correct, polite and efficient, and can be regarded as a better part of this airport. The seats were simple and not so comfortable. They offer some dining but it was not at standards as I am used to. It was expensive there too. The restrooms was not clean and non-functional. I was indeed happy when I left this airport, sad but true. One of the worst so far in my view. I will avoid it if possible.

Newark is the opposite of a user-friendly airport. Pull up to curbside and there's no one at the check-in area. Once inside and checked in, everyone, including TSA pre-selects, stands in the same single file line. They have only one security screening machine. Give yourself plenty of time. The bathrooms in Concourse A number 1 per gender. Get ready to stand in line if you're of the female gender. Oh yeah, and the air dryer doesn't work nor were there any paper towels to dry off your hands. As for collecting luggage upon arrival, I thought the workers were on strike because it took so long. Not a great experience.

I am handicapped, can't walk long distances. For at Newark Airport I ordered a wheechair which made my travels so much easier. The friendly person waited for us as we deboarded. There was no problem when my students were following us. This guy took us to a special exit, we were through immigraton and customs in no time. 60 minutes after deboarding we were already in our hotel. That was a pleasant experience for our little group of 6 people.

commentHeader: more traffic than it can handle
TSA needs to get their act together
said we were holding people up
No food. No retail. No newsstand
real decline in the past two years
modern and airy, but I'm unimpressed
managed to get on the plane
more employee surliness and filthy restrooms
only time I ever have any issues
I will avoid Newark at all costs
terminal itself once there was poor
A very easy airport to use
reviewContent: The passenger terminal in Fargo has limited but all the essential services. I used it for arriving and departing to hub cities for onward connections. Taxi drivers were near the baggage belts, soliciting fares. On departure, you check in on the main floor and take escalators one flight up. To your left is a large enough gift shop with the usual items plus North Dakota State University memorabilia. On the right is a food court with a few eateries, including a Subway. The security check was smooth. Once on the airside, there is a coffee shop and a kiosk of a shop - a miniatiure version of the gift shop on the other side. There are quite a few chairs and signage is good. A very easy airport to use and quick to get out of and quick to get in.

I have grown to hate this airport. First and foremost, when folks are stuck here for hours on end waiting for their connecting flight or rushing to make their connection, the LAST thing we want to hear are your obnoxious and loud recorded messages about everything there is to do in Florida.  God forbid you try to focus on something else or get some semblance of peace because FLL airport will ensure it does not happen. Are you sitting at gate G2 waiting to board a flight? You, too, will hear messages about why you shouldn't park your car in the unloading area! You will not get peace in this airport and must deal with rude airport employees. Very disappointing.

commentHeader: the worst airport I’ve been in
reviewContent: This was the worst airport I’ve been in. We got there 5 hours before our flight so could not check our baggage yet. No seating in this area so we had to sit on the floor - I’m 81 years old so this was quite uncomfortable. When i was able to check luggage in the man was very rude. Told me I should have gotten my luggage tag. i thought that’s what he was supposed to do.

This was my 2nd flight to FLL in 4 months after a 11 year absence. This review is limited to Terminal 1. Arrival was at the A Concourse gates 1-5 which mean a rather long connectors to the B/C concourses common area. One huge advantage of FLL airport over the others is the car rental facility which is directly across the airport roadway from the terminal. The renovated terminal 1 is spacious, brightly lit, and has a central TSA Entry point for all 3 concourses. Each concourse offers dining options a plenty. For Christmas Day travel, there was enough seating for all with power ports and USB ports at each gate. The bathrooms are very clean and maintained at regular intervals. Security was a breeze with no wait time for the TSA-Pre checkpoints. WiFi was easy to connect too and blazing fast. The refurbished Terminal 1 is a joy to travel through

commentHeader: does not have a single chair"
reviewContent: Terminal 4 does not have a single chair to sit on. People sit and lie down on the floor, giving the terminal the aspect of a refugee camp. Not acceptable for a large international airport.

commentHeader: “airport attendants did not care at all”
reviewContent: Our flight arrived on time, but the airport was unable to receive the plane. We had sit again and wait in the plane. Then, they told us that they had no resources to unload the baggages from the plane and we had to wait another hour. Finally, there are way more travelers than what the customs could manage and we had to wait in the side and then we were moved to the line. Because of that we lost our connecting flight. We had 3 hours between arrival and departure which is normally more than enough for a so small airport. The airport is accepting much more flight than they can manage and the customers are who suffer only. The airport attendants did not care at all. In consequence we had to stay the night at the airport outside the security area with nothing to eat and no where comfortable where to seat. They were not willing to lay anything because they said it was a “uncontrollable” situation. We booked the flight a month ago so they knew how many flights were arriving, it was not an uncontrollable surprise. If I can control it I’ll never fly through Fort Lauderdale airport again.

It's been 11 years since I traveled through Terminal 1. The refurbished Terminal 1 is a world class modern airport terminal. It is spacious, brightly lit with plenty of seating and dining options aplenty. There are oodles of power ports and USB ports at the gates; however, some of the power ports were not working. Bathrooms are very clean. The concourses are wide and directions easy to follow to baggage claim. Security was a breeze with no wait time for the TSA-Pre checkpoints. WiFi was easy to connect too and blazing fast. The refurbished terminal is a significant upgrade to the old terminal 1.

What a Zoo! For Jet Blue, Terminal 3, it was a 2 minute wait for a kiosk for checked bag. 45 minute wait to drop bag. Then, TSA pre-check and regular are in the same line for F Concourse! And regular line is backed up to easily before where you enter TSA Pre-Check. No waiting at TSA Pre-check line! Terminal 3. TSA has the entrance to TSA Precheck blocked off so that you have to wait in the regular line for 10 minutes before you can get to clear or TSA Precheck entrance.

commentHeader: closed for the past two days"
reviewContent: Avoid Ft Lauderdale Airport like the plague. I would give this airport negative 5 stars. I had a flight out of Ft Lauderdale today to Cancun to celebrate my 50th birthday with a large group of close friends in Tulum. It’s been raining in all of south Florida for past three days, and due to this, Ft. Lauderdale Airport has closed for the past two days including today. I can understand weather being a major issue resulting in airport closures, but somehow Ft Lauderdale airport is the only airport that has closed. They are currently close and ironically it’s been sunny all day. All of my friends were able to fly out of Miami International Airport which is a 30 minute drive to the south and somehow Miami International did not close at all. And Miami is extremely prone to flooding as it’s lower than Ft. Lauderdale. West Palm Beach airport which is just to the north did not close either. So needless to say, all of my friends are celebrating my 50th in Tulum without me because the airport will not open till tomorrow with the airline not being able to book me another flight for next three days. Worst part is as we are all sitting in the airport waiting for some news, airport staff had no idea what was going on or when they would reopen. I will never fly out of there, heaven forbid it rains a little again and the airport is shut down for a week. What did Miami and West Palm Beach airports figure out what to do that Ft. Lauderdale couldn’t.

Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport (FLL) is a total shambles. Unbelievable waiting times to park the plane, to access the luggage area and another two hours for customs and immigration. It really is a disgrace to treat visitors like this. I travel a lot globally and this is much  worse than countries the US really does not want to be compared to. In Houston two weeks ago this thing ran extremely smoothly.

commentHeader: missing connecting flights due to flight delays
reviewContent: My first plane landed 45 late. They did not open door for another 10 min saying other planes are waiting. Then we were supposed to go through customs, but the guy letting people into customs area was not allowing anyone except those with global entry to go through customs. I showed him my next boarding pass and told him I am boarding now. He said there is not room for me and held me for 20 min standing before allowing to enter customs area. But he allowed those with global entry to enter. How come there is space for them but not for those who are missing connecting flights due to flight delays? This was very very rude. I missed a flight of course and had to spend a night in a cold hotel. I lost desire to fly with American Airlines. What is going on at the airports in USA is totally unacceptable.

commentHeader: This is really disrespectful and unfair
reviewContent: Every time I use the Southwest terminal I find a couple of flights arriving, so hundreds of passengers waiting to go through the Custom's process and there are always two or three agents but no more. This is really disrespectful and unfair after traveling.

commentHeader: TSA agents are rude, unprofessional and this entire process is ridiculous
reviewContent: Absolute worst for layovers for international traveling. Our flight arrived 20 min early, only to have to wait for 25 minutes on the plane due to customs not being ready for us. The flight attendant said on intercom if you are changing flights to put the liquor you just bought into your checked luggage, because the TSA agents like to drink. I thought she was joking. Well when we finally got off the flight, we were held in a hallway for 40 minutes until we were allowed to go claim our luggage to take through customs. (Which took 90 min) After that, you have to check your luggage back in. I asked if we should put the liquor we just got from DR in the luggage and was told no, not if it’s sealed. Then we get to security and we’re told we can’t keep the liquor. I tell them to call down to the people we checked luggage in because we asked. First man says let it through. Second guy scans it and tells us either we surrender it, or let him re test it in a machine, but if it fails, my husband and all our belongings will be taken to another room for a recheck and a full body pat down. I think the flight attendant was trying to warn people. That they take your liquor here for their own use. 2 hours later, still trying to get our flight.
