We arrived on a surprisingly sparsely populated flight from London, a ten hour flight on which we were able to lie across three seats each - we thought we were lucky! (In retrospect, it seems other travellers have, perhaps, learned the lesson from experiencing what we were were just about to endure - and they found alternative routes). Plodding the long route to ‘Immigration’ brought us to a large hall where we were confronted with, probably, 20 modern, state-of-the-art, passport-reading, data-collection machines. It is apparent from 95% of all the passengers being directed to the snake-queue (with a cross on the machines’ print-outs) illustrate that these state-of-the-art machine were as much use as a chocolate tea pot! I estimate that there were 300 passengers in the queue (line) for immigration and only two of the immigration desks were open. 2 hours later we emerged from this inefficient, utterly farcical process, to rush on to Baggage Reclaim to retrieve our luggage for onward travel. All the carousels were stopped, little in the way of a clue which group of off-loaded bags might contain ours. 10 more minutes wasted. With just less than an hour left we rushed off to check-in our bags. Scanning the labels affixed in London we were then told that our flight to Pensacola (21:30) was ‘delayed’ until the next morning. (This is not any definition of delay with which I have been previously aware: the flight was cancelled, cynically categorise as ‘delayed’, without any regard for the inconvenience to us, United Airlines customers, or for those who were travelling to meet us.) As with others’ reviews, finding a member of staff to provide any help, reassurance or information was nigh on impossible as we passed through to this point. The staff directing us just were’t interested in our concerns at the speed of the queue/processing: indeed they said that we should complain to the immigration officer - see how we got on! We did: it’s all because of the reallocation of staff to the Mexican border, we were told. Seems to me that the technology employed to replace the immigration officers is unfit for purpose, the immigration management team are not fit for purpose. Please don’t think that this inconvenient, inconsiderate, inept system is only foisted on aliens (from outside the US) there were US citizens with us in this queue as a result of the ineffective, technologically defective equipment. In conclusion, reviews on this website of the Houston Airport’s customers seem to indicate that our flight was only 30% populated because those in the know have found another airline/hub airport to use in preference to this shambolic shower. It is fair to point out that after queuing for another 40 minutes, we spent a further 40 minutes being processed - we were provided accommodation at the local Holiday Inn and food vouchers - and a flight ticket to continue our journey the next morning. Interestingly, our onward flight was completely full - accommodating passengers who’s earlier flight had been cancelled. After this trip, we will not fly by United Airlines to George Bush Airport again. George Bush Airport management need to recognise and address these problems before they lose their rest of their passengers to others.

This is truly the worst connection airport ever. We had 1h25 minutes for our connecting flight to Frankfurt, but after 4! security checks we had to run to make it to our flight, if we were 1 minute later we would have missed our plane. Why isn’t there a separate queue for connections? We had a digital and manual passport control, a security dog check and when we thought that was it, we had to go through the scanner again! Already twice at our departure airport. We weren’t even entering the USA, but still had to go through this? I understand that security is important these days, but this was really ridiculous. Including rude security officers.

I had to send my Mom on a Qatar Airways flight alone, it was a very difficult time for me, but the Houston Airport staff at all levels made this process as smooth as they could. I greatly appreciate their hard work and consideration.

commentHeader: signage at this airport could be much clearer
reviewContent: The signage at this airport could be much clearer, they need to let someone with an advertising background revise them. The customs line was an hour and 45 minutes, then security was another 18 minutes and of course, after all that, we missed our plane and had to deal with totally unconcerned Spirit agents, but that's for another review. TSA agents here are surly and unhelpful if asked a question, when we were rushing to our (already departed) plane after waiting what felt like an interminable time in customs, my daughter asked an agent a question about the location of a terminal, and, I kid you not, we had to wait a few seconds so he could finish softly singing his song before he reluctantly turned his inept attention to us. The tram was so slow it felt like a children's train Cedar Point. Avoid this airport if you can.

We were on our way home to UK from Cancun via Houston . Our flight was delayed by United Airlines due to storm in Houston. Fare enough. Instead of 3.5 hours we had about 1,5 hours, landing about 2 pm local time at HIA. We had 1 hour and a half to catch our flight to London scheduled for 16:25. Going through the whole process of passport checks, security checks and customs we realized that we have very limited time and started to worry. As we approached the last hurdle the baggage check we were told to go to a certain queue obviously for other people like us catching other flights. My friend was also doing it on the next line. I noticed they searched his bottles of Tequila that we both bought in Cancun. They were properly sealed and put back in the boxes and we were assured that this is ok to travell via Houston. I went to ask what is going on and asked kindly what is going on and that we are running late for our flight. One of the girls working as security replied to me -What is it got to do with me! At that point i thought that this was appalling to get answer like this but as we had very little time to get to the gate i decided not to get involved anymore. I few minutes later to my horror i realized that i have forgotten the bag with my two bottles. Immediately returned back and asked for it. An officer has given them back to me but they started checking them one by one the slowest possible way. In the meantime they confiscated on of the bottles from my mate although they wanted to take the other one as well. While i was waiting nervously for it to happen rep of United airlines looked at the screen and said my flight was now gone and i have no chance of getting on the plane. I desperately tried to call my wife who was at the gate but could not get through. Eventually a got my bottles and looked at the screen hoping for delay but there was nothing to confirm it. I had to run to gate E5 with my 13 old son and when we got finally there, there was a huge queue and people were still getting on board. Obviously the flight was delayed but nobody advised us on that and it was not shown on the screens. I cannot believe how unhelpful and rude were some of the people from security department and United Airlines. They kept repeating we are going to miss the flight and did not help us whatsoever. It was the opposite. They were rude and sarcastic.

This is a very unprofessional group of TSA agents. I know the job can be stressful and I do not think the customer is always right but these individuals do not seem to understand common courtesy. Excuse me, please, and thank you go much further than poor attitudes and bad tempers. This is the worst group I have encountered in my global travels. I hope that this gets fixed and does not become a representation of IAH.

commentHeader: would avoid this airport if possible
reviewContent: If you are a visitor to the USA please don’t judge us by the unhelpful, unhappy people who work here. We have TSA and got three different half uttered, 0 eye contact answers about where the TSA was and if it was open or not. In the end they didn’t honor our TSA and performed a thourough search. There is no art or any small attempt to look anything but industrial. The food and drink is wildly expensive even by airport standards. The iPads everywhere are nice but otherwise I would avoid this airport if possible.

I have been to nearly 40 to 50 airports and have to say that Houston airport is the worst one I’ve been to in my life. First of all, the connecting international flight after a 15 hour flight from Australia was scheduled only 90 minutes apart. Which means we only had 90 minutes to 1) Go through customs. 2) Go through TSA screening. 3) Retrieve all of our checked in luggage and take it on a 20 minute walk across the airport and send it through the scanner. 4) Go through security Again with our carry ons. 5) And finally get to our gate which was another 20 minutes away. We had 2 little kids with us and every time we asked the security staff to let us cut the lines because we will miss our connecting flight. The answer was the same: we will make sure we get you to your gate on time. Well. Guess what happened? We missed our flight. We were stuck at this horrible airport for an additional 6 hours because appearently United Airlines closed their gates 10 minutes prior to departure even though they’re missing passengers and the security staff kept telling us to not pay any attention to the boarding time but the departure time is what we should aim for. Completely dumb and uninformed. At this point the gave us the boarding passes for our next flight which was on the other side of the airport. And we had to walk to the customer service to get those boarding passes which was at the other end of the terminal we were at. The worst thing was that the gate was changed one hour prior to boarding to a completely different terminal. We had to walk for another 25 minutes carrying our kids who at this point had not had any sleep in 30 hours and every time we asked an employee with a cart (people mover) to help take us to the gate, they kept coming up with some excuse to not take us by what seemed out of complete lazyness. I found 2 carts parked and attempted to drive one myself but it had a pad with a code on it to start it. So. Back to the walking we went. Rest areas are non existent. Terminal seating is horrible and you can’t find any family oriented restaurants in terminal C, D or E. It’s all a bunch of bars and snack shops.

Houston Bush is truly an ok airport if you are traveling domestically, as I have in the past. The terminal is clean, well lit, and modern. You start to realize why you should avoid this airport at all costs if you travel through customs. Got global entry? They didn’t staff the kiosks, back of the line. Got mobile passport? That line feeds in to the regular line overflowing with people. Once you get past the customs line do you realize you have to then wait in the three times as long TSA line. Got pre? They don’t have a preline. I gave myself a three hour connection in Houston and still missed my connecting flight. What a disaster.

I have decided to stop using United because they route me through Houston. The last two years I have traveled through Houston to a destination in Mexico. Both times it has been a nightmare. Departing wasn't so bad, except that I couldn't find a functioning water fountain even though I walked up and down two concourses looking for one. When I asked I was sent to one that was out of order. It is returning from Mexico that is horrendous. Even though we have Global Entry and TSA Pre, we invariably are sent on a wild goose chase (the employees don't seem to know that TSA Pre in Houston is closed and they always sent us to a different building so we can go through TSA Pre). We end up running like mad, trying to grab a sandwich and still making it to the gate in time to board. I suspect the TSA worker at Houston are some of the unhappiest. I would be too, working in such a poorly managed environment.

I fly quite a bit. But haven't experienced an airport with such poor signage. You can watch it everywhere. People stopping in their tracks and looking around for some sort of instructions to get to their gate. There also should be an advisory informing walking time as opposed to taking transportation. Signage to subway is poor, never saw any. Very few workers to ask. If possible, I'll avoid IAH like the plague.

I wanted to complement the staff in the security line on the morning of January 6th. Despite it being the early morning shift, in which you encounter groggy and stiff personalities, I wanted to say that they were very friendly and polite. They greeted me with a smile and kept the line going smoothly. Also to note, my husband was wearing his San Francisco government badge and they let him pass through without being scanned. Because they did that though, he accidentally left his garment bag in the conveyor belt. Luckily I heard them announce it on the intercom. It was a a very pleasant experience and I hope to fly through again.

Houston International Terminal C has the most uncomfortable waiting area I have ever experienced. Tables with iPads and charging stations everywhere. Chairs bolt to the ground. What normal seat that is available is limited to one row per cate. The club music from the bar floods the terminal. One review says this terminal is “Sexy”. Yes that may be a good thing for a night out clubbing but not waiting for an international flight. Thankfully I didn’t have a delay or long layover.

commentHeader: Stuck trying to get to gate
reviewContent: Stuck trying to get to gate for 2 hours on airport tarmac. Seen other flights moving in and out, but my Spirit flight was halted, supposed to have been at gate at 10:45 didn’t arrive til 12:45, don’t know if I will have a room anymore at my hotel because of the delay. There weren’t weather issues if other planes were departing, so what was the issue?

commentHeader: no food or drink for over 8hrs!
reviewContent: My flight was delayed for over 8hrs. All I had on me was cash. Nothing in the whole place would take my money. I was stuck with no food or drink for over 8hrs! They wouldn't let me go outside to smoke. If I did I wouldn't be able to get back in til morning! So I'm stuck, can't eat, can't smoke. Customer service said there was nothing they could do for me. They were rude and acted like I was a pain to them! Never ever fly into Houston IAH! If your flight is delayed you will be trapped! Customer service is a joke! Why haven't any of these issues been solved yet.

commentHeader: give this airport a big zero
reviewContent: The iPads are a great idea, but why can’t you just make an order with the bartender when they aren’t busy? Why so much emphasis on zero human interaction? I give this airport a big zero because I’d always rather be at home but especially when I have a long layover in Houston.

Landed at this airport on 11/04/18 via United Airlines. This airport is entirely too big to function effectively. The gates are to far apart, so do some inquires before hand to see which gate you land at and which one you will depart. As for me, I was asked to go to gate C from gate A. Quite a journey due to my heart surgery. There was absolutely no one to help me go from gate to gate, even though they had numerous empty golf type carts. An IAH employee called 3 separate times for a pick up for me but no one ever showed up. This airport is more concerned with the shops/restaurants than with passenger safety. I am a true Texan at heart but this airport needs functionality instead of being a big broken Texas mess. I will not be traveling through this airport ever again. You have officially lost my trust.

commentHeader: only one TSA agent verifying tickets
reviewContent: I have never had issues with this airport. I have flown in and out of Bush for years now. I had a flight that departed IAH at 5.15am on Saturday morning. I arrived at the airport early, as I always do, just in case something unexpected happens. I guess I should've given myself four hours because the line to get into security was around 200 people deep with only one TSA agent verifying tickets and identifications. I waited in that line forever. Then, my flight was scheduled to leave in 10 minutes. I knew I wasn't going to make it because there wasn't enough staff to accommodate the growing number of passengers entering the security line. There was another TSA agent, but he was just sitting there helping the small line of TSA-Pre Check. When there wasn't anyone in the Pre-Check line, he just sat there in his chair and didn't even bother helping the growing line. Once I got up to the TSA agent, she met me with anger. She was rude and didn't even communicate to me with words! She just motioned me to move to the side without any explanation. I had to wait another 10 minutes, and by that time, my flight had already left the gate. I am very dissatisfied with my experience. Why was there only one TSA agent? I'd probably be rude to customers too if I was the only one working that terminal with a line of 200 people and growing. If you're going to the airport, just remember to be there maybe about six hours before your flight, because you never know how short staffed they will be on any given day.

Worst for comfort, assistance to gates, signs for direction, and distance to change planes. Computer seating is very uncomfortable to wait at for flights. Not many comfortable seats for layovers. Walk, walk, walk, and have to stop people to ask diresctions. Poor signs.

The installation of new security check machinery has been let down by a complete lack of organisation of the personnel. I witnessed three individuals wait in excess of 15 minutes for an opt out search due to no communication. Bags that were pulled required a 25 minute wait until a team member could perform a search due to an absence of “appropriate” staff. A request to expedite the process (I nearly missed my flight) was met with aggression as opposed to an explanation. Fair to say that the investment of personnel has not been matched with employee training.

My experience at IAH mirrors the other negative reviews posted. I was returning from a vacation in Mexico with my teenage daughters and almost missed my flight due to the slowest TSA operation I have ever encountered. Customs was efficient and a simple process but not security to get on my connecting flight to VA. I figured it being spring break would add to congestion but when other passengers are panicked about missing flights because lines aren’t moving then it is truly Houston we have a problem. My sister traveled on a different fight and missed her connection due to the hold up. Agents were predictably rude, unhelpful, and uncommunicative. I actually had an agent push her finger into my stomach and asked why I still had a belt on and told me to lift my shirt up high. Guess what, no belt, just a muffin top. The airport looks nice as we raced around trying to get to our gate-would have enjoyed being able to eat at one of the restaurants.

Worst airport experience ever. TSA took their time as if we had nowhere to go. Even shut the lane down for 10 minutes when they only had one lane open in the first place. Our group missed our flights and had to instead drive to ATL from Houston (terrible experience with Spirit Airlines customer service as well). Will never fly into this airport again.

The immigration queues are the most horrendous I have come across. I had 1.5 hours between flights and thought this would be enough, but no. There appeared to be only 3 desks open and 2 large aircraft landed at the same time, so the queues were very long and no staff around to speak to. When I finally arrived at the kiosk, the lady asked me why I didn't tell someone that I had a flight to catch! IAH need to employ more people! It is a ridiculous system in the US where you actually have to collect your bag then check it in AGAIN for onward travel. This is the only country where you have to do this. Every other country you can check your bag all the way through to your final destination. For a first impression of the US, IAH has sorely disappointed and unfortunately this is the airport I have to travel through every time as I now live in Houston.

commentHeader: some of the rudest I’ve encountered"
reviewContent: Absolute worst customer service I’ve ever experienced in an airport. I travel to Houston often and am so very disappointed in what they’ve allowed their airport to become. Check in was a completely disorganized mess and the airport employees are some of the rudest I’ve encountered. I felt like I was in New York, not Texas. Houston should be ashamed. I will definitely try to avoid this airport at all costs in the future.

Horrible experience all around at this airport. Every security employee berated each passenger as they went through security, even using curse words and muttering under their breath about how stupid we all were because we did not know the proper security procedures, which at times were different than other airports (for example we did not need to take off shoes, and were yelled at for doing so). On top of all this they lost my luggage!

This must be the worst airport in US! We are on a transit flight and we needed more than an hour for immigration check! Lanes were labeled open, then they closed, and people standing there had to go back like us. We pick up the luggage for transit, and have to scan again and wait in line for another hour! This is unbearable after an 11 hour flight! No service, people unfriendly, and some women from United are screaming at the passengers! I know we cannot do anything about it, but more people have to report to make changes. I cannot recommend a transit via Houston!

Southwest terminal has no accessible charging stations! It is 2017! How the heck is there only one charging station at a gate and it's on 1 old school power strip. Only 6 people can charge their phones when there are over 80 seats available. We live in a time where we are dependent on our phones and you can't make the charging stations more available. You should be ashamed of yourself.

Very good airport, it has a good choice of shops but the airport is quite big so I'd recommend to only do shopping around the gate. The staff there are polite. However the parking lot might be quite dirty and the airport is usually crowded. You usually can find what you want or need at the stores or the supermarket.

A few months ago I've heard of a brand-spanking new high-tech Terminal C North was constructed at Houston and I was very pleased that my flight was there. This was the terminal of the future. The design was very modern and clean. Blue LED mood lighting filled up the whole terminal much like the one in the 787 Dreamliner. The terminal is huge with very high ceilings. The restrooms were like I was in a five-star hotel - very modern and clean and big. There was a nice selection of food and beverages to choose from. The restaurants were not your typical Mcdonalds (no McDonalds at IAH anymore though) or Subway restaurants rather they were the specialty, high-quality local restaurants that made it all the more special. There was also a decent amount of shops to choose from though I felt there too many selling the same things: souveniers, neck pillows, and magazines. What really got the kick out of my Terminal C North experience was the seating. They were not your typical airport seats rather they were leather and very cushioned armchairs and in front of you a table with charging ports and an iPad. Yes, an iPad in every seat! You can do countless things with the tablet to get you occupied such as games, access to the Internet browser, shopping, magazines and you can order food and drinks from it! Very cool and hip experience at Terminal C North and I can't wait to be there again!

Layover to and from a family vacation in Roatan. On arrival was 15 mins too late for shuttle trains between terminals. I had several hours between flights so I walked between Terminal A and E only to discover security and United counter were long-past closed so I couldn't check bag or get to more secure part of the Airport. On my return flight I arrived earlier in evening. Was told I couldn't check my bag until it was within 12 hours of my flight. Went back at the appointed time - original info was incorrect and again I'm outside the secure area - only another 6.5 hours to go. Nothing to do but wait - not paying $300 for a room. I have books and puzzles but even Starbucks is now closed. Place is bright and clean enough but there is not even anywhere to plug in my phone.

Before transitting via Houston from an international airline to United Airlines I read the reviews on this site. The reviews had me very concerned about that 2 hours we had for transit from Terminal D (internationl) to B (domestic). My husband also required a wheelchair and this only added to my concerns and yet, we were very pleasantly surprised by the help and friendliness of the American staff. We received help from the airport staff who assist passengers with needs such as with the wheelchair (but you must book the wheelchair or other assistance with your airline). We did not experience the long queues at customs and they were not rude. Note. We landed and departed at off peak times - ie midday and 8pm. The airport is very modern but there is a 1.5-mile (2.4 km) distance from Terminal A to Terminal D.and so you definitely need to take the upstairs Skytrain between terminals. There are some curvy corridors when navigating from arrival lounges, shops and the Skytrain but there are plenty of signs that point the way towards the Skytrain and other terminals. Note. For international to domestic transits you really need to allow 3 hours in case of queues and flight delays but it can be done within 2 hours if you are organised and only have carry on luggage and study the online airport maps to get an idea of where the Skytrain is located. Plus, the local USA airlines tend to stop passengers on to the domestic flights if is within 30 minutes of the plane leaving.

Customs was the worst we have ever dealt with. The waiting lines were more than 2.5  hours long. The staff was rude and kept moving us from line to line only to get put back in another line. There were dozens of people around me that missed their flights for the lack of help with customs. Out of all the times and places I have traveled I have never felt so frustrated. No one was helpful and they were certainly were not in a hurry. This airport has been the worst one of my life!

commentHeader: an airport to best be avoided
reviewContent: An airport to best be avoided. If you do use it for transit, be sure to talk with the crew of the incoming flight. They may be able to help speed things up. Otherwise it seems you need to allow at least three hours transit time. There is no transit area, so you must clear immigration. There is an automated system, but it rejects most people and you go into another queue for manual processing. When I was there, there were 3 immigration counters operating. It took about two hours with no possibility of sitting, eating, or going to the toilet. Staff were uncommunicative and only sometimes apologetic. Once out of immigration you must collect your bags and find where to drop them again. It seems easier if you are travelling United or Star Alliance. It's a longish walk to the departure part of Terminal D. After leaving your bags, you must go through security to get to the departure gate. It is extremely thorough. Because I missed my connection and was coming next day the line was short. There are no signs about the rules, but they include: Remove everything from pockets, remove laptop from bag, empty water bottle, remove shoes and belt. You get scanned in a machine, wiped with explosive test, then patted down. I forgot to empty my water bottle. If I wanted to keep the bottle, the only choice was to exit and repeat the whole process. Did so as I had time and no queue. Everything was repeated including patting down. In the gate area there is good fast free wifi. Lesson: travelling from NZ to Europe, go via Asia.

commentHeader: I'm done with this poor excuse of an airport
reviewContent: I'm done with this poor excuse of an airport. I fly internationally every month and will assiduously avoid IAH when coming in from Latin American cities. DFW is a much better alternative - international transfer security Pre-Check availability and TSA agents that don't treat you like garbage. IAH is also a dirty airport in general. You can tell when an organization has pride. At IAH, you can smell indifference the minute you get off the plane.

By far the rudest TSA I have ever experienced. I went through terminal A at Houston IAH. The employees were continually yelling at us as if we were incompetent. They were not helpful to anyone. Instead they made snotty remarks and gave so much attitude to passengers. I can usually tolerate rudeness but it was all I could do to not say something back. I'm sure their job isn't easy or fun but they could at least have some humanity.

commentHeader: travel through different airports to avoid unnecessary stress
reviewContent: The worst airport with the rudest staff. I travel all the time and I have never met ruder people in my life, they seem extremely unhappy working there. They are yelling at people like we were going through military training. We were traveling on our honeymoon, coming from London, through Houston to Costa Rica. It was such a bad system, we had to go through customs, wait in line forever, why? I have no idea when we were in transit just trying to get to Costa Rica with no intention of staying in Houston. On the top of this, they had two hours to transfer our luggage and they failed to do so. They lost them! I will avoid this badly organized airport in the future for sure. I suggest you travel through different airports to avoid unnecessary stress.

We have been through Houston IAH airport 6 times now. We wish there were other options. Once again the arrivals hall and immigration was full of hundreds of people. About 5 lines were open. It took over an hour to get to the immigration official. Then we were in another long line, about 40 minutes waiting for security screening to re-enter the terminal and go to our gate. We were lucky with a long layover and bags checked through but poor folks with tight connections and baggage that had to go through customs were really hooped. People using this airport for international travel need to be aware that one hour connecting time doesn't even come close to what is needed.

Nice arrival & departure - on time both ways. But please do something about the restaurants. I am Vegan as are many of your visitors. Nothing at your airport is Vegan nor Vegan-friendly. Please note that even small airports and international ones like Cancun have Vegan-friendly options at their restaurants. Do know that the entire world is not "grits and gravy; ribs and chitlins; as is assumed in your airport. A salad of lettuce-only is not sufficient. How about some other options! Even chain restaurants offer Vegan-friendly. Do better; be inclusive.

commentHeader: clean, but not helpful or friendly
reviewContent: Upon arrival, I was: treated in a condescending manner at security because I did not understand the precheck system even though I had already purchased it, ignored when I had questions at the gate to clarify I was in the correct place, workers on their phones instead of acknowledging passengers, I felt like I was an inconvenience. I have never been treated in this way at any other airport. My experience occurred in terminal B, United airlines. The airport was clean, but not helpful or friendly.

Horrible long immigration pass at Houston IAH. Despite having ESTA kiosks you still have to line up in ordinary lines. Transferred through Chicago 5-6 years ago and zero waiting. The most backward process I ever experienced. Same with customs. This airport is operated as it was a 2 gate domestic airport. Of course lost my connection flight. I have been transferring through IAH at least 50 times and it is only getting worse.

commentHeader: customs and immigration line over 2 hours
2.5 hours connecting, I barely made it
had to run for the plane
this airport is huge and chaotic
avoid for international arrivals if possible
2 hours transit might not be enough
Ample seating in the gate areas
reviewContent: Vast upgrade from the previous terminal. Far more space at check-in counters, baggage claim, and security. Baggage service is efficient. Ample seating in the gate areas. But there are few food options, especially if you are on the concourse after 5 p.m.

I fly in and out of here regularly, and am very impressed. For a small airport, TSA is efficient and does not do a lot of unnecessary screening just to have something to do as at other small airports. The gate crews work very hard to get you out on-time, and luggage retrieval is easy. Rental car offices are next to baggage claim, and other than Budget, are extremely helpful. There is a coffee shop upstairs, as well as a bar/restaurant; everyone is friendly here and pricing is reasonable. Two minutes from I-15. The place seems pleasantly ignorant of airport hassles that have descended upon much of the industry.

Nice looking airport with lots of great vendors but TSA security check is a nightmare. TSA PreCheck only available on the A terminal side. Airlines don't make you aware of that or let you know there is a quick path from A terminal to B. TSA checks were very slow so go to your gate early

commentHeader: for flying domestically we like IND"
reviewContent: IND is one of our two main options along with CVG when flying. Both are excellent. Traveling from Indy this week reminded me why I like it. In morning and afternoon there are multiple good choices and most are reasonably priced in comparison to many other world airports, crowds are nowhere near some airports, so it is easy to move around, TSA has always been friendly and efficient unlike some airports, restrooms are generally cleaner than many other airports. We do wish there were a couple of direct flights options to Europe, but for flying domestically we like IND

The directions for the TSA PreCheck are confusing for travelers. When headed to the B concourse gates, the precheck sign points to the right and the TSA Administrative office is on the right, but closed. The sign should read that the PreCheck is on the otherside of the concourse, next to Chick-fil-A. Now, once you get to the TSA Check Point, the sign directs you to the employee entrance because someone turned it around. If the sign is in the correct direction, then travelers would know to join the amusement chains on the left. Indianapolis International, you can do better.

commentHeader: bag handling and logistics take so long
reviewContent: IND is my main hub for the last 10 years and it’s an overall very easy airport to navigate. However, I wait 45 minutes minimum every time I land here. Usually also have to wait 5-10 minutes, sitting 20 yards from the gate before anyone guides the plane in. I don’t understand how this airport continues to get awards when the basics of bag handling and logistics take so long.

5 stars every time for years and years. First time for one star. We are in B section and while waiting for our delayed flight to come in there is construction going on in the closed restaurant located in the middle of the airport. Not a little but extremely loud mechanical tools sawing through metals and wood. Dust coming over the protective walls causing coughing and eye irritation. What were they thinking. Hire a heavy metal band and throw in some flame throwers to match the noise in this airport. There was nowhere to go unless we wanted to not hear our gate screaming over the deafening madness.

commentHeader: disappointed that everything was already closed
reviewContent: Had a flight leaving late. So disappointed that everything was already closed. Ridiculous! The only food available was a snack machine that didn’t work. Thank goodness the bartender at The Fan Zone bar, which should have closed at 9pm, stayed open for a sizeable number of us travelers. No restaurant, Hudson store, candy shop - nothing - open. Can’t one or two places stay open at least until 10pm?

Literally everything closes at 8pm. No food. No drink. I have never seen anything like this. Terrible. I would have eaten before arriving to the airport if I had known this was such a barren wasteland.

commentHeader: I can't relax with a beer and a burger
reviewContent: 8:30 P.M. on a Monday night, no restaurants open (other than fast food). No beer/wine/cocktails available in the whole airport, even outside of security. I just busted my butt working for four days at my elderly parent's yard and flying home sore, but happy to have spent time with them. Four days of hard labor vacation and I can't relax with a beer and a burger.

commentHeader: I would not fly out of here again
reviewContent: Horrendous treatment by TSA on March 18, 2022. I would not fly out of here again. Extremely rude, unfriendly and unhelpful.

commentHeader: It has a casual laid back atmosphere
reviewContent: I been through many airports and no one airport is the same other than it is an airport with like amenities and services. However like amenities and services do vary in traveler experience. Indianapolis Airport is by far the best at everything. It has a casual laid back atmosphere but it’s efficient in all aspects of getting passengers to and from their positions whether you are coming or going. The bathrooms are clean and in working order. Food vendors are unique and suitable and quick to get you in and out. The next closest airport to Indy I would have to say is Phoenix.

It's 3.30 on a Sunday afternoon. Both coffee shops and the 3 quick pick restaurants are closed. This forces people to have to pay $11 for for sandwich that's possibly been in a cooler for 3 days. Do better.

commentHeader: they seem to be intentionally not following guidelines
reviewContent: Maintenance/janitorial guys - using their mask for their beards only - walking around boldly with nose and mouth not covered - watched them for some time and they seem to be intentionally not following guidelines - we're all in this together and need to follow health guidelines.

Overall, this is a good--even excellent--airport. However, once my husband required a wheelchair to get to and from the gates, we encountered a significant and repeated service deficiency. This last trip was not, unfortunately, an anomaly. We called ahead, followed instructions to call again when we were within ten minutes of the airport. No wheelchair. The attendants at curbside luggage called again, and pointed to a bench where we were to wait for the chair. Twenty minutes elapsed; no chair. I asked at the service desk. Another ten minutes and no chair. I finally found one and pushed him most of the way to the concourse when a wheelchair attendant finally appeared and took him the rest of the way. We have not encountered this in any other airport. If we had not had similar, repeated problems at Indianapolis International, I would not complain. This is really unacceptable.

Indianapolis International Airport is great. Since it is relatively new, the inside is very clean and well-maintained. Compared to other US airports, it's significantly less crowded. The waiting areas by the gates are very nice with USB chargers and outlets, and there are many great stores and restaurants in the terminals. Baggage claim is nice and checking in is easy. Before you even go through security, there is a very nice food court. Staff are always friendly and parking is convenient.

commentHeader: I must have missed my car

reviewContent: Courteous and friendly staff. Flight left early by about 10-15 minutes, when it was confirmed all planning to fly were on board. Crew was great. Seating was great.

commentHeader: Long Island Macarthur Airport customer review
Long Island Macarthur Airport customer review

reviewContent: Hilo Airport does the job. Large area of unused terminal, but the part we used was OK. Travelled with carry-on only, so can't comment on baggage. Went in and out with no fuss, (TSA pre-approved). Not much in the way of shopping, but not many people about to shop. Sat and had a qiuet drink whilst waiting for our flight, no rush. It's a bit outdated, but as I said, does what it's supposed to.

commentHeader: airport is poorly managed and staffed and unacceptable
Alejandro is hands down the best
reviewContent: While I found the Jacksonville airport to be very clean with exceptionally friendly, professional employees, my review is regarding one in particular. His name is Alejandro, a wheelchair provider for people departing and arriving at the airport. I first met him on October 17, 2023 when I arrived at JAX. He was prompt, friendly, and a very nice person. Well, when I left JAX I ran into Alejandro again and he recognized me (after a week and all the people he'd met). He was so pleasant. I have required wheelchair assistance when traveling for over 7 years and Alejandro is hands down the best.

commentHeader: the most inefficient TSA security checkpoint
reviewContent: The gate agents are great, but they might have the most inefficient TSA security checkpoint I’ve ever witnessed. It took them around 30 minutes to scan 15 bags and only one was flagged out of the 15. They seem to be the only airport where the analogic machines have actually made the security checkpoint slower, which is wild considering the technology of those things. Everywhere else seems to have competent people to run them.

What a discombobulated mess! I bought TSA pre check to expedite airport security but what I witnessed today was a nightmare. Their new TSA pre check area and process for screening is atrocious. The plastic bins don't go in the same order as the prior who pass through - the person in front of me received his second container after I had received my first and the person after me had a container come through before mine as well. It creates longer wait times and more people standing around waiting for the bins. Lots of confusion causing additional travel stress.

commentHeader: hour for the baggage belt to even turn on
reviewContent: Lousy baggage claim. Actually the worst ever ! And it’s consistently bad. An hour for the baggage belt to even turn on is completely unacceptable - pitiful!

commentHeader: basic customer service has gone out the window
reviewContent: I was checking in my 15 yr old daughter for her flight to Chicago, to visit her father for the summer. She travels as an unaccompanied minor but we still like to walk her to her gate, sit with her while she waits and say our goodbyes before she gets on her flight. I have had minor issues with doing this with other airlines, due to security concerns/COVID/9-11 but this most recent visit, I feel I have to say something about the customer service. We get to the airport 1.5 hours before her flight. It's me, my daughter and her half sister. The ticketing agent was not pleasant from the word go. No greeting, no "hi, how are you", just a very bland "how can I help you". She asked me for ID and I said "mine or my daughter's" - as my 15 year old doesn't have an ID as she doesn't drive yet nor does she have a job. She got a bit of an attitude and was like "hers" meaning my daughter. I stated she did not have one for said reasons above. She proceeds to check my daughter in and as that is going on, I tell the ticketing agent that me and her half sister will need passes to walk her to the gate. She finishes with my daughter, then asks for my ID. I give it to her, she checks me in and gives me a gate pass and sends me on my way. I tell her I need a gate pass for her 17 year old half sister. She asks for her ID and when we told her it was in the car and we weren't sure she needed it, she was like "of course she needs it, if she wants a gate pass, she needs to have an ID". Me, not traveling much, didn't know the rules so I had both girls run out to the car (which was not close), get the ID and run back. My daughter was very distraught at this point and we are getting close to her departure time. I calmed her down, we go back to the ticketing agent where a man took over getting her the gate pass and we were on our way. We then get to the TSA line and it was a disaster. The line was miles long and travelers were stressing about missing flights. The line moved S-L-O-W. We had less than 30 min to get through TSA and to her gate. A lady in front of us asked a TSA employee about the line and what could be done to move it along faster and the TSA employee stated "Lady, a lot of people are going to miss flights today". I know airports are crazy and it was the start of summer but basic customer service has gone out the window. Almost every airport employee we encountered was rude.

commentHeader: Poorly run with no concern for passengers
reviewContent: Waited 1 hour in line to be checked by TSA. Unacceptable. Poorly run with no concern for passengers. Attitude of staff. For such a small terminal there should be a more efficient way to expedite passengers through and still provide the required safety needed. At least 15 passengers did not make their flight on this one airline due to the inefficiency of TSA. These passengers arrived an hour or more before flight. Totally disappointed.

On June 7, 2018, I was departing from Jacksonville airport on American Airlines to Philadelphia, flight 4705. At Gate C8, an employee who was very supportive and accommodating to me. She was extremely busy; however, took the time to be sure I had a wheelchair waiting in Philadelphia. She also arranged to have me boarded early with someone. She offered to check my carryon bag as I was having difficulty. This woman is a credit to American Airlines. The plane was extremely cold the flight attendant gave me a blanket which I did not know were available. Very good experience.

commentHeader: Who talks like that to people?
reviewContent: Unfortunately security staff at airport security check point was very rude, it was a male security officer. I placed my belongings in tray at check in point than on rolling rack and attempted to walk away. He came yelling - “whose stuff if is? Who is watching your stuff? You like you staff than stay there”! He sounded and behaved literally like an abusive spouse. What is this? Boot camp? Who talks like that to people? Most people coming to airport are stressed out already, and last thing anyone needs is a stranger coming out of nowhere yelling at them when only simple redirection is needed. What about being calm and professional instead? Otherwise airport was clean and easy to use, also rest of employees we encountered were very polite. Just this one individual gave airport bad rep for a day.
Avoid like the plague. Waiting for 3 hours with 2 people processing the entire queue. Absolutely ridiculous. Asked why it takes so long and all I got was. It’s like this everyday. Sort it out people

Was going to security with me husband and son, appreciate all airports have there own way od doing things, but the girl at the conveyor bell was extremely rude raised her voice when my husband put his shoes in tray instead of putting them directly on belt, I then said in a raised voice also will admit that ok we heard her, she was passed off that I had spoken up, call another lady over who then asked Mr where all the luggage mine I said no, she asked my husband were we together he said yes , then she looks at me and said so these are all yours, I said nope that my husband had his luggage and I had mine, it wasn't even that hard to explain, it was her attitude over the whole thing, even at check in no acknowledgement no please or thanks, I work in customer service and to say I'm astonished by the customer service at this airport, never again will I use this airport, and I've been to many but my god this was the worst airport I've ever been in, customer service so low.

Due to flight delay, we were very tight for our connection flight. Using JFK on connections, we were forced to leave the secure area going from T5 to T7. This required us to recheck in at airline and go through the security screening process a second time. Airline facilitated us, but security were the rudest, uncaring, belligerent staff I had ever encountered. They simply barked to get to the back of the queue, which was huge. Avoid JFK at all costs.

The airport staff very rude and like it is not enough the trauma we have to go through with the checking time; we also need to experience the TSA staff rudeness and lack of emphaty. It is just sad how horrible we are all turning to be as human.

It is specific for Delta Airline Check-in process staff at JFK airport! My flight was to Seattle on July 1, afternoon, ~4:00pm. I checked-in online before I headed to JFK Airpot and so I did not have too much time before departure time. In security check point, the officer told me that, the birth date in my ticket (My son booked the ticket for me. It is his/our fault, I know.) is not the same as that in my driver license. So he asked me to go back to the check-in point for correction. The waiting line in the check-in (Maybe most of them are for checking in baggages while I do not have.) that day is super long. If I lined up from the end, I probably I will miss the flight. So, I talked to staff around the check-in area. It was so crowded. Someone said, you go to there, pointing. Totally, I talked to 5 difference people around that area. Still no one is responsible for my issue. They were saying differently. It seems I have to line up from the end. In the end, I stick on one lady. She said, I understand your situation. I can do nothing about it. She hinted me I have to line up again. Finally, I have to cut into the line by some people's kindness to allow me to cut into the middle of the line. I am OK to line up, even it is long, if I did not check in online. I would leave more time to do that. My question is. For this kind of special situation, should Delta Airline have some specific rules to handle??? would you like the custom to miss their flight? Thanks!

The border control employees are some of the most unhappy, rude people I have ever encountered. Why anyone would want to employ these nasty, aggressive, individuals to not only protect our border, but to be the first face of America that visitors encounter upon arrival, is beyond me. It's as though all of them did their customer service training at the DMV. Ironically, most of the immigrants they are charged with preventing from entering the U.S. could probably do their job 10 times better. Do the reputation of the U.S. and New York City a favor. Fire this surly, attitude-y, chip-on-their-shoulders crew. I gave the queuing time a bad score, because the staff's yelling and rude behavior actually inhibits the smooth processing of entrants.

Border control absolute incompetent, unruly nightmare. Almost got crushed on the escalators because entire area was mobbed. Has to push my kids through the crowd so they didn’t get trapped and possibly injured as scores more people were pushed up the escalators behind us. There was one single staff member there to manage a crowd of hundreds, and he was nonsensical with his demands (“don’t merge!” - as if there was any semblance of lines that anyone could merge into), rude, and dictatorial. Lines weren’t moving at all; air conditioning wasn’t working; and invariably tempers began to flare in the confusion. I’d describe it as “third world” but most third world nations are better managed than this.

What a miserable set of entitled jobsworths! We don't expect TSA staff to be grinning from ear to ear all shift long but do they all have to be so overtly rude and miserable? Can they read? They presumably did not read the job description. They must all feel very satisfied on completion of their shifts when presumably they go home and inflict their miserable selves on their families. Dead behind the eyes, not a good look.

commentHeader: find a way to avoid this airport
reviewContent: If you can find a way to avoid this airport with the longest wait on earth and worst customer service you will thank me later. I had a connecting flight and I had to wait 2 hours to pass the CBP and then I had to pass again thru security check (over 2 hours) to get in my other plane - unbelievable.

This is worst airport I ever been too! So rude, not helpful, why have an atm that you can take out money but not put in! Cashless system is fast way to lose customers, should be more people that are certified in different languages to help instead of make fun of them. New York JFK is a shame of an airport.

Every time I go through JFK, there are always delays. I flew JetBlue from Paris to JFK, and ended up getting delayed more than five hours after already having a four hour layover for my connection to Boston, as well as having had a long flight. Airport was not clean and staff were very rude. TSA confiscated a bottle of rum my dad bought in France that had already been cleared by customs. There also were limited food and shopping options. The only positive experience was spending part of the layover at the TWA hotel. I will never fly through JFK again, and I highly advise anyone flying to this airport as well.

commentHeader: impressed by the service and facilities
reviewContent: This is specific to Terminal 7, used by Aer Lingus. On arrival, we were escorted from the plane to the immigration hall and being first in there was somewhat taken aback by the fact that it was devoid of passengers! We were through the line snake and out to collect baggage in under five minutes from entering. Our bags were on the line within a few minutes too and we were through the whole immigration process and out to the taxis very quickly and smoothly. Our departure experience was equally smooth. We had arrived very early due to transfer arrangements from our cruise and had to hang around for a couple of hours for the check-in desks to open. The area around the desks is quite sterile and functional and only one shop, on the lower arrivals level was available. Luckily it did sell snacks, and drinks as the one food outlet down there was closed. Once open the check-in and security process was very straightforward. T7 now has scanners where there is no requirement to take items out of your bag so that was very smooth, delayed only by the usual one or two who left items in their pockets, forgot to take jackets off and so forth. T7 is not overly big so nowhere is a long way, which is great. The usual shops for Duty Free and food and drink outlets were present and done well. This is our third time using this terminal with Aer Lingus and we continue to be impressed by the service and facilities.

Appallingly rude staff throughout, from TSA to Duty Free staff to Aer Lingus check-in staff. Horrible people employed to deal with customers who pay their wages. Have to say TSA at Terminal 5 O'Hare in Chicago a few years ago was much the same...don't do the job if you don't like doing the job. TSA was a total shambles (Term 7) on a busy Saturday afternoon - nobody gave a toss. And don't start me on the price of stuff in "Duty Free".

I flew back from France on a flight that returned and unloaded a bit late (close to midnight). I had six hours between the time I got off and to terminal 8 before my next flight, which would take me home (final destination). I had tried to go through security but the man at security rudely denied me by stating I was too early. I didn’t know there was a maximum amount of hours you could not check in. I did take the time to look this up in advance and couldn’t find anything. Six hours seemed common. Many people have layovers too short to check in to a hotel. I even looked into the sleep pods and mentioned this as a question. The peach of a worker replied “this isn’t a lodge.” Sorry, but my costly flights help pay for him to have a job. A little courtesy and kind explanation would go a long way. Then when I could finally go through security I noticed pure rudeness and power tripping. Workers snapping at people telling them to get moving through security and hurry up. It was 3:30AM. Chill. Have a coffee first. Something. So blown away. I will avoid this airport at all costs in the future.

commentHeader: worst airport I have ever been to
reviewContent: The worst airport I have ever been to. You spend hours at arrivals with absolutely no information given about how long you are going to be there. They said the wait was 60 minutes but hours later still queuing. No staff around to ask either.

My feedback will be redundant, for the prior reviews are spot-on. After an eight-hour flight from the UK to the US, my daughter and I were exhausted when we went through security a second time to make our connecting flight home. As others have indicated, the staff was completely rude, but what was more disturbing was an interaction between one TSA worker and my daughter. Because she misinterpreted his directions to get into the cattle stall queue, he was outright condescending. Such demeaning comments/interactions should be illegal.

What a lack of respect with travellers! Hours and hours at passport control. Just a bunch of officers to check hundreds of people. Connection flights missing, people feeling sick because of the ridiculous waiting time, rude/grumpy staff everywhere, and so on. I don't know what they think they are, there is definitely nothing attractive about coming to America! Horrendous experience again, avoid it if you can.

Horrendous TSA! I could write a few pages but all I can say is they are unbelievably rude and disrespectful. If I could never fly there again, I wouldn’t. The girls were just awful. They should never have been hired to work with the human population.

The absolute worst TSA experience I’ve had in my life. Had a 3 hour layover from Paris and ended up having to run to re-check our baggage and catch our connecting flight because we spent over two hours in this particular layer of hell. The staff act like they’re having one long temper tantrum after another. Sure I get that they probably deal with a lot of difficult people, but the goal should be to deescalate and not escalate situations. Especially routine ones, like traveler confusion and slow lines. The lady “helping” people get their stuff onto the belt was yelling, snapping at people and barking out orders that made no sense. She was holding onto bins as if she were trying to actually make it more difficult for people. Kept barking for people to “move it along”. I have reduced mobility and I told her it’s very hard for me to move fast without my proper footwear (which they made me remove). She actually bellowed at me that she wasn’t taking to me, she was talking to the person behind me. Zero empathy, complete nastiness. You could tell she was burnt out and over it. TSA should seriously have some sort of plan to rotate out employees who hit the wall and can no longer function on any given day. The lady who ended up physically checking my bag could barely articulate in English and I’m pretty sure it was her native language, as it is mine. She confiscated some of my food and when I asked she said it was because it was a “sprayyyyyyeee”. Took me three tries to realize she was trying to say “a spread”. The whole experience was so nasty my daughter actually burst into tears. Ironically, my partner got through with his own “spraee”/spread—they only confiscated mine. Making me wonder if this is all really just theater. Either way, this experience does not need to be made so horrid. The agents are awful but it makes me wonder what kind of support (if any) they’re getting from on high. To those people I say this—like it or not, TSA are ambassadors of the cities they work in. I’ve had better experiences with TSA around the world and have returned to those cities again and again. I have absolutely zero interest in ever connecting through JFK again. Newark is no picnic but if I had to pick, I’d chose it over this layer of hell.

Others have already said it but I’m genuinely considering flying into LaGuardia or Newark next time, despite the fact it would take me longer to get to my destination after landing. I travel a lot for work and barring none, JFK is the worst experience. Incredibly rude staff at TSA, horrible people making aside comments and barking orders at people. They don’t have enough staff so the queues are always horrendous - we made it to the airport with plenty of time and still were the last ones almost to board because the queues were so astronomical. No air conditioning so just stuck with no seating in a hot corridor for over an hour waiting to go through security. And we didn’t even check bags! I’m disgusted. Ruined the whole experience of flying. This airport has serious problems - puts me off coming here ever again.

A lot of your security people are unnecessarily abrupt in America. TSA at JFK take the award for being the rudest and most abusive, throwing tubs around, bullying everyone. I get it that you are over the many stupid people that you have to deal with daily but just get a new job please don’t take it out on everybody else.

commentHeader: TSA at JFK are horrible people
reviewContent: The TSA at JFK are horrible people. Everyone is trying to comply with their demands but they shout and are verbally abusive and throw things around. I am American and used to the appalling behavior of a lot of the agents. I am ashamed that this is the impression visitors receive of America. We are so strictly told how and where to move in passport lines to enter from a foreign trip then the TSA bullies yell if you don’t do the opposite and move to form new lines quickly. It’s just appalling. Why do customers of airlines deserve to be treated like criminals?

I know all airports are expensive but $5.49 for water and $14.99 for jack links jerky! $40 for a charger - all in all this airport has cost me with 2 children $140 for a charger, food and beverages! It’s really not ok, we pay extortionate prices for the flights, plus baggage now and then the airport are doing daylight robbery! It’s not fair And really shows the level of greed for these multi million dollar business’. Oh and please do not call your Duty free ‘Duty Free’ when the alcohol is the same price in a U.K. Tesco and we’re supposed to be the expensive country! I really hope to not have to use this airport in the future.

Female agent barking orders to put items in trays and place on belt. As there were only a stack of white ones everyone started grabbing and using them. Once several people had placed trays on belt she then stated yelling at them to put the white trays back and wait for more grey ones to arrive. She them singled out an older Indian gent and yelled at him non stop for little things until he passed all the way through and even rolled her eyes at him and started bad mouthing him to another agent, really sad and disgusting.  I know this job is thankless but there has to be other ways to get your kicks and feel self important.

Airport staff waiting at the line for Global Entry - woman working 1pm on 12/3/2024 needs to be trained. There were no back ups in the queue and when my Face ID didn’t work she proceeded to yell at me saying I didn’t have it (when I know full well that I do and have used it 7 + times in the past 2 years). She proceeded to scream over and over that I didn’t have it and the border patrol gentleman was nice enough to signal to me that there was a line I could go to to see what the issue was with it not picking up my Face ID. Technology is not prone from error and this woman was not trained and unnecessarily rude and assumptive for no reason. There was no one even waiting on me with 5-6 machines wide open. Please train your staff.

Terrible! The ESTA line is not moving, there are 1-2 customs officers here in total, who are as slow as a snail. Some are taken out of line, so the others do not progress. 2 meters in an hour. Ridiculous and requires serious remedial action. Air is not moving.

You need to train TSA agents at this location on true American hospitality and common human decency. TSA staff was extremely rude. They yelled at travelers, waived at them to move through lines with insulting hand gestures that showed impatience, abrasiveness, and disrespect. One agent dropped the buckets on the floor in front of everyone to show them she was unhappy about how the buckets were supposed to be lined up. The TSA agent verifying passports at the entrance was rude taking pictures answering questions with sarcastic and condescending comments to travelers who asked for clarification. It is not like there was a huge line or there were lot of travelers. Most of the end rows were empty. So the excuse that this is a busty airport and that TSA agents have to deal with lot of travelers will not fly in this case. I have gone through this airport many times in the past and I think the service at the international level is getting worse. Yes most travelers are immigrants and their level of English language knowledge could be limited but that is an excuse to bark at people and treat them like dirt. Not in America anyway.

JFK is the worst airport ever. The staff is unfriendly and the waiting times are unbearable. How can such a big airport have such garbage service and border control. It’s ridiculous. Think twice before flying JFK.

commentHeader: security scanning was a complete shambles
reviewContent: After a disappointing immigration experience, on departure to UK, the security queue was long but did move reasonably, however the security scanning was a complete shambles. We got through but what a fiasco.

commentHeader: 1.5 hrs in line waiting for immigration
reviewContent: Spent 1.5 hrs in line waiting for immigration, 5 officers to process 100's of passengers. Immigration officer was so miserable. Terrible experience.

Extremely rude TSA agent at Arrivals, Terminal 7 Mobile Passport Control Line on October 20, 2023. This guy must have felt he was on some power trip and made a point to be as rude and condescending as possible because I didn't hear his question. It didn't matter that he was talking very low, the area was busy with arriving passengers. I have never encountered anyone this unprofessional at JFK (and the bar is already low there). He even had a nerve to suggest I was talking over him. What a poor representation of TSA for arriving US Citizens.

Horrible experience. I landed on a flight from London, heading to a connecting flight to Minneapolis. We cleared customs but signs for connecting flights departures were not apparent/user friendly. Staff guided us to an area that eventually mixed with an area where new arrivals could merge. This meant that we had to go through security/x-ray screening all over again. If they had guided through an area of the airport that was still contained within the airport we would not have had to repeat screening, as we had already been screened at our last airport. The line for screening moved extremely slowly, perhaps due to being understaffed? Several of us were concerned about missing connecting flights, I almost missed mine despite having a 2 hour layover. I had to race to the gate and made it just in time to be one of the last people on the flight. I didn't even have enough time to grab a cup of coffee or use the bathroom. Very bad experience.

TSA rude and careless, barking orders and unhelpful. My items were dumped and scattered in various trays and people honestly don’t care. I will avoid this airport in future. With your reviews awful, you really need to have some care training. I am a senior citizen and treated very inequitably.

commentHeader: goes from disgraceful to utterly disgusting
reviewContent: This airport goes from disgraceful to utterly disgusting. Not only is the staffing for immigration clearance so poor - this is the second time in 2 months I’ve waited over 2 hours but the staff did not stop the cheats from going round via US Citizen queue then walking across and cutting the line. Complaints fell on uninterested staff who shrugged their shoulders. I will try avoid this airport as much as possible. What a horrible advert for a country when’s its main airport is such a shambles.

commentHeader: really leaves a sour taste in your mouth
reviewContent: I never have much of an issue departing from this airport, but the line attendants for passport control on arrival are always rude. It really leaves a sour taste in your mouth. The passenger in front of me was an older Hispanic woman - she was walking a little slowly, getting her papers and passport together, but there was nobody behind us and I could tell she was older, so I didn’t mind. The line attendant rudely said “let’s go!” To her and then immediately asked her if she was a green card or visa holder - I’m assuming because of her race? It turned out she was an American citizen (duh - we were in the US Citizen line). The attendant just kept barking commands at her and giving her no time to answer any questions. Then she starts barking at me and just being really patronizing. I’ve seen similar behavior multiple times from passport control line attendants when arriving from an international flight.

Absolutely awful experience at this airport! After an amazing 5 night stay in NYC with my family, our holiday quickly turned sour when going through security here. If the 1 hour queue wasn't bad enough, being greeting by shouting security officers made it the worst experience we've ever had in an international airport. I can't single just the one security official out, they were all aggressive, abrupt, and completely unprofessional. This must be in the training, as it was quite consistent throughout. I could add a little assistance if anyone from JFK is reading this. Instead of saying "if I see those phones in your hands I'm pulling you to one side" perhaps say "could everyone please place their phones in the trays provided". Its just a little common courtesy, and plain good manners, and you'd be surprised how far it gets you in life. The whole experience has actually put us off coming back to New York again. Which is a shame, as we really enjoyed it. I was emptying my bag of my laptop and tablet at which time the lady took it from me and put it in a tray, and told me to take my shoes off. I said my laptop is in there and she looked at me with a steely gaze and said "I know.....take your shoes off". Honestly it was just horrendous. Herded through like cattle and shouted at. The whole airport needs massive improvement, and lessons in basic decorum.

Simply awful and frustrating. We were almost missing our connecting Flight despite around 5 hours of transit time. Running and sweating because of unbelievable queing at passport control first and then unbelievable hundred and hundred meters of queue. Laziest staff ever experienced, they don t care nothing about pax, repeating same controls several times, only very few security staff for thousands of passengers, quite rude and totally against passengers. No transit area, no connection line, no way to send bags to final destination. I will never never fly to or via JFK in the future. Shame on Airport authority and tsa and staff working there.

This is by far the worst airport I have ever had the misfortune to travel through. The security staff are the laziest, most rude individuals imaginable and the security system is like something out of the dark ages. How this airport has the cheek to carry the name of such a great man is beyond me - shameful. Would put me off ever coming back to New York!

Despicable experience. People pushed around in a very long line as though they are animals. Women standing with little babies in their hands for hours and no one giving them priority! The whole security experience is the worst I have seen in any airport in the world. What is the JFK management doing? They should be fired for humiliating JFK passengers, who are their clients. Stop following modern standards of service, this airport has a really unpleasant, almost fascist feeling. This is serious. I was in terminal 4.

commentHeader: TSA staff are so abrupt and rude
reviewContent: TSA staff are so abrupt and rude. The gentleman at the scanner told me me to pull up my pants...My pants were just fine (Im a 36 man, not a teenager) I asked him "should I pull up my pants". Then proceeds to say "yeah you heard that correctly, pull up your pants bro, pull up your pants bro", when I walked I said "no need to be rude" to which he said, "step out, bye". Not sure in what world is it acceptable to talk to people like that

Miserable experience. Security personnel were mouthy and rude and pushed people through security so quickly that it caused a large group of people trying to get themselves and their belongings back together while security personnel kept screeching, “move down, this is a working area.” There was only one bench and one small table and no room for people to put their shoes on, belts on, re-pack electronics etc. and there were only TWO agents screening hundreds of people. The process was so slow that we missed our connecting flight and had to spend the night in the airport which was freezing cold even in July. It also irks me that people cannot speak English clearly which causes more confusion and frustration. I loathe this airport and will avoid it at all costs in the future.

The TSA staff at JFK and the gate staff need a huge amount of training in customer service and process. Going through T7, a whole load of us experienced one particular TSA officer shouting instructions about what goes where in the trays and rather than do their job, which is to repeat the information, they decided to go up to people and shout at them in a tone as if the person is an idiot and then turn to the queue and say “see, they just don’t listen”, so everyone can look at you like you’re a criminal. Airports all over the world have different rules for security screening. Frequent flyers will often automatically go to the majority format, it’s not malicious and it definitely doesn’t deserve being made to be the focus of derision. The gate staff called people holding a mobile boarding pass to have their ID verified AGAIN at the gate, before the boarding process started. When asked why, rather than tell the truth, they said that’s the rules. It wasn’t the rule when flying out of JFK literally a couple of weeks ago and it still is not the rule. Mobile boarding pass holders do not require additional ID screening at the gate and this member of staff was not accurate. The process for ID verification is stated as follows: “The officer will insert each photo ID into the CAT unit where the ID is scanned and analyzed. CAT is linked electronically to the Secure Flight database, which confirms travelers' flight details, ensuring they are ticketed for travel that day.” Really poor travelling experience.

Don't ever fly through JFK if you have to go to New York city! Standing in queue for 4 hours along with 500 other passengers at JFK Airport customs was a harrowing experience. Can you imagine just 3 immigration inspectors for 500 passengers? The last thing I wanted after a long flight and fatigued legs was to be held up at immigration for an inordinate amount of time. All I wanted to do was rest, refresh and resume. Here I was waiting in JFK security lines.

This is the worst connecting flight experience I've ever encountered. We needed to collect our bags and go through border patrol/re-check bags/security. This in itself wouldn't be a problem if the airport was sufficiently manned and the process wasn't so slow. We landed into JFK at 5.45pm, our connecting flight was at 8.05pm. When coming off the plane we followed the signs for non USA citizens and stood queuing for 45 mins for passport control. It was only when we got near the front of the queue we realised there is a 'quick connect' queue for people on connecting flights. This isn't visible or well signposted until you are at the front of the queue, there were no staff directing. You would have to walk passed the 'Non USA Citizens' queue to see it. Even once we switched to that queue (as the other had stagnated completely) it still took an additional 30 mins. There was one border officer who had to take prints and pictures of every passenger. It wasn't something that can be done quickly and I understand why, however more staff would help. Once through there our bag collection was quick and easy, so that was a positive.  From there we followed signs for connecting passengers. We re-checked the bags which was quick for us. We headed for security, there is a specific security for connecting passengers. The queue was long but not overly long, the issue was again how slow it was. They had one belt open for all connecting flights. After 30 mins of queuing here, our family and others made it known to airport staff that due to the length of time queuing we were going to miss our flight. We had 30 mins until take off, others had even less. A lady who tried to be helpful took us to the front and asked security staff if we could go through as a priority as we were going to miss our flights, unfortunately she was told no. There was a belt for 'TSA' passengers that was empty, they were unwilling to let people use it despite the lady pleading with them on our behalf. I'd like to thank her, I don't know her name but she tried to help and got a hard time from others because of it. Another worker would let parties of 2 jump to the front but not us as we were a party of 4. It was so frustrating being refused help yourself to have others jump in front, making us more likely to miss our flight. After 45 mins of some passengers pleading for priority to get through and one young woman crying her eyes out because she was missing her plane, they decided opening a second belt was a good idea. After a 1 hour queue at security, we got through with 10 mins to go. We sprinted shoeless through the airport to our gate, the airport is huge so it was quite a way. We made it just in time. The icing on the cake was when we arrived at our final destination and all 4 of our bags had been left in New York. The only saving grace was that we did make our flight, despite it being an unnecessarily stressful situation. My advice is, if possible don't connect here. If you do, make sure you have 3 hours minimum to do it in case the service is as bad as it was for us. Look for the 'Quick Connect' queue at passport control if you are on a connecting flight.

JFK is arguably my least favorite airport, but I was pleasantly surprised with my experience this time. The check in and security process was exceptionally quick as I was able to get to my gate in less than an hour! I was also not expecting the TSA to be so accommodating considering my own past experiences at JFK dealing with their rudeness. There were a decent amount of food options, but most were charging pretty steep prices so the McDonald’s and Dunkin’ Donuts were a godsend. Ultimately, JFK’s biggest advantage is the range of destinations you can fly to directly, it’s not an aesthetically pleasing airport with world class amenities but at least this time was far less stressful.
