Finally, the inefficiency of this airport worked to my advantage and although I arrived 5 minutes after my flight was supposed to take off, there were people still boarding the plane. Moral of the story, I just came believe I had so many staff member telling me that I was going to miss my flight, but none tried to do anything about it. I also don’t understand why the TSA pre-check line is so hidden that not even the staff members know where it is. You can do better Orlando.

A shambles of an airport. After a long flight from the UK we were told by the apologetic captain that we were being held on the tarmac due to there being no free gates available to disembark. He mentioned how it was ridiculous that an airport of their size wasn't prepared for our arrival. When we finally disembarked an hour later, we entered the worst immigration queues I have ever had the misfortune of standing in. Two and a half hours it took, in a room with no air conditioning. We had a toddler that didn't understand what was going on and almost collapsed in the heat. No one was offering water or seats, just warnings that phones must be kept in pockets. To add insult to injury we had to endure the constant repeating of the flash entry video about how easy they make immigration. It was inhumane how they treated people, coming into their country to spend a lot of money. Eventually we got to baggage claim where our bags had been removed from the belts and deposited anywhere there was room. Then we were greeted with huge queues at the car rental desks. It may sound sensationalist, but it has honestly put me off travelling to Orlando again. The way out wasn't much better. An hour and a half to get through security on the way out. Staff looked like they didn't care and were rude and arrogant. I'm not sure I understand the idea of all the best shops and restaurants being before the security checks either. You can't spend any time browsing as you don't know how long it's going to take to get through. Once you get through security your choice is severely limited. Can I make one suggestion? Spend some money on the infrastructure and staff. You can't currently meet the demand. Your airport is an absolute shambles and I won't be returning.

Upon arrival and at departure there were problems with passengers not being allowed to exit the plane due to congestion. The staff were unhelpful and impolite, failing to remember we were customers. We ended up with a 5.5 hour delay, partly due to this treatment - it was amusing when the pilot explained that the luggage was being loaded onto the plane by 2 staff as the rest had gone home, which he wanted to do too. The infrastructure here obviously requires some modernisation.

Good signposting / access to taxis. Wide range of shops / restaurants. Friendly staff. Most impressed with support given to travellers with disabilities. Immediately upon arrival my wife (suffering a dislocated knee) was provided with a wheelchair which she was able to retain to departure gate / taxi service.

commentHeader: staff were officious, rude and abrupt
reviewContent: Quick initial bag check in with helpful staff, but when we reached security the staff were officious, rude and abrupt! My daughter was stopped for a body search and had her hands swabbed by a very unhelpful member of staff. This upset her a good deal and the procedure was at no time explained to her. When I asked at customer inquiries for a form of contact to make a complaint they were unhelpful and seemed uninterested in my query and unhelpful. Very small and overpriced duty free section. A poor end to our long saved for holiday!

commentHeader: the staff were also very helpful
reviewContent: As we arrived at the airport the check in was right in front of us, the staff were also very helpful. It was very easy to find our way around as all signs were clearly visible. We didn't have to wait very long in any queue, the staff sent us to a quicker queue. The airport was very clean, but there isn't many shopping stores around. The terminal seating wasn't great, the wifi wasn't great but it does work, just have to wait a bit.

commentHeader: looks run down and not well kept
reviewContent: MCO is the worst airpot with the worst TSA agents I have ever dealt with! Arrived at this airport and waited an hour to get our luggage in an area with no AC. Why in the world is this airport not up to date? It looks run down and not well kept at all. The airport only has a total of 3 elevators? People make lines and push each other to get into one elevator. Traveled with my husband and 3 daughters to Orlando, Florida. Our youngest daughter only 2, when flying out of MCO the TSA agent checking our tickets was very rude. He was yelling at my husband asking him to move out of the way with an attitude as my husband assisted me with our 2 year old while I was getting my ID to give to the TSA agent. There was no reason for this agent to act this way! These TSA agents are in need of customer service training. They look very unhappy and have a big attitude problem. TSA agents specifically at this airport if you don't like your job find another simple as that. If you like your job then consider looking at these reviews and improve your attitudes towards travelers! I have traveled into and out of several airports and by far this is the worst location!

commentHeader: This is no way to treat people
reviewContent: I can only echo the reviews of everyone else here. This is no way to treat people, especially by a country that is supposedly the most advanced in the world. The slick videos they play in arrivals are the complete opposite to the actual experience. The officer we had was actually pleasant but it takes an age to process each group. The most frustrating thing is that most people coming into MCO are there ultimately to spend a lot of money in the local economy so everything should be done to make the entry process as efficient and welcoming as possible. I for one will never fly into MCO again. Finally, a tip for car renters. Having got through customs over two hours after we landed we then faced the biggest queues ever at the car rental desk in terminal B. Literally two or three people on duty to serve a queue of at least 30 and we all know how long we have to spend at the desk as they try and up sell everything. I went and spoke to one of the other car rental agents as I could see another two hour wait on the horizon, initially to see if I could hire something from them for 24 hours to then come back to collect our pre-pay car the next day. She took me over to Terminal A and said queues are usually much less there than in Terminal B. She was right. One person in front of me and a two hour wait avoided. I told a few beleaguered families at the back of the queue in Terminal B on my return. Always pays to be a fox not a sheep. Don't follow the crowd - look for alternatives.

I travel internationally at least once a month and being that I live in Brevard County, Florida, I always travel through Orlando International Airport. Since October of 2016, each and every single time I have arrived at Orlando International Airport, the flights have been forced to sit on the tarmac or at the gate because the airport’s immigration service is unable to process more travelers. The wait times have typically been between 30 minutes and 60 minutes. When you finally are allowed to arrive in immigration, you will find that the wait times to pass through immigration are very long (unless you have Global Entry, which I have). Be prepared to spend at least 30 – 45 minutes. Once you finally pass through immigration you will enter into the baggage reclaim area. Note that the international baggage claim has only three baggage carousels. Recognizing that this is woefully inadequate, the airport management assigns teams of workers that rearrange and shuffle baggage as it arrives at each carousel. Of course, eventually the carousels become so overwhelmed with baggage that the workers have to remove the bags and start stacking them about the baggage area wherever there is room. Be aware that your bags may be stored on the floor areas along side the carousel. Again, this is not new or temporary. It has been going on without improvement for a very long time. As you’re waiting for your bags – get ready as this can be very long- I experienced times from 30 minutes to 60 minutes. When you finally do get your luggage you will need to head off to the tram that will take you to the main terminal. If it is not working, which does happen, then be prepared to haul your luggage and kin for a half-mile through hot (and maybe rainy) weather. Of course, the airport will tell you that they will provide a bus if this occurs but realize this is not a speedy exercise. The last bit is the on-going renovations inside the main terminal. Currently (mid 2017) the escalators are sporadically available. If you plan to retrieve your vehicle or rental car from the parking area, be prepared. The elevators (3 in total in any one area) will have a load of passengers waiting to move to one of the three levels. When one finally opens for you, the flood gates open. If you are not standing in front of the one that arrives, you probably won’t make it in. The wonderful feature of these elevators is, as people are scrambling to pack into the elevator that just arrived, the remaining elevators will not attempt a pick-up because the last arriving elevator cancels the selection for your floor. You will have to wait for the filling elevator door to completely close before you can attempt to again summons another elevator. Bottom line, if you are arriving from an international flight (especially with a connection) to MCO then give yourself plenty of time (I would say 3 hours), as it will not be a speedy transit time.

What is there good to say about Orlando airport? Nothing. Holiday to Orlando, 'The Magic Place' well let me tell you MCO if there is one thing you're good at is shattering everyone's dreams the minute they land. Everything is slow. Immigration seem to relish in seeing the queue getting larger and asking dumb questions when you finally get to the desk which took well over 1.5hrs. Having kids ask 'are we nearly there yet' and 'why is it taking so long' when you've run out of answers is exasperating. Then picking luggage up and transfering it to the car hire area rather than carrying / pulling it all which took no more than 10mins on foot meant another 1hr wait for the luggage to arrive with 3 other peoples luggage. God help them if they got busy! I've been to better more efficient third world country airports. Being a seasonsed traveller I have to hand it to you for being the worst airport  I've ever had the unfortunate experience to use.

Terrible airport, security is awful, baggage claim is the worst I have ever experienced anywhere in world. If you can, avoid at all costs. Waited over 1 hour for baggage to arrive, queued for nearly 1 hour for security. Restaurants are all terrible. Pathetic for such a well traveled destination. America you should be embarrassed, this is the 21st century. Will not come back to Orlando.

We arrived from Glasgow at 15.40 on 23 June. We were held on the aircraft for more than an hour because the immigration hall was full. That was followed by another lengthy wait in the queue at immigration and then a wait for one of our cases. By the time we left in our hire car, three hours had passed. The airport knows what that's going to be like every day so they need to step up and improve.

Worst airport in the US by far! With thousands of travelers every hour, they have only 3 security lines! In addition, all classes of travel have the same 3 lines, no point in being a FF, points member, first class, etc, it won't do you any good. Plan on arriving an additional hour beyond what the normal anticipated time to get to the airport is, plus an additional half hour if it is raining (freeway is a disaster). In other words, drive to Tampa or Miami and fly from there! Thank you TSA for making MCO the worst airport in America.

commentHeader: in total chaos with massive delays
reviewContent: Avoid this airport at all costs. I travel extensively all over the world, however the last time I had to fly via Orlando MCO was thankfully 2003 as it was pretty dreadful even then! I had the opportunity to visit a friend in Fort Myers and the only flight I could get came into Orlando, so I decided to fly and drive. My flight with Virgin Atlantic came in on time and we were all about to disembark when we were told we had to remain on the plane for an additional 30 minutes due to the fact that 'immigration was so busy'! We all waited patiently, and eventually allowed off the plane, just to join an enormous queue for the passport identification machines. Thinking this would speed things along, I waited a further 20 mins and eventually had my passport scanned and photo taken. We then turned the next corner to discover another snaking queue for the passport security check! After waiting a further 30 minutes, I eventually got in front of the Passport Control Security Officer, who I can honestly say was one of the most rude, acerbic and disrespectful men I've ever had the misfortune of meeting. He basically grilled me for around 10-15 minutes on every aspect of my life professional and personal. I eventually picked up my bag from the carousel, in a room with no air conditioning on day with temperature around 89 degrees, just to discover the necessity to join yet another huge snaking queue to show my documents yet again! This took a further 20 minutes and at this point, people were starting to look seriously unwell, with old people looking faint and babies crying non stop. In total this rigmarole took around 2 hours and all before having to get the shuttle to the other terminal in order to queue yet again to pick up my hire car. Unfortunately, I have to travel through the same airport with my children at the end of June and I can honestly say I am absolutely dreading the experience. Not only will it be even hotter then, but due to holidays I'm sure it will be twice as crowded! If they weren't coping with the volume of passengers in May, I really can't see how they will cope during the annual holidays. On the return flight, the security was yet again in total chaos with massive delays and once I got through this unpleasant part of travelling, there was basically only one restaurant which served table dinning; quite unbelievable for an International Airport. There also appeared to be no flight information whatsoever on the flight departures and the only way to get an update was to go to the actual gate. My advice to anyone with the choice, would be to fly into a neighboring airport, even if it's two hours or more away and just drive. I flew into San Francisco International back in March and the experience, could not have been different. The staff were quick, efficient and extremely polite an helpful. The whole process from leaving the aircraft to leaving the terminal was around 30 mins in total. I can therefore only sum up and say I will make sure everyone I know, avoids Orlando International at all costs. Just don't go there and they will have to review their policies.

commentHeader: can't cope with the number of travellers
reviewContent: Orlando is a zoo! Poor signage makes it difficult to navigate, not enough lifts to cope with the numbers, checking and security takes an age and some staff are not helpful and clearly under pressure. The airport can't cope with the number of travellers so I'll help them out by not using Orlando again, ever.

commentHeader: Welcome to Florida I don't think so
reviewContent: 5th May 2017 flight from Glasgow to Orlando International, scheduled to land at 14.05 landed at 15.15 due to 1hr + delay at Glasgow, then held on the plane for 3+ hrs due to reduce handling capacity in airport then queued for 2.5 hrs for immigration checks, then queued for secondary security checks then pick up hired car and drove out of airport at 21.30. I would not believe this story if someone else told me it. Welcome to Florida I don't think so.

Arrived at about 5.30pm, Fri 5th May on BA 2039. We had then to wait initially an extended 30 mins on the tarmac as the gate was occupied, then at the gate we were told it would be another hour which again was extended before Immigration would let us off the plane. After we were allowed off the queues were horrendous and even after using the APC machines had to queue to see and be questioned by an immigration official also dealing with non machine authorized people. The best welcome from the immigration officer was to tell me that I wasnt allowed to hold my cell phone in my hand, even after telling him it was turned off, and he said I had to put it in my pocket. He even grilled me as to why I was travelling alone but looked sheepish when I told him my wife died tragically 18 months ago, but he didnt manage to say "Oh I am sorry to hear that" as most people do, especially after a 9 hr flight and 3 hour unnecessary delay. Then there was a horrendous queue at Customs making it difficult to get bags off and then to get to the exit. Overall I was delayed 3 and half hours from landing, the only consolation was that talking to Virgin and Lufthansa passenger arriving at roughly the same same said they were delayed 4 hours! Can you imagine the pain for about 2000 people arriving and being delayed by an average of 3 hours. What an awful airport, will never fly to MCO directly again, they just cant cope and don't seem to want to welcome people or to help to reduce the delays. Just get audio messages on the hub trains saying what a modern hi tech and progressive city Orlando is, maybe the authors ought to experience what visitors really experience.

Orlando airport is generally fine. Decent food options, easy access from city, good signage and easy to navigate. Unfortunately, both the TSA security setup and the TSA staff is just plain horrendous compared to TSA at all other airports I have ever been to. I'm a frequent traveler. 2-4 flights a month is normal, and sometimes it's a lot more than that. I have been to over 30 airports in the country and I've never seen a TSA setup like this. Lines coming from 2 different, opposite terminal entrances running into each other and then being allowed in one at a time. It's quite bizarre especially given the elegant alternative of just splitting the available security lanes into two - one for each terminal. This creates a lot of blockages and inefficiency as each side is temporarily halted while the other side goes on. The TSA staff only adds to this confusion. Not only are the staff incompetent at this airport, as is evident from their mismanagement of the lines, they are also rude, almost all angry, and very loud and unempathetic. I saw people getting yelled at unnecessarily, being made to wait, being given conflicting instructions and just generally having a bad experience over the course of 2 different departures in the same week from this airport. This is not including my own personal experience where it took 3 agents to resolve the security threat of me having a personal flask of water with...water inside. Instead of being allowed to drain it or drink it, I was sent back outside and forced to go through the entire security process again. My only other option was throwing the flask which was a biryhday gift and which I didn't want to forfeit. Overall, this airportms TSA general manager needs to look into the situation. They are turning what could otherwise be quite a decent airport into a terrible one.

I have used Orlando Airport in the past and had forgot what arriving here is like. The past couple of times in Florida I have been to SFB and what a pleasure that small airport is in comparison. On to MCO, we arrived on time from London and taxied to our gate, everyone was getting things sorted to disemabark when we're were told the airport could not handle anymore people. We were kept on the plane for 20 minutes before being allowed to leave and that was just the start of the waiting. Queued for the self service machines to scan passports answer questions etc, you then have to queue to do exactly the same thing with a real person so I don't understand the self service machines use? Having finally cleared security we got our bags only to have to put them on another belt to collect in terminal B belt 29 according to screens. Anyway 3 out of 4 bags arrived on belt 28 despite screens saying 29. By the time I got 4th bag from belt 28 and got up to Avis and collected the car it had been over 3 hours since landing. When I used SFB time from leaving aircraft to driving car away was an hour, that's the reason I stopped using MCO as it is so painfully slow.

I moved to Orlando almost a year ago. I travel extensively. This airport has easily the worst baggage delivery times of any airport in the world. I routinely wait up to an hour and have had to wait over that once. I have no idea why every other airport can figure this out and they cannot. Do not check baggage unless you absolutely have to.

We were extremely fortunate our plane was the only one landing at this time - and the delay getting through immigration was only one and a half hours. Delays in Miami of up to two and a half hours are not uncommon and I suspect this would have been worse had 2 planes landed at the same time as almost all the immigration booths were manned. The system is even more ridiculously convoluted here than in Miami. You join the ESTA queue for the automatic machines, then join an endless immigration queue where you are quizzed on reason for visit, then you queue for a third time to hand over your automatic ESTA slip at customs. Why this could not be done in queue two is a mystery. As I said, we were lucky. Had more than one plane landed, it would have been chaos. These issues with immigration will soon have a serious effect on America, after a ten hour flight these delays will soon cause people to stop visiting.

commentHeader: staff at the security gates were loud and rude
reviewContent: We flew back to London Gatwick on 20th February 2017 from Orlando International Airport and were not impressed at all. The staff at the security gates were loud and rude. At least two members were shouting out to the hoards of passengers ordering everyone to 'push your own bags through X-ray, they won't move themselves' and 'this is what happens when you don't put your stuff in the box properly' referring to a mobile phone that had fallen on the floor. Going through X-ray was quite frightening. The guard yelled 'forward!' 'Stop!' 'Legs!' 'Arms up!' at me. It honestly felt like I was at an army boot camp! To cap it all, my 71 year old mum was body searched then asked 'have you got anything to declare, are you carrying drugs?' This left her severely shaken. We will not be returning any time soon! Disgraceful.

commentHeader: whole experience from tarmac to transportation took 3 hours
reviewContent: Absolutely awful experience! We arrived after a long 9.5 hour journey only to join a lengthy queue to get to automated passport control machines which took our photos and fingerprints. We then had to pass through immigration where, yet again, they took photos and fingerprints. Finally, we had to go through the Department of Agriculture section where our passports were checked again. Whole experience from tarmac to transportation took 3 hours. An absolute joke!

commentHeader: fine if not for the experience with TSA
reviewContent: Orlando airport would be fine if not for the experience with TSA. The staff attempt to be informative while also treating you like an idiot. A woman was placing her bags down to go through the scanner and one of then staff members yells out, "As you can clearly see, none of this is automatic. You need to PUSH your items down for it to work!" but a simple "push your bags down" would have been sufficient, and less time consuming. This is generally how all information was delivered throughout the process. Otherwise, the staff at the information desk and check in areas were professional and informative, and the airport was easy to navigate.

commentHeader: every area has delays and no sense of service
must be avoided at all costs
the rudest people I have met

reviewContent: The dining choices at Orlando airport are horrible. Too few options. It's sad when you are hoping to get a table at Ruby Tuesday - the airport needs to be current and competitive. Orlando has got to be at the bottom if the dining options list. After all it is 2016.

commentHeader: never fly to this airport again
found the whole approach very disorganised
not a good advert for the USA

reviewContent: I visit Orlando International (MCO) quite regularly and overall it is a nice airport but it is spoiled by one long term irritation (bag collection) and a more recent one (TSA related). International Arrivals MCO’s international credentials are irritating. Having collected your bags from the carousel and then gone through customs, unless you are travelling lightly you have to give up your bags for transfer to the main terminal building only to have to retrieve them from yet another carousel. Invariably the bags never turn up together and sometimes the time for them to arrive is excessively long. This airport needs a one-stop international arrivals terminal, collect your bags once and go. Departures security on my last few visits, the TSA have spoiled the party. They seem to think that by penning people together before allowing them to pass through the scanners, they are being efficient. Wrong. All this does is succeed in annoying normally mild mannered people who see that they are being processed out of turn. The first TSA person you encounter does not even check boarding passes in correct sequence. We had about 20 people behind us when 2 females just walked to the front of the line and the guy said they are next. It is no use arguing because they are clearly selectively deaf. Do not get me wrong, there are many very pleasant TSA staff and they have a tough job but the whole TSA management structure at MCO need to be re-trained. Last week they did not have the trays ready for the scanner so told everybody to just pass through with minimal checking. Whilst it made the process quicker becuase I did not have to get my laptop out or take my shoes off, their job is to check people properly. They might feel people constantly bash them but most times they deserve it by being stupid. Orlando airport management need to have words with the TSA before they become as bad as Miami airport.

commentHeader: seating at the gate was very limited
Baggage claim is nice and easy
wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy
park n fly for me next time
reviewContent: I have been flying in and out of Midway for 30 years. I am writing a review about ground transportation. I have always used Midway's parking for almost every trip made, tonight June 21st is the last time. The nice and considerate bus drivers have been traded in for aggressive, rude tip hustlers who need to handle everyone's bag. I fly frequently and this is 3rd or 4th time with this aggressive behavior by drivers and I'm done with it. On to the park n fly for me next time.

How does a modern airport not have shops open when flights are departing? Ever since covid, Midway has been a 3rd-rate airport with almost no options for food. The vending machines (I can attest to this) do not work and every shop doesn’t open until 5 am. Flights are already departing and there is not a single open shop to even buy water. And again, the vending machines don’t operate. My home airport is Austin and a few shops are required  to be open prior to the first flight departing. What is wrong with Midway?

commentHeader: Getting food is a big challenge
reviewContent: I transit this airport 3 times in one month for my business trip. Getting food is a big challenge. I have seen so many restaurants are closed by 7 or 8 pm. even airports and flights are operating till very late. The second time I been to 5 different restaurants and all had bad attitudes. They are out of items. And if you are vegetarian then it's worst. They don't want to help you make anything vegetarian or even salad. Customer service is not good in those restaurants. Airport authorities need to ask those restaurants to open late and have more food.

A person at a security checkpoint for TSA pre-check told me that my disabled daughter could not go through because she wasn’t prechecked. I explained I didn’t have time to get that for her as she hasn’t travelled in years. She said too bad she’s over 18 she has to go through the regular line. I explained that she is legally disabled and we can’t be separated. She insisted. That’s the rules. I was annoyed that she was embarrassing my daughter like that. I said I am using a walker because I have severe back pain. I can’t go stand in those lines. That’s why I have a walker. She said just go over there and cut in the line. So we have to walk against the flow of people to another station. We get there and they’re like what are you doing? I pointed to the other agent and said she told me to come over here and I can’t stand in the line. Luckily they didn’t argue. The rude attitude instead of understanding treatment is inexcusable!

Super overpriced items in every kiosk. I know the rule is "whatever the market will bear, but the prices at this airport are downright ridiculous. Expect LOTS of attitude from the bored, unfriendly staff.

Awful airport for any type of layover or any restaurant. They tried to “update” Midway a few years back, removing staple restaurants like Harry Carey’s, Potbelly, and even McDonalds. Now, multiple restaurants including Vienna Beef, Cafe Espresso, Bill Goat Tavern, PorkChop, among others, all closed. Weekends and weekdays. Plus, Dunkin’ Donuts, only hot coffee. Zero variety. Employees are angry and overworked. Restaurant Bistro, which replaced a few of the old restaurants is awful. Midway has gone way downhill. Hate it here.

commentHeader: this place is an operational mess!
reviewContent: Generally a good airport, but considering the covid, this place is an operational mess! The new security and system for wheelchairs is at a very low level. Customers with ADA accessibility is third-class, they simply are not equipped to handle these travellers. Lines are not clearly marked and wheelchair patrons are left to figure it out on their own. Security is mismanaged, no room for the chair itself. No seating once you get through security to get reset after going through the lines. Additionally, bathrooms are a disaster, no working soap during covid? Who is in charge of operations at Midway, they are not doing the job! No one is cleaning or sanitizing anywhere! Be aware, this management doesn't care, they make it look good in the photos, but actually come here and try to be safe, it's nearly impossible. Why don't the touchless hand sanitizer and towel machines work? Looks like cheap equipment to me, they are either empty or the sensors are poor. Very disappointing and wish Midway would be more serious about being clean, stay away if possible or try O'Hare.

commentHeader: This place is a complete dump
reviewContent: What a dump. Cramped seating areas, bad/slow food, narrow concourse, few 'walking' escalators, tiny bathrooms, short runways that necessitate abrupt, rough landings, very few (and ludicrously small) flight update boards - these are just a few bullet points on a lengthy list, which comprehensively and easily condemns Midway as the worst major airport in the United States. This place is a complete dump, and since Southwest essentially owns the joint, the blame lies squarely on their corporate shoulders. A renovation will not fix this mess - it's time to condemn and demolish Midway.

I had the best custermer experience at Midway airport. I had just gone through the TSA checkpoint when I realized I had left my work binder at the seating area on the way in. I was panicking and I asked a manager in TSA who took his time to walk me back though security and hunted down where I last saw it. There was a gentleman who told us that he saw another member of security take it to baggage claim. He went above and beyond to find the person who took it there and luckily it was descovered. Him and another member were able to get it back to me and I was in much relief. He was then able to help me get back though security so I could make my flight on time. I have never had such great customer service at any other airport.

As I go through the screening process, the TSA staff are extremely rude. I am the nicest, most patient person you’ll ever meet. However, when my pleasant trip becomes ruined by the screening people it has driven me to write a complaint. It important to give instructions prior to entering the scanner, but they don’t need to berate people. Then scold them for following your instructions but not exactly the way they like. It was a horrible experience and my trip is no longer happy. I don’t want to fly from here again. I would go back home if I could.

Changes have been made to the restaurants in the food court area and they have definitely gone downhill. The new choices are poor in terms of quality. Seating has always been poor as long as I have been flying through Midway. They lost about 20 tables for general seating as they gave it to a single restaurant for expansion. Most of these were empty when I was there on a Friday night. I go though Midway about 10 times a year, but this was the first time I arrived for departure after 8:30 PM. TSA Precheck was closed! I am so glad I never leave on Sunday as those lines for Security stretch all the way back to the parking garage.

Midway is okay. The airport is relatively clean compared to other American airports and the flights are typically on time and departure gates are easy to find. TSA, without Pre, appears to be a disgrace. The lines are frequently long with only one or two employees checking boarding passes. TSA Pre, however, is easy and extremely quick at Midway. Southwest dominates here, so the check-in process is simple and quick. It seems that on arrival checked baggage arrives extremely late without reason. Lastly, the food is below par and the seating is almost non-existent. But still, Midway's accessibility and gateway to the rest of the US makes the airport tolerable.

commentHeader: the seating is almost non existent
reviewContent: I travel weekly, Midway with no exception has the worse food of any airport in the country, better pack your own food. The selection is poor, the quality is the worst and the seating is almost non existent. Unti 2017 the selection was mediocre, but the new restaurants are horrible, you may believe that they intentionally made every effort to be bad.

commentHeader: new changes amount to less options
reviewContent: I travel every week for work and fly in and out of Midway Airport. Earlier this year, Midway airport had some renovations and changed out many of its long time restaurants. These new changes amount to less options, as well as poor food choices. Many of these changes include Home Run Inn pizzas at the court and at both A and B wings. Likewise they allowed Dunkin Donuts coffee at the court and on both wings (where donuts is the worst kind of breakfast option) Many of the pre-packaged foods along the stands were also reduced to less choices and wilted looking lettuces. Overall the food options are heavy carb load choices and do not offer high quality fresh foods and lack variety. Mayor Emmanuel reportedly eats healthy and the airport eateries are not a place that he would be found dining in as a meal. Disappointed that he and the city allowed these changes to be made.

The restaurant changes here have been terrible. The breakfast and coffee options are minimal at best. Lines are long for coffee. Zero healthy food options overall. Airport itself is easy to navigate. Lines for regular security are usually long, but precheck is generally quick.

This airport used to have efficient TSA but now only 2 lines open besides pre, they gave me excuse of shift change. Returned week later and passed area, still long lines with the same amount open. This is all agenda to get people annoyed so they purchase TSA pre for $90. Also there used to be inexpensive food such as McDonald's, Potbelly but now those are gone forcing us to buy $9 hotdogs or $12+ hamburgers. Most places all clone pricing. Also some use signs to block prices unless you get very close to look.

The changes made to the airport are horrible. The food/restaurant choices are horrible and the service is slow. I now get food before going to the airport every time. Also the wait time at security are getting considerably worse, even for TSA-PRE. I went through last week with a friend who didn't have TSA-PRE, and only two scanners were open. It took 35 min for a short line to get processed. This used to be my airport of choice for convenience and my preference for Southwest Airlines. I will start flying from O'Hare if they continue with the decline. Very unhappy customer!

commentHeader: Not a pleasant feeling leaving Chicago
reviewContent: The mayhem to get through security was very unpleasant. After waiting in the long line that wound back to the CTA, I got around and there was a lady in uniform yelling "Precheck open". This encouraged many people to step out of the long line and walk towards what we thought was precheck. Walked all the way in to learn that is was not precheck. Came out and were told to start the line over again. People were unpleasant and mean. I was able to get back in line to then be accosted by people around me. Please work to ensure this doesn't happen to other travelers. Communication will make or break any organization. This could have been certainly prevented by training all personnel on protocol. Not a pleasant feeling leaving Chicago - don't you want visitors leaving in anticipation of returning? Horrible experience!

Terrible terrible restaurants. Their bars are tiny and the service is very slow for food or alcohol. The security line is very unorganized and the TSA people working there couldn’t care less. I’ll fly into O’Hare from this point on and never here again.

The restaurant changes at Midway have been horrible. The quality, prices, choices and service is extremely poor. This was a poor move by Midway. I used to eat my meal at Midway prior to departure and on arrival. I now make sure and eat ahead as it's not worth it. Home Run in pizza may be good but the rest of the menu isn't good, healthy and the service takes forever.

commentHeader: this restaurant change is a travesty
reviewContent: I have used Midway airport regularly for almost 10 years. The recent change in the available restaurants selection has made it so that I don't eat here anymore. As a frequent flyer who has maintained status for every year of that time, this is a problem. They've removed a convenient, and inexpensive (!) Sandwich restaurant (Potbellys) and replaced it multiple times with a restaurant (Home Run Inn) that costs almost 2x as much for a simple sandwich. On the plus side, the new place appears to have the advantage of being slower also with less professional service. Truth be told, I like Home Run Inn Pizza. It's really good and I recommend you try a slice or two when you're in Chicago. However, pizza is more messy to eat than a sandwich. This is a big concern when you have on the same clothes you are going to attend a business meeting in. I like this airport, it's small, convenient and really easy to get around in. But this restaurant change is a travesty for me and food is a necessity. You've taken the normal routine of mild annoyance that air travel had become and taken it too a much higher level of annoyance. Now, I'm annoyed and hungry. One suggestion, maybe they could install a few more electric plugs. I think these cell phones and computers will catch on.

commentHeader: useless amounts of trash from the food court
reviewContent: I fly out of midway on a biweekly basis for business. I give this airport a lot of credit for how they keep the security lines moving fast. One area of suggestion is the useless amounts of trash from the food court. The airport boasts being green but the vendors will give you far more trash then you need. An example is, I went to buy a breakfast sandwich at the Greek place in the food court. They wrapped the sandwich in a sort of wax paper and put it in a small brown paper bag and then put it in a larger paper bag and then put in a fork and a knife and a pile of napkins. I told them a few times that I don't need need the fork, knife and extra bag and they can save I for someone else. So what did he do, he threw it in the garbage. Now, I'm not a crazy tree hugger but this happens every time I eat here. I just think Midway should step up its 'reduce waste' initiative. Thanks!

commentHeader: a functional airport with few frills
reviewContent: As a first-time user, I was satisfied with MDW, both arriving and departing. It is a functional airport with few frills, but it does its job well. The CTA Orange Line provides easy, quick and cheap access to The Loop, another MDW selling-point. TSA pre-check lines were quick, staff courteous too. No complaints about the food offerings before departure: the time passed agreeably in the Windy City Taproom.

commentHeader: food options are nothing but expensive
reviewContent: Supposedly Chicago Midway was upgrading the food options at the airport. Upon my arrival I was quite shocked that the new food options are nothing but expensive and are completely not nutritional whatsoever. At least McDonald's had some healthy choices. Home Run Inn pizza and Dunkin' Donuts appear to be the only food options. Considering the trend has been going in the opposite direction relative to healthy food options, obviously these new vendors were chosen based on how much they are paying in rent. Awful!

commentHeader: plenty of places to eat, drink, and shop
TSA claimed they were not responsible
reviewContent: Yesterday, 5/14/24, we arrived at Memphis airport at 4:55am for 6:05 am flight to Philadelphia. Upon receiving our boarding passes at the kiosk, we noticed a long line of at least 500 passengers waiting to pass through security. The line seemed endless, and we later found out that the airport only had four security checkpoints for over 12 flights scheduled to depart between 6am and 7:30am. When we inquired about the delay, TSA claimed they were not responsible, despite the airline attendant mentioning that TSA's understaffing had been an ongoing issue for morning flights. Due to the long wait, we missed our flight by 11 minutes and were rebooked on a connecting flight to Philly via Charlotte. Shockingly, 70 other passengers (fact) also missed their flight to Charlotte from Memphis. My advice to others is to arrive at least 2 1/2 hours early for flights departing from Memphis. The understaffed TSA seemed indifferent to the chaos, and there were confrontations in the line. Many latecomers appeared distressed, and there was even a member of the Memphis SWAT team present to maintain order before passengers entered the security checkpoint. Good luck! Side note: Huge shout out to Rejoice, the Gate Attendant at American Airlines, for having the patience of a SAINT and getting us on the next connecting flight to Charlotte!

commentHeader: Somebody needs to fix this place
reviewContent: Great MEM airport. This airplane has been here for hours. We’ve been loaded for 30 minutes. Waiting for fuel. Apparently they only have one damned small fuel truck. He fuels a commuter jet and has to go back to the farm before he can do a second one. Fantastic. Crew had to wait 3 hours last night for fuel. Somebody needs to fix this place. Nice terminal but management and operations suck at their jobs.

The airport itself is tidy and seems pleasant. Being a solo traveler with hidden disabilities, I am very pleased with the staff who were able to assist me. They were helpful and kind. So far on my departures, the ques haven't been too long a wait or crazy, timely manner in my experience. Look forward to coming back again as I'm a frequent flyer to this airport.

Appalling Covid prevention measures at the airport. Crowding at security with new rules about food, slowing the process because of confusion about what needs to be removed . No social distancing guidelines at gate and no mask enforcement. People sit wherever they like and pull masks down. I am truly shocked at how Memphis airport operates at the times when there is a mandatory mask mandate in place, and all good businesses work toward social distancing. Would not recommend flying out of Memphis any time soon.
Check in staff was very rude. Team Sports food service was horrible. Lost my order and did nothing to apologize. Time is a factor but they apparently don’t care. Do not go there!

Departure from Memphis. The airport was ok. I regard it as the best airport I experienced during my trip - much better than Newark (EWR) and better than Chicago O'Hare (ORD). The stores and restaurants was plentiful, but the airport is quite small. The staff was friendly and efficient. It was also quite clean, much better than the other airports I passed through this trip in the USA. It was easy to navigate through too. Many small airports are better than their reputation.

United Airlines flight 301 supposed to depart at 5:35am. We are currently still waiting at 6:07am because MFR is using a new 3rd party crew with only 1 person qualified to load luggage. Unacceptable! We pay good money to fly with an airline that makes you feel safe. Now, at 6:19 am were waiting on another company to deice the wings. Flights are made months in advance. The airport and airline were aware that trained ground crew is needed to load a plane along with de icing planes. This is ridiculous!

commentHeader: Rogue Valley Medford Airport customer review

reviewContent: Forget your TSA pre-check here. You are still required to take you belongings out of your bag and go through that disgusting equipment that is almost as bad as being felt up. Add more time to your departure if you want to make your flight on time.

The airport is on the smaller side which usually means shorter TSA lines, especially during non-rush hour times. The airport also tends not to be too crowded but can feel a little tight around the Southwest gates due to their large presence at the airport, but overall the terminal is not very crowded. I have TSA-Pre check and on my last trip through the airport in October of 2018, it probably took less than 2 minutes from when they looked at my boarding pass to when I picked my bag off of the screening belt. Talk about efficient! The parking is also cheap with always plenty of spots available. There is also a small rental car location as well which is more than adequate for an airport of its size. The terminal and the bathrooms are also kept very clean and I've never had too much of a problem. There is also some restaurant variety past the security checkpoint with there being a Starbucks, a sit-down restaurant, Burger King, Dunkin Donuts, Hudson News, and a small bakery. Overall, the regional airport is a nice cheaper option rather than going to the congested Boston Logan airport and is super convenient for anyone living in the Seacoast area. The only downfall of the airport is that most flights are going to have to be connecting flights since they only fly to major hub cities and the planes tend to be smaller regional jets so I recommend to bring a very small carry on or just a backpack since it will have to be gate checked when boarding.

Dunkin donuts coffee shop closing at 6pm on a Saturday night. Ridiculous! Flight gets delayed 1 hour and nowhere to go. Just wrong. You can get alcohol no problem. Wonder why there are issues on fights? There it is.

Every time I arrive from international flights there is confusion, delays and closed sections to go from customs to connecting flights. On this occasion you had to exit the airport security after i rechecked bag then re entere to the terminal, I had duty free bottles of wine so i asked the bag check attendant and told since it's duty free it should be fine... not a chance had to check my back pack and hope it makes it without breaking. Also When Sky train has non functioning station there is a sign for it after you've gone all the way up to the station. I always try to avoid this airport for international entry.

Started with rude traffic officers when my husband was helping bring my 7 year old son across the street. The baggage check is confusing, signs don’t matter and there’s virtually walls of people and no one helping direct you. I was redirected to a different entrance 3 times, even though I was following the signs properly. TSA was rude. No bins for small items or your bags. After getting to the gate it was fine but going through back check and TSA was an intense nightmare. It’s fine for solo travel I guess but traveling through this airport with children was awful

TSA staff rude. Moved about without purpose or care - slowly with apathy. One rep on their phone. 2 security lines open. One line jammed up due to having to take a bag off line to check. Waited 15 minutes in the line. Said they were short staffed and didn’t have anyone to check the bag. When we moved over to the next line because the one we were in directed us to, the other rep yelled at us and said she had customers waiting before us. Are we not also her customers that were waiting? She then glared at us and was whispering to another rep about us. Condescending and rude to travelers. They were laughing at people trying to get through, including airline crew and airport staff for being frustrated. This causes anger and frustration and a poor overall mood for passengers when good and positive attitudes would support happy and positive travelers and less issues on airplanes. Embarrassed for this country with international travelers when other countries are kind and calm to travelers because they know it is important for commerce, mental health, and relations with other people. When we finally made it through there were 15 TSA staff standing just inside the concourse having a meeting. Gate staff were kind as well as the staff at the Juan Valdez coffee shop, otherwise would have given a zero.

Worst customs ever. Consistently crowded and confusing. Staff are condescending and rude. Facilities are dirty. The connecting flights lines were very disorganized and people were panicking had a 2 hour layover barely made it to my connection. Trash bins were overflowing in terminal D. No water stations. Very outdated.

commentHeader: keep a lot of time to complete security
reviewContent: Really sad airport, not clean, equipment breakdowns but keep a lot of time to complete security checks. They do not open multiple security check areas which basically means that up to 10 flights use the small security check areas. It took me 1.5 hours to clear this.

Shameful. A city with the international importance and financial opulence as Miami cannot have third world services and facilities like MIA. I used to like this airport but in the last year there has been a significant decline.
This place must be a joke. No, seriously, how is it even possible an airport like this one in a city like Miami? Worst experience ever. If you are flying to/from Miami please be careful.

What is wrong with the people running this airport? Dirty, no decent restaurants at least on concourse G. Minimal electrical outlets. Bus had to take us to two separate sides to unload the bus. When was this airport built?

commentHeader: What a joke of an airport
reviewContent: Dirty airport. Surly retail people. There was a fight that broke out and I told 2 workers to get police and they couldn’t understand English. What a joke of an airport.

Such a messy place. It’s a very crowded place with not enough staff. Due to air traffic my flight got delayed from the departure city. At the arrival due to the same issue it took us awhile to get off the plane. Once out we had to walk miles to get to the passport control area where we found hundreds of people waiting in line. Many of us having a connection flight and there were only a few agents working so because of this a lot of us were late for the connection flight. After this the check point took even longer to get through and once again not enough staff was there working. Also I had to pick up my luggage and drop it for the connection flight something I never had to do with any other airline. We traveled with American Airlines (not recommended) after getting through all of this we had to walk miles again to get to our gate which was at the very end of the hallway only to let us know that we had lost our flight and there was nothing to do other than placing us at a standby list and hope for the best only because it wasn’t the airline fault. According to the American airlines agent this had to do with the controllers and the air traffic so they wouldn’t offer us a hotel room or food just because this was the airport fault. We ended up spending a whole night there where we couldn’t even get a bag of chips because they got rid of vending machines so they have no food options passed 11 pm. Honestly a pretty bad experience. I’ve been to plenty of airports and they’re never this disorganized. Miami you need to step up!

commentHeader: lowest on my list of airports
reviewContent: I flew in and out of Miami airport twice in Mar 2024. What a zoo! Uber did not find us, Hotel taxi drove past us twice. Getting to the car rental area was long and then waited forever for a car to be taken off campus. This airport is lowest on my list of airports.

I amazes me as European how Americans think everything they have is the best in the world, when it comes to first impressions of a country its main airports fly the flag as to what to expect once you are there. Sadly Miami airport has to be one of the worst organized airports in the world, everything takes forever, the staff are miserable, no one could care less, the facilities / shopping / dining consists of basic third world stuff, the place is grubby, half the elevators don’t work. Place is a dump. Thought that DeSantis bloke was supposed to be good, judging by Miami airport he’s a dunce. Airport looks and feels like everyone has given up. Won’t be flying back through here again, don’t care if it costs more to go through somewhere else, this place just ruins the start or finish of any joinery.

commentHeader: baggage claim was a hell of disorder
reviewContent: Coming into Miami from abroad to connect to a flight in the US none of the walkways worked from Terminal D to passport control nor the Skywalk. the baggage claim was a hell of disorder. Then to go through to-our connection we had to go through security again//really! And the line was unbelievably long, the TSA staff did not give clear instructions about what to put in the bins, bags that had already successfully gone through inspection were shunted off for detailed inspection, which lasted 15minutes. Then we had to walk all the way back through Terminal D to its far end to get to our gate. This is a failure of the Airport Administration.

Worst airport experience in decades. Broken skytrain, walkways, escalators and elevators. Unhelpful and rude staff. Forced to walk miles and wait in lines for hours. Almost missed a connecting flight in the same terminal (D) with 3 hours time. We did not have time to use the restroom, sit down, eat or drink a thing. 3 hours were spent running, hauling bags and waiting in long lines. Staff is rude and goes out of their way to not help you. My 3 year old got hurt and was bleeding from the mouth due to the hazards in this airport and staff not only refused helping her but laughed and talked about how she had fallen in Spanish (which I understand and speak!) . Golf carts meant to replace the sky train do not help even those with children or disabilities (they seem to only help other staff members and chat in their cell). They also broke my bag, however I didn’t have time to file a claim due to the terrible experience. Avoid this airport at all costs!

Our flight was at 7am and Enterprise only opens at 5am. When we finally got everything sorted out it was 5:20 and the elevator as well as the escalators didn’t work so my husband had to carry 4 luggage items up 4 flights of stairs. Then the moving escalator to the train also didn’t work. When we got to the terminal the escalator to the ticket counter didn’t work. The security line wait time was 25mins. Overall terrible experience.

If you're a fan of inefficiency and a dash of the cold shoulder,  venturing into MIA is like stepping into a time machine, and not the cool, futuristic kind. It's more akin to a leap backwards into an era where charm and functionality are myths, and cramped, outdated spaces are the harsh reality.  The staff ability to maintain an aura of indifference in the face of any question or plea for help is truly commendable. It's as if they've taken the concept of 'the cold shoulder' and elevated it to an art form. Navigating the airport is akin to participating in an escape room you never signed up for. The layout is so cramped and convoluted. It’s clear the design was inspired by a labyrinth, with a dash of "let's see how many people we can confuse before noon." Calling it 'old and dated' is a kindness. It's as if the airport is stuck in a bygone era, stubbornly refusing to join us in the 21st century. The charm of yesteryear has certainly overstayed its welcome here. But the pièce de résistance has to be the TSA security clearance - a spectacle so inefficient and embarrassing, it deserves its own reality TV show. The TSA staff, not wanting to be outdone by their airport colleagues, take rudeness to new heights, skirting the line of abusiveness with a finesse that would make a drill sergeant blush. It's a process so fraught with frustration, you'd think it was designed as a test of human endurance. In an era where digital connectivity is akin to oxygen, MIA somehow manages to turn free WiFi into a luxury item. Thanks to the generosity of American Express, passengers can access the internet, provided they have the patience to sit through ads. It's a charming reminder of the dial-up era, a nostalgic throwback that no one asked for. The concept of passenger experience seems to be an alien one at MIA. From the lack of food outlets to the scarcity of lounges, it's as if they're pioneering a new minimalist approach to airport amenities - less is more, and in the case of MIA, much less. In conclusion, if you're seeking an airport experience that combines the charm of a Soviet-era bus station with the efficiency of a sloth, look no further than Miami International Airport. It's an adventure you won't forget, no matter how hard you try. I wholeheartedly advise anyone to avoid this horrible, dingy, old, awful airport at all costs. It's truly a masterclass in how not to run an airport.
Over 2 hours in immigration line. Miami Airport is a disorganized mess and no one seems to care. Non citizens line must have been 3 or 4 hours judging by the lines. Disgraceful.

Avoid this airport whenever possible. We have travelled over 10 times and going through Miami on an international flight is by far going to be your worst experience. Do not go through with a short connection. They are unorganized and mismanaged. For such a busy airport you would think they had a great system. Send your management to Japan or any other US airport to see how to do it. Hire someone that wants to improve.

My experience at this airport was terrible. I was connecting through Miami in a flight to Barcelona (Spain). The connection was quite short (90 mins) due to an earlier delay in the first flight. The lines for passport control were massive, I have never seen anything like it, so I asked the staff if there was a priority line for connections and emphasised my short connection. After a bit of confusion and me having done most of the regular line, eventually someone came and handed us the orange cards and we went into a separate queue. The short connection queue was still quite long, so I requested one of the staff if he could organise it prioritising those with flights leaving earliest, like my own. I was understandably quite nervous about missing my flight, as I was travelling with my mother, a senior with a disability. The gentleman said he couldn’t do anything and that I had to wait, I insisted that the system was making little sense but was in no way disrespectful. Another passenger was allowed to go to the front of the queue however, which I thought was unfair particularly to me as I was the one with the earliest flight. I also can’t understand as a key international hub there isn’t any organisation whatsoever to connecting flights

Miami Airport is a disgrace to Florida. Filthy areas with rubbish left everywhere and disorganized staff! The immigration and security staff were extremely rude to everyone lining up. I would not recommend this airport ever again as this airport needs to seriously improve. Seeing an airport looking filthy, no carpets, and disgraceful staff is absolutely disappointing and it seriously needs to improve if it wants to step into competing with different airports! Disgraceful place and avoid at all costs!

This is the worst airport I’ve ever been. The security check is extremely slow and the staff are very rude. It took us about an hour to go through the security checkpoint and we missed our flight. We have to stay an extra day at Miami and we missed our family gathering for New Year’s Eve. The airport design is so poor, if you went to the gate A-D and you want to go to gate E or F, you have to come out completely and redo the security check. So if your gate is at E or F, you can’t enjoy the priority lounge which locates at gate D. The security staff asked us to check in our prepaid carryon luggage as she thinks it is bigger than the standard size although we measure the size at home and it fits the measurements of the allowed carryon according to the airline instructions. So combined with the worst airline the Frontier our vacation is ruined although Miami is a beautiful city, we don’t want to come back.

commentHeader: will never fly through here again
reviewContent: This airport shows no compassion or consideration for those citizens from around the world who arrive at its doors. A two hour wait in stifling heat, shuffling forwards to an area where just 6 booths were in operation to take account of the thousands of people arriving no water or seating provided. After dealing with COVID and all of its implications Miami has learnt nothing and appeared to move at a pace that was unable or unwilling to respond to the numbers amassing. I can honestly say that I will never fly through here again and I can only pass this information on to those yet to experience it.

Horrific. Does not acknowledge disabilities unless you have a wheelchair. My daughter has severe autism and we were told it doesn’t matter unless she was in a wheelchair. Next time we know to rent a wheelchair to get the help needed for a child with a disability. I don't know how they can completely ignore the Americans with disabilities act and still receive federal funding

commentHeader: I will avoid it at all costs
reviewContent: Our arriving plane had to sit on the tarmac for 25 to 30 minutes because there was no gate available. This made us late to our connecting flight, since the gate for that was about a mile away and this skytrain was broken, which I understand is as usual. I can’t walk that far and was so exhausted after clearing passport control, US customs, TSA, and then getting to the faraway gate. My American Airlines rep was not overly helpful or friendly either. The whole experience makes me never want to go there again. I will avoid it at all costs.

The arrival process is shambolic. It took us 90 minutes to get through immigration. The queuing is poorly organized to the extent that you have to queue to enter the main queue, but as nothing is organized, there are loads of people milling all over the place. The immigration officer, once we got to the front of the queue was pleasant and friendly enough, but looked as though she had seen enough for the day too. Oh and of course only about half the booths were manned. Remember that immigration is the first thing that visitors see when they arrive in the USA. It's almost as though the country was trying to discourage tourists from coming.

This is a horrible airport. The signage is difficult to find. The bathroom was dirty. You had to walk miles because the skytrain was broken. Based on earlier reviews this has been the case for a long time. Asked people for directions to rental cars and nobody was able to help. Information desk or better signs would be useful. Avoid this airport if you can and Uber/Lyft rather than renting a car which was a separate disaster.

I was disappointed with Miami airport on my departure on Oct 11, 2023, and then became even more disappointed upon my arrival on Oct. 18. The airports "SkyTrain" was not operational, and they had limited number of carts to help those in need. I am 73 years old but having to walk from baggage check-in (around gate 20) to gate 45 was not a pleasant experience. According to a friend, the Skytrain has been broken for about 6 months. I only witnessed two golf carts for seniors while walking about a half mile to my gate. Deplorable. To make matters worse, there was one section where the AC was broken. You think they would contract with a vendor to provide golf cart service above their normal service if the SkyTrain was out of order. My arrival was almost worse with a 1/2 to 3/4 mile walk with NO CARTS and NOT ONE OPERATIONAL PEOPLE MOVER (flat escalator). Try to avoid this airport at all costs, especially if you are elderly. They did have AED's. Now I know why.

This is the most mismanaged airport that I have encountered in over 500,000 miles of travel.  Poor signage (DFW successfully redid all of their signs a few years ago). We were directed in the wrong direction several times. Asking employees for directions was no help because they did not know where baggage claim 6 was either.  Poor maintenance - Most elevators were out of service, and had apparently been so for months or years, since the signs directing you to the next working elevators were ragged and worn.  Restrooms not serviced - no paper towels or air dryers. Transportation services not available - the train was not operable; the golf carts were sitting unused with no driver. This was in Terminal D which is almost a mile long. When we arrived on an international flight we had an extremely long walk to customs and there were no chairs in which to rest.  There were unreasonably long distances to walk to immigration and customs - sometimes the signs sent domestic and international passengers in different directions, only for them to join again. The signs indicating which line to get in were confusing - we saw dozens of people being moved from one line to another.  It was very difficult to find hotel shuttles, and they are located in a dark area across several roads from the terminal. The electrical outlets in our seats had no power.  The entire design of the airport appeared to be by an architect who specializes in corn mazes.

I was traveling through MIA last weekend and found so many problems. There is no-one at the information desks. and when i ask some employees for some help, they ignored me or gave me bad information. Where are the friendly volunteers like other airports? Why are so many elevators not working and/or dirty? Perhaps MIA should retrain their employees.

commentHeader: disappointed and embarrassed of our airport
reviewContent: I was born and raised in Miami Dade County and so disappointed and embarrassed of our airport. Restrooms need maintenance, the acoustics throughout are poor and transportation is either non existent or impaired. My flight had a gate change at the last minute. The gates were about a football field apart. I hitched a ride on one of many wheel chairs, but got off soon as woman was suggesting she expected a tip. The security was unorganized, crowded. Management needs a good management system. It's done at other airports in Florida, successfully. The whole airport looks like it has patchwork construction and design, archaic layout. Wheelchairs and transport buses running where people walk! Gate signs don't make sense. I had to ask people where to find everything. Loud speaker sometimes can't be heard, sometimes loud. Terrible!! Where is our tax payer money going. It's certainly not going to this place. Governor DeSantis needs to overhaul the management. Tampa has a beautiful airport, comfortable, organized and beautiful restrooms. Jacksonville too...What the heck is going on in Miami??

commentHeader: have more regard for the elderly
reviewContent: This is a plea for Miami and all other international airports to have more regard for the elderly at the airports. =I am 82 and walk much slower than before and standing in the one spot is a struggle. I arrived somewhere in Miami Terminal E after a horrid BA flight, walked for 20 minutes to the Immigration Area where I waited an hour before my turn came and then I walked some 30 minutes to a lounge at D 30 and then had to take a small train to the gate. I do not mind the walking if there are the electric walking lanes that are working but the standing in lines is a strain. - I have occasionally used a wheelchair but these are often promised but do not arrive. My other problem was going through security at Miami where I was told to keep my shoes on although I have artificial knees but then the person at the screening told me to take them off which is more difficult than the young may imagine.

Our originating flight from Miami to Belize was 3 hours late. When arriving in Miami the customs line was a mile long - no exaggeration - I have video and photo. There were maybe a handful of officers to handle customs and thousands of passengers. We missed our connection. From standing in line for 2 hours. Then after getting baggage another line to leave so add another hour because 1 man was letting people out. Then a line of 550 feet to get vouchers from American Airlines. We did not wait because was already 10:30pm. No employees here to assist thousands of people. Same experience this morning. Stood in two huge lines to check in and get through security due to few employees working. Now we arrive at our gate, and not even half enough seats to sit in to wait. Meanwhile, remodeling is furiously happening. Perhaps Miami airport should hire people to work rather than remodel right now. Complete inept and terrible customer service.

An absolutely disgusting airport! The most uncomfortable airport with lack of services that are found in most other airports in the U.S. Had an overnight stay, a loud buzzer sounded every 3 seconds from midnight to now 5.40 am, escalators going down operated but those going up were not functioning. The sky train was not operating for hours preventing me from being able to go to purchase water. This is not the only occasion that this has happened, it's just a poorly run airport!

Poor signage, everything was broken. Elevators, moving sidewalks, bathrooms were filthy, not enough charging and if you find a wall plug your plug literally falls out of outlet. Overall a dirty airport. Forget going to a gate if you are looking for selection of restaurants.

Miami airport is the most disgusting airport I’ve ever been in. The once-blue carpets are black in most places and appear to have never been washed. Littered with food and trash everywhere - and the bathrooms are as back as a filthy run down gas station. I’m looking around as I write this and literary every service is filthy - the floor, the seats, the columns holding up the ceiling. Not just dusty, not just some loose rubbish - truly filthy. Avoid at all costs.

commentHeader: beneath those of many third world nations
reviewContent: I clear customs and collected my bag. I exited customs only to discover that the sign saying, Checked Baggage, abruptly ended as I found myself unsure where to bring my bag in the middle of the airport. I asked the single officer on duty. He had no idea. There was no there to assist passengers, only a pair of women behind a booth selling phone cards. The lack of signage or any personnel to guide passengers is shocking, and makes me think that Miami Airport has worse service (and security protocols) than airports in less developed nations. But I don’t think anyone in Miami or Florida gives a damn. Your standards are beneath those of many third world nations.

This airport is a joke! The worst airport I ever been! Who ever is the manager should be sacked straight away. 2.5h waiting in the longest line ever, 3 officers behind the desk not rushing at all. At some point was only two of them and amount of people waiting more and more. Another airport in US which is 100 years behind of any airport in Europe - shame on you!

I’m embarrassed for the U.S. that this airport is a “gateway” for so many people. My flight from Dallas Love Field arrived in the G Concourse which reminds me of the old New York LaGuardia terminal. Low ceilings, narrow walkways, dirty, dark, interior. I made my way to ground transportation which was a nightmare. The signage is confusing and with the proliferation of ride share apps like Uber, Lyft, etc., one would think there would be ample signage. The entire ground transportation area is confusing, with inadequate signage. Then, there are the airport staff. I had trouble getting a Lyft, and decided to take a cab. The cab driver told me that since I was going to Hilton Airport Blue Lagoon, I had to take a “blue” taxi. I asked an airport ground transportation worker for directions and he pointed and said, “at the end.” I never found the blue taxi and finally ended up waiting for my hotel’s courtesy van for another 30 minutes.  Upon arrival back to the airport for my departing flight, the same chaos ensued. I arrived at the airport at 8:00 a.m. for my 11:55 a.m. flight back to Dallas. Since I had time to spare, I went to the Star Alliance Lounge between H and J. Security checkpoint was horrible. Crowded, confusing, and I was in the line for the TSA Pre-Check which they were merging with the CLEAR and general security screening. Employees are brash, if not just downright rude. The walkway between H and J was much nicer; except for the restrooms. Wow - I think they imported these from old gas stations. Dark, dirty, in disrepair. I finally made my way to the Star Alliance Lounge. The entrance to the elevator from the concourse level is two double doors that made me think I was going into the back kitchen of an old diner. Followed, by a dirty elevator with taped signage directing me to the lounge. The walk from the elevator to the lounge entrance made me think I was in the wrong place, but I kept walking and eventually found it. Finally a nice escape from the worst airport I’ve ever experienced.

This airport is filthy. There is dust under the chairs, food, and trash all over the floor. There are very limited food choices and they automatically charge 18% gratuity. The guy was so rude and did not deserve a tip. If I ever have a choice in the future, I will not pass through this airport. Also, there is not enough seating at the gates. The charging station has 4 slots and you have to stand near it to charge your phone. So pathetic.

Dirty airport. I can see the dirt on the overhead pipes where I am waiting for the departure. I am tired to see the airport not cleaning and not keeping up. We don't have any other choice to use other airport to travel and this airport needs new management.

I only came across people who spoke Spanish, and they were constantly chit-chatting. It seems as though we are interrupting their conversation when we pose a question or offer advice. For the same reason, the customer support is nonexistent. The coffee served at the terminal is bitter, of poor quality, and overly priced for subpar coffee. At 7 a.m., the airport's tables were already dirty, and people were chit-chatting in their coffee shops rather than cleaning them. I assume that even though people work and are paid to help others, the interruption of their conversation to answer questions or offer advice causes them inconvenience. Our TSA cards and Global Entry cards don't seem to signify anything.

What a horrible experience! I have never seen an airport with no sit down restaurants, rude employees, and very limited accommodations to sit and wait for hours. Never again, I will fly into Fort Lauderdale next time I leave Miami on a cruise, this place is a dump - not a fan of much in Miami!

Nightmare! International arrival Passport/Customs takes forever, need to go to checkin again and TSA (without precheck available) idiotic. A woman in TSA line making smarmy comments about people’s luggage icing on the cake. Avoid this dump.

The logistics and operations of their international arrivals (customs and the baggage check and re-check) is a complete shambles and needs to be completely reconstructed, organized and properly staffed. When 2.5 hours is insufficient to ensure making your connecting flight something is wrong. We witnessed dozens of missed connections on 3/18 due mainly to the baggage carousel in the international arrivals terminal. A complete zoo. Several Inoperable escalators and moving walkways further complicated passenger movements. We recommend avoiding international transfers through Miami whenever possible.

commentHeader: This place needs a total revamp
reviewContent: This airport is a joke. Rude staff, zero directions, and disgusting upkeep. They promote reducing plastic bottles yet only provide unsanitary drinking fountains to refill your water bottle. Good luck finding facilities that are even remotely clean let alone any food that isn’t cooked beyond consumption or the price you could get a decent meal elsewhere for. Security is a complete nightmare due to lack of communication, ticketing is so archaic you may as well have a punch style ticket. Save yourself the hassle and fly out of Ft. Lauderdale or Tampa. This place needs a total revamp from the ground up.

My recent experience connecting through MIA was absolutely atrocious. My wife and I flew into Miami from the Caribbean, where we were connecting to a flight back to our home in San Diego. Getting through Customs with our Global Entry status was a breeze. But then MIA put all connecting international passengers into one gigantic line to get through security. There was no TSA PreCheck. The line was agonizingly slow. When we finally cleared security, we had to sprint more than 30 gates to get to our connecting flight. We made it with just a few minutes to spare. When I later emailed a complaint into TSA, I received an automated response. I have never been to any other U.S. airport that didn't offer PreCheck. That a major airport like MIA doesn't offer the service is inexcusable. If you're connecting internationally, avoid this airport if you can.

Got off an American flight from Ecuador. First, none of the escalators were working so we all had to drag heavy baggage up a couple flights of stairs to get into immigration.
