Although I was in group 1 boarding it was hogged up by people from groups 2 and 3. But gate agents were great at policing the boarding process. I agree the prices at MIA are outrages. $3.50 for a bottle of water!

Very large airport but, simple and logical. You can use the airport train within your way to the gate. Crowded but fast secuity check. Clean restrooms. Free Metromover to Car Rental Centrum. The staff is helpful and kind.

All the restaurants nd bars that I've been to have been a rip off! Lousy food, nobody there cares the least about quality, and they charge huge prices. $17 for a lousy burger at Spring Chicken, 10 oz tap beer is $9.50, Islander Bar & Grill near D8 shows certain prices out front only to find that for a margarita you order house version they charge for Patron Silver, they charge separately for mix and tequila so it gets to $16. Two very lousy margaritas and one Heineken $48! When you inquire about that they just say, "Hey, its in the airport! What do you expect?" MIA is a complete rip-off! Spent over $100 for a lousy small fast food meal and a couple drinks and all I got in addition was a very bad attitude! I can get a bad attitude for free most places.

Layout is horrible. Security lines are disorganized and are very far away from departure gates. Skytrain is a good idea but signs aren't clear how frequently they run. Staff are very nice but I feel like I'm being made to traverse the entire length of the airport whenever I'm here. Will use FLL instead given the opportunity.

Miami airport continues to compare with a third world facility. Dirty, disorganized, poor service (to put it mildly). Shops all sell the same useless wares, and automated distributors out of order. Sad place.

commentHeader: disgusted at the level of service
reviewContent: I am disappointed and disgusted at the level of service at the Miami Airport. We arrived from Costa Rica a family of four, which we had booked our reservations as a family. We were told to stay together through the screening, through customs all the way, which we did. However, the chaos began as soon as we arrived at the Miami airport. My ticket was pre-check as we thought all four would be since they were all booked under my name as the lead person. We were instructed to go to the two different check-points. After being turned around twice, I informed the young lady that we had gone through this twice. If we had to come back, a manager is going to have to get involved. She instructed us to go back to checkpoint three because” the staff member there was new and didn’t know what she was telling us.” We went back, and sure enough, the staff member began to tell us to separate again. I told her what the previous employer had said to us, she pulled up our ticket on her phone and told us to go ahead. I couldn’t believe the level disconnect of communication here in the United States; there is a lot to be learned from Liberia Airport. Courtesy and politeness from the employees for starters. We finally arrived at our gate for departure. As we sat there trying to listen for the changes of gates. The intercom system is not the best; one could barely hear the changes. We saw so many travelers missing their flight and upset, as they should have been. The announcement should have been clear, and anyone on that flight name should have been called before that plane departed. I felt bad for those that were unable to hear the message in the mist of all the chaos. I’m sure that with all the upgrades in technology the intercom system can be much better, employee interaction should be superior. Staff should act as if they want to assist you and not as if they owe you something, remember we are “paying” travelers whether by awards or by credit cards we have paid for service and should be treated with politeness, respect, and clear communication.

Twice disappointed with the service at the transportation center. I understand that the staff may want to be friendly but they appear to be selectively friendly. I was trying to make a train; the person at the kiosk was having a leisurely chat and had no time to help me with my questions. He misinformed me, pointing me to the ticket machine and stating that I first had to purchase a ticked on the level where he was. Even after I had the ticket he still was talking and giving his opinions on some subject and did not stop talking to assist. The area was not crowded, but I had to figure things out myself. When I got down to the tracks there were ticket machines I could have bought a ticket. But by the time I had traipsed my luggage down the stairs (no mention or direction regarding an elevator) the train had departed. It being a Sunday afternoon I had to wait another hour. A week earlier, I had to wait for more than 5 minutes while the kiosk person spoke to another traveler about where he grew up and the schools he went to. Like I say, friendly—I get it—but isn’t the job one of helping travelers get from one place to another?

It is sad to see that for arriving International passengers they must pay $5 USD if they need an airport baggage cart. That's quite expensive and foreigners may not have American money to pay besides being alot of money for a cart. International arriving passengers may have alot of luggage they need to claim and transfer after a long flight. I have not seen having to pay for a luggage cart in most International destinations. It's a sad comment to welcome them to the land of the free and the home of the brave.

The sky train is an awesome idea but how difficult is it to put a sign in front of the gates “closest sky train at gate xxxx”. You land and you don’t know if one is right around a corner or the other way. Again great concept, horrible execution when a simple directional sign could fix it.

Flew into MIA on September 26 from Madrid and out on October 2, going back, both legs on Iberia. Despite of what is being said compared to other airports, Miami worked quite all right for us. On arrival there were some works and had to walk longer than necessary, but went through immigration and an acceptable speed. All staff were polite. At arrivals got the chance to buy a US sim card. Waiting for hotel shuttle was tiring after a long flight, as there was not enough seating there. Also, TSA at MIA is much faster than at Orlando airport. Most importantly, arriving from Orlando on American Airlines and having to pick up luggage, as we didn't have a through ticket, and having to check in for Iberia was not bad! We just had to walk straight on from the AA part of the airport to that of Iberia. No need for elevators, or shuttles! Spanish-speaking staff are polite and courteous and do make an effort to help out. Overall, we have a positive impression of Miami!

Poor organization of the planes and gates. Our incoming flight had trouble having a free gate to arrive at. Our departure gate has been changed twice and delayed by 2 hours. Their explanation was that they were waiting for a plane to get out of a hangar.

Probably the worst airport experience I've ever had. I was only there for a connection as I was travelling from MBJ- MIA then back to the UK. Customs in the UK is so simple and quite quick considering. The staff were so rude at customs in particular at security, they ignored you pretending they were speaking on the radio and couldn't hear. When we had to get our ESTA tickets it was a shambles as we had to do everything in 1.5 hours in time for the connecting flight. Instead of managing the queues one particular staff member kept shouting at me because I was using a different kiosk from my dad, which makes no sense because those questions were long so if there is a kiosk next to him it makes sense to use that - as I did on my way here 5 days ago. Other people were using more than one kiosk but she spent her time focusing on me instead of organising the queue. She kept shouting saying 'Mam Mam Mam' you can't use the kiosk, despite telling her 2 times our connecting flight was soon. The guy at customs was so rude, I'm sure that if you are travelling with a family member you're supposed to go up with them? But, we got yelled at and only my dad was allowed to go, I eventually went up and then a few seconds the customs guy called up another man who was after me - assuming he was my dad, I had to tell him we were not travelling together. In addition, we had to rush through security bear in mind by this point we only had 25 minutes left until we boarded the plane. My dad tried to ask one of the security women a question and she just pretended that she was listening to her radio and that it was so important, she didn't even acknowledge my dad. We kept telling them we were boarding in 25 minutes and no-one cared. Also when they give out blue cards when you go through security - the ones that determine whether you take your shoes off or not/take out your laptop. I just wanted to double check if I needed one as my dad got one and a few people before him did and she just shouted to 'go in that line'. Surprisingly we made the flight, and it was delayed by 45 minutes due to the manifest being typed up incorrectly.

I've never been to a more confusing airport in my life. The signs were not straightforward. On our boarding pass, it said Terminal CE, but none of its signs stated that, it will state Concourse and a list of letters that did not make any sense to us, which was not helpful at all. Our flight was delayed by 5 hours because the captain was unable to arrive at the Miami airport due to the weather in Tampa, which is completely reasonable. However, the situation could've been handled much better. The people that worked outside the gate were unhelpful. They pretty much expected everyone to have smart phones and therefore were negligent in giving us, customers, regular updates as to when our flight will arrive. They only updated people who stood waiting in line for 15 minutes, instead of just efficiently announcing it to the general public, not that their updates were helpful to the individuals that stood in line because they kept pushing it to every hour, so it was very hard for customers to plan accordingly. By giving us an incorrect ETA, we were not able to decide whether to rebook to another flight or not. If we had known that the flight was going to be delayed for 5 hours, we would've gotten on a different flight. But the people at the gate kept ensuring us that it would only be an hour delayed, and then another hour if we asked again and again. This misinformation is unacceptable. In addition, the airport was freezing. I had to wait in line for 30 minutes at the Service Center for blankets to be told there were no clean blankets. I would check in with them a few more times and was told there were still no clean blankets available, during this 5 hours waiting period, this huge international airport did not think to provide blankets. So not only was my flight delayed, I caught a fever due to waiting at the cold airport for 5 hours, and had to call out of work the next day.

Dealing with a late international arrival, my connection was on time and I really had to hustle! Signage was confusing for getting to baggage, collecting it, navigating customs, rechecking bag and then security finally! It was around 6am and MIA was well staffed at every turn and due to crowds and rushing I overlooked my laptop and ipad after scanning all my carry on stuff. I was down the hallway running to flight when they caught me and delivered those! Thanks Miami TSA!

The people running this airport should not be aloud to pump gas. Unbelievable immigration, baggage claim, security checks. It’s like every employees first day. "Your flight boards in 5 minutes" (should have left 40mins ago), "Your flight is now boarding at a different gate" (1/2 mile away), "Now boarding in 40 more minutes". Never again.

Another delay on arrival and baggage wait. Not sure why these “lightning delays” only happen at MIA and not FTL or other South Florida area airports. Flight arrived at 8:30, it’s now 10:30 and still waiting on bag. Best to not check in bag for MIA arrival, or fly through other airport. You would think whoever runs the place would find the way to do better.

This airport is the most unorganized establishment, and my experience here was horrific. Security check in terminal D was where I needed to be at. Without explanation, I was asked to go to Checkpoint E. Get to checkpoint E, asked to go to F (10 min walk). Get to F, go through security, walk 10 min to just come back to see the original security checkpoint area I was supposed to go through! Absolutely unacceptable. Working for a city, my self, I am appalled at this airports lack of customer service. You want to attract tourists, get your airport crew on the same page, talk about customer service to be a number one priority! Take a page from my city airport system - Houston Airport systems...look them up!

I have never experienced a travel experience as horrible as that of the Miami International Airport. From Check-in, all the way through TSA. The whole system is a disorganized, unprofessional mess. There was not one indication of competence anywhere in that hellish place. I promise that I will never visit Miami again. No way will I risk going through that again!

I have been traveling throughout the western states for the past week and a half. I have been in 7 different states, and unfortunately, my home state of Florida, the airport is by far the dirtiest. It is an embarrassment. The floors, the bathrooms, the seats are filthy. Developing countries have more pride and cleanliness.

commentHeader: staff members have the worst attitude
reviewContent: Horrible airport. Signs were not clear for security check points and terminal J TSA sent us all the way to H security check point for precheck only to be routed through the wrong line. Terminal employees cut in line and held the line up at check points. All Bathrooms are nasty, staff members have the worst attitude and lack professionalism. Restaurant was fully staffed but no one was “working”. Obviously there was a full bar and no one knew how to make a Mojito. Hope I don’t have to move through Miami soon.

It's a pity, that such a nice, big airport, has women's toilets so smelly and dirty. I refer specifically to the bathroom that is next to checkpoint # 3 (American Airline). It's the dirtiest bathroom I've seen since I live in USA. I hope this serves to improve the hygiene conditions of it.  Es una pena,que un Aeropuerto tan bonito y concurrido ,tenga los baños de mujeres tan malolientes y sucios.Me refiero especificamente al baño que esta al lado del punto de control#3 (American Airline). Es el baño mas sucio que yo he visto desde que vivo en Usa . espero que esto sirva para que mejoren las condiciones higienicas del mismo.

The airport is clean and easy to navigate, you don't have to walk miles between gates. There are not so many restaurants as one might expect, but there is a sufficient variety of dining options. Arrivals: Passport control lines are long, but that is the case in most places. The "fastrack" option or using an automated machine and then passing a receipt to the officer actually takes longer because you have to take 5 minutes to use the machine and then join the back of the queue of people who didn't use it. As always the staff shout at you like they are herding cattle. Departures: Check-in is simple and well signposted, queues are short as there are a lot of desks. Security takes a while, the priority line is not much shorter than the main lines. As with most Americans the staff are very rude and unpleasant. One of them pointed at me and shouted "shoes" whilst another shook his head and announced to the waiting line "we shouldn't have to tell y'all the obvious". It transpired this obnoxious exchange was in fact their attempt to ask me to remove my footwear and place it in the scanning machine, something I would say about 30 percent of airports require, so to me not obvious. But perhaps it was obvious to "y'all".

commentHeader: it is not a pleasant airport
reviewContent: Can MIA achieve any level of competence? I have long boycotted it and advised others to avoid for immigration purposes, and it is not a pleasant airport to negotiate in terms of TSA security. But I did opt to use for transiting between BA6578 (operated by AA) TPA-MIA and BA0208 MIA-LHR on 21 May. On paper, I had two hours for the transit. Flying time between TPA and MIA is just 37 minutes, but weather-related issues made for a TPA departure that was 20 minutes late. On landing at MIA, we then taxied to a halt that lasted 40-45 minutes before a gate was found for us. Pax with tight connections grew anxious as we waited. The AA captain himself lost patience with the false promises of any early move to a gate. A rush to connecting gates and disgustingly dirty bathrooms ensued when we finally deplaned. BA0208 was just starting to board when I finally reached my gate. This was located in a subterranean area of stygian gloom, the waiting customers looking like lost souls, doubtless with their own negative opinions of MIA.

commentHeader: hard to find the luggage claim area
reviewContent: My family and I traveled from Miami to Rhode Island with Frontier Airlines - great deals, by the way. Overall I have to say our experience at the airport was fair. It was hard to find the luggage claim area after we landed and it seems like most people there spoke Spanish. One good thing I have to say is we used www.parkon.com/mia for our airport parking reservations. Great ROI. I like that MIA is expanding and upgrading it's features.
Absolutely awful. At least 90 minutes to transfer from Jamaica to Raleigh even though we were traveling in first and had both Global Entry and TSA pre. Total chaos.

We went on a trip to Orlando and because we couldn't find a fair price for a flight we opted to fly out of Miami. We arrived at midnight so not much to be said about that. Arrival and luggage was ok as was the transportation to the rental cars. On the way back home however, we 'experienced' this airport. The security lines were horrible. Everyone walks around at an immensly slow speed. One person can't be bothered with helping out others. No real info on who needs to go through regular detection gates and who needs to be bodyscanned. Our carry ons were taken apart after being scanned and it took one single security officer about half an hour before he went through our stuff to check. I don't mind that my carry ons need extra screening for whatever reason but please, do it at a decent speed. The security lines were chaotic at best. Once through security I can't say the airport was dirty but the amenities were very limited as was the seating. Once home I also noticed that the TSA cut the security belt around my suitcase open with bolt cutters, even when it had a TSA lock. And they must have had a key since the suitcase as well had a security TSA lock which was correctly opened. I also put a special cloth sleeve around my suitcase to protect it from wear and scratches which I didn't even bother putting back on. When waiting, there is free WiFi but only for 45 minutes. Great when WiFi was a novelty but nowadays simply incomprehensible. Miami Airport is truly on my to-avoid-list of airports now. I guess when visiting Orlando and the airfare is to expensive, you are even better off flying to Atlanta and drive to Orlando.

Never change here if you can avoid it. Took nearly 2 hours to get through immigration and then we had to run through airport and push to the front of security in order to make our connecting flight (which we had already allowed a 2 hours layover for!). The staff couldn't understand what they were doing, we were queuing into an area where we had to get ESTA receipts and then 45 mins later another load of planes arrive and get guided into a similar area which is inexplicably not being used, with the result that people who had arrived 45 mins after us got through immigration quicker due to poor poor queue management. Cannot understand why those on connecting flights need to do the immigration process, transferring in the UK doesn't require this and it seems really unnecessary when you aren't even leaving the airport.

As an American citizen, I can say that the Miami Internationals airport customs was the worst we experienced after visiting at least 8 other countries in Southeast Asia. Why is there not a separate line for Americans? Every other country does this. Why do I have to wait 2 hours in line so that someone can approve my customs information in 2 minutes! I pay taxes and the salaries of custom officials - foreigners don’t - so make it easy for your own citizens to pass through. How hard is that to understand. Every other country we visited understand that. But, that’s US government for you.

From the moment we got off the plane every single employee we encountered in customs and immigration were disrespectful, rude and even down right mean. One gentleman’s job was specifically to tell people which line to filter into and yet he managed to sound extremely annoyed with every human being he came in contact with. The line was painfully long in immigration especially for the non-citizens and when I tried to ask a question to one employee she interrupted me mid question to tell me to keep walking. She treated the next two people who approached her in this same manner. The two women trying to organize the line did it by yelling and talking in bossy, annoyed tones to the hundreds of innocent people who were all just trying to do what they said. When someone made a mistake, heaven forbid if you didn’t exactly understand what “go to the end” means when the room is the size of a football field, then that poor person was berated by the employee who then walked away shaking her head as if every human was an idiot. After our first two negative interactions I started talking to my kids about how we should treat people. They could see how the employees we treating everyone and they could tell that we were just trying to obey whatever “rules” were in place to avoid being singled out. Unfortunately we saw employees act like school yard bullies well over a dozen times and didn’t see one kind exchange in the entire 2 hours that we spent in the Miami airport. Chaotic and horrible.

Returned from overseas through Miami and it was the absolutely worst customs and transfer process I have ever experienced. If this is our “front door” to the world, I am embarrassed to imagine what overseas travelers must think. I have cleared customs in many other countries and they all put their best foot forward. Not so in Miami. Entire process took over two hours, airport is dirty and worms out, and never once did anyone try to assist with ensuring the process was understood. Then that had only one screening line open to get to your transfer and no TSA pre-check, so that took 45 minutes itself. We barely made our connection and had nearly a 3 hour layover! Embarrassing!

Miami airport was literal chaos. The employees were just shouting directions, which were unclear and confusing. I witnessed not 1 but 2 different employees talking down to people - one of which was a man who did not speak English. They were shouting at everyone to “keep moving, don’t stop.” At the security point they told us to keep our shoes on and don’t take anything out of our carry on bags to get us through the line faster. In my opinion this jeopardises the security of everyone there for the sake of speediness. The employees were rude and the entire process of catching my conncecting flight was chaotic.

One of the worst handled airports. Everybody knows that Miami has a very busy airport. The waiting time in the lines are however ridiculously long. The airport has obviously not been adapted to its increase number of customers. Waiting time going was at least 1 and a half hours. On the way back definitely shorter (30 to 45 minutes which is adequate) however at the expense of the politeness of staff. The immigration and security officers are extremely rude and obnoxious - amongst the worst I've experienced not only in the U.S.. How ironic to have staff shout "computers ain't gonna take themselves out of bags" and "dont you have a flight to catch" standing right next to a display saying that employees need to be patient and nice to travelers. Not everyone is a frequent flyer and most aren't familiar with airport procedures. The airport is clean however (toilets, floors and transportation) and the wifi works perfectly

commentHeader: courtesy and pleasantness goes a long way"
reviewContent: Horrible experience. The staff were unbelievably rude. My husband went to sit in a chair not knowing it was a handicapped only area and was told to rudely “get out of here”. When we were at the wrong entrance we were again yelled at loud enough for everyone to hear. We got an ice cream at Haagen Daz and were ignored as the two workers chit chatted while we stood there waiting. Then there were paper liners on the inside of the cone. I went into the ladies room and the cleaning woman proceeded to yell at me as I apparently went to the side she was still cleaning on and pointed at me telling me “you! You use this side only!” A little courtesy and pleasantness goes a long way when you deal with the public. I will never use this trashy, obnoxious hole again.

Miami Airport where the third world meets the USA. We arrived with no hassles as we had gone through US immigration and customs in Dublin. On the way back packed into a very small room, poor lighting, no investment to make the process slicker and no management. When the screening machine stopped working our line was told to cut into the other two lines. At this stage people have been waiting an hour to get to this stage so lots of grumpy unhappy travellers in all the lines. Make America Great Again - Come to Europe and see how it is done.

The worst experience ever. Will never use this airport again. 2 hours in immigration coming back from vacation in Antigua. Then another hour through security for the 2nd time. Then to show our passports another 8 times. Common sense we wouldn't have got that far without showing our passports in Antigua. Then to run to make the final boarding call for our connecting flight. What in the world is wrong with paying a few extra people to work in immigration. Also, it's always nice to return to your own country and get treated like a herd of cattle.

Dreadful, every part of it, from the TSA onwards. The departure lounge is particularly disgusting. Whilst I sat amongst the bottles and desbris on the floor, an attendant emptied the bins and strolled away. No shops or bars except a perfunctory “hut” and an awful cafe “Marseilles”. Bags of rubbish and no staff, it could be the worst in the world. I’ve been flying and traveling for 45 years and was shocked at how bad Miami is. I can’t believe that Americans put up with such standards. I can’t accurately give rating or stars There is no shopping no bars, no restraints, no redeeming features whatsoever.

commentHeader: worst service I have ever encountered
reviewContent: I can say with certainty, even by notoriously bad US airport standards, Miami airport was the worst service I have ever encountered. Signage was useless. Every member of staff I had the displeasure of meeting was hostile to the point of aggression. Information and directions were barked at travelers in an unclear and impatient manner, only for the next member of staff to bark contradicting information leading to the utter bewilderment of passengers. Although there was a large number of staff everything was chaotic and disorganised. A particular low-light of the experience was, when going through security, being told to take my shoes off, (even though I had been told to keep them on moments earlier) and place them directly on the rollers to be scanned. Predictably, seconds later the laces got stuck in the rollers. As I tried to untangle them a member of staff (rather than help) shouted at me repeatedly "Leave it! Leave it! Leave it!". When I explained the laces were tangled he offered no help or apology for his unnecessarily aggressive behavior. But rather stood idly watching the queue grow behind me. I have traveled through 50+ airports, and from the confrontational, incompetent and belligerent service I received, Miami is clearly ranked bottom of the pile.

commentHeader: I hope to avoid Miami altogether
reviewContent: When I arrived I was excited to see electronic passport controls. However, my passage was not so straightforward because I was not given clearance by the machine. My own fault, I had forgotten to include my middle name on my ESTA application. My friend who regularly transits through Miami says that electronic clearance may or may not help you beat the queues. I eventually reached the head of the queue and was then told to join another queue! I overheard two airport staff mocking a customer who didn't realise that she no longer needed to complete a paper landing form. Well, maybe the customer hasn't flown into the U.S. for a few years? Not a crime is it? Two ladies in the queue behind were appealing to staff because they had 1hr to clear immigration and check in for onward flight but the staff member just sneered at the customer and walked off. Waiting at the yellow line, I could see inside one of the booths where there was a male officer rocking on his chair, staring into space, ignoring the line. Rather strange behaviour. I suppose being an imigration officer must be a difficult job but I have not seen such an unfriendly bunch anywhere and I have been through Boston, New York, Washington, San Fran and Fort Lauderdale. If you are looking for something to eat at Miami airport be prepared for fast food. Next year I hope to avoid Miami altogether and travel via Panama.

Spanish speaking only heard. One employee said she did not speak English when I asked for directions. Lots of fratinizing in Spanish instead of waiting on customers that were lined up. Two very disinterested information persons who acted bothered that I needed information about my flight. I am very disappointed to find such insolence and entitlement.

commentHeader: airport staff were surly and rude
reviewContent: My recent experience at Miami airport when my husband and I were in transit from St Kitts to Toronto was very unpleasant and bordered on being traumatic. We joined the line to have our passports verified on the computers and were given a pass with an X on it. Therefore we had to join another very long line and have our documents verified by an agent. There was a very high volume of passengers and we felt like cattle being herded through, a term which has been used in several other reviews. While waiting, several very burly, tough looking men in uniform passed us by. It was like being in a police state. The agent who received us after a long wait in line was fine, however this was sadly an exception. Many of the airport staff we encountered were surly and rude and could not have cared less about customer service. The fact that they represent their country to a large number of travelers from around the world every day seemed to be irrelevant to them. When we went downstairs to the luggage claim area in order to go to our gate, there were a large number of more tough, burly looking men in uniform watching everyone as they were herded though the area which was intimidating to say the least. When we passed through security, one of the female security staff bawled at me in a loud voice which was totally unnecessary. I have never been spoken to in this manner in my entire life. In addition to the staff, the airport is poorly laid out and signage is confusing. We will avoid travelling via Miami airport in the future.

What an outstanding example of American arrogance and rude behaviour this dump is. To the staff: seriously, you're the first Americans that foreign visitors encounter. Why not try to at least make a small effort at being polite and friendly? The impression you give travellers is that America is filled with angry, unpleasant people - you're doing a huge disservice to your country. I witnessed a security guy being incredibly rude to the people in front of me, coming very close to actually yelling at them when all they did was turn right out of a doorway instead of left (and no signage to say otherwise). If you don't like people and have zero tolerance for other humans then stay away from a customer-facing job. Almost every staff member was rude, impatient and abrasive, all of them shouting and bullying the airport visitors. There were a few exceptions who stood out. Even though he probably sees a million people in a week, he was polite and told us to have a nice day and it made all the difference. Also, the passport guy we had was professional and friendly. It put me off ever going near America again, for a holiday or to pass through.

commentHeader: a shocking entrance to the US
reviewContent: An ok airport but a shocking entrance to the US. This airport has more staff than customers, it’s amazing how many people are employed here. Let’s talk about oddities, first thing you see when arriving in country, an immigration machine where you get a reciept to foto immigration. There are 2 huge English grammar mistakes on this, really that’s your first impression? Then there is an announcement on level 3 about “moving walks” they are called escalators in every country! Why make up child like words? 99% of the staff here are Spanish speaking which I like, but I could see how someone without Spanish may struggle. Doesn’t help I counted 3 different dialects/versions of Spanish translated on signs, confusing! Once they work out which way to face on the moving walk, seriously? Forget immigration checks, should of had IQ checks.

commentHeader: we would have not made it
reviewContent: Came in from Panama to Term E and our connecting flight was at D1. We had over 2 hrs to make it and if I was not able to flag down one of the golf carts, we would have not made it. Going through security and customs and getting our luggage and checking it again took a lot of time. The worst was how far it was from E10, then through security, custom, etc and the long walk It must have been 2 miles long. I will never book a flight that comes from another country to this airport.

I'm not at all surprised to read other reviews about rude staff, bad experiences and passengers being treated like prisoners or cattle at Miami airport. Chaos reigns, and is presided over by employees who make it blatantly obvious that they hate their jobs. When we transited via Miami in January and February 2018, a handful of the staff really stood out for their competence and pleasant attitude, but they were the exception, the other 90% were miserable, surly, disinterested and in some cases quite unbelievably rude. Procedures and systems seem ridiculously slow and inefficient, and passengers have to stand in long queues multiple times as they are inhumanely processed. The layout of the airport doesn't help, signage is poor and in any case you're directed to ignore the few potentially useful signs by stressed employees whose job is apparently to stand underneath them yelling the same thing at people all day long. No wonder they're grumpy. Overall, not a positive experience at all. Anyone who arrives here is made to feel very unwelcome indeed. Come on, Miami, there has to be a better way - just look at almost any other airport.

commentHeader: One of the worst airports in the US
reviewContent: One of the worst airports in the US. This is solely based on layout and design. The long walk between various gates in the E concourse is unparalleled. Why not a moving floor? Why not a team that connects the entire airport, not just D concourse. The many years of construction have only produced “lipstick on a pig”. Unfortunately I need to go through there now since that is the only place you can fly from on American to St Thomas. Charlotte is a much better AA hub.

commentHeader: lack of a common use lounge
reviewContent: The airport layout is OK and easy to navigate, however, the lack of a common use lounge makes it hard to stand the long layovers. I would really like to see an upscale common use lounge for when I'm not traveling business class, it makes a huge difference.

This is by far the worst airport experience I have ever had. A customs officer was extremely rude to my wife, I and others in the group that had to go through an extra layer of scrutiny because they didn’t have the capability to check standard immigration paperwork in the standard line. The rest of the officers were rude too and treated us like prisioners. Simply unbelievable. Process took 3 hours and we missed our connecting flight. AA was gracious enough to get us on a following flight the next day but didn’t provide any type of hotel vochure, so I had to pay $125 out of pocket. Airport staff I dealt with were also rude and incompetent, with one individual advising wrong directions on two occasions. I’ll avoid the Miami airport in the future.

Having endured lengthy immigration delays at this and other US airports I got trusted traveller status. This meant applying then attending an "interview" in the USA on my last trip. This was the best $100 I have ever spent. I literally walked from the plane to an empty trusted traveller machine (there were long queues at the other ones), then straight through immigration. The entire process took seconds, compared to the usual hour long wait or more. I bypassed literally thousands of people waiting to be seen. Highly recommended.

Landside of MIA is ok, nothing special, no guest experience. Security checkpoint was quite fast and well organized. Concourse E is awful. 3 tiny F&B area, that's incredible. Tiny duty free shop, unbelievable. At least do a common use lounge that people can have access to even if they are not flying business (priority card, or pay a fee at the entrance). Wifi didn't work. Very limited number of plugs for electrical equipment.

Arrived around 3 pm afternoon. Surprisingly no big queues at immigration. It would take me only 15 mins if they would not "invite" me for a secondary interview, but thats another story. My colleague at least made it fast. Unfortunately she still waited at the luggage belt after I processed my secondary interview, one hour after landing. Perfect timing for me as just at this moment our suitcases arrived. We proceed to rental car centre, no possibility to smoke somewhere after a long flight. We need to walk around 15 mins to a people mover on a fluffy carpet which is not so easy when towing a suitcase. The people mover then took us in 5 minutes to the rental car center. Overall average experience, especially as the long waiting time for luggage sucks.

Arrived from Frankfurt at 2.40 pm after flying business class. Got to the customs and noticed ridiculosly long lines. I looked for some type of separation by class or nationality and nothing, everybody was lumped together. There were at least 500 people in that large room, all lined up line cattle to the slaughter. Really, don’t American citizens deserve an easier entry into their own country? After waiting patiently in line for 3/4 hr, got to a passport machine where my passport was read and got a receipt with an X on it, I guess they could not believe I had nothing to declare, hence I was placed into another line where a real agent would re review my entry. Waited another 15 minutes and while waiting I noticed that most agent run kiosks were assigned to X passengers. Well if this the case, why bother with the machines, they cost money and they are useless. Finally, the agent called me and he seemed very nice, talkative and accomodating. He was sure to ask me if I had anything to declare which I responded: ‘maybe a cold’. Overall uneventful but why the bureacracy, can we not do better? One thing is for sure, if I can skip Miami airport, I will be more than happy to do so. I forgot to mention the hellishly long security lines when I left 1 week prior, what a total joke.

commentHeader: staff were quite abrupt and unhelpful"
reviewContent: I found this to be the worst airport I have used in recent years. It was cold - a chill that hit one as soon as one passed through the entrance doors. The check-in area was dirty, it was difficult to find information about amenities while waiting for check-in to open and a number of staff were quite abrupt and unhelpful when asked for help. Eating facilities were limited. It was a great relief when Virgin check in opened where the staff were courteous and helpful and we were able to move through to the more comfortable departure area.

Chaotic and poorly laid out airport that is difficult to navigate has poor facilities airside. Check in was chaotic busy and slow moving. Equally security screening was long and slow with some of the most miserable employees I’ve seen in any airport, prepared to be shouted at and treated less than human. Once you have survived the chaos of check in and security prepare to find yourself in a cold sterile airport environment with little facilities for eating drinking and relaxing in. Not sure who they got to design this airport but they need sacking!

This has to be the worst airport ever. Security a joke, very loud and strict rules shouted out by half interested staff and yet a person in front carried a 1ltr bottle of water through unchecked! Departure gates F10 - F23 dirty, smelly and very tired. Duty free is pathetically small and staff pounce as soon as you enter.

commentHeader: there is a serious motivational problem
reviewContent: I was surprised at how disorganized the Airport was. The advertised free wifi was not available, the security crew was extremely rude literally hearding the passenngers thru the checks calling out things like “pay attention”, “stay focused” etc. It reminded me very much of my military drill. I have not experienced such behavior at any other US airport where TSA is usually very efficient but polite enough at the same time to make passengers comfortable. While waithing at the Business line for the security check at least three wide-body aircraft crews (= min 75 to 80 crew) were bypassed and led thru the business checks (on most other airports I have seen dedicated crew security lanes). When it was finally my turn I was redirected to the economy lane and had to wait again. At the x-ray machine there were no bins and when I dared to point this out to the TSA staffI was rebuked with “didn't you hear me!? I already called this out twice! bins are on their way”. The entire process took over 45 minutes. After the security check, the food court service staff was pleasant but the janitors and cleaning crew were very unattentive with litter piling up on many tables. Once they did come around they cleared tables even while patrons were still eating their food. Tables were not wiped and felt very sticky obviously not having been cleaned for some time. It seems to me that there is a serious motivational problem with a large number of employees at MIA that I have not witnessed on the many other US airports that I arrive to or leave from.

One would think that walking from gate D8 to D36 would not be that far. I learned later that it is a mile from one end to the other of concourse D, a long walk for some of us. The problem was that we had no idea that there was a Skytrain we could have ridden. Unfortunately, there were no signs or any indication that there was any option other than walking. I finally asked an employee about an alternate, and was informed that the green columns in the middle of the hallways had elevators to Skytrain. No escalators. No signs. And of course there were very few passengers, since most travelers may not have even known about it. I was shocked that an airport with as much business as Miami was so poorly labeled.

Have just been through security check for departure. Have never experienced such amateur operatives. Didn’t bother to give clear instructions on what was expected, eg: where to stand, what was going to happen. Spent time chatting to each other. Would nearly all benefit from being reminded on how to be polite and courteous to travellers. Our arrival at MIA 2 weeks ago was completely differently, courteous and efficient staff.

commentHeader: better than it used to be
reviewContent: Miami - London Heathrow, Thursday 19 October: Despite the many bad reviews this airport, in our experience, has improved greatly since the car rental centre was moved virtually on site with a short connecting shuttle train service. No more catching those awful shuttle busses with all your luggage. Also the electronic immigration machines have sped up the previously awful queueing time upon arrival. This time we flew back to the UK with Virgin Atlantic: driving in with the aid of SatNav and the very few road signs we got to the car rental hub without any issues. Put the luggage into a storage facility until we could check in with Virgin - we were a bit early so first in the queue - and got through security after about 1/2 hour. Travelling Upper Class so found the Lounge and did not bother with the many, many fast food outlets, sports bars or coffee places. The big downside of Miami Airport has always been the crowded concourses and very poor signage - only seems marginally better now. The WiFi was also slow. But all things considered the airport is better than it used to be. Tip: If you don't have access to a lounge or have a few hours to kill there is an open air cafe/bar on the top floor of the Hotel that we used to go to. It also connects to an indoor bar with sports screens and air - con. I believe you can pay to use the Health Club and use the pool as well, and the view over the runways is spectacular.

I have traveled all over the world and Miami airport made my top ten worst airports in the world. Getting your passport stamp takes a long long time, they only have one person working and the guy took ten minutes for each passenger. I almost didn't make my connection to Atlanta due to slow and unorganized airport. After you get your passport stamped you will have to get your lugguage and drop it to your transfers which most airport do. It you have to get out the terminal again and go through security to get to your connection and that took a long time also because they only have one working scanner. An awful experienced after traveling on a long long flight.

commentHeader: by far the worst airport on the planet
reviewContent: I travel more or less weekly. This is by far the worst airport on the planet when you travel internationally. From arrival to immigration they're just way behind the curve and never seem to care. At least 50% of the time upon arriving the airplane has to sit on the tarmac waiting for a gate to open. This messes with peoples' connections and plans. The immigration system is run by a bunch of morons. The officers are just fine, but the employees directing you and the way in which it is all arranged is just mind-boggling. If you can avoid this airport do so.

Miami Airport Area H and J are very good. H and J halls very good. Nice space and light, and all is clean. The seats are comfortable and lots of room to walk and stretch the legs - nice! Shops in the proper place and many choices and deals. Check-in areas working in perfection. Seats are clean.

We were stranded in Miami airport due to Hurricane Irma. Airlines were of little to no support. Miami airport very uncomfortable as there were no hotels available in the area, airlines were not supporting us and all we were left to do was sitting on the floor for an entire night.

commentHeader: this has to be the worst airport ever
reviewContent: Worst passport control ever. We had hundreds of passengers and the line they directed my family to had no border control officer. We and other poor passengers are waiting and they just don't seem to care at all. I've been to many points of entry to US but this has to be the worst airport ever.

I loved Miami airport. We were flying to Belize and customs was a breeze. The scenery is amazing with a great monorail system to avoid walking. The directions were very clear how to get to customs. Food outlets are available but sometimes a little difficult to find. All in all a great airport. I would definitely fly thorough Miami again.

commentHeader: held in long snaking queues for three hours
reviewContent: My passing through Miami Airport was a horrible experience which marred the start of an otherwise fantastic holiday in Nassau. We were held in long snaking queues for three hours until we missed our connecting flight. Staff were unhelpful and intimidating, not answering any questions, just barking orders. After missing our flight we had to spend the night there in the freezing airconditioning with no instructions or help as to what we could do or where to go. This is the worst experience I have ever had in an airport. If at all possible, I would recommend people to avoid this dreadful place with it's dreadful staff.

Miami is a terrible airport. Over capacity, out dated and practically third world. No transit facility (meaning travelers passing through the US mingle with domestic travelers). Gate to Carousel is usually at least half a mile distance. (Gate 48 to Carosel 26). The last 8 flights from LGA to MIA have arrived with no gate available (over capacity). Signs say Baggage Claim both ways (left and right - one way uses the train, one way by foot - why not write 'Baggage Claim - Via Train) when you leave the aircraft. Credit Card and Sunpass lanes to exit parking are regularly broken. Greed and disorganization rule. I've used airports in every continent and this ranks in the worst 3. AA lounge dates to about 1992. Only positive is TSA line moves quickly and it's relatively clean in the terminal.

Who designed Miami Airport? Why are there 100 yards between each gate? And why are there 10 gates for every small bathroom? Unanswerable questions I guess. I have never had worse food at an airport than when I reluctantly buy food here, so I do it as seldom as possible. Seats in the terminal must be 30 years old, ripped. Tons of shops, whick is a plus for some, but I'm not interested in paying a premium price for anything so to me shopping is not very useful. In a word: awful. Positive reviews of this place are anomalies. Transfer internationally through Atlanta, Houston or even JFK before settling on any itinerary through MIA.

Miami airport is too big as there is not transportation between the linked terminals. The TSA and most ground staff was at best totally disinterested - on the whole rude, slow and deliberately intimidating. This is not a good advertisement for the USA and for the state / city of Florida / Miami. No wonder US visitor numbers are falling. My airline was American Airlines - who have a similar attitude to customers.

As a frequent Flyer I have never seen anything quite as slow as the customs line in Miami. We had to queue for more than 2.5 hours. The agent was on his mobile sending and receiving texts while checking our passports. I don't think workers should be allowed to use mobile phones while at work. On our way back the security staff were extremely impolite, talking to passengers in a very rude manner. In general airport workers are not instructed to be helpful in anyway and are extremely rude. The worst airport I have been so far.

commentHeader: a sad way to represent our country

reviewContent: Never really liked Miami Airport but it has improved in a few facets of operation but still has the same problems I experienced on my first visit in 1979. Poor mobility between terminals plus a new complaint. The hike from American Airlines baggage area to terminal J is still a lomg walk. No trams or walkways, zero! Poor planning. Internet service in the most advanced airports is now free but not in Miami. When will this airport join the rest of the world's leading airports? Never if the last 38 years indicates the lack of progression in this poorly organized airport.

I had to connect through MIA airport for an international to international connection. My flight arrived at 5pm and I was back at airside 35 min later. Immigration was fast which took about 10-15 min and walked through customs as bags had cheked through with ITI-tags. It took only few minutes to get through transit security check. This all happened in North terminal (D-gates) which was clean and airy. Have things chanced or was I just lucky?

commentHeader: there were only a handful of immigration officers present
reviewContent: I travelled to Miami in December and was through immigration before my bags arrived on the concourse. Perfect. This time it was a disaster. All passengers were directed through the automatic passport / fingerprint / photo machines. There were reasonable queues, but all fine. Normally one then takes the printed strip through the "quick" channel, it gets glanced at and you are in. However, this time, every single foreign visitor had to pass through the full immigration check - and there were only a handful of immigration officers present - literally 5 or 6. This meant queues of literally 2 plus hours minimum. I was one off the first off the plane and it took me two hours ten minutes. Others will have waited for 3+ hours It was shambolic and awful. I used to be suspicious of the horror stories about this airport - my past experiences have largely been ok - but this time, awful. Just awful.

commentHeader: I have never seen anything quite as slow
it was like stepping back in time
reviewContent: Miami is a very large and old airport. This place looks so dingy and old, it was like stepping back in time! I travel worldwide and it was one of the worst airports I have seen. Flew Iberia out of the E wing. Once you go past security there is very little in the way of food options or shops. It consisted of Pizza Hut, a small beer place, and two freestanding snack stands. That was it. When I got out to the actual gate, there was nothing. There were a few "stores" but they weren't open and I don't know if they are even functional. It was for a 5.30pm flight which ended up being delayed. There were bathrooms, and seating, but nothing else. Everything was closed up. There were 4 different gates where I was. There was a business class lounge not too far for Iberia business passengers, or American Airlines. At this area they did have a duty free shop which was small. The waiting area was fairly clean and the seats were comfortable enough. You have 30 minutes of free wifi after that you have to pay for it. I was early for my flight so the line to go through security and waiting to check in were not long. I had to take a short train to get out to the gates. This airport is serious need of an overhaul. It looks like the 1960's. The buses are in one area on the lower level. Depends on the airline you fly which terminal you are out of.

Both today and our arrival two weeks ago were horrible experiences in this airport. It is poorly laid out. It is old. It is slow. Everything is disorganized. Having to change planes and go back through security is asinine. Absolutely nobody at any point in time was kind or helpful from American Airlines to security to asking for help from airport staff. Not one person said hello or even cracked a smile. Upon landing in Tampa, we had the exact opposite experience which just reinforced just how bad Miami is. I will do everything I can to never return!

I have only ever connected through Miami, so I can't speak to check in, etc. But our connections have always been on international flights, so we have gone through customs and immigration. We have gone through early morning (6:30 am), so my experience may not be typical, but we had no issues. Everything moved pretty quickly. We actually had a 7 hour layover (thanks, American Airlines!) so we had plenty of time to wander and not be rushed. Overall, I think the signage was good, and the one staff member we asked a question was polite and gave us good directions. We ate at the Irish pub in the American Airlines section of the terminal. The food was good and reasonably priced for an airport restaurant. I know many people have had bad experiences at this airport, but ours was pretty positive.

Miami is an awful airport. Anytime I travel through it something goes wrong. Endless lines and frustration for travelers. So dirty, seats are the least comfortable and do not allow lying down. Food and shopping options are not attractive at all and on top of everything, WiFi is not even available for more than 30mins. Avoid if you have the option.

commentHeader: deplaning to jumping into a taxi took us about 30 minutes
reviewContent: I transited MIA on my way to St Maarten and arrived and departed on my way back to London. My first arrival was at 4pm from an international flight. The queue for APC machines was very long and a staff member directed us to the immigration desks, the queues here also looked horrendous, a helpful staff member asked if anyone had connections which said yes and she gave us a fast track orange voucher which enabled us jump the queue (our connection time was 2 hours). We had only carry ons so had no bags to collect, but had to go through security again, which was slow considering the queues were not long. From deplaning to clearing immigration and security took about an hour thanks to fast track voucher. As we were traveling business class we went to to business lounge rather than use any of the dining outlets. We arrived at MIA again a few days later. Our arrival time was 7pm and immigration was much quieter, the APC machines had no queue, but was so badly organised we opted to use the immigration desks instead and we were seen to very quickly. From deplaning to jumping into a taxi took us about 30 minutes.

commentHeader: previous experiences have also been positive
avoid and save yourself an awful lot of grief

reviewContent: Miami is a truly awful airport. Queues everywhere just to get to another queue. After 1 hour being aimlessly shuffled along, they finally opened more auto passport machines, which then proceeded to give at least half of trackers a big 'X' on their dockets, which meant another 45 mins to have photo and fingerprints dive again, thus time manually. I have arrived into the US at Orlando, JFK, La Guardia, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Honolulu, LA, Seattle, Vegas and Miami is by far the worst experience I have had. Totally incompetent management and processes. Avoid if at all possible.

commentHeader: our experience has been positive overall

reviewContent: I will avoid this airport at all costs in the future. We came through customs from England, connecting to Orlando. We barely made the flight, even though we had 2+ hours in this airport. The signage is pathetic - completely unhelpful. Staff are just as bad. They had us in one line, then pulled us to direct us to another, then back again and that was just to check our bags. We were Pre-TSA, but we were herded halfway down the airport to the second check-in line, which moved so slowly that we should have stayed in the regular line closer to our gate.

commentHeader: I will avoid in the future
efficient and queues do move fast
we made it, our luggage did not
will do my best to avoid this place
long walks and even longer queues
maybe I was just very lucky
what a nightmare this airport is

reviewContent: I showed up to MLU for my morning flight. I was there in plenty of time and I have flown out of Monroe multiple times. A family in front of me was buying tickets for a flight tomorrow. I waited and waited. Apparently, the woman at the counter, (the only one working) thought I was with the family. Once she realized I wasn't with the family, she tried to get someone to help me but no one was there. I waited long enough to miss the time to check a bag. Finally, a man came to help, but immediately gave me a spill about being on time so I can check my bag next time. I was polite, but I've done this many times. Let's just say the woman working was not happy with him. She tried to help me and I don't think it was her fault that no one was there to help her. I had to wait from 9:40-4:30 to catch the next flight. I guess it is a small airport, so there's not many staff. I think the problem could be prevented.

Mobile Regional (MOB) is honestly not a bad airport, even if it's showing some signs of age. The signage leading to anywhere a passenger needs to go is mostly straightforward (except for signage to short-term parking for some reason), though some of it is older and fading. Parking is easy and relatively cheap compared to airports in larger metros. The entry into the terminal is one covered passageway. Checking in luggage is painfully easy at one of three small counters. Going through security is easy with small lines, and painfully easy if you have TSA Pre-Check. There are only seven departure gates total and 2-3 stores post-security. One of those stores is one that almost everyone has to walk past or through on the way to their gate: Hudson News pairing up with a tiny restaurant and bar, equipped with cafeteria-style seating. It looks like the set of the old TV show "Wings," or perhaps a miniature version of a 1990s mall food court. This makes the airport so small that it's quirky. The personnel working in this airport are sweet and warm - yes, in an airport! As for the drawbacks, some of the ceilings post-security are quite low, with the lighting dim. Only some of the pre-security area looks like it's seen any renovation since the 1990s. The signage from I-65, and most of Airport Boulevard until you reach the airport, is almost nonexistent. MOB's location is so far out in the western suburbs that it's really quite inconvenient, whether you're coming from Mobile or other Gulf area cities in Alabama and Mississippi. Mobile Downtown Airport is expected to open in 2024 and should be a vast improvement in terms of modernity and accessibility.

commentHeader: You want to be here only to leave
reviewContent: The biggest plus for Monterey Airport is its size. This is probably the smallest airport I have ever seen. What that means is fast airport screening. Curb to your gate, including clearing security, is less than five minutes. Got it? Less than Five Minutes! On the negative side, the airlines treat the airport as a step-child. Until recently United used to fly its throw-away planes here for the Pebble Beach class masses. This is slightly unusual as there are a hell of a lot of big wigs from Fortune 500 coming in for Golf and right now the Centennial celebration at Pebble Beach. Up until this month, nearly every airplane you flew on was sketchy, dodgy, a throw away plane from once upon a time, long long time ago. That is the class of airplanes coming in and out of here. Not very good. The Airline personnel on more than a few occasions were nowhere to be found. Just not there. And you look around and it looks like a ghost town in there. Really - no body there. The On-Time in bound and out bound is about - lets just say - add 1 to 5 hours to your scheduled departure or arrival. Its very obvious Monterey Airport is not a priority for the major airlines. My guess is that they are thinking if you really are a Big Wig, then you really shouldn't be flying commercial. Fly your own Jet. The services at terminal itself is - well - lets just say - it looks like an 8th grader set up a Lemonade Stand. There is one gift shop. Next door is a 7 Eleven type of place with hand made signs all over and evidence that its a one person operation. There is basically two terminals. You go left or you go right, from the scan stations. And both of these terminals are very dark. What fluorescent lighting there is here does not add to the mood of it being very dark. It sports a couple of dated TV's hanging way too close to the roof. Its a little strange - the terminals. It could definitely use some better Feng Shui. Some art perhaps. Something to make it seem more human, than "Here is a terminal, you wanted one, here it is. It's up to code. They have lights." The restaurant upstairs looks like it could use a renovation. Its furniture and carpet look very 1980's. I'd put money on it that the furniture and carpet is at least a few decades old. Definitely not new. Its important to note, it is not inside the gate, but outside it. The parking here, for a small airport, is pretty steep. About $13 / day long term. $20 - 25 / day Short term. Yes, that is steep. For a tiny airport flying with the average one flight per hour. This airport definitely could use some sponsor subsidizing. Bring in some of the Golf companies. Advertise it as their lounge. Why not? Thats how all the majors work. Sponsorship. Make this thing look a charming, cozy, Tiger Woods world class than midwest airport hick woods class. Clearly the airport has some negatives. Usually at nice airports you want to arrive early and spend some time in there because its such a joy. This is not one of those Airports. You want to be here only to leave. Why am I giving it 7 Stars? Its tiny and convenient. And if it ever were updated with better airplanes and facilities, it would get 10 Stars easily.

Our Amsterdam flight arrived at time precisely. 1.5 hours wait on the tarmac because of the gate agent, because of other reasons. In the international arrival hall > 500 people, 3 officers to check passports, > 2 hours waiting. In civilized countries, usually helpers are asking passengers about tight connections and help them through to catch their flights. The assistants here were few and could not care less about us. The luggage’s checked in and out for customs - the re- check points with other assistants (watching their phones) directing passengers how to put their luggage on the right position - not helping or moving a finger in the process. Security - same rude treatment: we supposed to push our bags through the tunnel - at the flashing red light - who would know? workers standing there and screaming at us, not helping at all. I had to run like crazy to catch my flight and I would have never be able to do it without the help of a kind fellow passenger. Shame on the management to allow this to happen. “Welcome to the USA “ was written on monitors. It was a mess and a far cry from anything welcoming. I will try never to go through that airport again.

TSA line was long. The wait said it was 25 minute but it was 45 minutes. TSA security check didn’t say a word to get the process moving. They don’t tell anyone to take off their shoes or about electronics to be prepared. Everyone was upset because they didn’t communicate which made the process longer. One person was yelling at someone in a wheelchair.

You be prepared to walk a lot. Then at the Arrivals/Baggage Claim the cars are double, triple parked and will sit there for 20, 30, 40 minutes blocking traffic and making it impossible to load your car. We saw some cars just sitting there for over an hour while our man went to get our rental car. Security is non-existant, we never saw a guard until some dude threatened us while we were trying to back our car in to load, then one slow-witted airport security dude shows up, and basically does nothing because "that's always how it is here...and I'm supposed to be on my break." Eventually four real police arrived to deal with a situation that never should have happened in the first place. Try double parking at LAX Arrivals for longer than three minutes and see what happens. Stop letting people quadruple park at Arrivals before someone gets violent, because it will happen eventually if it hasn't yet. This airport is obviously poorly managed, and security is lazy.

I normally don’t review, however my experience at the Minneapolis airport was the worst experience I’ve had at any airport I’ve traveled to. I agree with other reviewers, if you can fly somewhere else, do that. The rudeness I encountered from the staff made me feel belittled, unwelcome, and left me shocked. We pay a lot of money to fly through your airport. And then, if you do try and say anything to any workers, about how awful they're treating you, your in the wrong because they work there. That’s not right.

commentHeader: Go somewhere else if you can
reviewContent: So getting checked in and boarding is easy. It's the customs that can't get things figured out. You know how many planes are arriving, and how many people are on each flight, then you should have enough staff to move people in a timely fashion. Yet the simplest jobs your in a 3hr waiting line. Go somewhere else if you can.

We are on a layover from Cancun to Portland, the deboarding, customs area had one, filthy gross restroom. The Delta wing of the airport has very few restaurants choices or shops to browse/entertainment while stuck here. We ate at Mill Tavern, although the customer service was great, the food was not, very few choices and very over priced. They offered to remake my burger as the first one was too raw, the second was cooked done, it was just wasn't good, fries soggy and flavorless. Airport restrooms unkept, poor food choices and/or restaurants with comfortable seating to waiting. Hope I don't have to visit this place again!

Security is a big deal, and everyone just wants to get though the most efficient way possible, but I have never seen such a disrespectful, ill-tempered employee ordering passengers about as I did today at Security checkpoint 1. I witnessed an extremely elderly couple arrive at the TSA que. They were traveling alone and obviously had trouble getting around. They did not have the correct boarding documents, but instead of showing compassion, or helpfulness, the airport employee yelled at them and told them to get out of line & go back to the ticketing counter. The elderly woman asked if her husband could wait there ( he had a very hard time walking) but the grouchy employee said,” No, you have to take him with you! I don’t have anywhere to stash him!” Like he was a piece of luggage or something. Next she ordered me & my family to a TSA booth that didn’t have an agent manning it. We stood there briefly, looking to see if an agent was coming. Next we stepped to the next agent to show our ID & boarding passes. She charged over to us and told us to stay where she put us! I pointed out that there was NO agent where she sent us, and she proceeded to start stomping around barking out orders. My husband just told her we were staying in the line we stepped to because the TSA agent was already processing my daughter.

Having traveled extensively in my 59 years, I have to say that MSP is one of the most ill-designed and unfriendly airports in the world. Yesterday I walked 2+ miles to my connection, the moving walkways not operating. Every single time I’ve flown to/from/thru MSP in the past 30 years there has been an issue. Entering the States from Europe several times we were detained in security for 3 or more hours, our kids taken to the other side of the room while we were interrogated. Never has this happened at any other airport in the world on our travels. Last time we waited for 20 minutes for a French translator to come to read the label on a can of foie gras to determine if it contained pork.  You need to do better MSP! And get better transport from C20 to F15 (in example) - no one should have to walk miles (literally) to get to their connection flights!

MSP Airport does a great job with stores and restaurant options and recently completed some moderate improvements in aesthetics to terminal 1. They currently offer a total of 15 electric parking spots which are spread out across 3 sites! It appears the planning team completely overlooked this aspect of the customer experience.

commentHeader: Not a bad airport but not a great one
reviewContent: Not a bad airport but not a great one. Getting from the outer C Concourse to the main terminal is not intuitive (there is a train I would have missed if not for the help of a local). Directions to Light Rail are not entirely intuitive and the airport maps online are absolutely useless for figuring out how to get from the Light Rail to the gates. The food selection is ok but not what I would expect at a hub airport. Ditto the shopping. Security was quick with little wait in the TSA or regular lines. I used Delta, which is the dominant carrier here. The service was okay. The thing with Delta is that they are pretty inept at their home base in Atlanta, but often better elsewhere, The most remarkable thing here was that one person managed the gate ---this may be a legacy of Northwest (which Delta acquired). Delta's legacy facilities usually have two people at the gate with one often more inept than the other (DCA and ATL). This is an ok airport of you can figure out the logistics.

commentHeader: This was very stressful for my family and especially my mom
reviewContent: My mom is a 67 year older paraplegic. As we were going through security she was pushed off to the side and left there for 20 minutes. My sisters and I started to complain after about 15 minutes and were told to be patient. Then after 25 minutes of mom sitting there as everyone passed her by we really started complaining about missing our flight. Finally we were told to find a manager where about 5 people were standing at a podium. There was a lady there with red hair visiting that came to help us. It then took another 15 more minutes to get mom passed through security. We missed our pre-board time and were told at the gate that she should have pre-boarded. Well no kidding. This was very stressful for my family and especially my mom. This should never be the case that she is singled out and made to feel like an annoyance in an airport on vacation.

commentHeader: I travel frequently and have never been so disrespected
reviewContent: I’m the first to admit that TSA is not a desirable position but I’m also a strong believer in being kind and I’m not sure these TSA agents are capable of being kind. There’s no instructions for what to do when you get up to security, yet they got extremely angry when people weren’t able to read their minds regarding their expectations. I travel frequently and have never been so disrespected as I was by these TSA agents. Otherwise, terminal 2 is clean and the bathrooms are nice.

This airport has two Terminals. Be very aware which terminal you need to be in: 1 or 2. Find out what terminal you are landing in and renting your car and what terminal you will be leaving from - ask for the address of where to drop your car off. Otherwise, your GPS may lead you unknowingly to the wrong terminal. Trying to figure out the public subway system to move between terminals was not easy or fast. The signs are somewhat confusing and, as a result of COVID, some of the Information Desks are closed. I found an open Information Desk, but the staff member was so mean I chose to figure out things on my own rather than be belittled by him for getting lost. I found a very friendly staff member in the hallway and he was able to clearly explain how to get to my destination. Otherwise this is a decent, clean, modern airport with an ok selection of shops and restaurants. It is what I expect for a city or cities this size.

commentHeader: Not a single restaurant or store open
reviewContent: Arrived at the airport at 8.30pm on a Sunday. Not a single restaurant or store open. No food, no drink, no amenities. Vending machines filled with just candy. Bad form.

Nice airport to transit through. There was a woman playing piano in between the E and C concourses. There were many volunteers around to give directions and advice. There were also lots of places to sit, eat, and charge your device as well. The seats would get high marks from the people at 'Sleeping In Airports'. My only complaint is getting around the concourses is by foot only. There is tram but it is outside security.

commentHeader: Needless to say no one impressed!
reviewContent: Airline (Sun Country) did a excellent job of getting us in before bad weather hit. Unfortunately the ramp manager decided that the workers shouldn't have to unload the plane in the rain. We arrived at 12.00am (midnight) and very light rain starting. Had to wait for over a hour for our baggage. Remember this is now after 1.00 am. and there were multiple small children on the flight. Needless to say no one impressed!

commentHeader: All but 1 food service option was closed at 6pm
reviewContent: All but 1 food service option was closed at 6pm and that location had closed about half their tables - leaving a lot of people unable to find food. Major city airports don’t close at 6pm on a Monday. All but one store closed and they were mostly bare shelves. Staff at airport very unhelpful on offering options. Will schedule around this airport for all future travel - clearly don’t want to service the travelers.

Those automatic machines are a mess: - long wait before the security porch - long wait after, gets your stuff completely disorganized. Watch the standard manual line for much faster. No cleaning of the bins, not safe! Stop wasting money and our time for non sense machine please!

Absolutely the worst. Got lost in construction, then lost in the building, as there were no people working on that floor. Got to check-in late and American Airlines check in staff were so incredibly slow, the entire line was freaking out! Had to take a later flight, this was not ok. Worst airport.
Great airport. It's clean and fast to transit through. The CBP staff were great as were the TSA staff. There are loads of shops, food outlets and seating. It's how airports should be!

The airport itself was fine. Clean and easy to get where I needed to go. My problem was with the security agents. Every one of the four TSA agents I encountered were rude and dismissive. I also heard an older women state - “there is no need to be that rude!” So I was not the exception. I had no issues or anything with my screening. There was absolutely no reason for their attitude. And, it makes no sense to ask if I recommend this airport - it’s all about location, not quality.

commentHeader: nearly all vegan options were gone
reviewContent: I have been flying out of the Minneapolis airport for years. I tell people often it is a great airport to be vegan. Well, that was until today. I traveled up and down the whole G concourse only to find that nearly all vegan options that I have come to appreciate were gone. In addition, I could not even buy a bag of nuts, unless they were covered in chocolate/candy.

This is a very large airport and it is very congested. When I first arrived and disembarked the aircraft, people were all standing around for the next flight. I had to squeeze my way through. It was a very long walk from the gate to baggage claim and getting to the Uber pickup from baggage claim was just as confusing. Not a traveler friendly airport.

commentHeader: would avoid making a connection at this airport
reviewContent: This airport sprawls. It could be a long distance to traverse between your arrival and departure gates. There is a tram connecting parts of the half dozen concourses but you need to be at the correct place to board it. In any case, be prepared to give quite a bit of time to make to your connecting gate. The food outlets are not evenly spaced out which also means quite a bit of going to and fro in search of a bite. However, directional signs are very clear. I would avoid making a connection at this airport which is a Delta hub.
