Once you’re past a certain point, you see how much unused space there is & start to wonder why they’re not using that space for TSA.

Customs is an absolute joke at O’Hare. They make you wait in line for hours to then have to scan your own passports. Both of our scanning machines didn’t work so after an hour in line I had to ask for help. I do want to point out a customs employee flagged us down and let us cut in line because we were traveling with small kids but that was after an hour. Total time was 2 hours and that was with them letting us cut in front of a the whole line.

Deliberately unhelpful "helpers" at immigration lines. The immigration staff themselves were fine, the two women on duty to manage the lines were downright unhelpful and nasty. They re-directed the line multiple times until there were about 10 people waiting for one immigration officer while the remainder of the line were filtered through about 3 other officers in the same time. Even when the 3 staff had processed the longer line, one of the women refused even to acknowledge a polite question by someone in front of me as to whether we could move back to the main line. So ridiculous and ironic given that she was wearing a jacket labeled "I can help you." She was just as rude to people who did not speak English and refused to answer other perfectly reasonable questions about where people should go. Staff like this just make the experience unnecessarily unpleasant, and detract from the good work that other people at the airport are doing in a stressful environment.

Being rude, dismissive, grumpy, and pretty much just don't give a damn attitude must be required to work here. Every single person not just one or two are this way. The people working for the various airlines are totally different - nice, kind and polite. The contrast is shocking. Lady next to me was basically dumped from her wheelchair into a seat and left. No conversation with her at all. Absurd. Horrible place. I had forgotten why I don't fly from here! Now I remember! I won't do this again. Darn shame people. Darn shame.

What’s up with the customs officers in this airport? So very rude - including Global Entry. We’re Americans re-entering our own country. We were treated like criminals. Such a poor experience for us, but worse yet for international visitors. ORD customs officers need customer service training! You’re a bad example for our country.

Not disabled friendly, airport does not have runways itsvery extensive, lacks water fountains, places for people to lounge/stay while in transit overnight. Staff at stands lack sympathy, empathy and good manners, airport has lots of plant adornments and is beautifully decorated with great photographs and some restaurants but lacks standards to make it accessible to for instance a diabetic, a person with impaired mobility and someone who needs accesiblity to fresh water fountains or quick transportation between far gates if they travel with kids or are disabled, diabetic have asthma or breathing or walking challenges. Lack of runway or belts like in other smaller airports (Colorado, Dallas 5 star for instance). Cleaner, more comfortable and more accessible is better than nicely decorated. Lack of chargers and electrical sockets to recharge pumps and medical equipment and phones and laptops those at the rotunda do not work. Nice plants though. Tables broken, not enough seating space, cluttered.

We had to change planes in Chicago and go from domestic to international on January 2/3. The airport was decently clean but the signage was not clear about where to go. The biggest problem I saw was the TSA agents in the international terminal. Never have I seen such a bunch of ill tempered, unhappy and condescending people in my life. This is one reason why we don't usually fly through Chicago.

After experiencing delays with United airlines a waitress at a restaurant was so rude to me and so insensitive. The bathrooms smelt like an outdoor toilet and they had not been cleaned in years the airport is filthy and they can do a much better job with training their employees at Customer Service.

Worst experience ever. First I was stopped at customs for about 30 minutes while all my bags were emptied and searched. Then i was forced to unlock my phone so it could be searched. I was asked rude and invasive questions during the searches. When i asked why my phone was being searched i was told it was "random extra searching." Finally finished that and was given bad directions by an airport official for transferring terminals. This led me to exit and enter security again which was painfully slow. After getting through security I learned that i was again at the wrong terminal (i was too early for my flight to be posted and both security and airline officials directed me to the wrong terminal.) I was in Beijing, Manila, Phnom Penh, and Macau airports this trip and was shocked to see how much more run down and inefficient O'Hare was compared to all of those. I will never transfer through Chicago again. Good luck to you if you decide to.

commentHeader: It's been like this for years
reviewContent: Why do none of the power outlets at the changing stations ever work. It's been like this for years, I travel for a living and dread getting delayed here with no way to power my phone or laptop, avoid all connections from this dump.

Unprofessional, rude, beyond disappointing TSA. How do these people have a job? TSA agents were rude from start to finish. Screamed at travelers in line to get in a different line in the rudest way possible! Laughed at people in line etc. I was disgusted.

It’s been several visits to O’Hare. Rude, aggressive, apathetic staff and TSA agents. People who are clearly irritated working with the public and want you to know. From the TSA ID reader at security checkpoint 7 near American Airlines in Terminal 3 who wants you to extend your left arm to place your phone on the reader but not move your body at all, and when you accidentally do, becomes angry and tells you how unhappy he is b/c people don’t listen, or the other agent who doesn’t explain how to place your bag on the roller but is very disappointed in your actions by yelling, “Do not push!” I get it. You hate me, you hate people, and you hate your job. I have traveled back with students from abroad to be greeted with angry agents who separated my students from me, sending them to separate security checkpoints, and rushed us so fast through lines my kids kept screwing up. TSA didn’t care. Kids were crying and the anxiety spiked. They still did not care. If you want to feel worse about your existence, go to O’Hare. They will let you know through their tones, angry looks, and aggressive actions. Something needs to change.

Absolutely terrible experience at Chicago O’Hare. I had just finished flying 15 hours from Dubai where I was greeted with a very rude and unhelpful airport staff. I then had to wait in line for over 2 hours for shuttle bus to get to the terminal for my connecting flight (some of which included standing outside in 38 degree weather). I had given myself 4 hours between flights and still barely made it to my gate on time. I got there as they were boarding. I heard so many people say that they were going to miss their flights because of this complete incompetence. Unacceptable.

Worst experience ever returning home after a 25 hour flight from Thailand. Made it through the kiosks and stood in line for 30 minutes getting closer to our turn when we were redirected to another section of kiosks - I asked why we were redirected and the girl started saying it wasn’t her fault and she didn’t know. Now I found myself standing in an even longer line. I’ve never experienced such inefficient, rude and unhelpful people at O’Hare in my life. I also don’t understand why us citizens and green card holders are in the same lines as visitors. Used to be a breeze getting through customs - not any more!

commentHeader: made me feel unsafe and violated"
reviewContent: My first time traveling internationally. The TSA that went through my luggage were completely unprofessional, condescending, rude, and disrespectful. He said "it's not my fault you don't know how to read signs and you are traveling" (after I told him I wasn't sure I was in the right place and needed guidance for my first time traveling internationally). I am Human Resource Manager, I am so disappointed in the verbal treatment from this male TSA. I understand they have a job to do. It does not include verbally abusing paying travelers. We are all tired and stressed (airport staff / travelers). In any other United States job this gentlemen would have either been terminated or severely disciplined. He made me feel unsafe and violated.

I was flying in to Minneapolis from Hong Kong, and having chosen United, needed to pass transit at either Chicago or San Francisco- seeing as he overall travel time would be shorter via Chicago, I opted for them. Despite most people I know telling me that O’Hare is awful, I thought it was okay overall - in fact, I found them quite efficient. I arrived in a Chicago on a Thursday. Being Canadian, I was able to breeze past immigration through their automated clearance system, and got through in 10 minutes. The immigration officer had a serious expression, and waved me through really quickly. My bags arrived shortly after I reached he reclaim area. Seeing as my flight arrived 2 hours early, I tried to get switched to the earlier flight, and after the United ground staff dealt dealt with the frustratingly lengthy process of rebooking my flight, she was able to land me a seat on the flight and helped me ensure that my bag would be checked in to that flight despite there only being a one hour window to departure. This also meant that I needed to rush to Terminal 1 from the international terminal. Rushing to Terminal 1 is normally easy, seeing as they have that automated people mover, but it’s undergoing long-term maintenance/being rebuilt in sections, so it’s closed on weekdays. This meant that I was at the mercy of the shuttle bus, which was obviously slower to board and arrive, due to the very peculiar traffic design between terminals. There was this one intersection that allowed one bus through at a time and took close to 10 minutes to clear. Despite all that rushing, I was still able to get to my flight in time, partly due to their speedy TSA crew that in dealing with the backlog decided that’s passengers could go through with their shoes on. My flight back from Minneapolis occurred without a hitch, though arriving with a 3 hour layover gave me a chance to really soak up the architecture and movie filming locations in the 3 main terminals. I probably could’ve also tried their dining, but alas, I have not. When it comes to waiting for flights, the seats at Terminal 1 are old, but adequate. I appreciate their provision of outlets near seating for device charging, but it would probably be even better if they also provided USB ports on the outlets, and fitted universal outlets seeing as travellers may not have the correct adaptors. Also, Boingo is still the main WiFi provider in the airport, but they now offer a few hours of unlimited wifi every time you watch an ad. The ads aren’t that long, so I’d argue that that’s okay, and for cost recovery, it’s not too annoying.

The most rude, unfriendly, unhelpful, and unprofessional employees. If I politely ask for your help, don’t tell me “I’m not getting involved, you know the rules, you have to figure out what to do.” I’ve only flown once before, 3 years ago - your job is to help me. You get paid to help me. I’m not saying you have to be the nicest, but the attitude from all 5 employees I came into contact with, is just inappropriate! Horrible..

Horrible. Seriously O’Hare get your transit up and running. After landing I had to wait over half an hour outside for a bus to come pick us up and take us to the parking lot. Unacceptable if you’re going to shut down the train have more buses at least.

I had a horrible experience at Chicago O'Hare recently. On September 3rd, we had an international layover on our way to Italy for our honeymoon. There were some weather issues which caused our incoming flight from Seattle to circle the airport for a while before we were finally able to land. No problem, I get weather issues. Once we were able to deboard the plane, we had to find the international terminal. The airport had very poor signage for this, so we stopped to ask a staff. He told us the quickest way would be to go to the end of the G gates and take a shuttle to the M International terminal to avoid having to exit the airport and go through security again. Once we got to G17 where the shuttle was, a female airport worker told us she needed to see our boarding passes and passports. We handed them over and she said she couldn't allow us to be shuttled until she confirmed our flight was still there. I told her that my Delta app confirmed that the flight was delayed by 30 minutes. I had also heard an announcement that all flights were delayed from the weather since no planes were able to take off or land. She insisted on checking Google Flights for her update as well as got on her walkie-talkie to ask someone who was in the international wing if our flight was still there. Meanwhile, the clock is ticking and we need to board our plane. This person who works at the damn airport would not use the airport computer to check our flight status and continued to rely on Google Flights. She told us that she would not shuttle us over because apparently our flight had left. I told her she was wrong and she refused. I was furious. I grabbed our passports and told my husband, "I don't trust that she is right. I think we still need to make a run for it and go to the international wing by ourselves." We exited the airport, caught the rail train and went through security with 10 minutes to spare. We finally made it to our gate and what do you know, our flight was still there! We were able to board and had about 5 minutes.

Avoid this airport if at all possible. Horrendous experience both arriving and departing. When we arrived it took over half an hour to get off the plane because information on connecting flights had be posted just outside the exit and caused congestion. We then made our way down to immigration control which was in chaos. There were no proper signs just some people shouting instructions which nobody could understand. We followed people and ended up in the wrong place. After 10 minutes we were then told where we needed to go by somebody we could understand. This was the longest queue I have ever seen, It took us 15 minutes to get to the back of it. When we got near the automatic machines we were stopped for about 15 minutes because the queue after the machines was too long and was clogging up the machine area. When we used the machines our documents were rejected. We later found out that the machines were rejecting 95% of people. This was the basis of the queue. Because of this we had to go in the next queue to be dealt with manually. Altogether it took nearly 3 hours to get through the immigration. Departing was not much better. After checking in, which took about 40 minutes because BA do not have a bag drop option and only 2 desks open for Economy and Premium Economy passengers we were then faced with another huge queue for immigration. It was so long it spilled out onto the check in area. Once through immigration the security check was relatively quick although I had to be body searched because I left a plastic comb in my pocket! It took over 2 hours to get through. One of our worst experiences at a USA airport, although departing from here was also bad a couple of years ago, so a place to avoid.

Airline travel is not always the easiest thing to do. The more stresses that can be eliminated from it, the better. I think one of the biggest stresses is the time it takes to go through security. O’Hare’s security is efficient and friendly allowing travelers to place their items on the scanning belt at their own pace without holding up the rest of the line. We were able to get in a through security in less than 20 minuets which is fantastic. Great job!

Check-in area in terminal 5 is far too small. One airline had two flights leaving within an hour but was assigned a limited number of check-in counters. This caused the line to spill in to the hallway and blocking foot traffic. Once you clear check-in, the immigration and final security is done in a small area where there is not much of a system. Lines can crisscross and you really need to be patient as you go through the process. I had a red eye flight and I wanted to get a meal before boarding. Unfortunately most restaurants were closed by 9pm. As expected the one open restaurant was swamped with customers. The restaurant staff could hardly cope with orders taking a long time coming. There appears limited seating in both check-in and boarding areas. Wi-Fi was not working in all areas.

I feel like O'Hare gets a bad wrap overall for a few reasons, but some issues are legitimate, and the experience will vary greatly depending on which terminal you go through. For starters I usually fly United, and usually go through Terminal 1 or 2. I don't fly through Terminal 3, and my experience in the International Terminal has only been for one arrival recently. That said, I can break down Terminal's 1 and 2 which are good overall in my view. For starters the main issue with United is connecting flights can take a little while to get around. Terminal 1 is separated into two concourses connected by an underground walkway. In theory you could have a connecting flight on United Express which are mostly located in Terminal 2 despite your regular United flight may land at the C-Gates in Terminal 1. Therefore, you may have to walk from the end of the C-gate to the central area to reach the underground tunnel, go underground the tarmac, pop up at Terminal 1, then go to the end to reach the walkway to Terminal 2, then you'll cross into Terminal 2, and finally you are at your gate. It sounds like a long walk because it is. I recommend at least have 30 minutes to transfer flights. Then the other issues at O'Hare can be queue times for TSA, or some restaurants. I can say from personal experience the TSA at O'Hare have been relatively quick, as in no more than 20 minutes to get through during most times, however, during some peak times such as 4-6 pm, then lines can get long and take over 30 minutes. It has been random since sometimes during "peak times" things have been quick. I finally got TSA pre-check, so I'll see how that goes when I fly out tomorrow. Finally the last big issue is the poor wifi. It's Boingo which is too expensive, and at times it doesn't process your purchase correctly. Try to get into a United Club for wifi. I have gone through some personal negatives, and likely negatives for flyers in Terminals 1 and 2. The good news there are pluses. For one, the food choices are good. There are some local chains including Rick Bayless own chain which has solid Tex-Mex sandwiches, and amazing Guacamole. I believe Wow Bao is located in O'Hare, and there is a local tea chain as well. Meanwhile there is an abundance of restaurant choices such as steak, Italian, seafood, cafe food, etc. From my experience I haven't had a bad meal. Keep in mind, don't expect Michelin star restaurants, but if you have a good layover, then you can get a good meal. Finally the bar scene isn't bad, but prices are airport prices. At least Goose island has bars with local tapped beer. Finally the last positive is the location. The blue line connects to O'Hare, 24/7, to the Loop. It's near I-90 and I-294 which help drivers get around anywhere in the Chicagoland area. That said, if you are going to Northwest Indiana, or Joilet, then it'll take a good hour to get there from O'hare. That said, the taxi stand is outdated and slow. Expect to spend a good 30 minutes to get a taxi. Overall it is a good big airport. It's not perfect, nor the best in the world since I've been to LHR to Narita, however, as a large US airport it's one of the better ones in my view. Especially compared to EWR or elsewhere.

commentHeader: very far with no moving walkways
reviewContent: Experience was ok. Because of delay at Rapid City Regional, I was late but the man at the desk quickly informed me I would have no trouble catching my flight to Madrid if I made my way quickly to the departing gate. Distance to the gate was very far with no moving walkways. Turns out I had plenty of time. Flight was delayed for over an hour.

We are sitting in front of McDonals in terminal L. There is garbage over flowing everywhere, all of the tables are disgusting and dirty. I see no one cleaning in the vicinity. Why treat customers this way? Have the food places clean the charging tables and other tables throughout the terminals as people are using the tables to eat their food. Have a cleaning person dedicated to specific areas so that it stays clean.

commentHeader: why cant the staff be understanding
reviewContent: My flight was cancelled due to weather, which I understand is not anyone's fault. So considering how understanding I was, especially in comparison to other very unhappy people. So you can imagine how upset I became when I was berated for moving a cot 3 ft into darker lighting. I was not aware this was a rule. I apologized and moved it back. Even after that I was harassed by the same staff member for not moving it back "right". Look, I was understanding about being stuck on a cot here after purchasing a 400 dollar ticket so why cant the staff be understanding and accommodating to me as well. It all just makes me never want to fly again.

Understaffed and rude. I mised my connecting flight due to delay with previous flight as American Airlines had overbooked their flight. They try to provide Express support to people with short connecting flights but they failed miserably due to lack of coordination. The staff at the boarding counter were rude and laughing at the time they were telling me that I missed my flight. Then they started speaking to each other in Spanish in front of me. Very rude staff.

commentHeader: too small for the volume of passengers"
reviewContent: Terminal 5 is simply not fit for purpose, security screening area is far too small for the volume of passengers. It took one hour 15 minutes to get through a tortuous winding and sweaty queue - one of my worst ever airport experiences. Once through the size and selection of the duty free shopping area is tiny - and the options on where to eat very limited and expensive. Chicago you can do way better than this.

commentHeader: passes on phones not adequate for TSA approval
reviewContent: You can tell by looking at my boarding pass that I’m TSA approved. But I was patted down because I was wearing a skirt (that’s what the TSA officer said.) I’m a 60 year old lady, who just had knee surgery and I was quite embarrassed by the this. The officer was extremely kind but I do not understand why my boarding pass on my phone was not adequate for this situation. There should be at least signs indicating that boarding passes on phones are not adequate for using your TSA approval.

Horrible, lazy, and unhelpful staff. So many open spaces where they could cut down the lines but they just lean against the wall, laugh and chat up with other security, and I even saw some sleeping on the job. After I asked 1 of the staff there for help on my gate number, they told me to google it and went back to leaning on the wall. I asked another one and they misdirected me to 2 different terminals before I finally found it on my own. They also were disrespectful and made jokes about us like " can you even see " and laughed about it with a co worker. I highly advise anyone that plans on a trip to steer clear of this airport.

Arrived from Phoenix on our way to Copenhagen. Signage is basically non-existent or useless in this airport, and it took forever just to find someone to ask where to go to catch our connection. Apparently information desks are only staffed when they feel like it. Probably the worst thing was the employees - rude, unfriendly, and unhelpful. My daughter kept saying, "can you imagine being from another country and trying to navigate this place?!" Oh, and don't come hungry if you need to travel overseas - everything in that terminal closes really early. I planned our trip so far in advance, and we were not supposed to transfer in Chicago, but unfortunately the airline changed our flight and we had to experience the hell that is O'Hare. Try very hard to avoid this airport!

The first thing I noticed was that employees in every area were lazy, rude, and disgruntled. They leaned against walls and chatted about their social plans while ignoring travelers. I believe the employees may purposely misdirected you if you ask for help. They tell you to go in the opposite direction. The airport must be managed by the same types who run Chicago. Masses of travelers bottleneck at crucial checkpoints where clearly it needs to be staffed by several employees, only one or two employees check documents when hundreds of travelers are trying to move to connecting flights. I don’t recommend that you ask anyone for help because they will lie or treat you with terrible rudeness. The entire airport is filthy, covered in food debris and dirt. It’s a little piece of Hell.

Typical ORD experience late in by an hour delayed out twice so far, travelers have experienced two gate changes and I suspect the final act of uncaring rudeness will be a cancelation. Take my advise - and I know this is hard too do - avoid this mess. Yes it's worth driving to alternative airports, yes it's worth timing headaches. Do not fly through this aeronautical gyer.

I sincerely hope I never have to travel via this airport again. It is the most disorganized, unhelpful disgrace I've ever encountered and I've travelled extensively including 3rd world airports which function far better than this place does. I had the misfortune of transiting through O,Hare on my way back from LAX, which isnt much better. On arrival in T1, I looked for the "In Transit" signs or directions to any sort of "Transit" desk or information. There was none. I walked for what seemed miles, looking for some sort of information or advice on how to proceed. The flight information board didn't show my connecting flight either so I had no way of knowing where to go or which terminal I should be looking for. The information desk was unmanned. Eventually I found a young lady who was on a security checkpoint. She advised me that I should make my way via shuttle bus to Terminal 5. Having done so, I then stood for 11/2 hours at security before I reached the gates only to find that there were no flights form my carrier (United). Again, I spent ages trying to find someone to speak to for information. Eventually I found a woman pushing a trolly. She advised me that I should be at T1 as that's where United fly from. By now my 3hr transit window had all but gone. I returned to the shuttle bus and the Queue was over 200 people deep. I approached an official with a yellow jacket on who was supposedly in charge of the queue and explained I have an extrememly short connection, he refused to allow me on the bus and told me to join the end of the queue. I had no option but to barge through or I woould miss my flight. Eventually I made it back to T1 and through security AGAIN and eventually to my gate with 5 minutes to spare. Frustrated, harassed and sweating. An absolute disgrace! No information and some very unhelpful staff. I don't blame the young lady I spoke to at T1, it was not her job and she made an honest mistake but the rest of the staff where totally uninterested and rude.

This airport is the most unorganized, chaotic, and hectic airport I have ever been to. I have flown through Chicago twice - the first time my flight was delayed for 6 hours and I didn't get to DFW until 4am the next morning, and this time my flight was delayed 5 hours and then canceled. I slept on the airport floor and my flight was rebooked to next day making it a 21 hour layover when I was only supposed to have a 3 hour layover. Now we are sitting in the airplane waiting for departure but now we cannot take off from the gate until the gate agents tell us we can. We are currently 30 minutes past our departure time. I have never been more frustrated with an airline, an airport, or the customer service received. This airport needs some serious help with organization and efficiency.

Arrived at O’Hare Terminal 5 on Monday evening around 8pm after a long trip to get there. We were hoping to get through security and then sit and have a drink and a meal as our flight wasn’t till 11:40pm. By 8:30pm nearly all the shops, bars and restaurants were closing or closed and we couldn't find nowhere serving food. The one Hudson shop open had queues snaking around the shop continually and was the only place available to get any kind of food. The services were completely inadequate for a large airport! If you can’t cater for passengers after 8pm - don’t have any flights from this time.

My husband and I arrived at the International terminal with baggage having been checked in Great Britain. We were connecting to another US flight. We had to pick up our bags and then turn them in again (all we did was carry them over, no checks occurred along the way, why can't the airline handle this along with any additional checks of our luggage?) Then, we were guided onto buses that took us out of the security zone, requiring another time through security. Unfortunately, some duty-free liquor we had purchased after clearing security in Britain had not been sealed as required, and we were forced to check it for an additional $100 fee and we almost missed our connecting flight. If we had known about the additional security clearance, we would have made sure the liquor was sealed as required or bought it in time to put in checked baggage. But never in international arrivals elsewhere have we had to leave security just to keep our original bags checked. This seems an unnecessarily cumbersome system that needs to be fixed. Until it is, we will never again book an international arrival into O'Hare. You have lost our business. For the sake of others, please see that airlines warn people that they will have to enter security again at O'Hare, so they need to be careful about liquids they acquire after initial security clearance.

I am a frequent traveler (bi-weekly flyer), and ORD was by far the worst organized airport I've ever experienced. From the food choices to the unorganized airlines to small terminal seat areas. Chicago O'Hare Airport is at the bottom of my list, and do not recommend this airport to anyone - experienced traveler or not. Doesn't seem like the airport staff care either. If they did, things would improve. It's extremely disappointing this is one of the Chicago airports. This has made my trip a very bad experience.

We had a connecting flight here between London and LAX. It was a horrible experience from beginning to end. Good thing our flight from London was an hour early because it took us 2.5 hours and we barely made our next flight. Every employee was either rude or unhelpful, and there were no visible signs to direct us. When we arrived we opted for Mobile Pass because they recommended it on our prior flight saying it would speed the process. The airport wasn't equipped for it and employees had no idea what we were talking about. We ended up in a long line for it after having a woman yelling at us for being in the wrong line. Several loud monitors blared Olympic-like music along with a weird "American pride" video which felt like something you'd see in North Korea. Picture this with a loud woman yelling the same thing over and over in the background and combine it with sleep-deprivation after a 9-hour flight. Welcome to America. There were multiple lines throughout the following process, from customs to another security checkpoint. All were very long with unhelpful rude employees. There were no visible signs telling us where to go. We ended up lost several times and nobody would help us except for a few volunteers in yellow shirts. We were then loaded up like cattle onto a bus just to get to terminal 1 after waiting in another long hot line. We then had to cut in line at security because the line looked like Disneyland and by then (2 hours later) our flight was already boarding. When I asked a TSA agent for help, he said he couldn't help me and that our only hope was to "ask everyone in front of us if we could go ahead of them", so we had no choice but to forge our way through hundreds of very angry people. We ran to our gate and barely made it for our next flight. We will avoid this airport next time.

My husband and I travelled to Chicago to attend a friend’s wedding when I was 5 months pregnant. For this reason alone we were taken aside and spent 3 hrs waiting to be questioned by customs officers. After a long flight I sat on a hard bench with no food watching customs treating people like they were sub human. At one point two officers high fived after they had upset one lady! Our questioning consisted of whether we were trying to have a baby in the US (“no we are only here for 10 days for a wedding”) and then lots of questioning regarding why we weren’t trying to have a baby in the US (“because we have a house, jobs, family, the NHS and we are just on holiday!”). He couldn’t believe we had free healthcare in the UK (perhaps do some research). At no point did he ask us whether we had insurance or to see our return flights. Completely inadequate questioning! Rather than question pregnant women for hours perhaps you should look at changing your laws so that anyone who has a baby there doesn’t automatically qualify to be a resident (if what he told us is even accurate). I won’t be returning. Really poor reflection of Chicago which is a beautiful city.

commentHeader: worst airport I have ever been in
reviewContent: Absolutely worst airport I have ever been in. Staff and security are rude and they don't tell you when they close check points at night and expect you to know already. So you get to stay outside the terminal all night. Will not travel through here again. Not to mention floors were dirty. The custodian vacuuming went down the aisle leaving food and drinks under the seats.

commentHeader: need a course in common courtesy
reviewContent: Your security clearance workers need a course in common courtesy. They are the most unfriendly and rude agents I have witnessed at airports and I thought JFK was bad. There is no excuse to treat paying customers so rudely. We follow the rules and don't need to be shouted at or treated like we stupid people. Chicago wants to improve their image, I suggest they start with the airport personnel.

Absolutely terrible. Probably the worst managed airport i’ve seen. So badly managed - how can get you get the whole airport shut down by having all gates blocked by taxiing aircraft? A bit of rain and the airport is down, complete chaos, nobody knows whats happening, all flights cancelled as crews run out of time, no planning no nothing. Look how Minneapolis MSP airport is run - no matter what weather is there it just runs like a clockwork. Shame to ORD.

This airport is terrible. The services have not been updated and for example Concourse C has terrible food service and hardly any place to sit down and everything is old and torn and there are no tables like Newark Airport or a lot of updated airports. It is uncomfortable and not very nice.

Signage is terrible in the international wing. Although it is easy to find where you need to go for immigration, the line for customs is not marked at all and I ended up in a very long line when I could have been in a short global entry line. The staff are clueless, I asked two people who sent me to the wrong line. There’s also insufficient signage to explain where to go to recheck your bags. Many people stood in one long line only to find that there was no line at all at their connecting airline but the signage not indicate any other option. It is bad enough the customs official asked me to please submit this review!

I am a born and raised Chicagoan that is extremely embarrassed at the poor operation for international arrivals at O'Hare. The airport staff are completely clueless and have no issue yelling at each other and at passengers (employees at passport control). They go out of their way to make the process more chaotic and difficult (customs). As an example, the line at customs to leave the baggage claim area was extremely long. Personnel waited until passengers went almost completely through the line before telling a few people "there is no line at carousel 3". If they had directed passengers to other available counters, the whole process would have been easier. The tram to other terminals and to access CTA was not available, but they had shuttle buses. Instead of having signage posted, they simply put "Closed" signs on the escalators heading up and had rude and unprofessional staff standing there. When asked how we were supposed to access the CTA, I was told "it's not running." What she really meant was that the tram was not running. At that point, I had already spent over 2 hours in the airport and was so tired of dealing with incompetence that I took a cab rather than deal with any other employees. Seriously, O'Hare. You need to get it together. So many people experience Chicago only through your airport, and you make us look hood. I didn't even mention the dirty bathrooms and old tattered looking furniture in many of the terminals.

My handicap father and I took six flights this April. Chicago O’Hare is the only airport that provided us with the requested wheelchair both times. The other airports failed to provide the wheelchair and forced us to wait the other 4 times. Great staff!

commentHeader: have no intention of helping you
reviewContent: I had a connecting flight from Narita to this airport going to Winnipeg. Rudest airport staff I have seen, signage is not so clear. Airport staff have no intention of helping you. Stay away from this airport. Very dissapointing.

The flight information displays in terminal 3 only show the flights from American Airlines. All other flights are not shown, not even in the display right in front of their boarding gate. We arrived at the airport several hours in advance, since we were traveling with young children. After passing security, we looked at the displays, saw that there was a single flight leaving for our destination and assumed that it would be ours, but it turned out that it was an AA flight leaving half an hour later than ours. We ended up losing our flight with Spirit, having to spend the night in a hotel and buy new tickets for the next morning with a different airline. We were going on a four day trip Friday to Tuesday, and the earliest flight that Spirit was offering us was leaving on Monday, unacceptable.

commentHeader: found the gate personnel more than helpful
reviewContent: I'm writing this review because of the negative reviews I always see for O'Hare. I've flown to this airport (to and from and mostly for connections) at least 30 times. Certainly smaller airports with no connecting flights are more comfortable because of the sheer volume of flights and customers. But I have to say that I have always found the gate personnel more than helpful each time I've needed them. Flights at O'Hare are typically delayed and take a long time but that's part of the business when you travel to a place with so many flights. When I have tried to board earlier flights or needed exceptions made, the gate personnel are always as accommodating as they can be. If you know what to ask for and ask politely you'll find typical Midwest hospitality at O'Hare.

Customs line was extremely long, the shuttle between terminal 5 and 2 was closed requiring us to use the bus between terminals, the bus dropped us off at terminal 2 that was closed. We had to run to terminal 1, go through security again due to having to go on the bus because the airport shuttle was closed. Security had 2 staff working, TSA staff extremely rude, then we had to run to terminal 2, still did not make our flight and plane left without us. Shuttles and terminals should be open until all flights are in, especially connecting flights. All airport direction staff should be informed of closed terminals to accurately direct people to their next flight to prevent delays. Airline staff at boarding window extremely rude - staff reported. I will avoid this airport from now on as customer service is very unprofessional.

commentHeader: don't want to deal with people
reviewContent: Arrived at the airport baggage claim and had to wait 45 min to 1 hr for my luggage. The whole flight was waiting and only one person checked where bags were saying they'll be coming soon. I had to phone my transfer up as soon as I was ready. Went to the information help desk to be dealt with by a rude and snotty girl. She was too busy wanting to eat and pick her orange instead of helping me. She told me I had to phone and speak to United Airlines. My transfer had nothing to do with United. All I wanted was to use the phone for 2 mins. My partner went over to United who were really helpful and phoned our transfer up straight away which took 2 mins. Don't work in customer service if you don't want to deal with people.

This is a very busy hub. Planes spend quite a bit of time on the taxiway before they are able to take off. The terminals are always crowded but there are lots of seating, eating places, and shops. Signage is good. Restrooms look old though are kept reasonably clean given the high usage. I had connections and was able to spend the time usefully. The biggest drawback I felt was the long distances between terminal gates and in the absence of moving walkways, going from one gate to another is rather tiring. Always worried about winter travel through ORD fearing a snow storm will be very disruptive. On this trip, the connections were made without any delays.

Chicago O'Hare Airport is a perfect airport if you prefer constant flight delays, dirty bathrooms and overcrowded airports. I find it amazing how this airport can continually disappoint at such a high level. Glad to hear that Appleton Airport is now starting a new route to Denver in June of 2018 so we can bypass this airport when flying west.

commentHeader: find O'Hare to be busy and crowded
reviewContent: I fly weekly for business, and connect semi-regularly through Chicago O'Hare on American Airlines. American is all in Terminal 3, concourses G, H, K and L. It can be a hefty hike from a commuter flight at the end of G to a flight at the end of L, as it's pretty spread out. In general, I find O'Hare to be busy and crowded. The concourses are too narrow for the number of travelers, and the usual boarding-time gate-cluster can choke off the entire concourse. The restrooms are generally abysmal - tiny, crowded, questionably sanitary. It's not through any fault of the staff, I regularly see staff cleaning them but O'Hare's restrooms are generally 2 or 3 stall wonders, sprinkled here and there for millions of travelers. O'Hare's dining options, on the other hand, are great. My personal favorite is the Cubana Torta from Frontera Torta in Terminal 3 - it's life-altering. There is an ample selection of dining choices whether you want fast food, upscale dining, healthy salads or a Chicago pizza. Shopping is also similarly good - I generally only need drinks and snacks, but O'Hare has the largest Hudson News I've ever seen, in the common area between Terminals 1 and 2. There are a fair number of upscale stores throughout, though. Connecting through O'Hare, I always make sure I have more than an hour between flights. Two hours is better. I have been delayed many times, to some extent or another, on my arrivals into ORD. Sometimes it's a broken regional jet. Sometimes it's a weather delay. MANY times, though, it's a delay from ground operations, after we land - my personal record is spending 45 minutes taxiing and parking out on the tarmac due to ground traffic. I would count on spending an average of 20 minutes between landing and actually reaching your gate. I still use O'Hare. It's the only airport American serves from one of my local airports, and one of only a few from my other home base. Flight selection through O'Hare is generally good. It's just the actual experience that suffers, in my experience.

commentHeader: why do they have to be so rude
reviewContent: I don’t like O’Hare anymore, all because of the rude staff at the security at the terminals 1 and 5. I know they handle thousands of people everyday and I understand that they must follow a lots of regulations, all for us travelers security, and I’m fine with that. But, why do they have to be so rude, unpolite and even humiliating? It feels like they treat us travellers as some kind of idiots and they can say and do whatever they want just because they can. This is not ok! Therefore I suggest that you give them an education in good behaviour. Unfortunately, I’m going to avoid O’Hare and chose other aiports as far as it’s possible.

Picking up exchange student, but flight again is 2 hours late! This airport is known for always departing late, and there is no accountability for this to the passenger or the waiting family! The should be accountability and reimbursement for delays, extra airport parking fees and food! This is totally irresponsible.

commentHeader: had difficulty flying through Chicago O'Hare
reviewContent: For the fourth consecutive time my husband and I had difficulty flying through Chicago O'Hare. This time, flying on United, we were delayed three hours into the airport because of weather. We arrived at 10 pm to discover we missed our connecting, express, flight by 30 minutes. No other flights to any nearby cities were leaving that evening. We thought about renting a car and driving (4-5 hrs) home, but the costs were over $250 for those agencies willing to even let us take a vehicle one way. United rebooked us on a 7 am flight the next day, but would not offer hotel vouchers. By this time it was almost midnight. The service agent mentioned that "somewhere" in Terminal 2 cots might be available for the evening. We wandered around until we discovered probably 100 people already resting in cots in Terminal 2. Kudos to O'Hare for making these available, however, never throughout the night were the lights dimmed in the corridor, nor were the TVs turned down or the overhead announcements stopped. Additionally, the airport employees continued to walk by talking loudly, or driving various vehicles as if it were 11 am, not 3 am. It was like trying to sleep at a racetrack. And then they woke us all up at 4.30 so they could put away the cots! I am sure the city of Chicago would prefer that we all go get a hotel room, but an additional expense of $100 and up is often not in the family budget - not to mention the time involved to travel in and out of the airport. We would have all been much more impressed if customer service in the form of a quiet corner to sleep had been offered.

Chicago O'Hare is a very efficiently operated airport. Flights were on time, service was good, and boarding was quick on all the gates I passed. I was using the International Terminal and I didn't have a chance to view the domestic wing of the airport, but I was impressed with the airport operations. The food near the international terminal is pretty good choice wise and the bathrooms near the terminal are clean. When asking for directions to a gate, or room, the cleaning staff and Customs Officers are very helpful. The flights from the terminal were all on time, except for one, which had a two hour delay coming from Brazil. From what I observed, the ground crew was working quickly, and getting the job done. Overall, Chicago O'Hare International Airport is a great place to use as a international departures airport if you live in the Midwest area.

commentHeader: you can do better than this
reviewContent: ORD, not a very international airport! We arrived from DFW connecting to international flight. There were absolutely no signage as to how to get to terminal M from the H/K terminal where we arrived. We walked a huge distance in the wrong direction returning to gate K19 area. Then after taking the bus to terminal M, they dumped us off at M16 where no flight information display exists. We had to walk to M8 just to get basic flight information. Come on, ORD, you can do better than this! Very unfriendly to international travelers. Even Heathrow does better than this!

I don't know where to start. Most airports have some kiosk where information can be obtained, or staff who can help arriving passengers. There was nothing. I was arriving after many hours of travel from South Asia via Qatar. After the surly, scowling passport control officer slapped my passport onto the counter with a sort-of grunt (no "Welcome home" here!), and after a harrowing experience at the baggage free-for-all, I was given no direction how to get my baggage through customs and back onto my ongoing flight to Seattle. Most airports have this part down, but queries resulted in mocking statements like "It's obvious, just follow the people over there." The people "over there" were not going to American Airlines to get their already-checked-through baggage onto the next plane, or to hand over their customs declaration form (by the way, nobody took my form and I never found any customs officials). Every query I made of some official-looking person resulted in more ridicule and less information, as the hour of my departing flight grew nearer. When I said that I had a tight connection to make, officials said that was just too bad. Why go on and on? I must say that this was my worst airport experience in 38 years of travel all over the world-mainly because of the rudeness and angry, scowling personalities of airport staff. They did not want to be bothered with helping or giving information. I barely made my connection, and that only happened because one nice woman took an interest and told me how to get my checked-through baggage back onto the plane and that I needed to go to a different terminal by train to get to my departing flight. When I finally found it, I was screamed at by security officials. Wow, Chicago, overall rating is a zero for you! I somehow doubt that you care, though.

I want first to second the comments of a UK traveler about passport control (I’m an American citizen, Chicago native.) The passport control officer was the rudest I’ve ever encountered, and I’ve traveled throughout the world, he had no eye contact, no speech, just pointed, with a scowl on his face and an attitude of pure hatred toward the people passing through. The personnel in the automated passport control, seeing people with clear need for assistance, ignored them, except to bark commands like “no cell phones” and it was unclear who they were talking to and what that really meant. I had just returned from Edinburgh where security was very careful but where people explained things clearly and were extremely polite. Apparently in Chicago expressing hostility is how you make things secure. Also last month I picked up my son there who flew in on Virgin America. Zero flight information posted for Virgin, zero. Virgin office closed. Employees I asked acted suspicious about why I was there. All the pretty restaurants don’t make up for the people.

commentHeader: rudest, least helpful, least polite staff
reviewContent: This passport has the rudest, least helpful, least polite staff in the USA. When my husband and I arrived at passport control, the guy asked us how long we were staying. We answered that we were residents with a visa. Very sarcastically, he replied "No you're not! What does it say here?" (pointing at our passports cover, as if we were unable to understand). It says "United Kingdom", not "United States". We tried to reply that we actually live in the USA and we have visas that allow us to do so, but he wouldn't have it. "Again (as if he were speaking to one year olds), what does it say here? "United Kingdom". You are not citizens". He repeated this several times, without listening to us. Knowing that, unfortunately, he could potentially be spiteful and delay our entrance to the country indefinitely (and our dog is here, so at least we wanted him back!), I had to restrain myself and just reply: "We are residents, we never said we are citizens. We live here and have done so for four years now". Finally, the penny dropped. "Ah, yes, there's a difference". And that was all. No apology for treating us like children, for his smugness, rudeness, or his mocking attitude. I can understand he can make a mistake, but it's unforgivable that he should have that attitude without even having listened to us. He treated us like we were having a hard time understanding anything, when in fact it was him who was misunderstanding the situation (and not making any effort to get the facts before answering with his stupid arrogance). It's always a shock to come back to O'Hare, as anywhere else staff is friendly and helpful. Every single time.

The more I travel, the more I appreciate O'Hare, one of my home Chicago airports. It's big and sprawling, but everything is clearly marked, staff are generally friendly and laid back, and boarding is by zone or section of the plane (not by who shoves as in much of Europe and elsewhere). You can eat well and get your drink on easily and without paying that much more than going city prices. You can take a train into town for $5. Overall, it might not be glamorous, and I'm sure that business-class travelers don't get the fawning attention they might receive elsewhere, but this is a solid beer-and-a-shot airport for the rest of us.

After the flight landed, was forced to sit on tarmac for more than an hour. Apparently due to weather, however, still very unacceptable. Crew seemed embarrassed since they were not able to predict when we would get moving. Were told "15 min" at least 4 times. Scheduling needs to be addressed by airport management.

commentHeader: every single employee was surly and rude
reviewContent: Following a great traveller/customer experience travelling out of Heathrow, where everybody I encountered was pleasant and polite, I arrived to the complete opposite at Chicago O'Hare. Every single employee of this airport I encountered was surly and rude. The immigration officer checking the kiosk outputs was off the scale rude - sarcastic, shouting out at other lines with a face like thunder - he was scowling so much. What a contrast from my Heathrow Terminal 5 experience - it just isn't necessary. Whomever is responsible for the staff at this airport needs to invest in some customer service training for their staff and sort out whatever it is which makes them so miserable if they hate their jobs so much!

commentHeader: not enough seating at the gates
queuing systems seemed to work perfectly
reviewContent: I arrived at Chicago O'Hare Airport on time from an international flight and it took me 15 minutes to leave the plane and to pass immigration as well as customs. The queuing systems seemed to work perfectly efficiently and the newly introduced one-stop-priciple for passengers travelling with handluggage only did a great job. In addition, the train service at this airport is great although there is no airside link between the terminals avialable. My general impression of terminals 5 and 1 was that they were very clean. Moreover, the variety of shops, restaurants and cafés cover a broad range of tastes and they are a gorgeous option to shorten the waiting time.

6th June. This airport was very crowded, and it was hard to navigate through it. It was also strange that I had to pass through security control again since I had to move from a domestic terminal to the international terminal. The queues were indeed very long and time consuming. However, when passing through finally, it showed up to be efficient with modern scanners that accepted to just put the bag through without having to put out computer and liquids apart from the bag. That system is well recommended in all Airports so the security checks can be more efficient. The worst thing is that it was not so easy to navigate and it was so crowded. It was quite clean, but it could be a bit better. I can however recommend the Airport since they actually do their best in their situation anyway.

commentHeader: plenty of options for food and shopping

reviewContent: No apparent courtesy carts for the disabled. I have a severely arthritic left hip and was forced to hoof it clear across Terminal 3 to Concourse L. Enroute, I has to pass through one of the most disorganized and slow TSA check-points I've seen. Halfway through the maze we get pulled out of line by a TSA employee who marches us halfway down the terminal in the opposite direction just to insert us into another long TSA line with no explanation, nothing. Not even an "I apologize." Midway (MDW) is a polar opposite.

commentHeader: a crowded mess but we survived
an ok airport for a local flight

reviewContent: I have been flying out of/into Norfolk airport my whole life and have always had a pleasurable experience with it; this time was no different. The Southwest check-in agent was very friendly, as were the TSA employees at the checkpoint. My bag got flagged as a possible explosive, but luckily they figured out it wasn't. A major plus ORF has to offer is its new bathrooms, which were installed less than a year ago. These are sleek, modern, and well-maintained by airport staff. The terminal itself reflects the era it was built in, with smaller windows and lower ceilings than, say, SEA. Instead of inducing claustrophobia, though, it gives the entire a building a more "cozy" feeling. New seats at the gates with electrical outlets are also a major plus, allowing you to charge your phone while you wait for your plane. One downside of Norfolk International, though, is the WiFi. It is very hard to connect to and hardly works. Aside from that, though, this is a small, practical, no-frills airport that is impossible to get lost in and is located near the Norfolk Botanical Gardens (another positive).

commentHeader: airport is dirty and falling apart

reviewContent: Great airport. Easy to park, easy to get to terminal and fast security. Beats almost every other larger airport I have been to. Not much to do but you won't be there long anyway.

Portland's airport feels slightly dated, not run down by any means, but still pleasant and functional enough. A lot of construction taking place at this time in the check-in area, I guess in an effort to modernize the airport and expand passenger capacity. The terminals themselves, again, are a little dated, but still nice enough and functional. TSA Pre-Check operates smoothly here, even where there are a lot of Pre-Checkers in line. Personnel, whether they're working at check-in, for TSA, in a restaurant, or at the boarding gate, are usually super bubbly, but still professional, helpful and polite. PDX is neither stellar nor bad, it's above-average but with a lot of potential. And, it's better than Sea-Tac!

A quiet afternoon at PDX. Short queues to get through security with efficient and helpful staff. As the space allocated for security was fairly small, I can imagine at that at busy times there could be problems.

commentHeader: they only had drinks and chips
reviewContent: We were pressed for time so we didn't stop and eat, our plane was scheduled to leave at 9.15pm. We arrived an hour and 45 minutes early but nothing was open except a place across from gate E11 and they only had drinks and chips. I realize there is a labor shortage but if you look at the chart that depicts the busiest time at this airport 9pm is the busiest. Wouldn't you think that would be the best time to schedule staff?

commentHeader: should really get their act together
reviewContent: I used to think the PDX was an ok airport, and after tonight’s security fiasco, I am changing my tune. 10 people got through the security line in 30 mins. She said my neck pillow, which had grains in it, could be explosive. She swabbed it on the outside then took out the sealed insert and swabbed the inner layer. And said “people try and take explosives, it could be explosive” my response was. “It's a neck pillow” if those weren’t allowed to take on flights, then put a sign up! The arrogance of the TSA staff is ridiculous. 30 minutes to let through 10 people! The two families with small children in front of me are not security risks. They’re now super stressed out single moms! Because you took apart all of their children’s things and made them wait in a line for no reason. It felt just like they were being mean and literally searching through every persons bags. It was the worst security experience ever, and I’ve flown through JFK and it’s not like the other TSA agents were doing anything, at least 10 of them they were just standing around talking about their weekend. Flying can already be stressful, there’s no need for the drama over neck pillows. It was ridiculous. Portland International Airport should really get their act together and maybe use some more common sense in the hiring of their TSA agents.

This is my local airport and not a bad little place. Yes, at times TSA slows things down to a crawl, but the TSA workers here seem to actually have a sense of pride and a sense of humor. I have a steel hip and this has caused numerous delays in other airports but either they know me by now or they have their collective ish together. Food offerings are decent and the Powell's Bookstore is a great place to grab a book for your flight. My only bummer is that it IS a smaller metro airport and thus fewer international nonstops.

Arrived at the top deck outside the ticketing counters to pick up my college-age daughter (American Airlines Flight 6088) after waiting near the airport to receive a text telling me she was approaching the exit. Airport traffic was light with several empty spaces for cars to pull up to the curb. I had been there no more than 2-3 minutes when a military-looking airport security guard suddenly started pounding on my passenger window. "Get out of here!" I rolled down the window to tell him I had waited for notice my passenger was available and he leaned all the way into my car and shouted, "If it was alright for you to be here, would I be talking to you?" I pulled my head back so fast I smacked the driver's door. He was completely out of control and shouting as if a major emergency were happening. I sincerely thought he was going to hit me or continue striking my car. I saw my daughter out of the corner of my eye and was immediately afraid for her safety. I pulled away as fast as I could so he wouldn't realize she was connected to me. I'm 62 and a small woman. Portland International Airport doesn't deserve all the high ratings. This isn't the first time I've had their airport personnel act like they enjoy menacing people. Whoever trains their security people needs to be trained themselves.

What is wrong with this place. My flight is leaving at 12.30 am and literally nothing is open here. You can get nothing here after 10pm apparently. Utter nonsense. They call themselves an "international airport"? Get real-it's a parochial bastion of complete boredom with no libations.

The international arrival system sucks. There are about 15 machines to verify your password and to answer customs questions which worked great, but then you get in a very slow moving queue with 2 customs officers to ask the same questions you just answered. Do the math 15 machines then down to two agents guess what happened ... we all got through the machines quickly just to get stuck in a slow moving line for the worthless additional step. Then you grab you luggage and yet another agent only one this time checks your customers and passport again. Then you get on a bus to take you to the main baggage pick up area, why can’t you just walk like the rest of the airport access. And yes there was another line for the bus. Seriously PDX you can do better ... lovely carpet only goes so far.

commentHeader: TSA is horrible at this airport
reviewContent: TSA is horrible at this airport. I don't hear well, but I'm well versed in the procedures we are forced to go through. Staff kept screaming something at me, I had no idea what, but I knew what was expected so ignored him and was just waiting my turn to go through the screener; he actually grabbed me by the shoulder and pulled me back! I am nearly 70 years old, female, I jerked away and he pulled me back and screamed at me to empty my pockets! I do not have things in my pockets, good grief.  Got to my boarding area, Southwest C12, and sat down to read and wait ... looked down and the metal bar between the seats was covered with filth. It was so thick you could run your fingers through it. So disgusting, I got up and looked for a clean seat, and they were all filthy, so I just got some exercise and walked for two hours. I cannot believe how filthy it was.

40 minutes to get through security. 25 in line and then the worst was the arrogant attitude of all TSA when my bag was pulled to be checked - it sat there for 5 minutes. 4 workers stood right there within 3 feet of it talking to each other. After 5 minutes another woman walked nearby and I went to her and said my bag has been there 5 minutes - she had an arrogant attitude as well and said with an annoyed tone - someone will get to it. I waited another 3 minutes - 2 of the 4 talking walked the other direction and 2 still talked a minute or more - I tried to get their attention but was ignored. I saw another man standing around and told him my bag had been there almost 10 minutes - same attitude - “someone will get to it”. With an attitude a minute later a still waiting - I saw a woman who I complained to and she said same thing with an attitude. Meanwhile a TSA man had gone to the next row over and started checking 2 or 3 bags that had come out way after mine - mine was only bag for a full five minutes at least. It took 15 minutes. Rude people that don't care and think they are god because they have so much power over your life and you can’t do anything about it. I hate this airport.

Every single time I have flown out of Portland it has been amazing. All of the staff are very nice and kind. I usually fly out of Portland on Alaska Airlines which I also think is the best U.S. carrier. It is relatively small and easy to navigate. Has enough seating for everyone on the flight. I once flew in to LAX and we had 3 hours till our next flight and there was no seating, well there was some, but only enough for about 20 passengers. So overall I think Portland International Airport is the best airport in the United States.

commentHeader: is now dropping to the unfavored list
reviewContent: One side of security check was closed, without notice at main entrance. At the D/E security check, my husband and I were told that our TSA passes on our phones 'could have been photo-shopped' so we'd need to proceed through security as usual - unpacking liquids, toiletries, digital devices, removing our shoes and jackets. This was super unusual and uncalled for. What is the point of paying for the additional service and being frequent travelers if there is no recognition of our ability to comply? Portland, once a favored airport, and our former home airport at that, is now dropping to the unfavored list - akin to San Diego - an airport that we avoid.

I fly 3x a year through Portland Airport and the TSA agents were so nice and helpful today that I had to give them props. Thanks for a very pleasant experience! Plus, the security lines were very short. Bonus!

commentHeader: Why do they need to be so rude?
reviewContent: I have been to this airport many times. It is a very nice, clean and for the most part friendly. But the last few times the TSA has been nothing but rude!We have had one TSA employee shove my son's stuff down the lane making him almost drop his computer and then yell at him because he said "what the hell?" Yes he said hell because it surprised him and he is 22. Then the guy got all upset because he said hell and told me he cursed at him when he didn't. The guy wasn't even wearing a uniform or a badge! He was completely rude to me when I asked why he had to shove his stuff down! Even the people around us where talking about how rude he was to my son so I know it wasn't just us. Then we were just at the airport this last weekend and there was a normal size line for security and it was moving fine. We got past the licence check and this little guy was yelling at people to "Pick a line or I will pick one for you!!" Everyone was moving fine there was an older lady who was a little slow because of her age and she looked so upset by what he said. Why do they feel they need to be so rude?! There was no reason for him say that even if we were all slow!!  I sure hope my next trip to PDX will be much better. It's always been a friendly airport so I am hoping that's what it will be next time.

I am not a world traveller but do have quite a bit of experience over my 60 years. I cannot find a better airport than Portland in terms of access, TSA service, parking, car rental, and restaurants. It is small enough to have that hometown feeling unlike LAX or SFO yet large enough that you will notice the long lines at peak periods. Yet, the TSA seems to be much more responsive and best of all, compassionate in this most painful point of travel. They seem to be able to open new lines, cross cover one another and be cheerful at the same time. Best of PDX is that the provide an area to accommodate families and fiends to greet incoming pax. All other airports just want you to drop off and get out. Here they have stores and restaurants outside of the security where we can meet and greet. I do not recall any other airport like this. Overall, just a smart, caring design that works for me.

Portland Airport has got to be one of the best airports in the system, with the sole exception of very long walking distances. Check-in is swift, TSA friendly and courteous, amenities are bountiful and terminal is clean. Food is reasonably priced and close to gates, parking is excellent compared to Chicago's mess. Would highly recommend this airport.

Long lines. Unable to hear employees calling for flights that need passengers to skip to front of lines that are 1 hour long. Missed my flight because they can’t communicate with passengers. I was literally there in line. I got a call asking if I was going on the flight. I confirmed I was but was waiting to check my bag. She told me check bag time for the flight ends 45 minutes before departure and it was too late for me and to find a representative. I cut everyone in line and spoke with a lady at the counter who said they announced for all people on my flight to go directly to the counter ahead of the line. I told her no one in line can hear anything they are saying. She said that’s what she’d been telling her coworkers. After she confirmed I couldn’t get a new flight for 2 days I sat and waited for my ride to come back and get me and I then witnessed an employee walk around and shout the names of 3 destinations whose flights were needing to have customers go to the front of the line immediately to check in. I was furious because had it been done sooner I could’ve been on my way home with my seven year old who was sobbing because he couldn’t go home to his dad. I will never use this airport again. I am so frustrated.

Very small airport which is not necessarily a problem. The problem we have every time we travel into or from PGD is that they have inconsistent rules nearly every time. We have TSA pre-check which we paid to obtain. At all other airports this allows us to leave our shoes belts and light jackets on as well as laptops and ipads in our bags. Not at PGD. Even though they hand us a piece of paper that identifies us as TSA pre-check travelers we have to remove belts, jackets and laptops/ipads nearly every single time. It is as if the TSA agents at PGD went to completely different classes than every other agent in the country. Not to mention how rude some of them can be about it as well. I really try to avoid this airport as much as possible.

They should spend more money on putting gates in the airport instead of a multi million dollar resort. Plus there isn't any place to eat and minimal places to sit. When a full plane comes in and you have to stand for a minimum of 1 hour it gets pretty bad - at least for seniors.

I found Philadelphia International Airport very confusing to navigate. Fortunately, we had requested wheelchair assistance for my mum who has limited mobility. The guy Cordell who helped us was friendly, approachable and kind which made our experience so much more pleasant!

I was subjected to a very intimate search three times by two different TSA agents. The scanner was obviously malfunctioning. How do I know? Well, I was clean but it kept saying I wasn't.  Then, walking on the tarmac to the plane, a baggage handler insisted that I had to "valet" my carry-on bag. Once inside, seeing the mostly empty luggage bays, I complained to the flight attendant. She went and brought the bag to me with apologies Arrival was okay, but the I had to follow a "bread crumb" trail of corridor, stairs and turns -- all with inadequate signage. Eventually I arrived at two luggage bays and was (at first) relieved to see my flight posted as "unloading." But it turned out that we did not get our luggage in hand for 1hr 50mins. No information from the uncommunicative employee in the Baggage Office. She said they were trying to find the agent to "see if he has any more bags." (I'm being generous here). She told me to scan a lost baggage claim code -- which did not work.

commentHeader: no peace or calm between flights
reviewContent: They play non stop super LOUD ads at the gates while you wait. That with the combination of fluorescent lights, It creates the absolute worst atmosphere that you can imagine. There’s no peace or calm between flights while you wait.

commentHeader: cleanliness of the gate was atrocious
reviewContent: I have been waiting in terminal b gate b8 since 4pm 8/19/24 for a flight which has been delayed 4 times and by 7 and 1/2 hrs. No information given over the speakers as to any changes. We have to constantly check the app. No airline attendants at the gate at all to ask any questions. (This is for aa flight 437). The lounge air was freezing and people were not prepared for that. Also the food areas that the airport offers in this section have no prices in the menu and he. You look it up online who the heck is paying $25 for a burger. Not even in London airports are they that expensive. And the cleanliness of the gate was atrocious. No one came by to clean up the trash all over the floor. It just seems like the airport did not care enough to provide good customer service. And the airline was a joke in giving us current information over the speaker system. I am rating this a 2/10 and that is generous!

Over an hour wait for a gate. Seems like it happens every time. Apart from the wait - the condition of the public restrooms and general cleanliness is embarrassing. The Philly airport aligns with Philly’s nickname - Filthadelpehia - why can’t we be better than this? Ideas - larger bathroom stalls so an individual traveling by their self can enter with their luggage? Warm water and soap to wash hands. Sensors that actually work and stay on while you are washing. Better coordination of empty gates. Clean more frequently. Power wash the exterior - gum and cigarette butts everywhere - yuck Ban smoking within 200 yards of the terminal Plant flowers

Specifically Terminal C: ladies rooms were filthy dirty and smelled terribly. Gate lounges were dirty and no trash picked up. Quick food place by gate 19 had gross looking sandwiches behind case, husband saw worker touch garbage then pick up slices of ham without washing his hands. Workers, including stores, restaurants, airline workers had bad attitudes, some not even acknowledging you spoke to them or asked a question of them. I have honestly never seen such deplorable conditions at an airport, hope basic manners and cleanliness return soon.

commentHeader: shocked at how few seats there were"
reviewContent: My first impression of this airport was the huge queue for passport control. I counted three desks open for hundreds of arriving passengers, it took around an hour to get to the front where I was greeted by a surly immigration officer. No smile, no "hello", just barking demands. Once I was through that I needed to change terminal to get my connection to Knoxville, which led to another problem, a distinct lack of signs. Eventually I found the shuttle bus and proceeded to security where a female employee was screaming, actually screaming at passengers. I overheard another employee ask her to dial it down but she ignored him and continued the screaming. Brilliant. Eventually made it to my gate only to find there was a distinct lack of seating, with people standing here there and everywhere. On my return trip I was heading to LHR on an AA 787, and was shocked at how few seats there were at the gate. Overall, it's a big airport with the staffing levels and seating provision of a small airport which also assumes passengers know the airport inside out and don't need signs to get where they need to be.

Me and my son arrived from Doha via American airlines on April 20, 2024 at 2:55 pm. We had a connecting flight Air Canada same day at 4.35PM. We had to pick up our bags and go thru security check again. They sent us thru a second Agriculture security check. We begged them that we are Canadian citizens but they would not allow us to bypass the queue for inspection of bags. We missed our onwards flight. We dropped of our bags after security and bags left for Toronto on April 20 and we were left behind. We check into a hotel as there was no night flight, bought new American Airlines tickets and left on April 21 at 8.35am.We lost $1600 for no fault of ours. Worst airport, worst service and very rude staff. Avoid this airport if you can,

Baggage claim, terminal A- 3 carousels but only one in use. Hundreds of people clamoring for luggage. Then our luggage was lost- INSIDE THE AIRPORT. AirTag and the AA app confirmed the luggage had arrived. But the geniuses at American couldn’t locate it. We all waited 2 hours for them to finally find the bags they misplaced. The lack of transparency and honesty made it worse than it had to be. PHL sucks.

commentHeader: lack any kind of civil behavior
reviewContent: They have staff who are fairly adept at their job but have accepted that the airport is abysmal, its pretty sad, that no one is responsible or has any idea on what to do. Their general demeanour is passing the buck to someone else. It would be generous to say they had any idea of how baggage control works. They have passengers running from one belt to another, like musical belts early in the morning or late in the evening, often losing passengers baggage because of connecting flights with the very lethargic excuse, well its not here.
