I was told to "wait". After 30 minutes, the wheelchair never arrived and there was no United Airlines employee at the gate to check on the status of the wheelchair while I waited. Needless to say, the walk not only caused me pain, but also exacerbated my injuries. Further, I was almost knocked down twice by people running to catch connecting flights because they were not allowed sufficient time to cover the 1 mile walk in a safe manner. In the future I will fly to Boise, St. George, Las Vegas or other locations which do not connect to SLC and then drive to SLC if I have to go there in order to avoid the airport. But otherwise, I'm now staying away from Salt Lake for vacations and will avoid it as much as I can for business purposes.

commentHeader: poorly designed airport should never have opened
reviewContent: This poorly designed airport should never have "opened" until all key components were up and running. The poor signage has still not improved despite numerous complaints. The wheelchair transport is a joke and virtually nonexistent unless it's between 8.00-4.00, Monday through Friday (and forget it if you dare fly on a holiday!). The bottleneck at TSA is a new twist which usually wasn't a problem before. One of the most egregious hallmarks of this billion dollar monstrosity is no train and/or shuttle. The walking sidewalks (if working) move pathetically slow. The elderly, the disabled, the unconditioned are forced to walk 1+ miles to terminal B. The response to these complaints from the paying public is signage "distracts from the beauty of the building", "wheelchair transport should be arranged through the airline by you", "TSA is being thorough", "we don't have a shuttle due to too many accidents", "there is a train scheduled to be up and running in 2024". Well none of these lame excuses helps today. I have one more trip planned this summer and after that I am done with the SLC airport.

This new multi million dollar airport absolutely sucks! Who ever approved the blueprints of this new terminal needs to be kicked in the rear end! You have to go to the third floor to check in then you have to go back down to the second floor for security. Seems like a waste of time and could be very confusing for some people. And why is it so humid in here? Somebody’s relative must of got paid well plus the kick backs some people got because this place makes no sense. The old airport was so much better than what has been built.

commentHeader: the worst laid out airport I've ever been to.
reviewContent: This is by far the worst laid out airport I've ever been to. It is legitimately >1 mile walk from getting dropped off at the curb, go through security, and make it to the middle B gates. I'm not saying they don't have carts for the elderly or disabled to be shuttled, but I didn't see one over the course of my 20 minute walk from security to my gate. There needs to be a subway/rail system set up to accommodate travelers better. They do have moving floors in the tunnel, but there are gaps that don't have the floor. Not sure why anyone would want to get off the floor midway through a tunnel that has no services or even a bench to sit on. At minimum they should have installed two floors for each direction and have them run the entire length. Restaurants and shops are sparse in the B terminal. Giving the new design a 2/10 only because it has new paint. There's not much else that was done right with this one.

What a shame the officials at Salt Lake City let the imbeciles who never intend to use this airport design it for them. Along that line, those responsible for approving the idiotic design, must be held accountable as well. I've traveled around the world on business and pleasure for 40 years and never have I witnessed such ineptitude in moving people through an airport, especially one that was built in the 21st century, as the mishmash known as SLC. Twenty to thirty minute walks are great, except when traveling through an airport, but that is what the geniuses responsible for this design came up with. I suppose it didn't dawn on them the elderly, or those with ambulatory issues, may have to use this facility. Designing from scratch, with no restrictions of trying to fit a new facility within the confines of an existing airport, and this joke of an airport is what nearly $5B got the traveling public using Delta's hub in Salt Lake City.

commentHeader: what a waste of space and money!
reviewContent: This is the worst airport I’ve ever had to travel to/from! Horrible design, ridiculous layout, incompetent staffing! I have traveled to several countries and all around the US. I don’t care how big or new SLC Airport is, what a waste of space and money!

Beautiful airport, awful design. I would hazard if at the end of “b” gates, you’d have to walk 1/2 mile to get to baggage. Any other airport of this size in the world would have shuttles or a train. I’m in good shape, and I’ve never failed to break a sweat walking either to baggage or exit. Very poor design. It’s time inefficient and unpleasant. The fix? Put in a train.

commentHeader: Do not go to this airport if you can't walk well or long distances
reviewContent: I have never seen an airport that requires the people traveling to walk as far between terminals as well as poorly marked as for which way to go such as A to B. Our plane sat on the tarma longer than it should have before letting us disembark therefore we had limited time to get from place to place. Signs were not placed well to direct which way to go to B terminal and the walk was horrendous. The mass of people walking through the airport was unbelievable and although moving sidewalks were offered, with people not moving over to allow the folks that need to get somewhere to get there. Do not go to this airport if you can't walk well or long distances. Get some trains like Atlanta, or something. Poor design. I will find another airport to go to before I fly back thru this one. How do you pass the ADA standards for disabled folks?

commentHeader: I now avoid SLC at all costs
reviewContent: I used to fly into SLC a lot since I'm living in a small town in Southern Utah who's airport only serves 2 flights a day (Delta to SLC). SLC used to be a great place to transfer with immediate access to the terminal via a short concourse upon deplaning. Now for the smaller flights you get dropped off on the tarmac where a shuttle specific to that flight awaits the plane. The worst part is that that shuttle will not leave the location until every last passenger, crew member and checked carry-on luggage has been piled into the shuttle. Expect an extra 20 minutes at least until you get to the terminal. I now avoid SLC at all costs and drive a bit to other airports that don't force an SLC stop, but unfortunately I'm captive many times and there are no other solutions. If you're picking up luggage in SLC from one of the smaller planes, it could be an hour from landing. It's a shame that what was once a great airport has been redesigned with such little concern to user experience.

I have never seen an airport that requires the people traveling to walk as far between terminals as well as poorly marked as for which way to go such as A to B. Our plane sat on the tarmac longer than it should have before letting us disembark therefore we had limited time to get from place to place. Signs were not placed well to direct which way to go to B terminal and the walk was horrendous. The mass of people walking through the airport was unbelievable and although moving sidewalks were offered, with people not moving over to allow the folks that need to get somewhere to get there. Do not go to this airport if you can't walk well or long distances. Get some trains like Atlanta, or something. Poor design. I will find another airport to go to before I fly back thru this one. How do you pass the ADA standards for disabled folks?

commentHeader: What a poorly thought out airport
reviewContent: I had heard they had expanded this airport but what a disaster. The airport is so spread out with no access to a tram or shuttle within the terminals. We walked from our Southwest Terminal to the baggage claim then to the rental car area. The moving escalators are available but so very slow to navigate (it really just provides a place to rest while you move at a snails pace) and we walked and walked to get to the baggage claim area. It was at least 30 minutes and both of us have bad knees. What a poorly thought out airport. There should be shuttles in the terminals for people who need some assistance. Even my friends who live in SLC remark about how poorly this expansion is designed when you have to retrieve baggage. After this experience this last Wednesday we are going to cut our vacation short and come back halfway from Yellowstone to SLC so we have enough time to navigate. Beware - besides the poorly designed baggage claim area - the rental car area is even farther. If you are going to rent from an offsite company it is poorly marked about where to pick up your shuttle. I am in airports every week - poor poor design. Get those shuttles running to assist people who need it.

I am a business traveler, who in a normal year, travels 200,000 miles and passes through 10-20 Airports. I was looking forward to the new Salt Lake City airport after all of the publicity touting that it would be one of the most spectacular airports in the country. What a disappointment! I don’t think the passenger experience was even considered. They amount of walking involved adds an extra 20 to 30 minutes to reach the gate. Even worse than that is there are few resources to help those who have physical issues. There is no seating on the long Aulson non functioning walkways and few carts to give people a ride. The wonderful restaurants that many of us had come to appreciate at the old airport are gone. I have to fly in and out of the airport frequently and each time I’m there I am profoundly surprised and disappointed at the layout of the airport which in actuality does not offer more gates than the old airport. I have written in voice my concerns and has been told that I am in the minority and that most people are quite happy with the airport.

commentHeader: it is the most poorly designed airport
reviewContent: I have issues with positive reviews on the SLC airport website in the past 2 months as last time I checked in Feb. 2021, 99% were negative. I think reviews have been altered so that the public thinks this new airport is a good thing. In reality, it is the most poorly designed airport I have traveled through anywhere (and I travel a good deal). There is no thought to customer convenience or time and ease of getting from one point to another. I had to walk over a quarter mile from my parking shuttle drop, through the parking garage across a skywalk to check my bag on a different level. Had to go to another level to get to security. 1.2 mile walk to get to Southwest terminal after going through security. No bus or train option. No seating in thoroughfare if you must stop. You have to find an open seat at a gate amidst those waiting to board a flight. No Smartcarts except in parking garage at $6 fee. When returning to SLC, baggage claim sign hardly visible as it has same size small letters as Delta lounge and ground transportation and is listed with those items even though baggage claim is the main thing people look for when getting off the plane. When you finally get to baggage claim, there are no benches or seats. The seats are in one place past baggage claim. I don't know why anyone would even use them there, makes no sense! Terrible, inconvenient, difficult to navigate airport. Every business associate and personal guest has complained to me about it. I am ashamed it is our only option.

commentHeader: new SLC airport is a disaster
reviewContent: The new SLC airport is a disaster. Everything about it is awful - they’ve crammed all arrivals and departures through a single limited space - so drop off and pick up is a mess. The have 2 concourses connected by an underground corridor which you have to walk - assume an extra half hour. They demolished the old terminals and don’t have enough gates - so planes park on the tarmac and they bus you to the farthest possible point from baggage claim. I’ve been to third-world countries with better airports. And the thing is it’s brand new - spent $1b - who are the nitwits who thought of this? I’d recommend skipping SLC and vacation elsewhere until they slap some fixes on this - a real solution is years away.

commentHeader: The new airport is a design disaster
reviewContent: The new airport is a design disaster. We arrived by taxi about 1.5 hours before the departure time. The first oddity is that you enter on level 1, go to level 3 to drop off baggage and get boarding passes, then go down to level 2 to access the gates. A bit strange, but not a deal breaker. On level 2 there is a single TSA check point. The line had to be at least a 1/4 mile long. We had first class tickets, but did not see the priority boarding entry until we were nearly thru the general boarding line. We had the misfortune of departing from Terminal B. It took us at least 1/2 hour to walk there. I do not think we ever had a longer walk to a departure gate.

The construction is very inconvenient, unloaded plane into a bus onto a long hot ramp. Delivered into the wrong gate, long walk to the correct gate. Walked up to the desk, clearly marked for my destination and started to ask a question. I was rudely informed that she wasn't servicing our flight yet (it was in an hour). Then asked if it was a full flight to which they replied that it was a relative term, what did I want! You know when people are being inconvenienced anyway, would it be so difficult not to act like a jerk on top of it? Is this a Salt Lake City thing? The Delta staff in Tucson were lovely.
I’m a frequent traveler and SLC is one of the worst airport in the United States.. The entrance is very confusing and distance between terminal is ridiculous. Very poor design.

commentHeader: Horrible is the best way to describe it
reviewContent: I didn't want to believe what I was hearing about the long hike through the airport from my dad who flies all the time. He doesn't want to fly anymore because of it and now after the other day when I flew out and back in on the same day, I see why. Horrible is the best way to describe it. I am glad it was just me flying and not my child. I thought the long walk was done after the security point but man was I wrong. It then starts a long walk down a hall, then down an escalator, then down a long hall, then up an escalator, then down a long hall till it breaks up into 2 halls to gates. So ridiculous. I am seriously considering never using SLC airport again. I would rather drive 12 hours to my destination then walk that ever again. Just getting to baggage claim is a nightmare and then figuring out how to get outside to get picked up, a whole new nightmare. I don't mind walking, even though medically it is hard for me right now and I did it but that was the most ridiculous thing ever. I left mad.

commentHeader: SLC Airport Authority should be ashamed
reviewContent: SLC Airport Authority should be ashamed. What a terrible design. Seems similar in footprint to ATL but no tram option? How could you miss that? Insanely long walks. Minimal seating for seniors to rest. Weak/unmanageable WiFi. Very poor restaurant selection; why no food court? Seriously you blew this one, and someone needs to be held accountable, but probably won’t be.

commentHeader: large, spacious and clean, but not designed that well
reviewContent: The airport is large, spacious and clean, but not designed that well. A lot of wasted space that requires a lot of unnecessary walking. The TSA priority lines are a joke. They have some agents sitting at their stations with no one to screen while other lines are overcrowded. Will not be coming through SLC airport in the future.

commentHeader: The new SLC airport fails at all of these
reviewContent: How to gauge if an airport is a good airport? Average walk time to a gate from the entry? Average walk time from gate to gate? Food options? Average distance of food/drinks from a gate? The new SLC airport fails at all of these. I've listened and talked to airline personnel, strangers, and friends about how painful it is to walk such long distances and the limited food/drink options. I read a Deseret article where they talk about it a "cathedral to transportation". I think that might be the problem, they thought they were building a church not an airport people need to use.

commentHeader: Laughable that anyone thought this was a good design
reviewContent: Worst renovation ever and will only get worse as more people travel. TSA struggled when few people there with new equipment. Can hardly imagine a busy day. The ingress and egress into the airport will lead to multiple accidents and already unsafe conditions driving into the airport. Laughable that anyone thought this was a good design.

commentHeader: should be fired over this airport design
reviewContent: Someone should be fired over this airport design. It is not reasonable to expect the average person to walk this distance dragging a 30 pound suitcase. If you don’t need to fly into SLC, don’t.

This airport is a disaster! This was the least friendly airport for its patrons that I have ever been in, and I have traveled a lot. I was excited to try out the new airport since I'd heard so many things about how streamlined and efficient it would be. That is absolutely not the case. When we first departed from the airport, I was very disappointed with how humongous it is, with no concessions for people to move through it easily (except a few slow moving walkways). It is so large it's difficult to get from one place to another, and it takes forever to get anywhere. It seems as if you're walking for miles before you get to your destination, and the signage is not clear, you're not sure where to go. It was a disappointing experience. However, our return experience was even worse! We are 65 and 70 years old. Although we're on the older side, we're in pretty good shape, having just returned from a dive trip. After traveling all day and being worn out from travel, we thought we were going to die of exhaustion before we got out of there. I'm sure we must have walked over two miles just to get out! I have a bad right hip which is usually manageable, but after walking and walking and walking, and walking some more, I thought I was going to die before I got out of there. There are no accommodations for those with health difficulties - how did they ever pass ADA regulations? I didn't see one vehicle that could move elderly or disabled people from one place to another. The design is horrendous - it is so spread out, it's definitely not conducive to anyone that has difficulties ambulating. There is no tram system, as is used in most other airports to move people from one section of the airport to another. Although there is a place for a future tram, it needs to be put in place immediately, not years down the road. And, the way it's laid out, I'm not sure it will decrease the walk time for the patrons. Who designed this thing, and did the city actually sign off on the design? Did they not care about whether it was doable for its patrons? Obviously, no one thought about those that cannot easily walk several miles. And, they have cast the parking shuttles into outer darkness, probably to benefit themselves and their own parking garage. After picking up baggage, you used to be able to walk out the door and pick up the parking shuttles. Now, after walking through the whole airport, you then have to walk another half mile to get to the outside rim of the parking lot to a small designated spot for the parking shuttles. It appears they're trying to drive them out of business and inconvenience their customers! It is really a travesty! The next morning I was almost lame with pain from trying to navigate the airport with my sore hip the night before. I will do everything I can to avoid this airport, I will be driving whenever possible simply to avoid this airport.

Agree with the poor reviews regarding layout and design. Whoever designed this and whatever board approved said design are clueless. The tight connections that Delta was known for here are still present, yet you have to strap on your Hokas and be ready to run a marathon. It really is a joke. I’ll take extra flights to avoid this airport.

commentHeader: they will never be able to fix the design of this airport
reviewContent: I can not complain enough, swear enough or be so damn disappointed in this airport. I have been flying out of the old airport for more than 15 years 2 times per month or more. It was amazing, easy and efficient. My colleagues loved coming to see us in SLC and always complemented us on our easy our airport was to navigate. We went from my No. 1 most favorite airport to the absolute worst airport in the whole world. Of course it looks nice and is clean, it's new. However they will never be able to fix the design of this airport and the amount of time it adds to my regular travel plans. It will take me 30 minutes just to walk from terminal B through terminal A out of the building and all the way back around to catch the train. I used to be able to walk off the train and onto my flight in 20 minutes, that includes going through security. Anytime you have to post walk times, you failed. I seriously want the tax money back that paid for this. I just cant tell you how mad I am that this is my home airport. Airlines! Please start trying to add flights in Provo! I don't want to have to use this airport.

What a shame. This airport might look flashy, but it worse than the one it replaced in literally every other way I have experienced and can think of. It is truly a tragedy that we are stuck with this utterly horrible design for decades.

commentHeader: We are so disgusted at the layout of our airport!
reviewContent: We are so disgusted at the layout of our airport! It is such a mess to find where to go! It takes forever to get from point A to point B, you could die of a heart attack! No help, no chairs! I could not take my mother on a trip, she would not survive the airport! Also the park n jet shuttles etc are cast out into outer darkness way behind the entire airport why? You can’t treat us all like this! We will try to avoid this airport, sad thing is that all of our kids and 11 grandchildren live out of state and it doesn’t make them want to visit home now. So sad!

A total and utter disaster. The people who designed the new SLC airport should have to spend every work day walking the miles and miles of corridors to go from plane to baggage claim or from entry to gate. It’s simply too much walking. I don’t know how anyone with a disability or anyone elderly can deal with this place. Are we not wanted in Salt Lake City? How on earth did it pass ADA regulations? Not only are distances a problem but checking in on one floor then having to go to another to get to security and the gates makes absolutely no sense. It may be more efficient for the planes but it’s hellacious for the flying public. Can’t understand how such a project could be so badly botched.

In an age of project planning, focus groups, and ADA, how is this even legal. Appalling. When I got on the departing flight, a young guy said to the person sitting next to him, "How many times do you think we've heard the word 'ridiculous' in the last 45 minutes?" I like to walk, and I didn't have a bag, so my concerns are for those with heavy backpacks, small children, the aged, the unfit, and those on tight schedules. I pity anyone who has more than one of those factors. After a shocking experience departing the airport, I decided to start my pedometer on the airplane when arriving at gate B8, which is not the most distant gate. You could very easily add another .25 miles to the number I'm about to share if you had a B25 gate, or similar. I started my pedometer when I got off the plane to see how far it was to the long-term parking shuttles. It clocked in right at .75 miles. (So if you had a B25 gate, for example, it would be over a mile, I think.) A few other factors to into it to make it better and worse than it sounds. 1) I didn't use any of the moving walkways last night, one of which wasn't working, anyway (at a brand new airport - it had an out of order sign). I did that for two reasons: to measure and also because no one stays to the right on the walkways so you can pass, because they're all so tired of walking. That means that the moving walkways actually slow down the sense of progress you feel you're making on the sojourn. 2) On the escalators, no one walks them, either (for the same reason), so you just have to stand there. Standing actually tires me more, and it's a little frustrating if you're in a hurry. The escalators serve a necessary purpose, though - you probably wouldn't want to opt for the stairs (stair steps, by the way, would add to the length I tracked). You're going under the tarmac above you, and the escalators cover a pretty significant drop and climb. Again, the escalator (and moving sidewalk) could either give you a sense of rest or drive you crazy because they poke along and no one moves on them. If you're in a hurry, you're pretty stuck or you'll need to break a sweat and do the stairs twice (down and up on the other side). 3) There was not a long TSA line, but the wait was still lengthy. The tray system is now automated, but it doesn't speed things up. I think it slows it down. Back in the day, a human being could remove trays and take them back to the front, now they have to be left on the belt to be collected at the end, and the belt isn't very long and there's no place but at the belt to pull your stuff off (often to put it on again). The way they file the people through and screen the trays, the trays and people conning through aren't in the same order--not even close to it (which has always been the case to some degree, but it is way worse now). So TSA will either give you the impression of being able to take a breather or it will ultimately add to the length of your airport marathon. A few other random gripes are that even that strange, white fabric wave art installation (which didn't appear to be working) is an extension of the utter lack of practical planning this entire airport disaster represents. The airport is barely six months old, and it already looks dingy from airplane exhaust. Whoever thought that was a good idea? I remember the lack of cleanability was something observers talked about from day one. The added time makes driving to surrounding states seem better.

commentHeader: I can only say what a disaster
reviewContent: As a business traveler I can only say what a disaster. The new airport was poorly designed. The construction is a problem however the larger problem is the Atomic security system at the checkpoint. Too small, too slow. The concourse widths were under designed, this airport post Covid will be a total train wreck. They need to fire the airport leadership. The taxpayers of Utah should revolt and demand a refund from the builders and design team!

commentHeader: Until the construction is done, I'll avoid SLC airport
reviewContent: Who designed this new airport? I've never walked so much in my life, I feel sorry for families with small kids or anyone physically disabled cause you have to use B gates, you're screwed. Unbelievable that anyone thinks this is acceptable. Until the construction is done, I'll avoid SLC airport.

I realize this airport is still under construction. It takes forever to get to the B Terminal. For this reason, I recommend checking in at least 2 hours ahead of flight. New seats are comfortable. Restrooms stalls are nice and roomy with lots of hooks. Not enough signs and directions, and not big enough. Queuing at check-in with my airline was a pure disaster. Over 100 people trying to use 6 kiosks (some weren't working), and the kiosks weren't spaced enough to allow for large families (a common occurrence at SLC) and oversize luggage (like skis). If I could have used a different airport, I would have.

This airport is a backbreaker. The hike from security to the B gates is longer than any chore you want to subject humans to. Anyone with limited mobility, carrying children, or lugging heavy bags will hate this airport. I heard some people joking about the Mormon Marathon, others swearing at SLC, and saw others lost and searching for signage. Too bad you didn't consult a human factors designer for what must be a $B airport.

commentHeader: SLC is a sterling, world-class airport, with some wrinkles
reviewContent: SLC is a sterling, world-class airport, with some wrinkles. To begin, I absolutely do not understand the onslaught of negative reviews for the newly-completed (and still under-construction) SLC redo. The only explanation I can think of is that those negative reviews are from people driving in from some place like Magna, West Valley, Brigham City, or Wendover who just don't like big cities and big changes. Let me start with the positives of the new SLC, and there are many: 1) TSA staff who are helpful, polite, and explanatory, who don't bark orders officiously, and who efficiently process passengers. The best TSA I've encountered in almost any airport in the USA, except possibly some small airports like Lexington. 2) Architecturally stunning, post-contemporary, and a generally relaxing, open-air design; the closest thing I've seen in the USA to a Seoul Incheon, Hong Kong, and Sydney's Kingsford Smith (though those airports are even more beautiful). 3) Countless art displays in the terminal, completed concourses, and the underground walkway connecting the concourses at present. 4) Dining and shopping options in the Delta concourse (A). 5) Ample displays and signage, from the time you leave I-80 or North Temple to the time you arrive at your gate. 6) Luggage carts prominently located at the entry to the terminal (although you have to pay for them, and I don't like that we have to do that at US airports in general when you don't always have to in other countries). 7) Accessibility by highway, TRAX light rail, or rideshare is a breeze. 8) It's close to downtown, and still a 45-minute drive from Park City, Antelope Island, etc. 9) The restrooms (men's anyway) have stalls which afford full privacy, common in western Europe and wealthier Asian countries but rare in the US. Now, there are some drawbacks that will need to be worked out: 1) There really needs to be significantly improved accessibility between the terminal, baggage claim and concourses, hopefully the new tunnel under construction will remedy that, but there is no excuse for this airport to not already have an active tram. However, despite the naysayers' reviews, it takes 15 minutes to walk across the airport, not 30 minutes. 2) The food and dining options in concourse B (Alaska, Frontier, Southwest, etc.) could stand to be more numerous. I'll also say that while Uinta Brewing is a great place for a locally-brewed beer, they could stand some competition, as the service frankly wasn't very attentive or friendly. 3) The Southwest personnel weren't very friendly, though at least they weren't rude or hostile like I've experienced from SWA at other airports. 4) If you want to rent a car from SLC, you'll be paying a ridiculous airport surcharge of some kind, I took an Uber to and from Millcreek to rent a car. Even considering the cost of Uber, I still saved $80-100 rather than renting at the airport. I noticed that the rental car facilities from Farmington all the way down to Sandy were almost entirely booked, but the airport still had rental cars available. This is an obvious problem. 5) The WiFI is terrible and needs to actually be accessible for passengers. So, wonderful job overall, SLC! In fact, I'm impressed. Just work out your wrinkles, always find ways to improve and execute plans of action, and you can complete with the very best in Europe and even some in east Asia!

commentHeader: I am thoroughly disgusted with the new SLC airport
reviewContent: I am thoroughly disgusted with the new SLC airport! It is an absolute joke to have to walk a mile to get from security to the Southwest gates! And to top it all off there are no transportation vehicles running along that corridor. The only option is a wheelchair! Why in the world would elderly people be expected to traverse that far? And what about families traveling with small children? Who designed this monstrosity? Another thing I am extremely bothered by is how the people on the shuttles from off site parking facilities are treated like second class citizens. Those shuttles are no longer permitted to drop passengers off at the main doors. Instead they are dropped off downstairs, outside and made to trek completely through the car rental parking lots and up escalators to check in. Hotel shuttles are permitted to drop off at the main doors so why not off site shuttles?. Let's see - could it be that airport officials are trying to force passengers to pay their outrageous rates to park in their long term lots? It almost seems like they are trying to put the off site lots out of business! Terrible, terrible experience all around! I am embarrassed that people coming to visit our great state have to be submitted to this as their first impression!

commentHeader: why would anyone think this monstrosity is an improvement
reviewContent: Why, why, why would anyone think this monstrosity is an improvement. Bring your track shoes and endurance to navigate the long corridors and endless tunnel to reach your gate. Oh wait, don't forget to stop in Terminal A if you want food, Terminal B has very limited choices especially if your flight is early.

I wanted to give a positive review about new airport. I had read several complaints about long walk to gate, bad signage etc. yes, the old airport was a lot smaller, but I am 67 years old and not a fast walker, but I walked off plane Terminal B gate 10, walked underground to Terminal A, found way to ground transportation. Used the people type movers where available. Took 20 minutes. Information desk told me where to wait for the shuttle to take me to SLC Trax to leave airport. Great signage. When I departed, dropped off at curb, up elevator to security check. Lines not long, but the automated bins seemed really slow compared to other security. So drop off to gate took 35 minutes. I have been in some big airports and 35 minutes is very reasonable. I did not check a bag. Roller carryon. I did not eat or shop. But saw Cafe Rio,

Extremely Disappointed! I travel for a living and have been in literally a hundred airports across the country and world. I have never been this amazed at the ridiculous lack of attention to the distance a passenger must walk from the parking garage/shuttle, through the hallways and security and then to the gate! I'm not kidding, I'm fit, no disabilities no issues and simply can't believe the distance and time this experience took. Who designed this? Did they consider people or just sculptures and ambiance? Seriously terrible! I loved the old airport, this is awful!
Wow true new airport is horrific. Not sure who designed it but it is terrible. Anybody coming should be prepared to walk for 30 minutes or more to get to your gate.

Highly disappointed in new airport. Give me back the easy to navigate old one. Left Southwest out of b19. Had to walk a mile. Took forever! Hope they expand Provo so I can avoid this place. Need a tram under the tarmac from main area to the other terminal. Need faster walkways, need carts at drop off. I came back from San Diego airport. Walked 50 yards from drop off to my gate...so much nicer.

commentHeader: get ready to walk and walk and walk
reviewContent: This airport is awful. Unless you happen to be in terminal A in some of the first gates, get ready to walk and walk and walk. In the design they did not include enough escalators and so both arriving and departing you queue to get on the escalator. Also, if you are in terminal B, you need to traverse under the tarmac. This is an incredibly long walk for an airport of this size - they state 7 minutes. Also, they oriented the entry to the airport at the end of terminal A instead of the middle. So for 3/4ths of the gates, get ready to walk. Also, terminal B, there are few amenities vs terminal A. Finally, for baggage claim, you need to commit to walk to one side or the other to see the posted bag claims for your flight. They should have signage before you have to commit to one side or another, otherwise you have to back track. Just feels like they could have accomplished all this with half the footprint. With all of the airport experience around the works, it is impossible to believe this airport could have been this poorly designed. I would recommend a serious rehab to fix these grave inconveniences. That said, it is new and clean. The skis come out on a dedicated ski carousel. The stores that do exist in terminal A are very nice.

commentHeader: Very inconvenient on policies for covid
reviewContent: Very inconvenient on policies for covid. I parked in short term parking to go inside and pickup my wife. Only to find out they wouldn't let me in the airport without a ticket. Then why did you let me pay to park short term?! I would have just used the park and wait lot.

commentHeader: If I could avoid this airport I would!
reviewContent: This is the worst airport ever! I have flown in and out of SLC Airport many times over the past 30 years. The old airport was very easy to navigate, but the new airport is horrible. The miles long walk to get from the gate to baggage claim (or security to your gate) might look pretty, but takes forever! We traveled with my elderly in-laws and that walk was the most miserable experience. I can't even imagine what I would do with small children and I even enjoy walking, just not with heavy bags and time constraints! Signage is confusing and it was very difficult to figure out where to find passenger pick up. If I could avoid this airport I would!

commentHeader: Shame on the people responsible for this terrible design!
reviewContent: I have not yet flown into or out of the new airport, but before covid I flew several times a month. I did have the unfortunate experience of negotiating the new parking structure recently. It is impossible except perhaps for someone in a smart car. Any driver in a normal size car will struggle and I can't imagine trying to access this structure in an SUV or a truck The amount of paint on the walls of every ramp tells the story better than any words. I do not have a large car and if I do say so myself, I'm an excellent driver, yet I came close to damaging the paint on my car several times going from one level to the next. There is barely enough room for the sideview mirrors to clear. Access to the ramps requires sharp almost impossible to make turns from the aisles. Even getting a ticket from the kiosk is challenging and the same is true for paying as one leaves. There is not enough room for two cars going opposite directions to pass in any of the aisles and backing out of a parking space without hitting the car parked opposite requires expertise in multi-point turning. One would think when designing a 4 billion dollar plus airport it would make sense to have it accessible to cars. I will never again attempt parking at this already white elephant airport. So disappointed! Shame on the people responsible for this terrible design!

commentHeader: By far the worst designed airport in the country
reviewContent: Fly in and out of this airport about 3x a month. By far the worst designed airport in the country. Staffing not far behind. Go early unless you are taking Delta and have good luck with security. Terminal B is an absurd walk. Security is really slow regardless of type of line you are in. Lines can be short or very long. Maybe anecdotal but extra security checks are high and I once waited over 10 minutes for someone to come check me on a random check. Had a shift change where the one did not move for 10 minutes once. Lost goes in and on. Baggage claim can take very long compared to other airports. Original SLC airport was old but great. New one is clean and good look looking, but terrible layout and administration.

commentHeader: avoid SLC international like the plague!
reviewContent: I'm glad to see it's not only me who really, really dislikes the new SLC International Airport. I've used an off-site parking lot/shuttle for years. The shuttles used to be able to drop you off and pick you up in front of the terminal. Now, the parking shuttles cannot get any closer than the parking garage. I'm guessing this is so you'll use official airport parking the next time you travel. With all your luggage, you must now walk for about 5-minutes, through the parking garage and then take an escalator or elevator to the next level. You're protected from rain or snow, but not heat or freezing cold temperatures. If you're flying Delta, you get to check in on that level. But if you're on another airline, you must take yet another elevator or escalator up to the top floor. I had a 28-inch bag to check in and a 21-inch carry-on. The larger bag got caught on a step while ascending, tipped back, and pinned me on my back, as the escalator moved upward. I was barely able to stand up before reaching the end of the escalator. During my weeklong vacation, I felt like I had a broken rib from the fall and had so many bruises, I was embarrassed to wear shorts. After checking my bag on the top level, I had to go back down a level to get to my gate. The terminals are now shaped like a giant T, but with 2 top crosses. Again, if you're on Delta, not so bad. All Delta gates are in concourse A. But to get to a non-Delta gate, you must take a very long tunnel to get to concourse B. Both the A and B concourses are linear and very long. It takes over 20 minutes to get from security to the very end of the B concourse! Just like on the freeway, there are digital signs telling you how long it will take to get to your gate. Thanks a lot. If it's a 15-minute walk and you only have 5-minutes to catch your flight, you're out of luck! Even with the "walking escalators" it's an extremely long walk, especially wearing a mask. The airport says it's adding a second tunnel to shorten the walk, but the tunnels are not going to be far enough apart to make a difference! If they wanted two parallel and linear concourses, they should have had parking, entrances, and TSA checkpoints on each side. I understand that SLC is a Delta hub. But if you're on another airline, you feel like you're being punished for not paying twice as much for a Delta ticket! If you're changing planes in SLC, make sure you have a minimum of 90-minutes between connections. If you arrive at the northwest end of concourse B and your next flight is leaving from the southeast end of concourse A, make sure you have running shoes on! I design buildings for a living. Not airports, but large hospitals. I love change! Especially in architecture. This design is horrible! Not well thought out at all! At least in Atlanta, you have the "plane train" to get you to the other end of the airport. How did someone not see this as a problem? Lots of people in SLC have lots of kids. Have fun carrying your little ones when he or she gets too tired to walk. Sure, the new airport looks nice, but it's awful to use! This is one of the worst architectural blunders I've ever experienced! Do yourself a favor, and avoid SLC international like the plague!

commentHeader: I hate the new SLC airport
reviewContent: I hate the new SLC airport. They took the best airport that I regularly visit and made it the worst. Too much walking and space between the security and baggage claim and the gates. I feel sorry for seniors, single parents traveling with children and the airline staff. I am so disappointed and hope that some improvements will be made. If not I may have to move my vacation home to a different location.

commentHeader: the most poorly designed airport in the US
reviewContent: Likely the most poorly designed airport in the US. If you have young children, traveling with someone who is elderly, disabled or ill, this is not the airport you want to fly to. Distances are so long to gates they have “highway signs” listing the average amount of time it will take you to walk to a gate. On average, expect a solid 20 minute walk, without stopping. Really Salt Lake, the reno is shameful, you need to make this airport user friendly for all people. the shopping, cleanliness factors etc are irrelevant when you take into account the poor design and services.

commentHeader: this brand new airport is unacceptable
reviewContent: It’s hard to believe this brand new airport is unacceptable! Too much walking to and from gates for seniors and single parents with small kids. Unless you’re flying Delta Air Lines, you’re screwed! Last minute gate changes.... awful.

commentHeader: Bring back carts for handicap and seniors
reviewContent: This airport is so sprawled out the distances are vast between flights. The Human Conveyor System runs way to slow and they terminate only at Vendors. Instead of the arrival or departure points. Sad, speed up the conveyors! Bring back carts for handicap and seniors.

commentHeader: They have turned the best airport into one of the worst
reviewContent: They have turned the best airport into one of the worst. Who designed this thing? You have to walk a mile to get to the gate. Looking at the plans it looks like it will only get worse in the future.

commentHeader: Way to screw it up again Utah
reviewContent: Worst airport ever. Don’t fly with kids because you have to have them walk a mile minimum to get to your gate. Utah’s “little brother” complex really came out here. Super progressive, technologically advanced, and the most non friendly and inconvenient airport in the country. I’ve been to hundreds of airports worldwide and the SLC is by far the very worst. Way to screw it up again Utah.

commentHeader: It is not built for people
reviewContent: Those that designed the airport must have forgotten that people use the airport. It is pretty to look at, although nothing special. Flying out of the airport included long walks but was not too bad because there were seats by the gate. However, you have to plan in an additional 20 minutes of walking time when compared to the old terminal. Arriving after red-eye flight was a nightmare. Once we left the concourse there is no where to sit. Baggage claim takes forever. Once you get your bags the only place to sit is on your bags. We arrived very early on a very cold morning. To get to the pickup curb you have to walk across a skybridge. But when your ride arrives moments before you do they don't let the car wait for you to come out. The driver to circle the airport and you can either stand out in the cold, or play roulette by going back into the terminal. I hope the architects and those that approved the design have to fly in and out of the airport often and they are motivated to add things like seats. I can't imaging taking an aged parent through this airport. It is not built for people.

commentHeader: a beautiful new airport which is not user friendly
reviewContent: This is a beautiful new airport which is not user friendly. The hike from gates to baggage claim is ridiculously long. Baggage took an extremely long time to reach baggage claim during non-busy time. Directions to get from baggage claim to passenger pickup are confusing at best. Airport employees are very courteous and helpful but tsa employees are rude and loud. Hike from tsa to gates is once again, ridiculously long.

commentHeader: it takes you forever to get anywhere in the airport
reviewContent: Horrible experience every time. As law-enforcement, military I show up with ID’s and badge and get targeted every time for secondary inspection so TSA doesn’t have to do paperwork on a safe passenger but they can meet their quotas. Lines are long and it takes you forever to get anywhere in the airport.

commentHeader: we intensely dislike the new airport
reviewContent: My husband and I agree that we intensely dislike the new airport. We heard a pilot say that it went from the best airport to the worst. I have no idea who designed it but you need to get your pencil out, sharpen it, and make a new design. Horrific would be out experience. We decided that other than overseas flights, we will drive, our drive to another airport to avoid using this one.

commentHeader: Completely disappointed by our innovative city
reviewContent: Completely disappointed by our innovative city. Old airport was 100 times better when I worked here. Everything from park n ride lot drop off area to having to go up two floors just to check in and then the ridiculous walk to b terminal? No shuttle? Train? Continuous fast moving sidewalk? Eating choices are horrible? No McDonald's? Burger King? Nothing but fancy choices and very income discriminating options especially for low income travelers with children. How could you spend so much and get the whole, I mean whole idea wrong. Did you not travel to great airports like Denver or Fort Myers? Feels more like elite club then fun travel center. Designers should be released from duty and citizens hired to fix who actually travel. Medellin Colombia has better airport at half the cost. You spent all this money and the security checkpoint is all you kinda got right. 1 star rating for design and execution.

Am absolutely dumfounded by the lack of customer/passenger flow dynamic in the design of the new airport to get from the terminal to gates if you are not flying Delta airlines. It's literally a mile of walking each way. Did the design get awarded to the lowest bidder?! Upon arrival and departure on my United flights, I/we had to walk over a mile to/from security to the gate, which only boarded you on to a ramp to get on a bus that took you to/from the plane a half mile away on the tarmac. If I was on the board of United, Southwest, American, etc. I would be up in arms about this lack of competent design flow for my paying customers. Calling it a work in progress is a cop out for a really poorly thought out concept. I've been flying in/out of SLC for 3 decades, and I am in awe that this was allowed to move forward like this. It's a significant step backward. The aesthetics of the main terminal are nice and interesting, but it's a small consolation for its poor layout. The murals on the south half of the underground walkway from concourse A to B are nice with the seasons of Utah being depicted, but the North half looks like it got awarded to a middle school in the district. Given all the revenue dumped into this project, I am left scratching my head that this concept moved through as many levels of review necessary for this type of new construction, and no one raised the very legitimate point of ease of use by their customers. They really missed the mark!

New design is terrible. It’s like I’m in Chicago O'Hare and its endless delays. I fly twice a month in/out of SLC and the new design is woefully lacking. Extended taxiing, long waits on the parking ramp for gates you have to be bussed to while there are open gates at terminals A and B. 10-15 min walk to bag claim or your gate. Long waits for baggage. Minimal concessions with very long waits. Traffic for passenger pickup is slow and terrible, there are cars constantly waiting on the shoulder. Parking garage is $5 for under 30min. Parking garage is very tight and cars are constantly making contact with the concrete walls. Somebody should lose their job and be drummed out of engineering, architecture or whatever made this abomination. On another note...the security check-in is swift and has some nice innovation. The facilities are clean.
Awful customer experience. Long walk to gates. No assistance for those who can’t walk. I miss the old restaurants Adobe. I travel to 26 airports a year and had such high hopes.

commentHeader: What were they thinking when they designed this airport?
reviewContent: Worst Airport Ever! What were they thinking when they designed this airport? Long walks to baggage claim, took an hour to get bags, totally unimaginative terminal. I feel like I went back in time and am pining for the old terminal. This airport makes LAX look like the Taj Mahal. After flying over 50 times a year I can honestly say that the designers of this fiasco should be barred from ever picking up a grease pen ever again. As an aside..let's be Covid safe by not putting four incoming flights onto one baggage carousel and concentrating 150 irate passengers in close proximity while the other carousel sit idle.

commentHeader: This is the worst designed airport ever
reviewContent: This is the worst designed airport ever. Way too far to walk. No electric chairs available. Confusing signage to some degree. There is hardly anywhere to rest. And security kept ringing alarms when they could not find anything. I used to enjoy this airport, now I really dislike it.

commentHeader: this airport is an absolute pain
reviewContent: I travel often for work and have been through many airports. None of them are as horribly designed as Salt Lake City. Unless you are flying Delta this airport is an absolute pain, and get ready to walk forever. To get to any airline gate other than Delta be prepared to walk a mile in a concrete tunnel to get to the B terminal. Walking from the high number B gates and then through the concrete tunnel, and then through almost the entire A terminal is ridiculous. On top of that, don't follow the ground transportation signs if you have a private vehicle picking you up. As soon as you leave the airport you only have access to buses or Lyft and Uber. Private vehicles are blocked by an 8 foot concrete and metal wall. There are zero signs pointing out that you have to then go back upstairs across a sky bridge and back down an escalator to have access to your private transportation. Extremely poor design, and even worse signage to point you in the right direction. Oh, and I better not forget don't plan on decent food if you have a layover. The food options are pathetic at best.

commentHeader: The older ugly airport was better
reviewContent: Awful new airport layout! TSA had maybe 3 lines open. Took forever. Then incredibly long distance to gate B15. I have always left my home at the same time for flights, giving myself plenty of time before boarding. Nearly missed the flight had to run from TSA to the gate! The older ugly airport was better.

The wife and I were thinking oh boy we get to see the new airport. Well looks nice! What a disappointment! I will take the old one any day over this new one. If you are some what limited on your walking ability like a mile or less you will need to make arrangements for assistance. If you are coming in on a tight flight schedule figure on missing your connection. There is no way you will get from one terminal to another in less than 20 minutes.

I’m not sure if who designed this airport but they need to have there head checked. They put so much thought into the artsy stuff that they forgot functionality for travelers. Hopefully you don’t have a flight out of B1 if so give your self plenty of time no thought was put into the b terminal or getting there especially if you land in A and have a short connection in B. Also pickup is ridiculous. They should have made all lanes accessible from bottom side like every other airport in the US. But hey the art and the lights are nice.

commentHeader: gorgeous, but horrible at the same time
reviewContent: The new airport is gorgeous, but horrible at the same time. My daughter and I flew into Concourse B. The fact that you have to walk all the way through that concourse, down a long corridor into the middle of concourse A, then walk that section before you can head down stairs into the baggage claim area. Wear a tee shirt because it’s the worlds longest walk. I thought O’Hare can be bad, but whoever architected this layout needs to rethink things!

Horrible design that wastes what is otherwise a beautifully finished airport. The planners and architects or whoever was charge of putting the B gates a mile away with no train are idiots. Fly Delta in Concourse A or fly to Prove. What a disaster!

The settlers probably had a shorter trip from the colonies to the western frontier than I did getting from terminal A to terminal B. It makes zero sense why they have to space the two terminals so ungodly far. I missed my first flight because I didn’t take into account the over 30 minute pilgrimage from security to my gate. Unless you are an Olympic marathon runner the walking distance will be nothing short of a ginormous pain. I practically broke my already sprained ankle just to get to my gate only to be greeted by an unsympathetic United airlines attendant who told me that I had missed the 10 minute boarding window. Who knows if this absurdly short boarding time is some cruel joke or the result of the attendant’s sub-first grade math skills, but it quite literally is beyond my understanding.  By the end of the ordeal my aim was not to return home but simply escape this hellhole of an airport.

commentHeader: I could not believe the amount of walking
reviewContent: I could not believe the amount of walking. I arrived on Southwest at the far end of terminal B. I started walking, and walking and more walking. I'm 65 years old and must have walked for what seemed like 25 minutes to get to terminal A and then struggled to see the signs for exiting. Once I got out of the airport I ended up first at UBER drop off, then UBER pickup. I had to go back in up an escalator, across a sky bridge and down to passenger pick-up. Very poor signage.

I guess when they were designing this airport they were trying to mimic the nightmares of Heathrow. The long walks are ridiculous. A18 to A25 aren't bad but any other gate is over a mile walk. If you fly anyone but Delta your screwed going to terminal B. What are the elderly, or people with young children, or the disabled supposed to do. This layout was obviously designed by marathon running 18 year old because no one with intelligence or experience would have done this.

commentHeader: new airport complex is not traveler friendly
reviewContent: The new airport terminal complex is beautiful in architecture and has plentiful and clean restrooms. However, the eateries seem to be almost all high end with focus on adults and alcoholic drinks. Traveling with children leaves essentially no food options conducive to young tastes or family budgets. We discovered there were hardly any food options for quick take away to take aboard aircraft. The old terminal avoided these shortcomings with availability of McDonalds, Burger King, Popeye Chicken, etc; why have such/similar eateries been omitted?. It makes no sense for the Shakes Shack eatery to be located where travelers have exited the secured terminal area. The new eateries seem to be focused more on high profitability and business travelers; while overlooking the need for traveling families to feed their children at reasonable prices. My wife and I are senior ages and the arduous 20 minute trek between TSA check and Southwest gates in Terminal 2 left us exhausted. Signage could be improved for luggage pickup carousels; overhead signs give the airline arrival flight numbers, but no information on which carousel luggage is to be found. The Honolulu terminal had a very helpful feature; public address system frequently announced which luggage carousel was being used for each incoming flight. This new airport complex while attractive, is not traveler friendly.

Lived in SLC in the 90's and travelled back and forth hundreds of times. Today was my first visit to new SLC Airport. What a disappointment! Need to walk miles to get the the exit. Terminal B is behind Terminal A connected by underground passage that looks horrible - cheap version of O'Hare United Terminal B to C connector. Both terminals look like anywhere USA, with the exit from the airport to the car rental that reminds of a scaled down version Miami International. Who did that project, and who approved it? Suddenly my favorite airport is gone, new not friendly for older travelers due to long distances to cover. Would recommend to have an extra hour or so to be able to get to the right gate.

commentHeader: The new SLC airport is a joke!
reviewContent: The new SLC airport is a joke! The amount of walking you have to do to get to any airline gate besides the Delta is absurd! 20 minutes even with moving walkways and that is no exaggeration. Very poor design. Clearly they don't value anyone's time or needs of senior citizens, small children, individuals with knee issues or individuals with weight problems. I was nothing but angry after coming in on a late flight. I had to wait for my luggage in the cold since my airline checked everyone's luggage at the gate for this flight. All I wanted was to get out of the airport and get home but had to walk 20 minutes from my gate to get to my pick-up. A real deterrent for anyone flying in or out from this airport. Does not meet needs.

I fly a lot out and into airports small and large all over the US and this new Terminal at SLC is absolutely the worst I have ever been in. For a big airport and only having 1 TSA check point is horrible, signage for Priority line is almost invisible and only saw it after waiting in half mile general boarding line. The walk to B gates is an absolute JOKE. And once there the options of food or drink or adult beverages is evan more depressing. To think of the cost of this new terminal and it’s extremely poor design for passengers is mind boggling. Salt Lake City you should be ashamed of your self for approving this airport. It needs major upgrades already.

New design is horrible. Getting to B terminal is a very long walk. Some of the automatic walkways were broken. You have to walk to the center of terminal A, then go down under the tarmac, walk another long way under the tarmac and then come back up. Then you have to walk again. With a spouse who has trouble walking it was brutal. Whomever designed this airport and signed off on the design should be fired.

commentHeader: I absolutely dread having to use this airport!
reviewContent: Just a suggestion if you are using the new SLC airport start physically training months in advance! I have never walked such a long distance at any other airport I’ve used! I’m a senior citizen, with back and knee problems, which makes this airport not user friendly. I was escorting my minor grandchild to and from her flights to gate A-2, by the time we made it to the gate, surely we had walked to the neighboring city of Bountiful! I can only imagine if they had gate changes, people would be livid! As for the luggage pickup. I agree there isn’t enough info to get you to the correct Carousel! I absolutely dread having to use this airport!

commentHeader: Had to walk over a mile to get to B gates
reviewContent: Had to walk over a mile to get to B gates! I watched a young mother with 2 small children try and carry luggage and push stroller all the way to B gate. Rolling walkways were not that helpful. 2 words, train system! It would not only help families with children but elderly get from tsa to gates. A passenger could easily miss their flight if not made aware of the long walk ahead. Poor design. Even the airport staff I spoke with told me how unhappy they are with the layout and encouraged me to write a review because the "higher-ups" won't listen to them! Very poor design.

commentHeader: No regard for COVID at all
reviewContent: No regard for COVID at all. No social distancing. TSA agents, people working at food places, and other staff with masks well below their nose or mouth. Lines for security are packed with absolutely no social distancing. Passengers in the airport with masks down or no masks at all in line for food, in walkways and at gates. Over half of the hand sanitizer stations are empty. Soaps in the bathrooms empty too. It's as if they don't know or care about COVID 19. SLC airport should be appalled. They most certainly are aiding in the spread of COVID19 in ways that are completely avoidable. Avoid this airport at all costs during COVID19. Make them reevaluate their practices and take this pandemic more seriously. I felt extremely unsafe in this airport.

commentHeader: a mess and needs to be completely renovated
reviewContent: I live in Park City and own a tourism driven business. In the past, I would brag to my clients how easy it was to fly in and out of SLC airport. It was efficient, welcoming, well marked, and had great food & beverage options. Having flown in and out in November-December 2020, I can no longer say that. Whoever designed and then approved the design of the new airport should be publicly fired and publicized so the persons/companies involved never get another chance to screw up a good thing. I actually used the pedometer on my phone when returning to SLC. It was over a mile and a quarter walk from my Southwest gate to baggage claim. There were a few moving sidewalks, but even so, with a heavy carry-on (same one I've used for years), a mask, and the exhaustion of flying several hours with plane changes, it was ridiculous. There were few places to sit and rest along the way and no places to get a needed beverage. I'm a fairly healthy 64 year old woman with minor back and knee issues. That walk left me in pain for 2 days. Why are there not trams like other large airports? Who actually thought this mess was a good idea? If I had another option, I'd use it. It's a mess and needs to be completely renovated now before someone has a heart attack or worse on the mile+ walk. The silly looking waves sculptures should be taken down and traded in for a few needed golf carts.

commentHeader: For a new wonderful airport, it was awful
reviewContent: The people of Utah got bilked. For a new wonderful airport, it was awful. I travel weekly for work and have done so for the past 10 years, apart from current COVID impacts. And I would much rather have been in the old SLC airport than the new one. First, off-site parking doesn't get to pull even close to the terminal. You have to traverse the rental car garage, really. Even Denver lets them pull on the outer lanes. Then if you have walking issues, like my spouse, you are hosed. Extreme lack of moving walk ways, and then the ones they have are like 20 years ago. Look at Denver, they need to be wider! Allowing people both to stand and walk without hitting bags or feeling like you are pushed to the side. And seating, who cares about the wonderful silhouettes of the canyons, people need comfortable places to sit, especially when they need to rest after walking from one end of the terminal to the baggage claim. And for baggage claim, again, not enough signs to find the right baggage claim. It was too much walking, and didn't make sense that passenger ride shares can pull up to terminal, but off-site shuttles are banned to the 'west 40'. I was just not impressed. I walked as much in SLC as I did in ATL, a much older airport, with no moving walkways in the gate terminals, where I had to go from an A gate to a D gate. So for a new state of the art airport, way too much unused space and total lack of moving walk ways. Not sure who this airport was designed for. Must have just looked good on paper. But is terrible in usefulness and reality. Really let down by the new airport.

commentHeader: I had to walk what seemed like a mile
reviewContent: Horrible design. My plane was at gate A2. My son was flying out of B24. I had to walk what seemed like a mile (didn't the designers/architects visit Detroit to find out how to get people from one end of the terminal to another?) and my son had to walk about 2/3 of it, only to have to then proceed down an escalator, walk to the B terminal, then walk back to the east another 1/4 mile in order to then ride a bus to his plane. Unbelievable. The entrance is beautiful, I enjoy the aesthetics but once past the entrance/security hall, the airport looks like every other major city airport but way less efficient. The beauty is quickly forgotten when you are walking over a mile, wearing a mask, dragging suitcases. People should be fired over this.

commentHeader: New airport is a complete design failure
reviewContent: Almost everything is worse, hardly anything is better. New airport is a complete design failure. Customer experience was never a consideration. I had high hopes for the new modernized airport as I travel out of SLC several times a month. Let's start with parking. Economy lot is exactly the same except the busses are running slower. Parking garage is about the same but less convenient now. Skycap is missing. WiFi is still slow and terrible. The long walk to terminal B for absolutely no good reason at all. Prepare for a hike, bring running shoes, water etc. Just remember to enjoy the gigantic, over-sized "artwork" on the walls of the terminal. They cut budget for a tram but the costly sculptures remain. Enjoy! Entrance - worse, like everything else. Be prepared to visit all 3 floors just to catch a flight. You might arrive at street level, up to level 3 to check in then back down to level 2 for TSA and to the gates. Whoever designed the airport was definitely buddies with the escalator company. Complete with people dragging their bags and kids up and down escalators because the airport was not designed for customers. They severely overlooked the importance of the entrance and check-in process. TSA - Worse, slower. Newer does not mean faster when it comes to the TSA. New bins are terrible, slow and there's a good chance your bin comes out the other side without everything you put in it! Watching the TSA poke around the machine with their stick, trying to find lost items is kind of amusing when it's not my item. Food - Less choices. The same restaurants as before like Squatters but got rid of the cheap stuff and fast food. I enjoy the nicer restaurants but sometimes just need something quick and cheap. Not enough coffee shops, not enough anything. The new strip of designer stores are a fail, empty or nearly empty every time I've walked by. Trying to have a mini-mall instead of more food options serves nobody. Prices in the convenience stores have gone up considerably. The good, barely. Pickup area is bigger. Previously, the lanes were sandwiched between the terminal and parking garage and could never be expanded. Same design but starting out bigger and should be adequate for now. Sitting areas not near the gates are larger, more spaced out and have plenty of electrical outlets and charge ports. Airport isn't completed, apparently they will chip away for years before it's done. There's a chance things will improve but several more years of transitional airport operations due to ongoing construction has the potential to suck.

commentHeader: the worst airport I’ve ever seen
reviewContent: I have 6 million miles. 80 countries. 300 airports. This is the worst airport I’ve ever seen. Did a whole team of monkeys draw this up? It is over a mile hike from security to the entrance to terminal B. No tram. A couple of people movers. A multi billion $ catastrophe.

commentHeader: Complaints about the layout are spot on
reviewContent: Complaints about the layout are spot on. Whoever designed it is either malicious or an idiot. I thought there was going to be another terminal added, but instead they added an extra set of gates a half mile away (more?) that you have to walk after security. There’s no access to outside drop-off/pick-up the way there would be with a new terminal. I held onto a misplaced optimism that this would be rectified and I think I finally realized today that it’s not coming. What a joke.

commentHeader: Not a good look for Salt Lake City
reviewContent: Too much walking. Layout / concept is somewhat similar to Denver, they should have just copied Denver.  I think time should be minimized getting through an airport, this is more like a day trip. It's awful to see families with children / seniors struggling to get where they need to go. They need more moving walkways and they need to have the speed turned up. This is an embarrassment and total waste of money. Not a good look for Salt Lake City.

commentHeader: the worst I have ever experienced
reviewContent: I have flown to Utah twice a year or more for a very long time. This so called new layout is the worst I have ever experienced in my years of flying. I am a senior and have trouble walking long distances. This new design is the worst design I have seen. I have traveled to many different airports. SLC international airport is so far the worst airport I have ever traveled to. I cringe when I think about going back to that airport.

The walk to terminal B is a joke. I have walked numerous airports in the USA and this surpasses them all for ridiculous design. From the time you get through TSA, you should expect a 20 minute brisk walk to arrive at a B gate. The locations where off airport Parking shuttles drop off is a good 10 minute walk to the TSA lines. Overall a colossal fail in design. They keep touting the new updated look, but who takes time to look at the updates when you spend most of your time transiting to the gate.
This is the worst new airport ever. Who designed this catastrophe. Too far to walk anywhere. Not enough trams (none) or people movers. Should have kept the old one.

commentHeader: In short, SLC is not enjoyable
reviewContent: I thought the same thing, “Who in their right mind would have designed something like this?”. This airport was built for singles under 40, neither families nor those not trading for a marathon, I saw numerous people running to catch their flight exacerbated by the distance between gates. When we arrived it seemed like a mile walk to the car rentals. Where are the sky trams or passenger trains. Did the architect design this in a vacuum? Go visit Atlanta’s airport, or Detroit. These airports move people as opposed to having the people hike. On our return flight today we sat on the tarmac for over 2 hours as over 100 bags were missing. The baggage system broke and the pilot said it was a fiasco. I can understand a mechanical breakdown, but failure to test seems to be in keep with the other lack of attention to detail this airport exhibits. In short, SLC is not enjoyable, Maybe it can be fixed.

commentHeader: one of the worst experiences I’ve had at an airport
reviewContent: This is one of the worst experiences I’ve had at an airport. Allow at least an hour just to walk to your gate - it’s insane how far apart the terminals are from each other. I arrived 2 hours before my flight, waited in line for security for an hour and then had to sprint to my gate to not miss my flight. Little did I know I would be sprinting for a good 2 miles, no exaggeration. The airport layout is ridiculous especially with no transpiration to these extremely far concourses.

commentHeader: get input from the traveling public
reviewContent: Obviously this airport was designed by an architecture student who had never traveled by plane. It is a more aesthetically pleasing airport than its predecessor, but the outdated predecessor was 10 times more functional. Security screening should be on the same level as airline check in as that seems to be the worldwide norm. Instead, you check in then immediately have to ride an escalator or elevator to security screening area. Guess what, security screening is located right where all the arriving passengers have to claim their luggage! Brilliant. Speaking of claiming your luggage, there is one thing that was brought over from the predecessor, the infamous luggage destroyer carousels. It’s 2021 and there are much better designs than the drop and crash luggage destroyer. Look it up, Nashville, Fort Lauderdale, even JFK have no dump and destroy carousels. Oh and after you claim your bags, you have to cross the sky bridge and then ride and escalator or elevator to get to the street pick up. Here’s an idea, put baggage claim on ground level. Don’t worry, I haven’t forgotten about the insane length of time it takes to get to the B gates and how they couldn’t figure out how to line up the connector with the main entry corridor. Obviously this airport was designed by a person who had a vested interest in escalator, elevator and moving walkway sales and installation as I find it difficult to believe any reasonably intelligent person could not figure out some of these challenges before this design was approved. Here’s an idea, get input from the traveling public, you know the people who actually pay for and use the facility. I can assure you even the least architecturally educated among us could create a more functional and less time intensive design. Alas, I’m just a simpleton who believes the shortest distance is a straight line.

As mentioned in other reviews, this is the worst airport design. I’m a healthy 67 year old woman and the distance of walking with luggage is ridiculous. I will not use this airport again unless they install trams or carts. My daughter had a time getting her two young children to walk with their carry-ons that distance. Very bad design, shame on the architects.

When I left I left from an A gate. I was impressed by the new airport. The modern art, the cool stores, the restrooms every 3rd gate. I have flown out of this airport for 15 years and was truly blown away. But my return was a nightmare. Our plane literally parked way out on the tarmac somewhere. We had to walk outside the plane down a ramp (in winter) to a shuttle bus. The bus drove us to B gates—which is nowhere near the baggage claim. 3/4 of a mile walk later around the entire airport I finally got to baggage claim. Got my bag and the signage that used to be so clear about where to get ground transportation didn’t exist anymore. I went out a door for shuttles, and had to ask a Trax bus driver where the Economy shuttle line was. She directed me to 6c which was further down. Who designs an airport like this? It’s a giant U, and no one thought “hey—how about a connecting tram between the gates? It’s insane. God forbid I had a connecting flight to make. Even so—it was practically an asthma attack just to get from the tarmac to my bag. And one of the walkways in the opposite directions wasn’t even working. I felt so bad for those people. Build a tram like every other city has done. These distances are crazy for a healthy person, let alone someone who is older, infirm, running late, and etc.

commentHeader: the worst experience I have had
reviewContent: After a life of much travel, domestic and international, this was the worst experience I have had. Had I known that I would be forced to walk for more than 45 minutes with a carry-on shoulder bag, I would have carried-on a roller bag. Next time, for sure. The signage was unclear: the moving walkways appeared to be going to A terminal and the baggage claim sign to the left suggested that one should walk on the left side where there were no moving walkways. When I figured out that I could go on a moving walkway, the last one ended and a left turn toward baggage claim presented a further long walk with no moving walkways.
