Also, the moving walkways were jammed: no social distancing and no airport attendants to make certain that would happen. The thoughts I wrestled with were that I am older but fortunately in good health. If I had not been and had a heart condition as do many of my age, I might have suffered a heart attack from the length of the walk and having to carry a bag. And I feared exposure to Covid on the jammed moving walkways and escalators. Thirdly, I wondered how far I would have had to walk in a short time, had I been making a connection. Finally, after retrieving my luggage, I stopped a bicycle-riding SLC policeman to ask how to go to passenger pick up and he looked at me with two large suitcases and brusquely said "go up those stairs over there." Right. I like to be supportive of police, but that was the unkindest cut of all. I would like to say that I would avoid SLC in the future, but I live in Jackson Hole and every trip I take must go through Salt Lake. In an era of technological advance and sophistication, what idiots designed the new airport? It is a crime -- and I suspect there will be many passengers suffering health problems while at the airport. They had better lay on large numbers of motorized carts and people to operate them and provide clearer signage.

commentHeader: too many problems with the new facility
reviewContent: Worst airport experience ever. I’ve been flying for 40 years, domestic and international. I always look forward to experiencing a new airport or sizable expansion, such as SLC has recently undergone. Unfortunately, there are too many problems with the new facility to enumerate. The remote (as in feels like you are in the next county) nature of the B terminal is particularly troublesome. On arrival in terminal B, the single down escalator designed to give access to the pedestrian tunnel to terminal A was out of service. There was no ongoing effort to repair the equipment nor any effort made by airport personnel to advise travelers of the situation—just a huge “traffic jam” (btw, interesting social experiment—social distancing immediately collapsed, health is apparently less important than getting ahead). I agree wholeheartedly with those who wonder if those who designed and executed the expansion actually travel regularly. Travelers beware: If you have a right connection you are likely to miss it, particularly if it in involves a terminal transfer. There are certain airports I have avoided for years. For instance, given the choice I would ordinarily fly through SLC over DIA every day of the week. Not anymore. SLC has catapulted straight to the top of my list of airports to avoid.

My wife (who is on oxygen) and I had to leave from and returned to gates at the very end of the main concourse - of the very, very, very long main concourse. There are moving walkways - 4, to be exact - that are very, very far apart, and there is nowhere for a handicapped person to sit and rest between those walkways. Everything is very clean and sanitized - with nowhere to rest. There are no kiosks in the concourse with airport maps showing what stores are available within that long concourse, either, so if you're looking for something, you have to physically re-walk that long, long concourse. On one of those walkways, I spied a food place with a few blocked-off tables, but nothing like at PDX or SeaTac or O'Hare. There are very few places to eat, anyway - so maybe that is why they don't bother with kiosks. Once out of the concourse and past the security doors, there are multiple "island" features where one can sit and get a breath, which is a good thing, because it is another long, long walk to get to baggage claims - which is another long problem. There are two sets of carousels - one to the left of the security exit, and one to the right. Neither is clearly marked overhead, but one is for Delta, the other for all other carriers. The video screens to tell you where your luggage will be are both a long way from where you first see them - so you have to walk hundreds of feet - only to find out you should have gone the other way. Then, I had to pass four empty, unused carousels to get to my luggage. So then, I could finally leave the terminal and go out to my waiting daughter. Except: When you leave the terminal, you are in the area for shuttles. You walk to one of two crosswalks, and get to the area for Uber and Lyft vehicles. Then you find that there is a concrete wall between you and the place passenger cars can pick you up, so you get to go back across the shuttle area, back in the terminal, up to the second floor, across those lanes and back down to the ground to get out where you can be picked up. All in all, it was a miserable experience. I have been in hundreds of airports around the world. I have never had such a miserable experience. Even getting kicked out of Elmas on Cagliari when it closed and my ride hadn't come was not as bad as this. Just one more proof that "new and improved" is a lie. It is a false lie!

commentHeader: The airport is made for solo travelers
reviewContent: After checking-in, in order to get to the TSA checkpoint, you must go down one level, which is uncommon for US airports. From what I saw, there is only one checkpoint for the entire airport, which could cause long lines during the busy time. We were departing in the late evening, and the line seemed to be about 10-15 minutes long, while the TSA-Pre and priority lanes were completely empty. The security equipment was brand new, and the process went smoothly until I was selected for an additional security check due to my arm brace. The agent was quite rude and forcefully patted down the brace and caused pain after collecting three substance samples and two hand metal detector tests. Additionally, the same agent flipped everything out of one of our suitcases to confiscate a bottle of lotion that was 5 millilitres over the limit and has passed through multiple airports before. Past security, there were a few restaurants like Shake Shack and only one lounge, the Delta SkyClub. Most stores are still under construction. The A gates, which are used by Delta are located within a few minutes of walking distance. However, all other airlines depart from the B gates, which require all passengers to once again go one level lower and walk for quite a large amount of time. The B gates do have restaurants, however, the best options are closer to the entrance of the airport at the A gates. The wifi worked well and all seats were equipped with a power outlet. The airport is made for solo travelers, the layout and long walking distances are not designed for families and people who may need assistance. If you plan on flying with a large group or require mobility help, flying Delta is best as their gates are closest.

I have used this airport for many years to travel on business in the western USA. After my recent experience at the "new" airport, I will be looking for a new western USA base. Simply put, I honestly cannot think of anything positive to say about this new airport. The new parking garage is a mess. The signage is quite poor. I wanted to park my rental car in the short term area as I have always done. But when I pulled up the ramp, there were two ways I could go: the left-hand ramp went up, so I took the right-hand entrance. The garage is very poorly designed. The entrances to the garage are VERY narrow, and you have to enter on a right-angle, which made things very tricky. Fortunately I had a very small car, but it was a tight squeeze even so. Once I got into Level Two, I saw a sign stating that overnight parking was not permitted. I drove around for a least 5 minutes, trying to find either someone to help me or the way up to Level Three. There WAS a booth that said "Information" but no one was around. So I drove around for another 5 minutes, trying to find the exit. There are signs pointing to "exit" but in fact many of them just lead right back into the same level! When I finally DID find the exit, it was unmarked, off to the side in an odd location, and not only did it require a 90-degree turn, but there was a long concrete barrier about six inches high alongside the exit. I couldn't pull into it, so I had to go all the way around and then swing wide. As it was, it was a VERY tight lane, as was the entrance to the down ramp. When I finally got to the exit, I asked the lady at the ticket booth where I could park overnight. She told me to go left, up to Level Three, and that she would immediately call her supervisor, who would meet me at the entrance, to help me. Needless to say, no one up there on Level 3 either. When I got down to the check-in area, it was absolute chaos. Long lines to get a baggage tag, even longer lines to drop the bag off: and the counters were fully staffed. The chaos was not the fault of the airline, but rather the poor airport design. Very poorly laid-out and definitely not customer friendly. I asked the lady at check-in how I was to get to my gate. She said, "you're at B20" and that's a bit of a walk: 1.2 miles, actually." As it turned out it was even further than that! Another airport employee told me later that they were going to build an underground train to connect Terminals A and B, but had no idea if/when that would actually be completed. Several of the rolling walkways were also not functioning. I felt sorry for the older people that I saw that were clearly struggling with that hike. The signage throughout the airport is poor. For example, to get to Terminal B from Terminal A, you have to walk halfway down Terminal A, then take the stairs (or escalators, if they're working) down to the tunnel that leads to B. One would think that this would be frequently signposted but in fact it is not. I wandered around for quite a while before I stumbled upon it. Returning to SLC was more of the same. There are a few signs for "Baggage Claim" and then they suddenly disappear. Again, a fair bit of wandering and I finally found: right at the entrance to Terminal A! Not secure at all. For those of you that travel internationally, let me describe SLC: it makes Frankfurt or Paris Charles de Gaulle seem organized and friendly. By the way beer and coffee are basically your only food options..

This is a horrible airport, the layout was not planned well. Be prepared to walk, add 30-40 tp get to your connecting gate, escalators down everywhere. I will definitely try and avoid this airport in the future.

commentHeader: the worst airport I travel to
reviewContent: SLC used to be an easy in and out airport. Now it’s the worst airport I travel to. You have to walk for ever to get to the B gates, sorry if you’re older or out of shape. Smaller planes require a long walk outside to a bus, which then inefficiently transports you to your plane on the tarmac. What was once a travel friendly airport has become a inefficient cluster of an airport. I feel sorry for anyone who arrives at b gate and has to get a quick connection in the a gates...good luck. The rental car facility is much better though.

commentHeader: had to walk and walk and walk
reviewContent: I am a 62 year old typical woman, not fit, not unfit. Arrived in SLC airport to visit family on November 18 and left November 29, 2020. I was shocked at the poor design when I arrived and had to walk and walk and walk. As a college professor from New England, I decided to collect annotated data on the trip back. Yes, the art is lovely but if your mood is impaired by the physical requirements to manage your experience, who cares? I was traveling alone with 2 suitcases and 2 carry-ons. I had a rental car. The moment I returned the rental and took my first step towards the terminal, I started my stop watch on my phone. Me and 4 pieces of luggage headed for the first elevator. Up to rental but unfortunately, my airline did not have a check in person at the rental area, nice idea but no help here. Over to the main terminal. Check in, a total of 5 elevators and 44 minutes of walking (there were no lines due to COVID travel so waiting did not change my time). Finally get to the gate to hear a disembarking flight attendant say to the pilot, "are you ready for a long walk?" The pilot says, this is my first time here. I think to myself, "this is my last time here." And I mean it, the family will have to visit later at one of our family reunions, I am not going back the the SLC airport ever again. Who in their right mind designed this building? My only last thought is to keep the poor employees who must push a wheelchair in this environment in your thoughts.

SLC Airport planning boo boo. So many complaints about unreasonable distances to walk have dominated reviews. The airport has now put up distances and times on the internet in their review. They did not count the distance from drop off or pickup. They posted outrageous times that could only be achieved by young athletes. Massive lack of regard for the less abled and elderly travelers. A word to the SLC mayor, stop your political cover up and address the problem.

Just road tested the new Salt Lake City airport and I'm appalled. Flew American and had to walk miles, and change levels repeatedly. It's the worst organized airport I've ever seen. There are almost no moving sidewalks, and the few there are are either broken or move so slow they're infuriating. I saw NO other people moving options like indoor shuttles. There are no shuttles between terminals. The signs are too infrequent to help, and almost invisible, and totally confusing. I made numerous wrong turns as a result and walked even further, then had to back track. Furthermore the sign for long term parking shuttle directs people out the wrong door, farthest from the shuttle. I don't understand how a new airport can be this bad and do virtually everything wrong. I don't see how people with mobility problems can get around that mess. Horrible ordeal using that airport. Disgraceful. Whoever designed this garbage should be ashamed, and jobless.
What a horrible layout, all you do is endless walking, nothing is centralized. Car rental clear at far end, you should take note of Tampa International Airport.

commentHeader: This new airport is an embarrassment!
reviewContent: This new airport is an embarrassment! If you’re traveling on any airline other than Delta (which I never will fly again) bring a sturdy pair of hiking boots, your walking stick and a snack to eat along the way. I’m only slightly exaggerating here. It’s almost exactly a mile walk from the airlines ticket counters to the B gates. I felt bad while following someone with a severe limp trying to make the trek. It’s seems obvious that the airport is trying to disservice customers into flying on Delta. I wonder how much Delta paid the city to make sure everyone who flies any other airline will have to walk forever! I enjoy walking when I’m in a national park, but in an airport when trying to make a flight? No good! You failed big time! Denver airport is far and above, even with the broken moving sidewalks and escalators. The long walk actually distracted from the newness of the airport which will get old really fast.

What a horrible horrible design! Get ready to walk and burn an extra 20 plus minutes walking to your gate. Who was the idiot that forces you to walk an extra 5 blocks so you walk thru the shopping mall. They could have built a tunnel straight out.

commentHeader: Salt Lake City Airport customer review
reviewContent: The SLC airport design is extremely deficient in the planning and designed length of walking required to most gates. Persons with limited ambulatory capacity are required to suffer with no options other than push roller chairs with no pushers. Unbelievable design, making it the worst in the US.

Brand new beautiful airport, but poorly planned. Plan an extra 30 min to get to & from terminal B. The walk is much longer now that it was when we were routed from Concourse A to the F gates. Really disappointed!

Did not have a good experience for my first visit. Plane had to deplane in the tarmac and then bus to terminal due to construction. I slipped and fell on the ramp outside due to snow and ice. Not very impressed!

This has to be the worst designed airport I have ever been in. You literally walk over 1 mile if you are in b concourse. The designers sure spent a lot of time and money on the art but totally forgot to worry about how to effectively move people. The walk ways are extremely slow and narrow. If you plan on ever using this airport allow 30 min of walking time to get to the gate. Sad sad state of affairs for such a new airport. If it were built in the 60’s would still be a poor excuse for moving people. I have been in airports easily 4 times the size of this airport and walk 75% less. The designers should go back to school and should be forced to pay to have this airport redesigned.

The new airport is horrible. Be prepared to walk a lot if you have to go to B terminal and I mean walk. C terminal was worse had to be bussed into B terminal and then had to walk forever and a day just to get to baggage claim. The only good thing I can say is that my bags were actually there waiting because it took about twenty five minutes to get from my gate to the baggage claim.

commentHeader: so disappointed in the new airport
reviewContent: I am so disappointed in the new airport. Be prepared to walk forever. The design is horrible. Salt Lake clearly went cheap in all aspects. I was not expecting luxury but I was expecting better than what Salt Lake already had.

The new SLC airport is the most poorly designed and dysfunctional airport I've seen in a very long time. It is gorgeous to be sure. But you have to walk through the entire Delta concourse before taking a very long underground tunnel to the second concourse where every other airline is housed. That underground tunnel is 50% longer than the tunnel at O'Hare between the two United concourses. To get to a Southwest or United gate is a solid 20 minute walk (approx. 1 mile) both when you depart and when you arrive. The "everybody but Delta" concourse also has very little food. It is as if Delta decided to punish every traveler who was not flying Delta with an extra 20 minutes of walking time, both arriving and departing. The tunnel to the second concourse could easily have been placed at the front of the Delta concourse instead of the back. Forcing someone to walk the entire length of the Delta concourse before having to then walk the entire length of the second concourse is punitive - I can't think of another word for it. Shame on Delta. Shame on the SLC airport authority. It used to be a delight to fly in and out of the SLC airport. Now it takes almost as long to walk from the gate to the street as it does to drive from the airport to Park City.

commentHeader: I will seek other options wherever possible
reviewContent: Horrible layout. Miles of walking! Moving walkways slow and none for those who want to walk rather than stand. Takes forever to get through this airport! I will seek other options wherever possible. Not proud to call this “home”.

commentHeader: I am very unhappy with the new airport layout
reviewContent: The layout of the new airport requires long walks without motorized assistance such as SEA and MSP airports. The trudge through YUL in Montreal seems from the gates to customs is reasonable compared to SLC. I am a cardiac patient with bad knees. The walk from security to the A gates is acceptable but the security to the B gates is ridiculous. The old airport design was simple and easy to navigate with reasonable distances between terminals. I travel for a living and I am very unhappy with the new airport layout. I will begin booking flights through other airports to avoid SLC.

For a brand new $2B airport, not impressed. Everything takes too much time, rude staffing, equipment broken, few signs that some can read or understand, pick up and drop off third rate, bus fumes in pickup area will choke you.

Very poor if you are elderly or handicapped. From drop off, near the rental cars, to the F and G gates it is a long, long hike, with little help from people movers. I have a walking problem, as does my wife and it took us nearly an hour to walk from the drop off area, through baggage claim, into security, through security, into the main concourse terminal, turn right at Starbucks. Then a long, long walk back to the farthest end of the old Terminal 1 to the F and G gates. There are few people movers along the way. I didn't see one golf cart to assist the elderly or handicapped. This is a brutal experience. We where exhausted and hurting, once we got to our gate, not a good start to our trip to So. Calif. I have over 550,000 miles on Delta, most of which originating from SLC. I was so looking forward the new terminal, but for me..bring back the old one.

commentHeader: very poor customer service for the airport staff
reviewContent: If you can avoid Salt Lake City airport do so at all costs, it is the worst! Unfortunately I have to deal with this every other week for work, back & forth from Dallas. Again, if you are able to avoid Salt Lake City airport do so at all costs! It is horrible even with the new construction and they do not make any accommodations unless they can physically see your disability! I have spinal stenosis and you have to walk a marathon to get to your connecting flight here, I have actually asked airport staff for assistance getting from one side of the airport to the other, and since my disability is not visible they refused on both dates, it is very painful when one whole side of your body goes numb & very poor customer service for the airport staff to refuse help when there are empty wheelchairs throughout the airport!

commentHeader: I will make every effort not to come to this airport
reviewContent: The new remodel makes this one of the worst airports in America. My times to get from the gate to a rental car have tripled. I used to be able to return a car and be at my gate in 15 min. My first trip after the new opening took 1hr and 18 min of confusion and exhaustion. Anyone who can make it from the rental car facility to gate G in one trip deserves a medal. I have to rest at 2 locations to make it. They have some people movers but so far at least 50% are always broken. They also don't have enough restrooms so if you come off a plane and have been holding it for 2-1/2 hrs plan on holding it a lot longer. Signage is poor. The main terminal is on multiple levels and confusing. The luggage machines at security take time and separate your bags making grabbing them less efficient. The whole airport sucks and they need golf carts for people who can't make the required hike to their terminals. I have been traveling for work for 14 years, I've been in all US airports and usually fly around 300 flights a year. I have no issues getting around any of them. Chicago Dallas, Atlanta all work well. Congrats to SLC for screwing up a decent airport. For future, I will make every effort not to come to this airport.

commentHeader: undergoing an impressive remodelling and modernization
reviewContent: SLC airport is undergoing an impressive remodelling and modernization as we speak, which is appropriate considering that the SLC region and Utah is one of the best regions in the USA in terms of actually maintaining and improving physical infrastructure. The regional and state governments there seem to understand that that not only improves the quality of life for the residents, but it also provides a wonderful aspect for people who are tourists or doing business in the area. That said, here are the airport's strong suits: 1) Signage to wherever you need to go, whether in the terminal, at check-in, or driving into or away from the airport, is usually ample and straightforward. 2) The airport is generally clean, with the major exception of a few gates in an older terminal whose remodel still isn't yet complete (in that case, that particular area I saw was actually pretty dirty). 3) Renting a car, returning a rental car, or taking light rail from and to the airport are all pretty easy (at least Enterprise Rent-A-Car was easy). 4) I don't remember ever meeting even a grumpy or gruff person working at this airport, even TSA, in my experience, were all business with their security monitoring, but courteous and efficient. If you have TSA Pre-Check, that always helps. 5) The exterior of the new terminal under construction as part of the remodeling process conveys SLC's ambition to be an even more modern, more ambitious, and more traveler-friendly metropolis. 6) I still find it hilariously ironic that there are direct flights between SLC and Amsterdam, considering the stereotypes of those regions. Now, for a real con, the present construction work has resulted in some lane changes driving around the airport that require the driver to pay close attention, or else miss their exit or turn or just crash into some concrete barrier. I'm not from SLC, but I love coming to the area by flying into this airport.

commentHeader: have been very impressed with the TSA staff
reviewContent: I’ve flown from the Salt Lake airport several times this year and have been very impressed with the TSA staff, especially over the rush of Thanksgiving and Christmas travel. They were respectful, friendly, efficient, and quick. The only annoying incident was in August when the man checking my ID had me take off my glasses. No one’s ever had me to that. Overall, I highly recommend the airport and staff!

commentHeader: need to consider a different approach
reviewContent: As I waited in line with everyone else for TSA (pre-check) I had two airport employees step directly in front of me as I was next in line pending TSA review. It was rude behavior and made everyone waiting angry. This process should not be allowed (or if it is allowed the airport should post a sign explaining the exception). I understand employees are “going to work” but when the rest of the world drives to work each morning do they pass other drivers on the emergency lane because they have a scheduled shift? The message airport patrons take away is that airport employees time is more valuable than the airport travelers (who by the way have a plane to catch). Many travelers find themselves in a hurry or experience higher than normal stress levels when traveling and having someone cut right in front of you because they didn’t plan accordingly annoys everyone. Salt Lake City (and other airports) really need to consider a different approach or risk escalated traveler irritation. Why make a stressful experience more stressful.

Totally impressed by the cheerful disposition and friendliness of all the staff at the airport. Noticing the empty water bottle in my back pag, the TSA agent, on her own, told me where to find a water fountain. The clerk at the enquiry counter suggested I call the hotel to let them know I had arrived instead of waiting for their shuttle to come on their own schedule - a very useful tip! Young staff greeted passengers and offered assistance. Signage throughout the airport was clear. Lots of seating around. Many shops and eateries. Bathrooms clean. Car rental garage adjacent to the terminal - a huge convenience obviating the need to take a shuttle to and fro from the lot. Finally, the setting of the terminal, surrounded by mountains which were snow covered was just memorably breath taking. Lot of construction taking place outside the terminal - hence one needs to pay attention to lanes and road directions when driving in or out. It was a pleasure using this airport.

commentHeader: wasn’t willing to help at all"
reviewContent: My roommate and I just got off our flight, she had to wait for her bag and I went ahead to make sure our next flight didn’t leave without us (on the other side of the airport) so I got to the bottom of the gate (this gate had metal bars/runway when heading away from it) and I just wanted to tell her that I’ll hold the plane to make sure she got it (our cell phones weren’t sending texts at this time). The attendant at the gate, as I got into talking space with my roommate yelled at me saying that I can’t go up there because they don’t know if I was on that flight. That I just got off of 10 seconds ago. Clearly trying to tell my roommate the game plan. She was very rude and wasn’t willing to help at all. I will make sure I avoid this airport at all costs in the future. I work in retail and am an Assisant Store Manager of a large world wide retailer and if someone was “breaking the rule” I would kindly tell them and ask how I could help/support to make sure their taken care of. Follow the rules, make the customer happy, keep everyone safe. Ridiculous and rude. Uncalled for. There was better ways to handle the situation.

Horrible with lost items. I reported my Driver's License lost immediate after exiting the airport and described it's exact location, and it was never found. It took three days to get ahold of a live person as they redirect you to their website every time you call. I'm shocked that they were unable to locate such an important item when they had its exact location immediately after the flight.

B Terminal restroom does not have heavy duty hooks installed in the men’s stalls to keep jackets and packs off of the urine soaked floors? Please fix this ASAP! This is a sanitary issue! Who dropped the ball here? The stalls are narrow I realize this but this is truly ridiculous.

commentHeader: This airport is my least favourite
reviewContent: This airport is my least favorite. Limited lounges, only a single Delta lounge. I always travel with a service animal and SLC is one of the least pet friendly airports. They do have 2 pet relief areas but you will be lucky to be be near one. I normally traverse through C gate and its a long walk to the B or E relief area. Worst part is once you finally arrive you have to search for someone to get the gate open which is about a 30 min process on all 3 times I have flown in to this airport. If your lucky a gate agent is near by, if not good luck to find one. Then any gate agent you find needs to call someone which is another 15-20 min wait. It's so horrible for any animal who just departed a 7-9 hr flight. Hopefully after enough pets relive themself on the carpets this airport will get smart and modern and build relief areas like all other airports where you can come and go without a gate agent. I alway cross my fingers I never have to travel through SLC but if your on Delta its a hard airport to avoid. Plus there are no signs to mark or inform you where the relief areas are so do your research.

Salt Lake City seems to have a fairly nice airport. My only complaint is the long walk to baggage claim from the B concourse on Terminal 1. Food options are somewhat limited compared to other airports. The place looked clean to me. The lines at check in looked rather long but the Southwest counter was adequately staffed. I was TSA Pre and that went quickly too. Another positive is the light rail line at the south end of Terminal 1. It took me from downtown to the Terminal in 23 minutes. It runs every 15 minutes on weekdays and every 20 minutes on Sundays and Holidays and is much cheaper than taking a cab or uber. It's not as pleasant as Long Beach or Jackson Hole, but it isn't the behemoth like Chicago O'Hare either.

commentHeader: very inconsiderate to remove all the smoking areas
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Salt Lake City Airport customer review
Shuttle service for rental cars is getting worse
reviewContent: Shuttle service for rental cars is getting worse and worse by the day. I have been traveling weekly to SMF and I can say the shuttle service has gotten worse by the day in the last six months. It used be couple of minutes wait to now it is over 20 minutes of wait with 100s of passengers waiting in shuttle line. At this point, I am seriously not renting car from the airport and just catch Uber ride to downtown rental agencies and it would be cheaper and faster.

Plan on waiting 50 minutes for the rental car shuttle from terminal B or use airlines that fly out of terminal A. Worst shuttle service ever out of Terminal B. Tons of business travelers needing to get to rental cars and the wait is inconsiderate to those of us who use the airport for work.

commentHeader: worst airport to arrive with luggage
reviewContent: This is the worst airport to arrive with luggage. The airport is tiny and they managed to take more than an hour to start releasing our luggage. It is absolutely the worst airport in Northern California

commentHeader: Budget lots more time for this airport
reviewContent: Budget lots more time for this airport, horribly inefficient. Taking the more difficult option of public transport (rental cars, etc.) is penalized by drop-off area furthest from each terminal. Rental car center requires dragging bags across lots, through building and then long wait on huge bus, only to be dropped off on outer land furthest from check-in! Maddening. If you miss turn-off to your terminal (no sign, only colors) be prepared for long delay as you drive miles to other terminal and terminal return. Why a smallish regional airport needs to be spread out over miles of terminal is difficult to comprehend. It’s one thing to have to significant transfer between terminals at London Heathrow (giant airport in urban area) it’s quite another at small regional. How about putting terminals together and allow passengers to access them without driving all over god’s green earth. Sorry for the rant but dragging heavy bags for 20 minutes at 5am needlessly requires some decompression.

Worst airport in a decade. The gas station on the drive in is great, but getting out was awful. No signs! And dark red Jersey barriers in the middle of the road impossible to see which is bad cause 3 of us were driving around trying to find an exit. No signs. Then one tiny sign across the road, no lighting to direct you to the airport. Can’t see in dark and fog. Drove the wrong way, it is a two mile trip to a dead end to get back to the airport. Signs to rental cars as bad. Can’t see in fog which is common this time of year. Another 2 mile misdirection. Rental rental requires a bus. Train to terminal B ok but just be warned. Marginal food choices. Coffee stand closed at 07.00! I have been in 3rd world countries with better quality. Take extra time. Be warned!

commentHeader: Every time I fly from this airport I have an issue!
reviewContent: Was easy to get to, however after I checked in my luggage, I never got them at the final destination as they never made it there! Every time I fly from this airport I have an issue! for both Domestic or International flights!

commentHeader: They are consistently rude and unnecessarily aggressive
reviewContent: I’m writing after multiple negative experiences with Sacramento Airport’s traffic operations staff (SMF Operations). They are consistently rude and unnecessarily aggressive. I understand the importance of controlling traffic relative to departures and arrivals, however, it is unacceptable and unnecessary for these employees to be as rude and aggressive as they consistently are. I am wondering if these persons are hired with afore knowledge of their inability to perform their duties without any public service etiquette at all. I would rather travel to the South Bay Area to fly than to fly out of local Sac International in order to avoid having any encounters with these employees whatsoever. I do not appreciate being verbally assaulted by these employees and this is something that definitely should be addressed and changed.

Easy to Navigate airport with a simple layout. Not many restaurants/food places were open due to COVID. Tons of seating available. Easy train connection between check in area and gate area. Extremely short security lines.

commentHeader: a very trying time getting out of Sacramento
reviewContent: What a horrible experience. Rental car shuttle line had hundreds in line. Took forever to board. Bus driver was singing and doing hand gestures, I felt unsafe. At airport security, TSA had a hundred people in line. Meanwhile 5 agents and a dog are standing around at the front of the line. The young agent ordering us through the xray took lessons on TV from a nazi program. Overall, a very trying time getting out of Sacramento.

commentHeader: priorities need to be shifted and staff re-examined
reviewContent: TSA are extremely rude. To the gentleman in the tsa pre line, learn manners if you’re going to be working with customers or work in the back in a dark room away from people. If I’m asking you something, don’t have attitude when responding. I’m asking to know because I don’t know the answer, sarcasm is not needed. Also out of the 30 airports I’ve been to throughout the world this is the first to tell me my cosmetic items were too large. I think it goes without saying priorities need to be shifted and staff re-examined.

John Wayne airport is a nice little small/humble airport good for traveling with kids. It is a small airport with only 22 gates everything in the airport is close by. If you live by John Wayne I definitely would recommend!
Beautiful airport in Orange County with incredible ease to all major interstates. Airport sits off the 405 and is perfectly situated for Los Angeles visitors. Large airport with a small town feel.

The staff here are absolutely rude and unprofessional. I arrived in a timely matter and said goodbye to my family and younger siblings who I have not seen in many years and as I walk up to baggage check in, they say I’m a few minutes too late (despite being over half and hour early) and that no exceptions could be made. They made me pay a fee for a new flight and the lady was extremely rude. This is definitely the last time I will ever fly from John Wayne and instead, will just still to LAX where they strive to please their customers.

I landed with wheels down at 12:05 PM. I was the fifth person off the aircraft and it took till 12:50 to get my bag back. That is horrible! This airport is way too small to justify that laziness and tardiness in a frequently visited area. I am a business traveler from Atlanta and Delta has bags up in 20 min at one of the busiest airports. Get it together and build your quality!
The restrooms were horrible, dirty and no paper towels, disgusting, the attendant was outside the door with her phone. Men’s restroom smelled of urine.

commentHeader: undersized for the traffic it has
reviewContent: This place is way undersized for the traffic it has. The restaurant selection is a joke. The main food court has been closed for months. Restrooms are dirty and small. Southwest needs to find a better Midwest hub

commentHeader: Wasn’t even welcomed by the staff
reviewContent: Was the worst experience of my life. Wasn’t even welcomed by the staff entering the airport plus I was trying to get all of the tags on the luggage’s and they just scolded us instead of helping us at the entrance.

Always a nightmare getting bags from baggage claim. I've never waited lass than 45 minutes for my bag, and usually it's at least an hour. Also, not enough seating. So many people have to stand or not on the ground while waiting for their plane. Absolute worst airport.

commentHeader: the true spirit of customer service
reviewContent: I recently had an unforgettable experience at the St. Louis airport that I felt compelled to share. It's not often that you encounter such exceptional customer service and genuine compassion in the service industry, but my encounter with two outstanding Huntleigh USA Corporation employees truly left me in awe. I found myself in a predicament when I was running late due to an unfortunate accident. Time was against me, and I was beginning to feel the stress and anxiety that comes with the fear of missing an important event. That's when Arlando Bolden and his colleague came to the rescue, turning my stressful situation into a heartwarming display of care and professionalism. Despite our best efforts, we arrived at our destination just a few minutes late. At this point, I had resigned myself to the possibility of missing my commitment, but Arlando and his coworker had other plans. They went above and beyond to ensure that I could still reach my destination. First and foremost, they helped me with the necessary arrangements, taking into consideration my convenience. This act of kindness was a relief in itself, but what truly touched me was their willingness to guide me personally. They recognized that my nerves were getting the better of me, and their calming presence made all the difference. Arlando Bolden deserves special recognition for his outstanding service and compassion. His dedication to his job and the well-being of customers is commendable. He was not just a helping hand but a beacon of support during a stressful moment. I am incredibly grateful to Arlando and his coworker for going the extra mile to ensure that I made it to my destination smoothly. Their actions exemplify the exceptional service that Huntleigh USA Corporation is known for, and I cannot thank them enough for their kindness. Huntleigh USA Corporation has earned my utmost respect and gratitude through this experience. They proved that they care deeply about their customers and are willing to do whatever it takes to make their journeys as pleasant as possible. I wholeheartedly recommend Huntleigh USA Corporation to anyone seeking reliable, compassionate, and customer-centric service. Thank you, Arlando Bolden, and your colleague, for restoring my faith in the kindness of strangers and for demonstrating the true spirit of customer service.

Probably the best example of "afraid to lay off useless people" I've seen in any airport. The check-in line for Southwest had to be a hundred people long with what appeared to be enough employees to shorten the line considerably. But no, they just stand around talking to each other with the occasional barking of doing everything yourself. Security was a joke, nobody around to tell you what to take out and leave in the bag - until after it's gone through the X-ray machine, then they tell you and call you back. Great examples of "not my job".

commentHeader: wish I could avoid this airport
reviewContent: What a horrible airport. In all of my years traveling for business I have never seen such a disorganized mess of an airport. Security line literally out the door. No one seemed to know what was going on. TSA was terrible. I wish I could avoid this airport. If it wasn’t for work I would never fly here again. Stay away.

commentHeader: one of the smoothest travel experiences
reviewContent: I travel frequently both internationally and domestically, and St Louis Airport provided one of the smoothest travel experiences I have had to date. Staff were efficient and seemed to actually care about their jobs, food and beverage options were plentiful, and the terminal was easy to navigate. The security process was also extremely efficient and well-staffed. The only negative thing I have to say about this airport is that the seating areas at the gates could have been cleaner, as chairs had dirt and particles of who knows what all over and in between them. However, not all of the seating was like this, and it didn't bother me as there were many cafes and bars to hang out in. Overall one of the better airports I have been through, and I have been through countless. Great job STL!

commentHeader: couldn’t be bothered to do his job
reviewContent: I have never been so angry. Because the security guard at the terminal two arrivals area couldn’t be bothered to do his job and manage traffic, people were parking and staying in spots long before their family arrived. This led to such a long line behind them that it took over an hour for my daughter to get through to pick me up. There was plenty of space at pick-up, but nobody could get through the single file line because of the idiots parking rather than driving around again. Had the guard just done his job it would have been fine.

The C gates shops/restaurants offered very little to no vegan food options. I always eat a fruit or veggie tray when I fly but this was not available here. The bathrooms and gate area floors were dirty, anywhere that sold food had a very long line because multiple shops/stalls were closed. Headphones I was looking to purchase were marked for $149 here when on Amazon they are selling for $89. Not my worst airport experience but I’ve defiantly seen better.

commentHeader: I have to say it was the only time it was this bad
reviewContent: I was stopped for "random" search. The palm swipes rejected and had to call woman for "body search" (outside of clothes search). It took 20 minutes to get a woman over there and no one was explaining anything. So you are sitting there barefooted, no sweater, purse, phone, etc. as every single person goes by you. Very degrading. It was a little odd also that 2 more women my age (behind me about 10 people in line) as well was also stopped. They must have passed the palm swipe. I have been in this airport for 20 years and I have to say it was the only time it was this bad. It was the employees I encountered.

While going through TSA they took my scissors. Tiny scissors I had had for years, that I was specifically told to buy for TSA approval. I crochet on planes as a stress/anxiety relief/distraction. These scissors have literally made it through years of TSA agents. From LAX to O'Hare, from PDX to LGB, JFK to McCarran.. Every other airport and TSA has either said nothing at all, or said they were fine. But for some reason St. Louis said they were not allowed? Where is the consistency?

commentHeader: It seemed to be more about harassing the customers than safety anymore
reviewContent: I checked a bag for my flight home and the guy at the counter handed me my claim ticket, no smile, no gate info, no “thank you” or “have a good flight”. So I looked at my phone to see my boarding pass with the gate #, and he angrily said “go”! I thought maybe somebody had come and was waiting, but nobody was behind me. I just said “thank you for your help”. Then I get to security. The lady who checked my boarding pass and ID was nice compared to the baggage check staff member and the grumpy one pushing bags into the X ray machine. She had something nasty to say about everyone ahead of me as she tuned to put the trays back. A man 2 people in front of me got reprimanded for not pushing his stuff through. “That is your responsibility sir, not mine”, then she muttered “idiot” as she turned to put a tray back. The lady in front of me put her backpack in a tray and she pulled it out, yelled something at her, and said “what is wrong with you people, you got a bag you put it on with no tray! Sheeesh”. I put my bag on the rollers—and she grabbed a tray to put it in to send through. Then she told me to go to the line for the X-ray (of me), where I was asked to remove my shoes, my glasses, my Fitbit, my necklace (not an easy task with arthritis, but not only would nobody help, they were really impatient with the time it took me to get it off) and my scarf. I have never been asked to remove that much before as I have TSA precheck (they have you carry a card to let TSA know, but they took it away with my shoes so I didn’t have it for every time I had to take another piece of clothing off, but it’s but it didn’t matter to them.). They complained that I didn’t get out of the way fast enough when I had to go back. It seemed to be more about harassing the customers than safety anymore. Anyway, I have more to say, but I need to get home and at least my flight is on time. Just don’t go here if you don’t have to!

commentHeader: She was a very intentionally mean person
reviewContent: TSA female employee found that an item I was hand carrying could not go through. I explained that I had just purchased the item and the box was not yet open. It was a snow globe from Cracker Barrel and the liquid was causing a problem. She told me to unpack some things and repack the box into my largest bag then check it through. As my husband and I started to do this she became very rude, telling us that her station was closed and that we had to immediately remove the bags. When I asked her where we were supposed to go, she picked up the suitcase and dropped it onto a green bench. When my husband zipped it shut she grabbed the bag and walked off. I followed and she dropped it just outside of the Security area and stormed off. I took it to baggage check and came back through Security where thank goodness she ignored me. She was a very intentionally mean person and offered no explanations. Maybe she assumed that we all check bags through but I don't and had no plans to.

commentHeader: has anyone else had the same experience?
reviewContent: Recently I took a trip where we flew to Austin TX, on the return trip to St Louis our bags, which usually take a while to come out took an exceedingly long time to come out this time, over a half hour. Then, when they came out and we picked up our luggage at the bag return the pull handles on both mine and my wife's luggage had some kind of goop on them, smelled like green apple. I smelled this in the bag return area before we got our bags too, has anyone else traveled and had the same experience? It was weird and it's bothering me! Is this some sort of TSA thing?

Rude and inefficient - counter attendant with Delta told us we each needed to hand her our own ID and boarding pass so she wouldn’t get confused and sent our luggage to the wrong destination. She then proceeded to give my ID and boarding pass to another passenger. Dirty and incompetent - restaurant (Starbucks), I ordered a lower temp coffee and it was made even hotter than normal - I couldn’t hold it in my bare hand even with a cup sleeve. Toilet cleaning staff was just rude - she is standing outside bathroom - three toilets in bathroom and none had been flushed, tissue on floor. I walk in, flush toilet, take care of business and flush. When I walk out of stall she is waiting to go in. She grumbles and flushes toilet and sprays down stall and then walks out and leaves other stalls dirty.

commentHeader: refused me to get back in line with my husband
reviewContent: A non descriptive woman, not clearly a TSA associate was monitoring the security line. I stepped back to hug my parents goodbye and she rudely refused me to get back in line with my husband who had my bag. She was extra loud and seemed to abuse her power while I had tears in my eyes. She was overly disrespectful to me and my family. I'm looking for a way to get in touch with her supervisor. Unfortunately, she was not wearing a name tag, she was not TSA. Thank goodness for options in other airports. I don't want to be treated like that again.

Incredibly rude TSA agent—I went through the TSA check line, my baggage had to be checked, but was held back for items to be checked. The agent spoke to me like I was dirt under her feet, then took her time searching through my bag—taking out each piece of underwear and opening all container—being slow on purpose. Very bad experience. I was here for my dad’s funeral and she handled the items I had from his home poorly. Glad I won’t ever have to go back through this airport ever again.
The TSA review process is haphazard and not very kind. The agents scold the passengers and talk to them like they are cattle. Manhandling people and their luggage. Very rude uncourteous behavior.

This airport is extremely annoying because they blast the volume of network television through speakers constantly. Don't they know that some commuters are tired and that airports are already noisy? Don't they know that air travel is expensive? It seems that they are wasting money on electricity to irritate their customers with noise. It's part of the reason your ticket was so expensive: this blatant waste of money. I even asked a handful of employees about it. All of them agreed that the TV noise is a constant stressful nuisance and a detriment to their focus and ability to do their jobs and stay alert. Whoever off on this should be terminated. It's so obviously ridiculous and stupid as to be unforgivable.

TSA stopped me and my husband for the amount of 3 oz bottles in my husbands carry on bag. They told him he could not take the 3 oz. bottle of shampoo and conditioner (which was mine) through security, meaning it would have to be thrown away. Now, that's not what makes me most mad, I was most upset because the TSA agent snatched it out of my hand when I asked if I could put it in my bag, or whether he wanted me to throw it away. This was such a rude and ignorant gesture. The agent could've given us an alternative or been a little nicer when handling the issue. He was treating us terribly, when in fact, we are a military family traveling for leisure. I'm very upset and disappointed with St. Louis!

I like this airport. It's very clean and has friendly people. But it's really dragged down by the lack of decent food options in concourse C. With flights not serving meals, a traveler can come into the airport famished, with a short layover, and there's nothing. The only place to get a decent comfortable table is Chili's and the food there is simply awful. Plus the staff seem to find the back row of tables by the work station a great place to hang out and share raucous jokes. With five or six of them going at it on my last trip, you could hear them all down the concourse. Trying to pass a quiet hour with my laptop was wrecked by the noise, like being next to a tailgate party. And here's some feedback for the Chili's people. When I was there none of the shouting parties were watching the tables while we customers were craning our necks trying to get menus or drinks or whatever. I couldn't figure out why there were so many employees doing nothing except having fun in mid afternoon when there were very few customers, the cooks were making the food and the bartender was handling the bar. Just one waiter finally started handling tables and while he was very nice he forgot my silverware and water - separate trips for both - and seemed shaky on the whole process. The manager, whom I met briefly, seemed to have no clue that a restaurant, even Chili's, is supposed to serve customers, not double as a social club for staff. As a former restaurant owner, I ranked him as worthless. Anyway, we desperately need a pleasant place to sit with at least decent food that's not just tasteless Chili's fare, liquids, bready pre-made sandwiches or sugary pastries.

TSA at St Louis airport is behind the times. I have flown through many airports and TSA precheck barely applies. This used to be a great airport, but now I will only fly out when absolutley necessary. Laptops in carry ons? Seems to be at the agents discretion, and he is stuck in September 12, 2001.

Alyce was working in United baggage customer service when I landed in St. Louis with the rest of the Arkansas softball group. United left 11 of our bags at Washington Dulles airport and I needed to file a claim for the missing luggage. Alyce was very patient, kind and helpful in making the claims (we had two reservations) for our group. We were able to retrieve the missing luggage later that night and she helped myself and our charter bus driver load the bags on the luggage cart. Additionally, I lost my wallet between Washington Dulles and United Flight 4749 to STL. When I told her she was willing to help me retrieve it any way possible. She called the hanger to see if it was left on the plane and even found the number for the lost and found at Washington Dulles airport. Although I have not found my wallet, I really appreciated her help.

TSA agents need additional training. I told them that I had a knee replacement and have a titanium knee. Instead of having me go through the X-ray, the agent sent me through the walk in which resulted in me being patted down and almost missing my flight to Seattle. This is just ridiculous. They took their time with the pat down and acted like they didn’t care. Just rude and insensitive. Not sure that I will visiting this place again.

commentHeader: It feels like a money grab
reviewContent: Every other airport offers free WiFi, providing one hour before starting to charge is very poor service. This is not customer friendly and pales considerably when compared to other airports. It feels like a money grab when everything else is already overpriced.

I pulled up to pick up some passengers and did not know where to go. So I then asked security staff at the airport where I should go and the security guard started yelling at me to move the car. I asked him several times that I did not know where to go and he kept yelling at me to move my car. A Saint Louis police officer then approached and started yelling that I need to move or leave the airport. I asked the St Louis police if he could help me and show me where to park, he then yelled saying move your car or we will tow it. As I was leaving the area I noticed the security guard yelling at other people visiting the area. I will not return to this airport, very bad PR work for the Airport.

I travelled from STL at 4.45 on Thursday, 7/20 to DTW, Gate A2. Please note that the temperature outside when we arrived at the airport was 100+. I brought a bottle to refill with water. Both drinking fountains near the gate were inoperable. I walked further down the terminal and came to 4 other drinking fountains. Nothing but a dribble came out. It was hard enough to get a sip of water but was impossible to fill up a bottle. This is ridiculous and leads me to believe you are forcing me to spend $3 on a bottle of water. It is time to update your fountains, first with ones that work and secondly with the bottle fillers that are offered in most 21st century airports. Secondly, the men's room near gate A2 had 4 soap dispensers none of which had any soap. These issues don't reflect the airport or the city of St Louis in a very good light.

commentHeader: allow 3 hours+ to check a bag

reviewContent: This place does not have air conditioning. So if you're delayed you will wait in extreme heat. I just spent 5 hours there. I'm in shock that no one was hauled away on a stretcher from heat exhaustion because it was dangerously hot in there. While we waited in our sweatbox inside our checked luggage that we had to carry thru TSA ourselves sat outside in the hot sun. Don't be fooled by thinking the US Virgin Islands are related to the US somehow and the airport will follow suit. That airport is like any other 3rd world country airport. Awful.

commentHeader: so many people missed their flights because of the ridiculous line
reviewContent: If I could give this airport zero stars, I would. The worst airport I have ever been to in my entire life. Our flight was delayed twice just like other airlines as well because for some odd reason the customs line was backed all the way out of the airport past Spirit’s outside check in. It was horrendous. The delayed flight didn’t really bother me because everyone was in the same boat. We arrived 3 hours and 20 minutes early and we literally needed all of that time. They said they were going to hold flights, but so many people missed their flights because of the ridiculous line. They made the process so confusing. If they had signs and warm and welcoming people in the front, it’ll be smooth-going. You’re literally scared to ask a question because they might bite your head off. It’s like, they have an attitude and make you feel dumb as if we are supposed to already know. People are asking questions because we’re all confused. Between customs and TSA, those were the rudest people I have ever met in my life. They were so mean and nasty to people. I felt so bad for the people they ridiculed and embarrassed in front of everyone. We met a guy in line that went through the 2 hour line before us, he went outside to get fresh air because it was so hot in the airport, and guess what? They literally made him go through the entire 2+ hour process all over again. Wow! I would’ve cried. When you’re coming into the island, it’s all welcoming and they have music playing, but when you’re leaving, it’s like the slums and feels so gloomy, dark, and depressing. The airport is already undeveloped, hot, and outdated, but can you imagine spending all this money during your vacation on this expensive island then, get treated like crap when we’re leaving? That was absolutely heartbreaking. I didn’t expect top notch service because a vast majority of people we met were not very nice outside of the airport, just on the island itself, but overall, I’ve never been so ready to get on a plane in my life. I will not recommend this vacation spot to anyone honestly. I’m glad I went and saw the beauty of the island especially the beaches, but the treatment these people give you, is just horrible. It makes you not want to visit there. Unfortunately, the mean people outweigh the nice ones. I’m good. I’m glad I went, but never again.

commentHeader: the worst Airport I ever been to
reviewContent: This is the worst Airport I ever been to, and to tell you truth, it would be helpful if they gave people more jobs to make this environment less stressful. It took 3 and a half hour to get through TSA. So makes sure if your flying out of St Thomas to arrive 4hrs before your flight because they will leave you. A lot of people were rude that works there, especially TSA, I now know what it's like to be treated like an immigrant. I pray their whole process gets better.

This is the worst, nastiest, pathetic airport I have ever visited. It's absolute amateur hour and all is designed for the convenience of the workers - nothing for the actual passengers. No air conditioning! You must lug your own bag, that you've just checked, through security and then put it on the belt yourself, while some employee just stands there. Insane. Many of the employees can barely hide their disdain for the tourists. Half the ceiling tiles are missing, shops still boarded up a year after the hurricane. And the airport was awful long before the hurricane.

Food in the airport was extremely overpriced. Even though the area had recently went through a hurricane the lack of interest in making repairs or working on repairing the airport was not present. The areas that were damaged were simply covered over with plastic.

The staff was very rude. It was like they were inconvenienced. Was very dissatisfied with the whole experience. Everything from check in and through security. You would think they would be people friendly.

This airport is horrible. TSA is unorganized and slow. Please do not underestimate this small airport please get there 2 hours early maybe 3 because TSA will slow you down. I’m not sure who is in charge of TSA but you need have better protocol. I almost missed my flight.

commentHeader: an hour wait at a one baggage
reviewContent: Over an hour wait at a one baggage carousel to receive luggage absolutely unacceptable. This place is a joke for all the money that they invest into it. Strongly recommend avoiding this airport at all costs if you are able to.

The airport layout is horrible. The elevators don’t match to all parking levels. Staff unable to give basic directions about location of airport services. Over 40mins wait for baggage. Gates not identified for arriving planes. Just exiting parking garage is confusing.

The service is absolutely awful! I cannot express how rude and inconsiderate these people are. If I had a choice I’d never use this airport again, unfortunately I don’t have a choice. Extremely disappointed.

Waited 65 minutes thru security yesterday and was closed out of my 11.43 to Charlotte after finally getting to the gate at 11.40. Get there 2 hrs early these days. TSA painfully slow. No sense of urgency or willingness to help. Horrible. Cost my company thousands in missed meetings. Complete joke.

As a frequent traveler, this is the worst airport I’ve ever been in. Flights are perpetually delayed with no information given to passengers. Luggage has been left on the tarmac twice and not put on the plane. TSA is horrendously unprofessional. Searched through my entire luggage and strip searched me with no information given as to why I was being subjected to this. After requesting a private room for the degrading pat down, they made me remove my pants to examen my knee brace and then the TSA agent opened the door to the screening room before I was dressed. If I didn’t have to frequently come to Tallahassee for family I would boycott this airport. This is the worst excuse of an airport I’ve ever seen.

They were incredibly rude at TSA by the Southwest gate. They wouldn’t let me on to pick up my sons even though I had a gate pass. They said the machine couldn’t recognize my ID, despite me flying all the time. My ID and appearance match up. Finally a supervisor came over, after 20 minutes, looked at me, and said ok. The gate guy yelled to not get depressed over missing picking up my sons

The customer service at this airport is the worst I have ever experienced. The staff just seem to shout instructions which are very unclear. I don’t think I have ever come across such a rude check in staff as the lady that was checking in the BA flight to London on 31st May at F gate. We were business class and we had our passports and e tickets. She shouted at us to leave the queue as we had the wrong tickets ( or that is what she thought ) we were confused as had used them earlier, she made us feel awful and when we said we had both e tickets and paper she said we had to use paper, with that she snatched them out of our hands, rolled her eyes and huffed, she then passed them on to a colleagues whilst we stood there waiting for one of them to give back both our tickets and passports. There had been no communication or advise when we checked our luggage in that you had to have a paper boarding pass. In this day and age it seems very out of date. I felt like I was being told off, awful experience. Collecting and returning car hire was good although a pain that you have to get two separate trains but pretty quick Also if you like a wander around shops this is not the airport for you.

The customer service was absolutely terrible during security. They yelled at everyone going through and we’re not giving clean instructions and then proceeded to get mad if you got confused. I am an anxious flier and this made it so much worse. The rudeness ruined my whole experience. Absolutely do not recommend.

Worst airport for customer service. Automated boarding pass scanners don’t scan right and when you have an issue you can’t find an employee in sight and when you find one they do not care one bit. Don’t ask for a manager because they will start saying that you the customer is being disrespectful.

commentHeader: Immigration hall is far too small
reviewContent: Immigration hall is far too small and the number of agents processing arriving passengers was far too few. There were only two agents processing arrivals (no kiosks available) yet about a dozen standing around with their thumbs hooked in their armored vests doing nothing but chatting with each other. Fortunately almost all the passengers on the flight I arrived on were American citizens and it seemed somewhat resigned to being treated with disdain by the immigration and customs agents. It's a pity if first time arrivals from a foreign country experience a "welcome" as such.

Nice airport. However, poor signage for pickup by Lyft or Uber. Baggage clam then have to go back upstairs to get picked up. Very poor design. A lot more walking for disabled. Any very confusing for someone not accustom to the area. Very disappointed in the design.

Tampa International Airport is huge and very confusing that I ended up going to the wrong direction upon exiting. I ended up in the sky center. I asked one of the people who I assume work there because he has an ID and he happily helped me and walked with me back to where I supposed to go. He worked as a chef in PF changs yet, he helped me. He was waiting for his ride after a long busy day at work, yet he got up and assisted me. Thank you Sir for going above and beyond. There really is hope in humanity.

TPA is the cleanest airport I have been in compared to ATL and BOS. This time I lost my ID and was frantic. The TA were so nice and said that it happens more than you think. There was a slight delay on Jet Blue but they made it up in the air. I prefer Jet Blue cuz I have never had a problem. Only once flying into Newark but it wasn't the airlines fault. Our flight was diverted because their was an explosion at Newark so all flights were diverted to LGA and JFK. Luckily I wound up in PA somewhere and they had to get us a hotel. Missed the wedding shower cuz then pilots were on overtime. Big mess. Finally I got to Newark and rented a car. Was glad to get back to Tampa.

Airport staff offered no assistance with flight cancellations or my wheel chair due to a significant injury to my foot. Personnel stood by while party struggled managing luggage, a 3 year old and my disability.

Incredibly rude TSA employees throughout the entire check-in process. Going through security is the absolute worst. Every employee was rude. TIA service is terrible all around anymore. They used to be very polite.

commentHeader: it has gotten progressively less customer-focused
reviewContent: Parking: Had a cruise scheduled, with flight out of Tampa International. Due to last minute CDC and govt Covid rule changes, it was canceled. Every other group did a full refund or at least full dollar credit for future purchases, since the cancelation was due to COVID and govt reaction: airline, 3 shore excursions, cruise line, hotel. The only deposit we could not fully get back was parking at Tampa International. Of the $90 charge, we got back only $45. Tampa airport used to be the best airport in the country. Since Lopano took over, it has gotten progressively less customer-focused. Maybe Tiliocos, VP of Customer Service, has something to do with it? I emailed those two and the Feldman, head of parking. Obviously they got my emails, since Feldman, head of parking, called me to tell me personally to bugger off. Of the $5K for the trip, 45 is peanuts. But it shows how cold and uncaring the TPA has become. My flying has decreased in recent years, but I used to have gold cards on 4 different airlines and traveled at least once every week, out of Tampa. I marveled at having one of the best airports in the country nearby. I'd be extremely cautious about booking anything through TPA in these times of Covid.

The TSA security check in was one of the worst and rudest I've ever been through. The only people security bothered to run through the wringer of special security checks are senior citizens and those needing assistance. I am on crutches and was told I should have been in a wheelchair because TSA did not provide chairs for someone like me to sit on to take their shoes off. I told them that I'd happily takes my shoes off if they could provide a chair. They didn't. Then after going through the xray they had to pat me down. Twice. And check for residue. Why the heck did I have to hobble through the xray without my crutches if I was going to get pat down anyway. Looking around as I was pat down, the ONLY people getting the special security treatment was senior citizens and persons like me. And on top of that they weren't even polite about it. Someone need to answer why those two groups are treated like this. I would understand it if they at least selected some random people or other demographic but for the 20 minutes it took me to go through security they did not once check anyone else and multiple times had people go through the regular walk through metal detector because the line was getting long. The whole ordeal was ridiculous. I rarely leave reviews so this is a whole level up of bad experiences.

commentHeader: A smile and gentle reminder would have been far more effective
reviewContent: Dear female TSA agent, gate A, 4/1/2021, 1.20pm who chose to shriek at me and berate me for forgetting I had an electronic in my purse. Top of her lungs - “Yeah! There’s an electronic in your bag - despite him saying over and over to remove your electronics you chose not to listen, now we had to take it out!”  Wow! A) The area was hugely crowded, overhead announcements etc - people may have a hearing impairment and cannot hear in that situation - even with hearing equipment. B) I’m traveling with a special needs Child - my attention is on him as much as possible helping him to navigate a crowded and confusing situation. C.) I’ve just experienced a tragic death in my family. D) I’m sorry I forgot. I’m human last time I checked. People fly, as you know, for all reasons. While I understand your need to educate - your tone, terrible attitude and general demeanor are a terrible reflection on TSA. Sorry you had a bad day. Leave that at the front door. I can promise you didn’t make mine any better. A smile and gentle reminder would have been far more effective.

commentHeader: the rudest people I have ever encountered
reviewContent: The Delta employees at Tampa airport were the rudest people I have ever encountered. Throughout the entire experience trying to get to my plane was one rude person followed by another. I will never fly Delta again because of the Tampa employees. You should be ashamed and everyone should be warned not to travel with them.

commentHeader: I've never encountered the level of rudeness
reviewContent: I've been in several dozen airports in the US, Europe, and Asia, and I've never encountered the level of rudeness in airport staff as I did in Tampa.

What a disaster. Currently standing in customs line as we speak having been off the plane for an hour and still have a very long line ahead. Poor management with little staff to meet the heavy demand. Find this off putting and would make me chose an alternate Florida airport in the future. Even US nations mentioning how this is embarrassing.

commentHeader: I saw an outdoor smoking area
reviewContent: At TPA on 04/30/2019 waiting to fly back home to LGA. I love this airport. It is huge, clean and has so many food stores. Now I love it more for the following reasons. I was bored so I started walking toward gate 75 (Delta). I saw an outdoor smoking area. My goodness, it was about time as TPA had eliminated the big outside smoking area inside the airport (what is this world coming to). When I saw the people smoking there, I went inside.

Terminal A restroom smells of urine. No hot water. Water fountains do not work. Carpet dirty. Got through security very quick at 0730. I do not use rental cars here anymore. It takes too much time and high prices. I use Lyft or rent off airport.

commentHeader: very pleasant, modern and very clean"
reviewContent: Tampa is our home airport and even with the construction it’s still a very pleasant, modern and very clean. It’s very easy to navigate, my only complaint would be long term parking it’s a little confusing but overall we love TPA.

After waiting for several hours in Tampa Airport we were finally allowed to board. As I approached the ramp I realized I had lost my boarding pass. I spoke to a Spirit employee, I had spoken to him earlier in the evening so I know he recognized me. My wife told him I needed to board the flight. He said, "I was going to be nice and help you, but you can go over go the ticket counter and get your boarding pass reissued." I am a retired, disabled military member. I also have MS." This whole departure experience was dreadful. This staff member made the evening that much worse.

commentHeader: too large for its own good
reviewContent: I have to say I have been flying in and out of Tampa airport since the 80's and I understand that as it has grown in passenger volume, it has gotten too large for its own good. I will say that, what I call a Mall with shops and endless food options is fantastic. However the extremely high escalator is ridiculous and the distance you have to go with the tram and the speed at which it goes to the rental car location is way too far and too fast. I have anxiety and the speed is just waiting for a accident as it is way too jittery. And once you are their you have more to walk. I am not old but I did have major heart surgery but for elderly it is not passenger friendly to have to walk that much. This all makes me wonder about choosing a different airport or a different way to travel. I loved when the garage housed the rental cars. It was perfect. I would have kept the 1st and 2nd floor of the garage for car rentals and the top floors for passengers who kept their cars there. And why dont you have stars below for the Tram to the rental facility or the rental car experience.

I always love flying to and from the Tampa Airport. From the drive into TPA, the airlines are cleverly color coded and then you are directed to either arrivals or departures. Then you simply have to look for the door with your airline. Once inside the main terminal, head to the appropriate ticket counter. If you have pre-checked in online, just take the air conditioned tram to your terminal (A–F). There you will go through security. There’s always ample TSA agents there to keep the crowd moving along securely and swiftly. Once through security, you are welcomed into a massive airy terminal. There’s plenty of food options from Cigar City Brewing (a popular craft beer producer in Tampa) to The Colombia Restaurant, a staple in Tampa since 1905 serving authentic Spanish fair. There’s plenty of workspace and outlets to charge up your devices. I flow the flow of this airport with plenty of signage. It’s almost impossible to get lost and everything is relatively closeby.

Have always found Tampa to be a reasonably good, user-friendly airport. Overall it's still not bad but had a few red flags come up this time. Arrived in terminal E and used the men's washroom only to find the floor completely flooded (helps if you don't think too much about that). Fair enough, stuff happens. Except when we left a week later the same washroom still had a flooded floor. Seriously? Are there no plumbers in Tampa? Pretty disgusting. Check-in areas in the main terminal are starting to show their age. Trek to the car rental facility is a bit of an adventure. Up and down endless escalators plus a far from smooth train ride. Layout of the car rental area also seems to be an accident waiting to happen. Pedestrian walkways are not well defined and (in the case of Avis) cars were parked on the walkway back to the main building. Still gets a recommended grade but barely.

Avoid this airport!! Passenger flow choke points, intersecting traffic, triple tram rides just to get to security check point, conflicting passenger flows, enter on fourth level, go down to second them back up to fourth. Three dimensional dysfunction! Time and frustration makes the chaos of Orlando much more appealing.

Have been flying in and out of TPA for 15+ years. The experience was always a pleasant one. After landing, take the tram to the luggage area, get you bags, cross the street and pick up your rental car.
